question: Prove that $\zeta(s,C)$ extends to the region $\mathbb{R}(s)>1-\frac{1}{n}$ except for a simple pole at $s=1$ with residue $\frac{2^{r_{1}}(2\pi)^{r_{2}}R_{K}}{w\sqrt{|d_{K}|}}$. Deduce that $\zeta_{K}(s)$ extends to $\mathbb{R}(s)>1-\frac{1}{n}$ except for a simple pole at $s=1$ with residue $\rho_{K}:=\frac{2^{r_{1}}(2\pi)^{r_{2}}h_{K}R_{K}}{w\sqrt{|d_{K}|}}$ where $h_{K}$ denotes the class number of K.
solution: If we let $\alpha_{K}=\rho_{K}/h_{K}$ and consider the Dirichlet series $f(s)=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{a_{m}}{m^{s}}:=\zeta(s,C)-\alpha_{K}\zeta(s),$ then by Theorem 11.1.5, we have $\sum_{m\le x}a_{m}=O(x^{1-\frac{1}{n}}).$ By Theorem 10.1.4, $f(s)$ converges for $\mathbb{R}(s)>1-\frac{1}{n}$. As $\zeta(s)$ has a simple pole at $s=1$ with residue 1, the latter assertions are immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.7}
question: Prove that there are infinitely many prime ideals in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ which are of degree 1.
solution: We have $log~\zeta_{K}(s)=\sum_{\mathfrak{p}}\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}}+\sum_{n\ge2,\mathfrak{p}}\frac{1}{nN(\mathfrak{p})^{ns}}$. The second sum is easily seen to converge for $\mathbb{R}(s)>1/2$. The first sum can be separated into two parts, one over primes of first degree and the other over primes of degree $\ge2$. Again, the second sum converges for $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1/2$. If the first sum consisted of only finitely many terms, the right hand side would tend to a finite limit as $s\rightarrow1^{+}$ which is not the case as the Dedekind zeta function has a simple pole at $s=1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.8}
question: Prove that the number of prime ideals of degree $\ge2$ and with norm $\le x$ is $O(x^{1/2}log~x)$.
solution: If $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal of degree $r\ge2$ then $N(\mathfrak{p})=p^{r}\le x$ implies $r\le(log~x)/log~2$ and $p\le x^{1/2}$. For each prime, there are a bounded number of prime ideals in K above p. Thus, the final estimate is obtained by counting the number of possible pairs $(p,r)$ and this is $O(x^{1/2}log~x)$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.9}
question: Let $\mu$ be defined on integral ideals $\mathfrak{a}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ as follows. $\mu(\mathcal{O}_{K})=1$, and if $\mathfrak{a}$ is divisible by the square of a prime ideal, we set $\mu(\mathfrak{a})=0$. Otherwise, we let $\mu(\mathfrak{a})=(-1)^{k}$ when $\mathfrak{a}$ is the product of k distinct prime ideals. Show that $\sum_{\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{a}}\mu(\mathfrak{b})=0$ unless $\mathfrak{a}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: Clearly, the function $f(\mathfrak{a})=\sum_{\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{a}}\mu(\mathfrak{b})$ is multiplicative and so, it suffices to evaluate it on prime ideals. But this is clearly zero.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.10}
question: Prove that the number of ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ of odd norm $\le x$ is $\rho_{K}x\prod_{\mathfrak{p}|2}(1-\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})})+O(x^{1-\frac{1}{n}}),$ where the product is over prime ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ dividing $2\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: By the previous exercise, the number of such ideals is $\sum_{N(\mathfrak{a})\le x}\sum_{\mathfrak{b}|(\mathfrak{a},2)}\mu(\mathfrak{b})$ since an ideal has odd norm if and only if it has no prime ideal divisor above 2. Interchanging summation and using Theorem 11.1.5, we obtain the result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.11}
question: Let $A(x)$ be the number of ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ of even norm $\le x$ and $B(x)$ of odd norm $\le x$. Show that $lim_{x\rightarrow\infty}\frac{A(x)}{B(x)}=1$ if and only if $K=\mathbb{Q}$ or K is a quadratic field in which 2 ramifies.
solution: From the previous exercise, we see that $B(x)=\prod_{\mathfrak{p}|2}(1-\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})})\rho_{K}x+O(x^{1-\frac{1}{n}}).$ We see that $A(x)\sim B(x)$ if and only if $A(x)+B(x)\sim2B(x)$. That is, if and only if $\frac{1}{2}=\prod_{\mathfrak{p}|2}(1-\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})})$. Let $\mathfrak{p}_{1},...,\mathfrak{p}_{t}$ be the prime ideals above 2 with norms $2^{m_{1}},...,2^{m_{t}}$ respectively. The above equation implies $\frac{1}{2}=\prod_{i=1}^{t}(\frac{2^{m_{i}}-1}{2^{m_{i}}})$. In other words, we have $2^{m_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+m_{t}-1}=\prod_{i=1}^{t}(2^{m_{i}}-1).$ The right hand side is a product of odd numbers and so the only way the left hand side can be odd is if $m_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+m_{t}=1$ which means that there is only one prime ideal above 2 and it has norm 2. This can only happen if $K=\mathbb{Q}$ or if K is a quadratic field in which 2 ramifies.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.1.12}
question: With notation as in the discussion preceding Theorem 11.1.4, let $V_{x}$ denote the set of n-tuples $(x_{1},...,x_{n})$ satisfying $|\alpha^{(1)}\cdot\cdot\cdot\alpha^{(n)}|\le xN(\mathfrak{b})$. Let $t=x^{1/n}$. Show that there is a $\delta>0$ (independent of x) such that for each lattice point P contained in $V_{(t-\delta)^{n}}$, all the points contained in the translate of the standard unit cube by P belong to $V_{x}$.
solution: We fix $\delta>0$ and choose it appropriately later. We may write the norm form $\alpha^{(1)}\cdot\cdot\cdot\alpha^{(n)}$ as $\sum_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}a_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}x_{1}^{i_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot x_{n}^{i_{n}}$ where the summation is over all positive integers $i_{1},...,i_{n}$ such that $i_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+i_{n}=n$ and the $a_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}$ are rational integers. If $P=(u_{1},...,u_{n})$, then any point contained in the translate of the standard unit cube by P is of the form $(u_{1}+t_{1},...,u_{n}+t_{n})$ with $t_{i}$ bounded by 1. Thus, by the solution of Exercise 11.1.1, we deduce that the norm of any such point is $\sum_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}a_{i_{1},...,i_{n}}u_{1}^{i_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot u_{n}^{i_{n}}+O(x^{\frac{n-1}{n}}).$ This has absolute norm $\le(t-\delta)^{n}+O(x^{\frac{n-1}{n}})\le x-n\delta x^{\frac{n-1}{n}}+O(x^{\frac{n-1}{n}})\le x$ if we choose $\delta$ sufficiently large so that the negative sign dominates.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.1}
question: Show that $L(s,\chi)$ converges absolutely for $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1$ and that $L(s,\chi)=\prod_{\mathfrak{p}}(1-\frac{\chi(\mathfrak{p})}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}})^{-1}$ in this region. Deduce that $L(s,\chi)\ne0$ for $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1$.
solution: We have by multiplicativity of $\chi$, $L(s,\chi)=\prod_{\mathfrak{p}}(1-\frac{\chi(\mathfrak{p})}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}})^{-1}$ and the product converges absolutely for $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1$ if and only if $\sum_{\mathfrak{p}}\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}}$ converges in this region, which is certainly the case as there are only a bounded number of prime ideals above a given prime p. The non-vanishing is also clear.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.2}
question: If $\chi$ is not the trivial character, show that $\sum_{C}\chi(C)=0$ where the summation is over the ideal classes C of H.
solution: If $\chi$ is not the trivial character, there is a $C_{0}$ such that $\chi(C_{0})\ne 1$. Thus, $\sum_{C}\chi(CC_{0})=\chi(C_{0})\sum_{C}\chi(C)$, where we have used the fact that as C runs over elements of the ideal class group, so does $CC_{0}$. The result is now immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.3}
question: If $C_{1}$ and $C_{2}$ are distinct ideal classes, show that $\sum_{\chi}\overline{\chi(C_{1})}\chi(C_{2})=0$. If $C_{1}=C_{2}$, show that the sum is $h_{K}$.
solution: If $C_{1}=C_{2}$, the result is clear. We consider the sum $\sum_{\chi}\chi(A)$ for $A\ne1$. We can then take a non-trivial character of the subgroup generated by A and extend this character to the full ideal class group in the usual way. Then, $\sum_{\chi}(\chi\psi)(A)=\psi(A)\sum_{\chi}\chi(A)$ and as before, the result is now evident.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 11.2.4}
question: Let n be the degree of $K/\mathbb{Q}.$ If $\chi\ne\chi_{0}$ then $L(s,\chi)$ extends analytically to $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1-\frac{1}{n}$.
solution: By Theorem 11.1.5, we have $\sum_{C}\chi(C)\sum_{\mathfrak{a}\in C,N(\mathfrak{a})\le x}1=\sum_{C}\chi(C)N(x,C)=O(x^{1-\frac{1}{n}});$ since (by Exercise 11.2.2) $\sum_{C}\chi(C)=0$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.5}
question: Let C be an ideal class of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. For $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1$ show that $\sum_{\chi}\overline{\chi}(C)log~L(s,\chi)=h_{K}\sum_{\mathfrak{p}^{m}\in C}\frac{1}{mN(\mathfrak{p})^{ms}}$ where the first summation is over the characters of the ideal class group and the second summation is over all prime ideals of $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ and natural numbers m such that $\mathfrak{p}^{m}\in C.$
solution: In the left hand side, we insert the series for $log~L(s,\chi).$ By interchanging the summation and using the orthogonality relations established in the Exercise 11.2.3, we obtain the desired result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.6}
question: Show that $\sum_{n\ge2,\mathfrak{p}^{m}\in C}\frac{1}{mN(\mathfrak{p})^{ms}}$ converges for $\mathbb{R}(s)>1/2$.
solution: As noted earlier, the number of prime ideals above a fixed prime p is at most the degree of the number field. Thus, the result is clear from the fact that $\sum_{m\ge2,p}\frac{1}{mp^{ms}}$ converges for $\mathfrak{R}(s)>1/2$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.7}
question: If $\chi^{2}\ne\chi_{0}$ show that $L(1,\chi)\ne0.$
solution: We use the classical inequality $3+4~cos~\theta+cos~2\theta\ge0$ as follows. We write $\chi(\mathfrak{p})=e^{i\theta_{p}}$ so that for real $\sigma>1$, $\mathfrak{R}(3~log~\zeta_{K}(\sigma)+4~log~L(\sigma,\chi)+log~L(\sigma,\chi^{2})) =\sum_{m,\mathfrak{p}}\frac{1}{mN(\mathfrak{p})^{\sigma m}}(3+4~cos~\theta_{p}+cos~2\theta_{p})\ge0.$ Hence, $|\zeta_{K}(\sigma)^{3}L(\sigma,\chi)^{4}L(\sigma,\chi^{2})|\ge1$. If $L(1,\chi)=0$ the left hand side of this inequality tends to zero as $\sigma\rightarrow1^{+}$, which is a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.8}
question: Let C be a fixed ideal class in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Show that the set of prime $\mathfrak{p}\in C$ has Dirichlet density $1/h_{K}$.
solution: We have by the orthogonality relation, $\sum_{\chi}\overline{\chi(C)}log~L(s,\chi)=h_{K}\sum_{\mathfrak{p}\in C}\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}}+O(1)$ as $s\rightarrow1^{+}$. Since $L(1,\chi)\ne0$ we may take limits of the left hand side as $s\rightarrow1^{+}$ and obtain a bounded quantity from the non-trivial characters. Since $L(s,\chi_{0})=\zeta_{K}(s)$, we deduce immediately that $lim_{s\rightarrow1^{+}}\frac{\sum_{\mathfrak{p}\in C}1/N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}}{log~\zeta_{K}(s)}=\frac{1}{h_{K}}$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.9}
question: Let m be a natural number and $(a,m)=1$. Show that the set of primes $p\equiv a(mod~m)$ has Dirichlet density $1/\phi(m)$.
solution: This is immediate from Exercise 10.3.7.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.10}
question: Show that the set of primes p which can be written as $a^{2}+5b^{2}$ has Dirichlet density $1/4.$
solution: We have already seen that the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ is 2. The set of prime ideals lying in the principal class are of the form $(a+b\sqrt{-5})$ and have norm $a^{2}+5b^{2}$. By Hecke's theorem, the Dirichlet density of these prime ideals is $1/2$ and taking into account that there are two ideals of norm p in the principal class gives us the final density of $1/4.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.2.11}
question: Show that if $K=\mathbb{Q}$, the principal ray class group mod m is isomorphic to $(\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z})^{*}$.
solution: The elements of the principal ray class group are the ideals (a) modulo m with a totally positive generator and $(\alpha,m)=1.$ The result is now clear.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.1}
question: Show that the action of the Galois group on the set of prime ideals lying above a fixed prime p of k is a transitive action.
solution: Suppose not. Take a prime ideal which is not in the Galois orbit of $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$ (say) lying above the prime ideal p. By the Chinese remainder theorem (Theorem 5.3.13), we may find an element $x\in\mathfrak{p}$ and $x-1\in\sigma(\mathfrak{p}_{i})$ for all $\sigma$ in the Galois group. But then, $N_{K/k}(x)$ is an integer of $\mathcal{O}_{k}$ which on one hand is divisible by $\mathfrak{p}$ and on the other coprime to p, a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.4}
question: By taking $k=\mathbb{Q}$ and $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$, deduce from Chebotarev's theorem the infinitude of primes in a given arithmetic progression a (mod m) with $(a,m)=1$.
solution: The Galois group consists of automorphisms $\tau_{a}$ satisfying $\tau_{a}(\zeta_{m})=\zeta_{m}^{a}$. Comparing this with the action of the Frobenius automorphism of p, we see that $\sigma_{p}=\tau_{a}$ where $p\equiv a$ (mod p). By Chebotarev, the Dirichlet density of primes p for which $\sigma_{p}=\tau_{a}$ is $1/\phi(m)$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.5}
question: If $k=\mathbb{Q}$ and $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$, deduce from Chebotarev's theorem that the set of primes p with Legendre symbol $(D/p)=1$ is of Dirichlet density $1/2$.
solution: By Theorem 7.4.2, we see that these are precisely the set of primes which split completely in K and by Chebotarev, the density of such primes is $1/2$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.6}
question: If $f(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is an irreducible normal polynomial of degree n (that is, its splitting field has degree n over Q), then show that the set of primes p for which $f(x)\equiv0$ (mod p) has a solution is of Dirichlet density $1/n$.
solution: By Theorem 5.5.1 and Exercise 5.5.2, we see that the set of primes p for which $f(x)\equiv0$ (mod p) has a solution coincides with the set of primes p which split completely in the field obtained by adjoining a root of f. By our assumption, this is a Galois extension of degree n and to say p splits completely is equivalent to saying that $\sigma_{p}=1.$ By Chebotarev, the Dirichlet density of such primes is $1/n.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.7}
question: If $f(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is an irreducible polynomial of degree $n>1$, show that the set of primes p for which $f(x)\equiv0$ (mod p) has a solution has Dirichlet density < 1.
solution: Let K be the splitting field of f over with Galois group G. Let H be the subgroup corresponding to the field obtained by adjoining a root of f to Q. It is not difficult to see that $f(x)\equiv0$ (mod p) has a solution if and only if the Artin symbol $\sigma_{p}$ lies in some conjugate of H. This is a set stable under conjugation. If we take into account that the identity element is common to all the conjugate subgroups of H, we obtain $|\cup_{g\in G}gHg^{-1}|\le[G:H](|H|-1)+1=|G|+1-[G:H]<|G|$ if $[G:H]=n>1$, which is the case.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.8}
question: Let q be prime. Show that the set of primes p for which $p\equiv1$ (mod q) and $2^{\frac{p-1}{q}}\equiv1(mod~p)$ has Dirichlet density $1/q(q-1)$.
solution: The second condition happens if and only if $x^{q}\equiv2$ (mod p) has a solution and together with $p\equiv1$ (mod p), the conditions are equivalent to saying p splits completely in the field $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{q},2^{1/q})$. As this field has degree $q(q-1)$, the result now follows from Chebotarev's theorem.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.3.9}
question: If a natural number n is a square mod p for a set of primes p which has Dirichlet density 1, show that n must be a square.
solution: If n is not a square, the field $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{n})$ is quadratic over and by Chebotarev, the density of primes for which n is not a square is $1/2$. (This shows that we can assert the conclusion of the theorem if the set of primes p for which n is a square has density $>1/2$.)

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.1}
question: Let G be a finite group and for each subgroup H of G and each irreducible character $\psi$ of H define $a_{H}(\psi,\chi)$ by $Ind_{H}^{G}\psi=\sum_{\chi}a_{H}(\psi,\chi)\chi$ where the summation is over irreducible characters $\chi$ of G. For each $\chi$, let $A_{\chi}$ be the vector $(a_{H}(\psi,\chi))$ as H varies over all cyclic subgroups of G and $\psi$ varies over all irreducible characters of H. Show that the $A_{\chi}$ are linearly independent over Q.
solution: If $\sum_{\chi}c_{\chi}A_{\chi}=0$ for some integers $c_{\chi}$, then by Frobenius reciprocity, the character $\phi=\sum_{\chi}c_{\chi}\chi$ restricts to the zero character on every cyclic subgroup. By the linear independence of characters (or equivalently, by the orthogonality relations), each $c_{\chi}$ is equal to zero.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.2}
question: Let G be a finite group with t irreducible characters. By the previous exercise, choose a set of cyclic subgroups $H_{i}$ and characters $\psi_{i}$ of $H_{i}$ so that the $t\times t$ matrix $(a_{H_{i}}(\psi_{i},\chi))$ is non-singular. By inverting this matrix, show that any character $\chi$ of G can be written as a rational linear combination of characters of the form $Ind_{H_{i}}^{G}\psi_{i}$ with $H_{i}$ cyclic and $\psi_{i}$ one-dimensional.
solution: Since the row rank of a matrix is equal to the column rank, it is clear that we can choose a set of such $H_{i}$ and $\psi_{i}$'s. Thus, $Ind_{H_{i}}^{G}\psi_{i}=\sum_{\chi}a_{H_{i}}(\psi_{i},\chi)\chi$. Moreover, $a_{H}(\psi,\chi)=(Ind_{H}^{G}\psi,\chi)$ are all non-negative integers. Thus, the inverse matrix consists of rational entries.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.3}
question: Deduce from the previous exercise that some positive integer power of the Artin L-function $L(s,\chi;K/k)$ attached to an irreducible character $\chi$ admits a meromorphic continuation to $\mathfrak{R}(s)=1$.
solution: By the previous exercise, we may write $L(s,\chi;K/k)$ as a product of functions of the form $L(s,\psi_{i},K/K^{H_{i}})^{m_{i}}$ with $m_{i}$ rational numbers. By the Artin reciprocity law, each $L(s,\psi_{i},K/K^{H_{i}})$ coincides with $L(s,\chi_{i})$ with $\chi_{i}$ a Hecke character of $K^{H_{i}}$. As $L(s,\chi_{i})$ has a meromorphic continuation to $\mathfrak{R}(s)=1$, the result follows.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.4}
question: If $K/k$ is a finite Galois extension of algebraic number fields with group G, show that $\zeta_{K}(s)=\prod_{\chi}L(s,\chi;K/k)^{\chi(1)},$ where the product is over all irreducible characters x of G.
solution: Since the right hand side represents the L-function attached to the regular representation, which is $Ind_{1}^{G}1$, we have that it is equal to $L(s,1,K/K)=\zeta_{K}(s)$, by the invariance property under induction of Artin L-series.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.5}
question: Fix a complex number $s_{0}\in\mathbb{C}$ with $\mathfrak{R}(s_{0})\ge1$ and any finite Galois extension $K/k$ with Galois group G. For each subgroup H of G define the Heilbronn character $\theta_{H}$ by $\theta_{H}(g)=\sum_{\chi}n(H,\chi)\chi(g)$ where the summation is over all irreducible characters $\chi$ of H and $n(H,\chi)$ is the order of the pole of $L(s,\chi;K/K^{H})$ at $s=s_{0}$. Show that $\theta_{G}|_{H}=\theta_{H}$.
solution: We have $\theta_{G}|_{H}=\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)\chi|_{H}.$ But $\chi|_{H}=\sum_{\psi}(\chi|_{H},\psi)\psi$ where the sum is over irreducible characters of H. Thus, $\theta_{G}|_{H}=\sum_{\psi}(\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)(\chi|_{H},\psi))\psi.$ By Frobenius reciprocity, $(\chi|_{H},\psi)=(\chi,Ind_{H}^{G}\psi)$ so that the inner sum is $\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)(\chi,Ind_{H}^{G}\psi).$ This is equal to $n(H,\psi)$ since $L(s,\psi,K/K^{H})=L(s,Ind_{H}^{G}\psi,K/k)=\prod_{\chi}L(s,\chi,K/k)^{(\chi,Ind_{H}^{G}\psi)}.$ Thus, $\theta_{G}|_{H}=\sum_{\psi}n(H,\psi)\psi=\theta_{H}.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.6}
question: Show that $\theta_{G}(1)$ equals the order at $s=s_{0}$ of the Dedekind zeta function $\zeta_{K}(s)$.
solution: We have $\theta_{G}(1)=\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)\chi(1)$ which by Exercise 11.4.4 is the order of $\zeta_{K}(s)$ at $s=s_{0}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.7}
question: Show that $\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)^{2}\le(ord_{s=s_{0}}\zeta_{K}(s))^{2}$.
solution: We compute $(\theta_{G},\theta_{G})$ using the orthogonality relations to obtain $\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)^{2}.$ On the other hand, $(\theta_{G},\theta_{G})=\frac{1}{|G|}\sum_{g\in G}|\theta_{G}(g)|^{2}.$ By Exercise 11.4.5, $\theta_{G}(g)=\theta_{\langle g\rangle}(g)$. But if H is abelian, $n(H,\psi)\ge0$ by Artin's reciprocity law and so for $h\in H$, $|\theta_{H}(h)|\le\sum_{\psi}n(H,\psi)|\psi(h)|.$ Thus, $|\theta_{H}(h)|\le\sum_{\psi}n(H,\psi)=\theta_{H}(1);$ which by Exercise 11.4.6 is the order of the Dedekind zeta function $\zeta_{K}(s)$ at $s=s_{0}$. The result is now immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.8}
question: For any irreducible non-trivial character $\chi,$ deduce that $L(s,\chi;K/k)$ admits an analytic continuation to $s=1$ and that $L(1,\chi;K/k)\ne0$.
solution: Since the Dedekind zeta function has a simple pole at $s=1.$ we see that the previous exercise applied to the point $s_{0}=1$ implies $\sum_{\chi\ne1}n(G,\chi)^{2}\le0$ because $n(G,1)=1$ Hence, $n(G,\chi)=0$ for any $\chi\ne1$ By Exercise 11.4.3 we are done.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.9}
question: Fix a conjugacy class C in $G=Gal(K/k)$ and choose $g_{C}\in C$. Show that $\sum_{m,\mathfrak{p},\sigma_{\mathfrak{p}}^{m}\in C}\frac{1}{N(\mathfrak{p})^{ms}}=\frac{|C|}{|G|}\sum_{\chi}\overline{\chi(g_{C})}log~L(s,\chi;K/k)$ .
solution: This is an immediate consequence of the orthogonality relations.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.10}
question: Show that $lim_{s\rightarrow1^{+}}\frac{\sum_{\mathfrak{p},\sigma_{\mathfrak{p}}\in C}1/N(\mathfrak{p})^{s}}{log~\zeta_{k}(s)}=\frac{|C|}{|G|}$ which is Chebotarev's theorem.
solution: We take the limit as $s\rightarrow1^{+}$ in both sides of the equation of the previous exercise. Observe that by Exercise 11.4.8, the limit as $s\rightarrow1^{+}$ of $log~L(s,\chi;K/k)$ for $\chi\ne1$ is finite. Since $L(s,1;K/k)=\zeta_{k}(s)$ the result is now immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.12}
question: Let $K/k$ be a finite Galois extension of algebraic number fields. If $\zeta_{K}(s)$ has a simple zero at $s=s_{0}$, then $L(s,\chi;K/k)$ is analytic at $s=s_{0}$ for every irreducible character x of $Gal(K/k)$.
solution: If $\zeta_{K}(s)$ has a simple zero at $s=s_{0}$, then $\sum_{\chi}n(G,\chi)^{2}\le1.$ By the meromorphy of Artin L-series, we have that each $n(G,\chi)$ is an integer. The inequality implies that for at most one x, we have $|n(G,\chi)|=1$. If x is non-abelian, then the factorization of $\zeta_{K}(s)$ as in Exercise 11.4.4 gives a contradiction for the corresponding L-function introduces a pole or zero of order greater than 1. Hence x is abelian, but in this case the result is known by Artin reciprocity and Hecke's theorem.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.13}
question: For any irreducible character x of $Gal(K/k)$, show that $L(s,\chi,K/k)\zeta_{K}(s)$ is analytic for $s\ne1$.
solution: This is immediate from the inequality $|n(G,\chi)|\le ord_{s=s_{0}}\zeta_{K}(s)$ for $s_{0}\ne1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 11.4.14}
question: If $K/k$ is solvable, show that $\sum_{\chi\ne1}n(G,\chi)^{2}\le(ord_{s=s_{0}}\zeta_{K}(s)/\zeta_{k}(s))^{2}$.
solution:
Let $f=	heta_{G}-n(G,1)1$ and note that $(f,f)=\sum_{\chi
e1}n(G,\chi)^{2}.$ Now by Exercise 11.4.5 $f(g)=	heta_{\langle gangle}(g)-n(G,1)=n(\langle gangle,1)-n(G,1)+\sum_{\psi
e1}n(\langle gangle,\psi)\psi(g).$ The subfield fixed by $\langle gangle$ is a subfield of K and we know Dedekind's conjecture for this extension. Thus, $n(\langle gangle,1)-n(G,1)\ge0.$ Therefore, $|f(g)|\le n(\langle gangle,1)-n(G,1)+\sum_{\psi
e1}n(\langle gangle,\psi)=ord_{s=s_{0}}(\zeta_{K}(s)/\zeta_{k}(s)),$ from which the inequality follows.

label: Example 2.1.1
question:
Let $R$ be an integral domain. Suppose there is a map $n:R\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that:
(i) $n(ab) = n(a)n(b)$ for all $a, b\in R$; and
(ii) $n(a)=1$ if and only if $a$ is a unit.
We call such a map a norm map, with $n(a)$ the norm of $a$. Show that every element of $R$ can be written as a product of irreducible elements.
solution:
Suppose $b$ is an element of $R$. We proceed by induction on the norm of $b$.
If $b$ is irreducible, then we have nothing to prove, so assume that $b$ is an element of $R$ which is not irreducible. Then we can write $b=ac$ where neither $a$ nor $c$ is a unit. By condition (i),
$$n(b)=n(ac)=n(a)n(c)$$
and since $a, c$ are not units, then by condition (ii), $n(a)<n(b)$ and $n(c)<n(b)$.
If $a, c$ are irreducible, then we are finished. If not, their norms are smaller than the norm of $b$, and so by induction we can write them as products of irreducibles, thus finding an irreducible decomposition of $b$.

label: Theorem 2.1.6
question: Show that if $R$ is a principal ideal domain, then $R$ is a unique factorization domain.
solution:
Let $S$ be the set of elements of $R$ that cannot be written as a product of irreducibles. If $S$ is nonempty, take $a_{1}\in S.$ Then $a_{1}$ is not irreducible, so we can write $a_{1}=a_{2}b_{2}$ where $a_{2}$, $b_{2}$ are not units. Then $(a_{1})\subsetneq(a_{2})$ and $(a_{1})\subsetneq(b_{2})$. If both $a_{2}$, $b_{2}\notin S$, then we can write $a_{1}$ as a product of irreducibles, so we assume that $a_{2}\in S$. We can inductively proceed until we arrive at an infinite chain of ideals,
$$(a_{1})\subsetneq(a_{2})\subsetneq(a_{3})\subsetneq\cdot\cdot\cdot\subsetneq(a_{n})\subsetneq\cdot\cdot\cdot$$
Now consider $I=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}(a_{i})$. This is an ideal of $R$, and because $R$ is a principal ideal domain, $I=(\alpha)$ for some $\alpha\in R.$ Since $\alpha\in I$, $\alpha\in(a_{n})$ for some $n$, but then $(a_{n})=(a_{n+1})$. From this contradiction, we conclude that the set $S$ must be empty, so we know that if $R$ is a principal ideal domain, every element of $R$ satisfies the first condition for a unique factorization domain.

Next we would like to show that if we have an irreducible element $\pi$, and $\pi|ab$ for $a, b\in R,$ then $\pi|a$ or $\pi|b$. If $\pi \nmid a$, then the ideal $(a,\pi)=R$, so there exist $x, y$ such that
$$ax+\pi y=1$$
$$abx+\pi by=b.$$
Since $\pi | abx$ and $\pi|\pi by$ then $\pi|b,$ as desired. By Exercise 2.1.4, we have shown that $R$ is a unique factorization domain.

label: Theorem 2.1.7
question: If $R$ is a domain with a map $\phi:R\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$, and given $a,b\in R$, there exist $q, r\in R$ such that $a=bq+r$ with $r=0$ or $\phi(r)<\phi(b)$, we call $R$ a Euclidean domain. Prove that if a ring $R$ is Euclidean, it is a principal ideal domain.
solution: Given an ideal $I\subseteq R$ take an element $a$ of $I$ such that $\phi(a)$ is minimal among elements of $I$. Then given $b\in I$, we can find $q,r\in R$ such that $b=qa+r$ where $r=0$ or $\phi(r)<\phi(a)$. But then $r=b-qa$, and so $r\in I$ and $\phi(a)$ is minimal among the norms of elements of $I$. So $r=0$, and given any element $b$ of $I$, $b=qa$ for some $q\in R.$ Therefore $a$ is a generator for $I$, and $R$ is a principal ideal domain.

label: Theorem 2.1.9 (Gauss' Lemma)
question: If $R$ is a unique factorization domain, and $f(x)\in R[x]$, define the content of $f$ to be the gcd of the coefficients of $f$, denoted by $\mathcal{C}(f)$. Prove that for $f(x)$, $g(x)\in R[x]$, $\mathcal{C}(fg)=\mathcal{C}(f)\mathcal{C}(g)$.
solution:
Consider two polynomials $f,g\in R[x]$, with $\mathcal{C}(f)=c$ and $\mathcal{C}(g)=d.$ Then we can write
$$f(x)=ca_{0}+ca_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+ca_{n}x^{n}$$
and
$$g(x)=db_{0}+db_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+db_{m}x^{m}$$
where $c, d, a_i, b_{j}\in R$, $a_n, b_{m}\ne0$. We define a primitive polynomial to be a polynomial $f$ such that $\mathcal{C}(f)=1$. Then $f=cf^{*}$ where $f^{*}=a_{0}+a_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{n}x^{n}$, a primitive polynomial, and $g=dg^{*}$, with $g^{*}$ a primitive polynomial. Since $fg=cf^{*}dg^{*}=cd(f^{*}g^{*})$, it will suffice to prove that the product of two primitive polynomials is again primitive.

Let
$$f^{*}g^{*}=k_{0}+k_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+k_{m+n}x^{m+n}$$
and assume that this polynomial is not primitive. Then all the coefficients $k_{i}$ are divisible by some $\pi\in R$ with $\pi$ irreducible. Since $f^{*}$ and $g^{*}$ are primitive, we know that there is at least one coefficient in each of $f^{*}$ and $g^{*}$ that is not divisible by $\pi$. We let $a_{i}$ and $b_{j}$ be the first such coefficients in $f^{*}$ and $g^{*}$, respectively. Now,
$$k_{i+j}=(a_{0}b_{i+j}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{i-1}b_{j+1})+a_{i}b_{j}+(a_{i+1}b_{j-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{i+j}b_{0}).$$
We know that $k_{i+j},a_{0},a_{1},...,a_{i-1},b_{0},b_{1},...,b_{j-1}$ are all divisible by $\pi$, so $a_{i}b_{j}$ must also be divisible by $\pi$. Since $\pi$ is irreducible, then $\pi|a_{i}$ or $\pi|b_{j}$, but we chose these elements specifically because they were not divisible by $\pi$. This contradiction proves that our polynomial $f^{*}g^{*}$ must be primitive. Then $fg=c~df^{*}g^{*}$ where $f^{*}g^{*}$ is a primitive polynomial, thus proving that $\mathcal{C}(fg)=cd=\mathcal{C}(f)\mathcal{C}(g)$.

label: Theorem 2.1.10
question: Show that if $R$ is a unique factorization domain, then $R[x]$ is a unique factorization domain.
solution:
Let $k$ be the fraction field of $R$. Let us examine the polynomial ring $k[x]$. We know that $k[x]$ is a Euclidean domain, and thus a unique factorization domain.

First notice that given any nonzero polynomial $f(x)\in k[x]$, we can write this polynomial uniquely (up to multiplication by a unit) as $f(x)=cf^{*}(x)$, where $f^{*}(x)\in R[x]$ and $f^{*}(x)$ is primitive. We do this by first finding a common denominator for all the coefficients of $f$ and factoring this out. If we denote this constant by $\beta$, then we can write $f=f^{\prime}/\beta$, where $f^{\prime}\in R[x]$. We then find the content of $f^{\prime}$ (which we will denote by $\alpha$), and factor this out as well. We let $\alpha/\beta=c$ and write $f=cf^{*}$, noting that $f^{*}$ is primitive.

We must prove the uniqueness of this expression of $f$. If $f(x)=cf^{*}(x)=df^{\prime}(x)$ with both $f^{*}(x)$ and $f^{\prime}(x)$ primitive, then we can write $f^{\prime}(x)=(c/d)f^{*}(x)=(a/b)f^{*}(x)$ where $gcd(a,b)=1$. Since the coefficients of $f^{\prime}(x)$ are elements of $R$, then $b|a\gamma_{i}$ for all $i$, where $\gamma_{i}$ are the coefficients of $f^{*}$. But since $gcd(a,b)=1$, then $b|\gamma_{i}$ for all $i$. Since $f^{*}$ is a primitive polynomial, then $b$ must be a unit of $R$. Similarly, we can write $f^{*}(x)=(b/a)f^{\prime}(x)$, and by the same argument as above, $a$ must be a unit as well. This shows that $f^{*}(x)\sim f^{\prime}(x)$.

Let us suppose that we have a polynomial $f(x)\in R[x]$. Then we can factor this polynomial as $f(x)=g(x)h(x)$, with $g(x),h(x)\in k[x]$ (because $k[x]$ is a unique factorization domain). We can also write $cf^{*}(x)=d_{1}g^{*}(x)d_{2}h^{*}(x)$, where $g^{*}(x),h^{*}(x)\in R[x]$ and $g^{*}(x), h^{*}(x)$ are primitive. We showed above that the polynomial $g^{*}(x)h^{*}(x)$ is primitive, and we know that this decomposition $f(x)=cf^{*}(x)$ is unique. Therefore we can write $f^{*}(x)=g^{*}(x)h^{*}(x)$ and thus $f(x)=cg^{*}(x)h^{*}(x)$. But both $f(x)$ and $f^{*}(x)=g^{*}(x)h^{*}(x)$ have coefficients in $R$, and $f^{*}(x)$ is primitive. So $c$ must be an element of $R$. Thus, when we factored $f(x)\in k[x]$ the two factors were also in $R[x]$. By induction, if we decompose $f$ into all its irreducible components in $k[x]$, each of the factors will be in $R[x]$, and we know that this decomposition will be essentially unique because $k[x]$ is a unique factorization domain. This shows that $R[x]$ is a unique factorization domain.

label: Example 2.3.5 (Part 1)
question: Let $\lambda=1-\rho,\theta\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Show that if $\theta$ is not divisible by $\lambda$, then $\theta^{3}\equiv\pm1$ (mod $\lambda^{4})$.
solution:
From previous results, we know that if $\theta$ is not divisible by $\lambda$ then $\theta\equiv\pm1$ (mod $\lambda$). Set $\xi=\theta$ or $-\theta$ so that $\xi\equiv1$ (mod $\lambda$). We write $\xi$ as $1+d\lambda$. Then
$$\pm(\theta^{3}\mp1)=\xi^{3}-1$$
$$=(\xi-1)(\xi-\rho)(\xi-\rho^{2})$$
$$=(d\lambda)(d\lambda+1-\rho)(1+d\lambda-\rho^{2})=d\lambda(d\lambda+\lambda)(d\lambda-\lambda\rho^{2})$$
$$=\lambda^{3}d(d+1)(d-\rho^{2})$$
Since $\rho^2 \equiv 1$ (mod $\lambda$), then $(d-\rho^{2})\equiv(d-1)\pmod{\lambda}$. We know that $\lambda$ divides one of $d$, $d-1$, and $d+1$ (since $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]/(\lambda) \cong \mathbb{Z}/3\mathbb{Z}$), so we may conclude that $\xi^3-1 \equiv 0$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$), so $\xi^{3}\equiv1$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$) and $\theta\equiv\pm1$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$).

label: Example 2.3.5 (Part 2)
question: Deduce that if $\alpha$, $\beta$, $\gamma$ are coprime to $\lambda$, then the equation $\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}+\gamma^{3}=0$ has no nontrivial solutions.
solution:
We consider this equation mod $\lambda^{4}$. Indeed, if such a solution were possible, then somehow the equation
$$\pm1\pm1\pm1\equiv0\pmod{\lambda^{4}}$$
could be satisfied. The left side of this congruence gives $\pm1$ or $\pm3$; certainly $\pm1$ is not congruent to 0 (mod $\lambda^{4}$) since $\lambda^{4}$ is not a unit. Also, $\pm3$ is not congruent to 0 (mod $\lambda^{4}$) since $\lambda^{2}$ is an associate of 3, and thus $\lambda^{4}$ is not. Thus, there is no solution to $\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}+\gamma^{3}=0$ if $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are coprime to $\lambda$.

label: Theorem 2.3.6
question:
Consider the equation
$$\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}+\epsilon\lambda^{3n}\delta^{3}=0 \quad (2.1)$$
for a unit $\epsilon$. Show that any solution for $\delta, \alpha, \beta$ coprime to $\lambda$ must have $n\ge2$, but if (2.1) can be solved with $n=m$, it can be solved for $n=m-1$. Deduce that there are no solutions to the above equation with $\delta, \alpha, \beta$ coprime to $\lambda$.
solution:
We know that $n\ge1$ from Example 2.3.5 (since if $n=0$ we are in the case of the previous example which has no solutions). Considering the equation mod $\lambda^{4}$, we get that $\pm1\pm1+\epsilon\lambda^{3n}\delta^{3} \equiv 0$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$). There are two possibilities: if $\lambda^{3n}\equiv\pm2$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$), then certainly $n$ cannot exceed 1; but if $n=1$, then our congruence implies that $\lambda|2$ which is not true. The other possibility is that $\lambda^{3n}\equiv0$ (mod $\lambda^{4}$), from which it follows that $n\ge2.$ We may rewrite (2.1) as
$$-\epsilon\lambda^{3n}\delta^{3}=\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}$$
$$=(\alpha+\beta)(\alpha+\rho\beta)(\alpha+\rho^{2}\beta).$$
We will write these last three factors as $A_{1}$, $A_{2}$ and $A_{3}$ for convenience. We can see that $\lambda^{6}$ divides the left side of this equation, since $n\ge2$. Thus $\lambda^{6}|A_{1}A_{2}A_{3}$ and $\lambda^{2}|A_{i}$ for some $i$. Notice that
$$A_{1}-A_{2}=\lambda\beta , \quad A_{1}-A_{3}=\lambda\beta\rho^{2}$$
and
$$A_{2}-A_{3}=\lambda\beta\rho$$
Since $\lambda$ divides one of the $A_{i}$, it divides them all, since it divides their differences. Notice, though, that $\lambda^{2}$ does not divide any of these differences, since $\lambda$ does not divide $\beta$ by assumption. Thus, the $A_{i}$ are inequivalent mod $\lambda^{2}$ and only one of the $A_{i}$ is divisible by $\lambda^{2}$. Since our equation is unchanged if we replace $\beta$ with $\rho\beta$ or $\rho^{2}\beta$, then without loss of generality we may assume that $\lambda^{2}|A_{1}$. In fact, we know that $\lambda^{3n-2}|A_{1}$.

Now we write
$B_{1}=A_{1}/\lambda$, $B_{2}=A_{2}/\lambda$, $B_{3}=A_{3}/\lambda$.
We notice that these $B_{i}$ are pairwise coprime, since if for some prime $p$, we had $p|B_{1}$ and $p|B_{2}$, then necessarily we would have
$p|B_{1}-B_{2}=\beta$ and $p|\lambda B_{1}+B_{2}-B_{1}=\alpha.$
This is only possible for a unit $p$ since $gcd(\alpha,\beta)=1$. Similarly, we can verify that the remaining pairs of $B_{i}$ are coprime. Since $\lambda^{3n-2}|A_{1}$, we have $\lambda^{3n-3}|B_{1}$. So we may rewrite (2.1) as
$$-\epsilon\lambda^{3n-3}\delta^{3}=B_{1}B_{2}B_{3}.$$
From this equation we can see that each of the $B_{i}$ is an associate of a cube, since they are relatively prime, and we write
$B_{1}=e_{1}\lambda^{3n-3}C_{1}^{3}, \quad B_{2}=e_{2}C_{2}^{3}, \quad B_{3}=e_{3}C_{3}^{3}$
for units $e_{i}$, and pairwise coprime $C_{i}$. Now recall that
$A_{1}=\alpha+\beta, \quad A_{2}=\alpha+\rho\beta, \quad A_{3}=\alpha+\rho^{2}\beta$.
From these equations we have that
$\rho^{2}A_{3}+\rho A_{2}+A_{1}=\alpha(\rho^{2}+\rho+1)+\beta(\overline{ho}^{2}+\overline{ho}+1) = 0$
so we have that
$0=\rho^{2}\lambda B_{3}+\rho\lambda B_{2}+\lambda B_{1}$
and
$0=\rho^{2}B_{3}+\rho B_{2}+B_{1}$.
We can then deduce that
$\rho^{2}e_{3}C_{3}^{3}+\rho e_{2}C_{2}^{3}+e_{1}\lambda^{3n-3}C_{1}^{3}=0$
so we can find units $e_{4}$, $e_{5}$ so that
$C_{3}^{3}+e_{4}C_{2}^{3}+e_{5}\lambda^{3n-3}C_{1}^{3}=0.$
Considering this equation mod $\lambda^{3}$, and recalling that $n\ge2$, we get that $\pm1\pm e_{4}\equiv0$ (mod $\lambda^{3}$) so $e_{4}=\mp1$, and we rewrite our equation as
$$C_{3}^{3}+(\mp C_{2})^{3}+e_{5}\lambda^{3(n-1)}C_{1}^{3}=0.$$
This is an equation of the same type as (2.1), so we can conclude that if there exists a solution for (2.1) with $n=m$, then there exists a solution with $n=m-1$. This establishes by descent that no nontrivial solution to (2.1) is possible in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.

label: Example 2.4.1
question: Solve the equation $y^{2}+4=x^{3}$ for integers $x, y$.
solution:
We first consider the case where $y$ is even. It follows that $x$ must also be even, which implies that $x^{3}\equiv0$ (mod 8). Now, $y$ is congruent to 0 or 2 (mod 4). If $y\equiv0$ (mod 4), then $y^{2}+4\equiv4$ (mod 8), so we can rule out this case. However, if $y\equiv2$ (mod 4), then $y^{2}+4\equiv0$ (mod 8). Writing $y=2Y$ with $Y$ odd, and $x=2X$ we have $4Y^{2}+4=8X^{3},$ so that
$$Y^{2}+1=2X^{3}$$
$$(Y+i)(Y-i)=2X^{3}=(1+i)(1-i)X^{3}$$
We note that $Y^{2}+1\equiv2\pmod 4$ and so $X^{3}$ is odd. Now,
$$X^{3}=\frac{(Y+i)(Y-i)}{(1+i)(1-i)} = \left(\frac{1+Y}{2}+\frac{1-Y}{2}i\right)\left(\frac{1+Y}{2}-\frac{1-Y}{2}i\right) = \left(\frac{1+Y}{2}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{1-Y}{2}\right)^{2}.$$
We shall write this last sum as $a^{2}+b^{2}$. Since $Y$ is odd, $a$ and $b$ are integers. Notice also that $a+b=1$ so that $gcd(a,b)=1$. We now have that
$$X^{3}=(a+bi)(a-bi).$$
We would like to establish that $(a+bi)$ and $(a-bi)$ are relatively prime. We assume there exists some nonunit $d$ such that $d|(a+bi)$ and $d|(a-bi).$ But then $d|[(a+bi)+(a-bi)]=2a$ and $d|(a+bi)-(a-bi)=2bi.$ Since $gcd(a,b)=1$ then $d|2$, and thus $d$ must have even norm. But then it is impossible that $d|(a+bi)$ since the norm of $(a+bi)$ is $a^{2}+b^{2}=X^{3}$ which is odd. Thus $(a+bi)$ and $(a-bi)$ are relatively prime, and each is therefore a cube, since $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ is a unique factorization domain. We write
$$a+bi=(s+ti)^{3}=s^{3}-3st^{2}+(3s^{2}t-t^{3})i.$$
Comparing real and imaginary parts yields
$$a=s^{3}-3st^{2}, \quad b=3s^{2}t-t^{3}.$$
Adding these two equations yields $a+b=s^{3}-3st^{2}+3s^{2}t-t^{3}$. But $a+b=1$, so we have
$$1=s^{3}-3st^{2}+3s^{2}t-t^{3} = (s-t)(s^{2}+4st+t^{2})$$
Now, $s, t \in \mathbb{Z}$ so $(s-t)=\pm1$ and $(s^{2}+4st+t^{2})=\pm1$. Subtracting the second equation from the square of the first we find that $-6st=0$ or 2. Since $s$ and $t$ are integers, we rule out the case $-6st=2$ and deduce that either $s=0$ or $t=0$. Thus either $a=1, b=0$ or $a=0, b=1$. It follows that $Y=\pm1$, so the only solutions in $\mathbb{Z}$ to the given equation with $y$ even are $x=2, y=\pm2$.

Next, we consider the case where $y$ is odd. We write $x^{3}=(y+2i)(y-2i).$ We can deduce that $(y+2i)$ and $(y-2i)$ are relatively prime since if $d$ divided both, $d$ would divide both their sum and their difference, i.e., we would have $d|2y$ and $d|4i$. But then $d$ would have even norm, and since $y$ is odd, $(y+2i)$ has odd norm; thus $d$ does not divide $(y+2i)$. Hence, $(y+2i)$ is a cube; we write
$$y+2i=(q+ri)^{3}=q^{3}-3qr^{2}+(3q^{2}r-r^{3})i.$$
Comparing real and imaginary parts we have that $2=3q^{2}r-r^{3}$ so that $r|2$ and the only values $r$ could thus take are $\pm1$ and $\pm2$. We get that the only possible pairs $(q,r)$ we can have are (1, 1), (-1, 1), (1, -2), and $(-1,-2)$. Solving for $y$, and excluding the cases where $y$ is even, we find that $x=5, y=\pm11$ is the only possible solution when $y$ is odd.

label: Example 2.4.4
question: Solve $y^{2}+1=x^{p}$ for an odd prime $p$, and $x, y\in\mathbb{Z}.$
solution:
Notice that the equation $y^{2}+1=x^{3}$ from an earlier problem is a special case of the equation given here. To analyze the solutions of this equation, we first observe that for odd $y$, $y^{2}\equiv1$ (mod 4). Thus $x$ would need to be even, but then if we consider the equation mod 4 we find that it cannot be satisfied; $y^{2}+1\equiv2$ (mod 4), while $x^{p}\equiv0$ (mod 4). Thus $y$ is even; it is easy to see that $x$ must be odd. If $y=0$ then $x=1$ is a solution for all $p$. We call this solution a trivial solution; we proceed to investigate solutions other than the trivial one.

Now we write our equation as
$$(y+i)(y-i)=x^{p}.$$
If $y\ne0$ then we note that if some divisor $\alpha$ were to divide both $(y+i)$ and $(y-i)$, then it would divide $2i$; if $\alpha$ is not a unit, then $\alpha$ will thus divide 2, and also $y$, since $y$ is even. But then it is impossible that $\alpha$ also divide $y+i$ since $i$ is a unit. We conclude that $(y+i)$ and $(y-i)$ are relatively prime when $y\ne0$. Thus $(y+i)$ and $(y-i)$ are both $p$-th powers, and we may write
$$(y+i)=e(a+bi)^{p}$$
for some unit $e$ and integers $a$ and $b$. We have analyzed the units of $\mathbb{Z}[i]$; they are all powers of $i$, so we write $(y+i)=i^{k}(a+bi)^{p}$ and $(y-i)=\overline{(y+i)}=(-i)^{k}(a-bi)^{p}$.
Thus
$$(y+i)(y-i)=i^{k}(a+bi)^{p}(-i)^{k}(a-bi)^{p}=(a^{2}+b^{2})^{p}=x^{p}$$
and it follows that $x=(a^{2}+b^{2})$. We know that $x$ is odd, so one of $a$ and $b$ is even (but not both). We now have that
$$(y+i)-(y-i)=2i = i^{k}(a+bi)^{p}-(-i)^{k}(a-bi)^{p}.$$
We consider two cases separately:

Case 1. $k$ is odd.
In this case we use the binomial theorem to determine the imaginary parts of both sides of the above equation. We get
$$2=Im[(i)^{k}((a+bi)^{p}+(a-bi)^{p})]=Im[(i)^{k}(\sum_{j=0}^{p}a^{p-j}(bi)^{j}\binom{p}{j}+\sum_{j=0}^{p}a^{p-j}(-bi)^{j}\binom{p}{j})]$$
$$=2(-1)^{(k-1)/2}\sum_{0\le j<p, even}a^{p-j}(b)^{j}(-1)^{j/2}\binom{p}{j}.$$
Thus
$$1=(-1)^{(k-1)/2}\sum_{0\le j<p, even}a^{p-j}(b)^{j}(-1)^{j/2}\binom{p}{j}.$$
Since $a$ divides every term on the right-hand side of this equation, then $a|1$ and $a=\pm1$. We observed previously that only one of $a, b$ is odd; thus $b$ is even. We now substitute $a=\pm1$ into the last equation above to get
$$\pm1=\sum_{0\le j<p, even}(b)^{j}(-1)^{j/2}\binom{p}{j} = 1-b^{2}\binom{p}{2}+b^{4}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm b^{p-1}\binom{p}{p-1}.$$
If the sign of 1 on the left-hand side of this equality were negative, we would have that $b^{2}|2$; $b$ is even and in particular $b\ne\pm1$, so this is impossible. Thus
$$0=-b^{2}\binom{p}{2}+b^{4}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm b^{p-1}\binom{p}{p-1} = -\binom{p}{2}+b^{2}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm b^{p-3}\binom{p}{p-1}$$
Now we notice that $2|b$ so $2 | \binom{p}{2}$. If $p\equiv3$ (mod 4), then we are finished because $2 \nmid \binom{p}{2}$. Suppose in fact that $2^{q}$ is the largest power of 2 dividing $\binom{p}{2}$. We shall show that $2^{q+1}$ will then divide every term in $b^{2}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm b^{p-3}\binom{p}{p-1}$, and this will establish that no $b$ will satisfy our equation. We consider one of these terms given by $(b)^{j-2}\binom{p}{j}$, for an even value of $j$; we rewrite this as $b^{2m-2}\binom{p}{2m}$. We see that
$$\binom{p}{2m}=\binom{p-2}{2m-2}\frac{(p)(p-1)}{2m(2m-1)} = \binom{p-2}{2m-2}\binom{p}{2}\frac{1}{m(2m-1)},$$
so we are considering a term
$$\binom{p-2}{2m-2}\binom{p}{2}\frac{b^{2m-2}}{m(2m-1)}$$
Now, $2^{q}|\binom{p}{2}$ by assumption. Recall that $b$ is even; thus $2^{2m-2}|b^{2m-2}$. Now $m\ge2$; it is easy to see then that $2m-2\ge m$, so $2^{2m-2}$ does not divide $m$. Thus when we reduce the fraction
$$\frac{b^{2m-2}}{m(2m-1)}$$
to lowest terms, the numerator is even and the denominator is odd. Therefore, $2(2^{q})|\binom{p-2}{2m-2}\binom{p}{2}\frac{b^{2m-2}}{m(2m-1)}.$ Thus $2^{q+1}$ divides every term in $b^{2}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm\binom{p}{p-1}b^{p-3}$ and we deduce that no value of $b$ can satisfy our equation.

Case 2. $k$ is even.
This case is almost identical to the first case; we mention only the relevant differences. When we expand
$$(y+i)-(y-i)=2i=i^{k}(a+bi)^{p}-(-i)^{k}(a-bi)^{p}$$
and consider imaginary parts, we get
$$1=(-1)^{k/2}\sum_{0<j\le p, odd}a^{p-j}(b)^{j}(-1)^{(j-1)/2}\binom{p}{j}.$$
We are able to deduce that $b=\pm1$ substituting we get the equation
$$\pm1=\sum_{0<j\le p, odd}a^{p-j}(b)^{j}(-1)^{(j-1)/2}\binom{p}{j} = 1-a^{2}\binom{p}{2}+a^{4}\binom{p}{4}-\cdot\cdot\cdot\pm\binom{p}{p-1}a^{p-1},$$
which we can see is identical to the equation we arrived at in Case 1, with $b$ replaced by $a$. Thus we can reproduce the proof of Case 1, with $b$ replaced by $a,$ to establish that there are no nontrivial solutions with $k$ even. We conclude that the equation $y^{2}+1=x^{p}$ has no nontrivial solution with $x,y\in\mathbb{Z}$

label: Exercise 2.1.2
question: Let $D$ be squarefree. Consider $R=\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{D}]$. Show that every element of $R$ can be written as a product of irreducible elements.
solution:
We define a map $n:R\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that for $a+b\sqrt{D}\in R,$
$$n(a+b\sqrt{D})=|a^{2}-Db^{2}|$$
We must check that this map satisfies conditions (i) and (ii) from the previous example.
(i) For $a+b\sqrt{D},c+d\sqrt{D}\in R$
$$n[(a+b\sqrt{D})(c+d\sqrt{D})]=n[(ac+bdD)+(ad+bc)\sqrt{D}]$$
$$=|(ac+bdD)^{2}-(ad+bc)^{2}D|$$
$$=|(a^{2}-b^{2}D)(c^{2}-d^{2}D)|$$
$$=n(a+b\sqrt{D})n(c+d\sqrt{D}),$$
so condition (i) is satisfied.
(ii) If $r=a+b\sqrt{D}$ is a unit in $R$, then $\exists s=c+d\sqrt{D}\in R$ such that $rs=1$. But by condition (i), since $1=n(1)$, $1=n(r)n(s)$. Since our map $n$ only takes on values in the positive integers, then $n(r)=n(s)=1$ for all units of $R$. The converse is clear.
Since we have found a map $n$ which satisfies the conditions of Example 2.1.1, we can deduce that every element of $R$ can be written as a product of irreducible elements.

label: Exercise 2.1.3
question: Let $R=\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$. Show that $2,3,1+\sqrt{-5},$ and $1-\sqrt{-5}$ are irreducible in $R$, and that they are not associates.
solution:
We define a map $n:R\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that $n(a+b\sqrt{-5})=a^{2}+5b^{2}$.
If 2 is not irreducible, then there are elements $r,s\in R$ such that $rs=2$, with $r,s$ not units. But then $n(r)n(s)=n(2)=4$, and since $r,s$ are not units, it must be that $n(r)=n(s)=2.$ Then we must find integers $a, b$ such that $a^{2}+5b^{2}=2$, which is clearly impossible, so 2 must be irreducible.
If 3 is not irreducible then we can find $r,s\in R$ with $rs=3$ and $r,s$ not units. Since $n(3)=9$, we must have $n(r)=n(s)=3$. But by the same argument as above, we see that this is impossible.
$n(1+\sqrt{-5})=6$. The only proper divisors of 6 are 2 and 3, and so if $1+\sqrt{-5}$ is not irreducible, then we can find $r\in R,$ $r$ not a unit and $r|(1+\sqrt{-5})$ with either $n(r)=2$ or $n(r)=3$. But we showed above that this is not possible, so $1+\sqrt{-5}$ is irreducible. Since $n(1-\sqrt{-5})=6$, then $1-\sqrt{-5}$ must also be irreducible.
If two elements of $R$ are associates, then they must have the same norm, a fact which follows immediately from the condition that all units have norm 1. If $a+b\sqrt{-5}$ is a unit, then $a^{2}+5b^{2}=1$. This will only occur when $a=\pm1$, and so the only units of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ are 1 and -1. Of $2,3,1 \pm \sqrt{-5}$, we see that the only two which could possibly be associates are $1+\sqrt{-5}$ and $1-\sqrt{-5}$ because they have the same norm. However, if we multiply $1+\sqrt{-5}$ by either of the units of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$, we will not get $1-\sqrt{-5}$, and so they cannot be associates.
We conclude that 2, 3, $1+\sqrt{-5}$ and $1-\sqrt{-5}$ are all irreducible and are not associates.

label: Exercise 2.1.4
question: Let $R$ be a domain satisfying condition (i): every element of $R$ can be written as a product of irreducibles. Show that condition (ii): this factorization is essentially unique, is equivalent to $(ii^{*})$: if $\pi$ is irreducible and $\pi$ divides $ab$, then $\pi|a$ or $\pi|b.$
solution:
Suppose $R$ satisfies both (i) and (ii) above. Let $\pi\in R$ be an irreducible element, and suppose that $\pi|ab$, where
$$a=\tau_{1}\tau_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\tau_{r}$$
$$b=\gamma_{1}\gamma_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\gamma_{s}$$
and $\tau_{i}$, $\gamma_{j}$ are irreducible. We know that $\pi|ab=\tau_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\tau_{r}\gamma_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\gamma_{s},$ so it follows that $ab=\pi\lambda_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\lambda_{n}$ where each $\lambda_{i}$ is irreducible. By condition (ii), $\pi\sim\tau_{i}$ for some $i$, or $\pi\sim\gamma_{j}$ for some $j$. Thus, if $\pi|ab$ then $\pi|a$ or $\pi|b.$
Now suppose that $R$ is a domain satisfying conditions (i) and $(ii^{*})$ above, and suppose that we have an element $a$ which has two different factorizations into irreducibles: $a=\tau_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\tau_{r}$ and $a=\pi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\pi_{s}$. Consider $\tau_{1}$. We know that $\tau_{1}|a$, and so $\tau_{1}|\pi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\pi_{s}$. By $(ii^{*})$ we know that $\tau_{1}|\pi_{i}$ for some $i$, and since both are irreducible, they must be associates. We can now remove both $\tau_{1}$ and $\pi_{i}$ from our factorization of $a$. We next consider $\tau_{2}$. Following the same process, we can pair up $\tau_{2}$ with its associate, and we can continue to do this until we have paired up each of the irreducible factors $\tau_{i}$ with its associate $\pi_{j}$. It is clear that if we continue in this fashion, we must have $r=s$.

label: Exercise 2.1.5
question: Show that if $\pi$ is an irreducible element of a principal ideal domain, then $(\pi)$ is a maximal ideal (where $(\pi)$ denotes the ideal generated by the element $\pi$).
solution:
We define $gcd(a,b)$, the greatest common divisor of $a, b\in R$, to be an element $d$ such that the ideal $(a, b)$ equals the ideal $(d)$. It is unique up to units. For a unique factorization domain, this definition coincides with the usual one. We note that $d$ must divide both $a$ and $b$ since they are in the ideal $(d)$.
If $\pi$ is irreducible, we consider the ideal $(\pi, \alpha)$ where $\alpha$ is any element not in $(\pi)$. Since $\alpha$ is not a multiple of $\pi$, and $\pi$ is irreducible, then the only common divisors of $\alpha$ and $\pi$ will be units. Then $gcd(\pi,\alpha)=1$. In other words, the ideal generated by $\pi$ is a maximal ideal.

label: Exercise 2.1.8
question: If $F$ is a field, prove that $F[x]$, the ring of polynomials in $x$ with coefficients in $F$, is Euclidean.
solution:
We define a map $\phi:F[x]\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that for $f\in F[x],$ $\phi(f)=deg(f)$. Now consider any two polynomials $f(x)$, $g(x)\in F[x]$. If $deg(g)>deg(f)$, then we can certainly write $f(x)=0\cdot g(x)+f(x)$, which satisfies the Euclidean condition. Then we can assume that $m=deg(g)\le deg(f)=n$ and write $f(x)=a_{0}+a_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{n}x^{n}$, and $g(x)=b_{0}+b_{1}x+b_{2}x^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{m}x^{m}$, where $a_n, b_{m}\ne0$ and $m\le n$. We proceed by induction on the degree of $f$. That is, we will prove by induction on the degree of $f$ that we can write $f(x)=q(x)g(x)+r(x)$, where $r=0$ or $deg(r)<deg(g)$.
Define a new polynomial
$$h(x)=a_{n}b_{m}^{-1}g(x)x^{n-m}.$$
Observe that the leading term of $h(x)$ is $a_{n}b_{m}^{-1}b_{m}x^{m}x^{n-m}=a_{n}x^{n}$ which is the leading term of $f(x)$, so that if $f_{1}(x)=f(x)-h(x)$, either $f_{1}(x)=0$ or $deg(f_{1})<deg(f)$. The theorem holds for $f_{1}(x)$, so we can write $f_{1}(x)=f(x)-h(x)=q(x)g(x)+r(x)$, where $r=0$ or $deg(r)<deg(g)=m.$ Now $f(x)=q(x)g(x)+h(x)+r(x)$ and since $h(x)$ is a multiple of $g(x)$, the result follows.

label: Exercise 2.2.1
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
We define a map $\phi:\mathbb{Z}[i]\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ such that $\phi(a+bi)=a^{2}+b^{2}$. Now, given any two elements of $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, say $\alpha=a+bi$ and $\gamma=c+di,$ can we find $q,r\in\mathbb{Z}[i]$ such that $a+bi=q(c+di)+r$, where $r=0$ or $\phi(r)<\phi(c+di)$?
Since we cannot divide $\alpha$ and $\gamma$ in the ring $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, we move temporarily to the ring $\mathbb{Q}[i]=\{r+si|r,s\in\mathbb{Q}\}$. In this ring,
$$\frac{\alpha}{\gamma}=\frac{(a+bi)}{(c+di)}=\frac{(ac+bd)}{(c^{2}+d^{2})}+\frac{(bc-ad)}{(c^{2}+d^{2})}i=r+si,$$
with $r,s\in\mathbb{Q}$. We can now choose $m, n\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $|r-m|\le1/2$ and $|s-n|\le1/2.$ We set $q=m+ni$. Then $q\in\mathbb{Z}[i]$, and $\alpha=q\gamma+r$ for some suitable $r,$ with
$$\phi(r)=\phi(\alpha-q\gamma)=\phi(\alpha/\gamma-q)\phi(\gamma)$$
$$=[(r-m)^{2}+(s-n)^{2}]\phi(\gamma)$$
$$ \le(\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{4})\phi(\gamma)=\frac{1}{2}\phi(\gamma)<\phi(\gamma).$$
We have shown that our map $\phi$ satisfies the properties specified above, and so $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.2.2
question: Prove that if $p$ is a positive prime, then there is an element $x\in\mathbb{F}_{p}:=\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ such that $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$) if and only if either $p=2$ or $p\equiv1$ (mod 4). (Hint: Use Wilson's theorem, Exercise 1.4.10.)
solution:
If $p=2$, then $1\equiv-1$ (mod 2), so $1^{2}=1\equiv-1$ (mod 2). Hence we can take $x=1$. Conversely, if $1\equiv-1$ (mod $p$), we can see that $p=2$ since $1=ap-1$ for some integer $a$ which implies $ap=2$.
We will show that in any field $\mathbb{F}_{p}$ where 1 is not congruent to -1 (mod $p$), $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$) for an element $x$ if and only if $x$ has order 4 in the group of units of the field. Suppose that $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$). Then the first four powers of $x$ are $x, -1, -x, 1$. Hence $x$ has order 4. Conversely, suppose that $x$ has order 4. Then, $x^{4}=(x^{2})^{2}\equiv1(mod~p)$, so $(x^{2})^{2}-1\equiv0$ (mod $p$). Hence $(x^2 + 1)(x^{2}-1)\equiv0(mod~p).$ Since $x$ is an element of a field, $x^{2}+1\equiv0$ (mod $p$) or $x^{2}-1\equiv0$ (mod $p$). However, if $x^{2}-1\equiv0$ (mod $p$), $x$ has order 2. Hence $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$).
If $p\ne2$, then $\mathbb{F}_{p}$ is a field where 1 is not congruent to -1 (mod $p$). Hence the existence of an element $x$ such that $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$) is equivalent to the existence of an element of order 4 in the group of units of $\mathbb{F}_{p}$. Let $U_{p}$ be the group of units of $\mathbb{F}_{p}$. Then $|U_{p}|=p-1$, and since the order of any element divides the order of the group, if $U_{p}$ has an element of order 4, then we have $4|p-1$ or, equivalently, $p\equiv1$ (mod 4). Conversely, if we suppose that $p\equiv1$ (mod 4), then we can write $p=4k+1$ where $k$ is an integer and $U_{p}$ is a cyclic group of order $p-1=4k$. If $g$ is a generator of $U_{p}$, then $g$ has order $4k$. So $g^{k}$ has order 4. Hence we can see that if 1 is not congruent to 1 mod $p$, $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$) occurs if and only if $x$ has order 4 in the group of units of the field, which occurs if and only if $p \equiv 1$ (mod 4).
Alternate Solution: Wilson's theorem gives $(p-1)! \equiv -1$ (mod $p$). We can pair up $k$ and $(p-k)$ in the product above so that $k(p-k)\equiv-k^{2}$ (mod $p$) implies $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}(\frac{p-1}{2})!^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$). Thus, if $p\equiv1$ (mod 4), there is an $x\in\mathbb{F}_{p}$ so that $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$). The converse follows from Fermat's little Theorem: $1\equiv(x^{2})^{(p-1)/2}\equiv(-1)^{(p-1)/2}(mod~p)$ so that $(p-1)/2$ is even. That is, $p\equiv1$ (mod 4).

label: Exercise 2.2.3
question: Find all integer solutions to $y^{2}+1=x^{3}$ with $x, y\ne0$.
solution:
If $y$ is even, then $x^{3}\equiv0$ (mod 8), which implies in turn that $y^{2}\equiv7$ (mod 8). However, if $y\equiv1,3,5,7$ (mod 8), then $y^{2}\equiv1$ (mod 8). So $x$ must be odd, and $y$ even.
We can factor this equation in the ring $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ to obtain $(y+i)(y-i)=x^{3}$. If $\exists\delta$ such that $\delta|(y+i)$ and $\delta|(y-i)$ then $\delta|2i$, which implies that $\delta|2$. But this would mean that $\delta$ is divisible by 2, which we know is not true. Therefore, we know that $(y+i)$ and $(y-i)$ are relatively prime in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, and that they must both be cubes. We know that we can write $y+i=e_{1}(a+bi)^{3}$ and $y-i=e_{2}(c+di)^{3}$ where $a, b, c, d\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $e_{1}$, $e_{2}$ are units in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$. However, the only units of $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ are $\pm1$ and $\pm i,$ and these are all cubes, so without loss, assume that $e_{1}=e_{2}=1$.
Next, we expand our factorization for $y+i$ to get
$$y+i=a^{3}+3a^{2}bi+3ab^{2}-b^{3}i.$$
Comparing the imaginary parts, we get $1=3a^{2}b-b^{3}=b(3a^{2}-b^{2})$, with $a,b\in\mathbb{Z}$. The only integers which multiply together to give 1 are $\pm1$, so we know that $b=\pm1$. If $b=1$, then we have $1=3a^{2}-1$, implying $3a^{2}=2$, which has no integer solutions, so $b\ne1$. If $b=-1$ then we get $1=-3a^{2}+1$, and so $3a^{2}=0$, and $a$ must be 0. However, if we substitute $a=0$ back into our original equation for $y+i,$ we find that $y=0$ which we did not allow, and so $b\ne-1$. We conclude that the equation $y^{2}+1=x^{3}$ has no integer solutions with $x,y\ne0$.

label: Exercise 2.2.4
question: If $\pi$ is an element of $R$ such that when $\pi|ab$ with $a, b\in R$, then $\pi|a$ or $\pi|b$, then we say that $\pi$ is prime. What are the primes of $\mathbb{Z}[i]$?
solution:
Given $\pi=(a+bi)\in\mathbb{Z}[i]$ we define the complex conjugate of $\pi$ to be the element $\overline{\pi}=(a-bi)$. We note that $n(\pi)=a^{2}+b^{2}=\pi\overline{\pi},$ and so given any prime $\pi$ in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, we know that $\pi$ divides $n(\pi)$. Using this information, we observe that we can find all the Gaussian primes by examining the irreducible factors of the primes of $\mathbb{Z}$. For, let $n(\pi)=p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{k}$ be the prime decomposition of $n(\pi)$. We know that $\pi|n(\pi)$, so $\pi|p_{i}$ for some $i$. If $\pi|p_{i}$ and $\pi|p_{j}$, with $p_{i}\ne p_{j}$, then $\pi|1$, since $gcd(p_{i},p_{j})=1$. But then $\pi$ would be a unit, and thus not irreducible. So, by examining all of the divisors of the primes in $\mathbb{Z}$, we will discover all of the primes of $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ once and only once each.
We let $\pi$ be a prime in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, and $p$ the prime in $\mathbb{Z}$ such that $\pi|p.$ By the properties of the map $n$, $n(\pi)|n(p)=p^{2}$ so $n(\pi)=p$ or $n(\pi)=p^{2}$. If we let $\pi=a+bi$, then $a^{2}+b^{2}=p$ or $a^{2}+b^{2}=p^{2}$. All the primes of $\mathbb{Z}$ are congruent to 1, 2 or 3 (mod $p$), and we will examine these cases separately.
Case 1. $p\equiv3$ (mod 4). We just proved that if $\pi=a+bi$ is prime, then either $a^{2}+b^{2}=p$, or $a^{2}+b^{2}=p^{2}$ for some integer prime $p$. Let us assume that the first of these possibilities is true. We know that $p$ is odd, so one of $a, b$ is even. Let us say that $a$ is even, and $b$ odd, so that $a=2x$ and $b=2y+1$ for some $x,y\in\mathbb{Z}$. Then $a^{2}+b^{2}=4x^{2}+4y^{2}+4y+1 = 4(x^{2}+y^{2}+y)+1 \equiv1$ (mod 4). Since we had assumed that $p\equiv3$ (mod 4), we have a contradiction. So $a^{2}+b^{2}=p^{2}$, which means that $n(\pi)=n(p)$, and so $p$ and $\pi$ must be associates. Therefore, primes in $\mathbb{Z}$ that are congruent to 3 (mod 4) and their associates are prime in the ring $\mathbb{Z}[i]$.
Case 2. $p\equiv2$ (mod 4). There is, of course, only one such integer prime: 2. Assume we have a prime $\pi$ which divides 2. Since $2=(1+i)(1-i)$, then $\pi|(1+i)$ or $\pi|(1-i)$. But $n(1+i)=n(1-i)=2$ and it is easy to show that $(1+i)$ and $(1-i)$ are irreducible in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$ and so they are prime. So, if $\pi|2$, then $\pi\sim(1+i)$ or $\pi\sim(1-i)$.
Case 3. $p\equiv1$ (mod 4). We recall Wilson's Theorem, Exercise 1.4.10, which states that if $p$ is a prime, then $(p-1)!\equiv-1$ (mod $p$). We will in fact be using a corollary of this theorem, which states that if $p$ is a prime number of the form $1+4m$, then $p|(n^{2}+1)$, where $(2m)!=n$. (We can also apply Exercise 2.2.2.) If $p|(n^{2}+1)=(n+i)(n-i)$ and $\pi|p$, then $\pi|(n+i)$ or $\pi|(n-i)$. If $p$ were to divide $(n\pm i)$, then $p|n$ and $p|1$ which is clearly not the case since $p$ is not a unit. We conclude that $p$ and $\pi$ are not associates, so $n(\pi)\ne n(p)$, which implies that $n(\pi)=a^{2}+b^{2}=p$. Thus, if $p\equiv1$ (mod 4), then $p$ does not remain prime in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$. We can deduce that if $\pi=a\pm bi$ and $a^{2}+b^{2}=p$ then $\pi$ is prime in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$.

label: Exercise 2.2.5
question: A positive integer $a$ is the sum of two squares if and only if $a=b^{2}c$ where $c$ is not divisible by any positive prime $p\equiv3$ (mod 4).
solution:
Suppose that $a$ is the sum of two squares. Let $a=s^{2}+t^{2}$ and let $(s,t)=b$. Then $a=(bx)^{2}+(by)^{2}=b^{2}(x^{2}+y^{2})$ where $(x,y)=1$. Let $c=x^{2}+y^{2}$. Then we have $a=b^{2}c$ where $c$ is the sum of two relatively prime squares. By Exercise 2.2.2, $c$ is not divisible by any prime $p\equiv3$ (mod 4). In fact, suppose that $p|x^{2}+y^{2}$. Then, $x^{2}+y^{2}\equiv0$ (mod $p$), $x^{2}\equiv-y^{2}$ (mod $p$) and so $((y^{-1})^{2}\cdot x^{2})=(y^{-1}\cdot x)^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod $p$). By Exercise 2.2.2, either $p=2$ or $p\equiv1$ (mod 4). Hence $c$ is not divisible by any prime $p\equiv3$ (mod 4).
Now suppose that we have an integer $a$ which we can write as $a=b^{2}c,$ and suppose that $c$ is not divisible by any positive prime $p\equiv3$ (mod 4). Then $c$ is a product of primes each of which, by Exercise 2.2.4, is a sum of two squares. Then $b^{2}=n(b)$ and $c=n(t+ri)$ where $t$ and $r$ are integers. Then
$$b^{2}\cdot c=n(b(t+ri))=n(bt+bri)=b^{2}\cdot t^{2}+b^{2}\cdot r^{2}=(bt)^{2}+(br)^{2}.$$
Hence $a=b^{2}c$ is written as the sum of two squares.

label: Exercise 2.3.1
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is a ring.
solution: First observe that $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is a subset of the complex numbers, so associativity, distributivity, and commutativity are immediate for addition and multiplication. Also, $0,1\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, so we have additive and multiplicative identities. If $a+b\rho\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, then $-a-b\rho\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, so we have additive inverses. It remains to verify closure under addition and multiplication; if $a, b, c, d \in \mathbb{Z}$, then $(a+b\rho)+(c+d\rho)=(a+c)+(b+d)\rho\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, so we have closure under addition. Also $(a+b\rho)(c+d\rho)=ac+(ad+bc)\rho+bd\rho^{2}$. We will therefore have closure under multiplication if $\rho^{2}\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. But $\rho^{2}=-1-\rho,$ so $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is a commutative ring with unit.

label: Exercise 2.3.2 (a)
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
Define $\phi:\mathbb{Z}[\rho]\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ so that $\phi(a+b\rho)=a^{2}-ab+b^{2}=\alpha\overline{\alpha}$ for $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. We consider $\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, $\beta\ne0$. We have $\beta\overline{ eta}=\phi(\beta)$. Now $\beta\overline{ eta}\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $\alpha\overline{ eta}\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, so
$$\frac{\alpha}{\beta}=\frac{\alpha\overline{ eta}}{\beta\overline{ eta}}=\frac{\alpha\overline{ eta}}{\beta\overline{ eta}}=s+t\rho$$
for some $s, t\in\mathbb{Q}$. We set $m$ and $n$ to be the integers closest to $s$ and $t$, respectively, i.e., choose $m$ and $n$ so $|m-s|\le1/2$ and $|n-t|\le1/2$. We set $q=m+n\rho$. Now,
$$\phi(\frac{\alpha}{\beta}-q)=(s-m)^{2}-(s-m)(t-n)+(t-n)^{2}\le\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{4}<1.$$
So, writing $r=\alpha-q\beta$ then if $r\ne0$, $\phi(r)=\phi(\beta)\phi(\alpha/\beta-q)<\phi(\beta)$, and with the map $\phi$, for any $\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, we can write $\alpha=q\beta+r$ where $r=0$ or $\phi(r)<\phi(\beta)$. Thus, $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.3.2 (b)
question: Show that the only units in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ are $\pm1$, $\pm\rho,$ and $\pm\rho^{2}$.
solution: Observe that $\phi$ is a multiplicative map into the natural numbers, so that if $\eta$ is a unit of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, then $\phi(\eta)=1$. We thus see immediately that $\pm1,\pm\rho,\pm\rho^{2}$ are all units (it is easy to see that they are distinct). Suppose $\eta=a+b\rho$ were a unit of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Then $a^{2}-ab+b^{2}=1$ and $(2a-b)^{2}+3b^{2}=4.$ From this equation it is clear that $b=0$ or $\pm1$ are the only possible integer values $b$ could take, since $3b^{2}$ must be less than 4. To each solution for $b$ there are two corresponding solutions for $a$, and thus at most six distinct pairs $(a,b)$ in total. By the pigeonhole principle the list given above includes all the units of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.

label: Exercise 2.3.3
question: Let $\lambda=1-\rho$. Show that $\lambda$ is irreducible, so we have a factorization of 3 (unique up to unit).
solution: We have that $\phi(\lambda)=3$. If $d|\lambda$, then $\phi(d)|3$, i.e., $\phi(d)=1$ or 3, so $d$ is either a unit or an associate of $\lambda$, and $\lambda$ is irreducible.

label: Exercise 2.3.4
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]/(\lambda)$ has order 3.
solution: Suppose $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, so that $\alpha=a+b\rho$ for integers $a, b$. Then $\alpha=a+b-b(1-\rho)=a+b-b\lambda\equiv a+b$ (mod $\lambda$). Considered mod 3, $a+b$ could have residues 0, 1, or 2. Since $\lambda|3$ (see Exercise 2.3.3, above), then $a$ will have one of these residues mod $\lambda$. Since $\phi(\lambda)$ does not divide $\phi(1)=1$, or $\phi(2)=4$, none of these classes are equivalent mod $\lambda$, and so we have three distinct residue classes, which we may denote by 0 and $\pm1$.

label: Exercise 2.4.2
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$ is Euclidean.
solution: We define a norm $\phi:\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ by $\phi(a+b\sqrt{-2})=a^{2}+2b^{2}.$ For $\alpha, \beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$, we consider $\alpha/\beta=\alpha\overline{\beta}/\beta\overline{ eta}.$ Notice that $\beta\overline{ eta}=\phi(\beta)$ so $\beta\overline{ eta}\in\mathbb{Z}$. Also, $\overline{\beta}\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$, so $\alpha\overline{\beta}\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$, so $\alpha/\beta=\alpha\overline{\beta}/\beta\overline{ eta}=c+d\sqrt{-2}$ for some $c, d\in\mathbb{Q}$. We choose $m$ and $n$ as the closest integers to $c$ and $d$, i.e., so that $|m-c|\le1/2$ and $|n-d|\le1/2$. We write $q=m+n\sqrt{-2}$. We have that $\phi(\alpha/\beta-q)=(c-m)^{2}+2(d-n)^{2}\le1/4+1/2<1$. So we write $\alpha=q\beta+r$ and $r=\alpha-q\beta$. If $r\ne0$ then $\phi(r)=\phi(\beta)\phi(\alpha/\beta-q)<\phi(\beta)$. We conclude that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.4.3
question: Solve $y^{2}+2=x^{3}$ for $x,y\in\mathbb{Z}$
solution:
Write $(y+\sqrt{-2})(y-\sqrt{-2})=x^{3}$. If $y$ were even, then $x$ would be also, but if $y$ is even, then $x^{3}\equiv0$ (mod 8) whereas 8 does not divide $y^{2}+2$. So $y$ and $x$ are both odd. Observe that $(y+\sqrt{-2})$ and $(y-\sqrt{-2})$ are relatively prime, since if $d$ divided both, then $d$ would divide $2\sqrt{-2}$ and would thus have even norm, which is not possible since $y$ is odd. Thus $(y+\sqrt{-2})$ is a cube multiplied by a unit. The only units of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$ are 1 and -1, which are both cubes. Without loss, assume that the unit in question is 1. We write
$$(y+\sqrt{-2})=(a+b\sqrt{-2})^{3}=a^{3}-6ab^{2}+(3a^{2}b-2b^{3})\sqrt{-2}.$$
Comparing real and imaginary parts, we find that
$$y=a^{3}-6ab^{2}, \quad 1=(3a^{2}b-2b^{3})=b(3a^{2}-2b^{2}).$$
Thus, $b|1$ so $b=\pm1$. It follows that $a=\pm1$. Substituting into the equation for $y$, we find that $y=\pm5$. Thus, the only solution to the given equation is $x=3,$ $y=\pm5$

label: Exercise 2.4.5
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
We define a norm $\phi:\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]\rightarrow\mathbb{N}$ by $\phi(a+b\sqrt{2})=|a^{2}-2b^{2}|$. Let $\alpha, \beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$. We write $\beta=c+d\sqrt{2}$ and consider
$$\frac{\alpha}{\beta}=\frac{\alpha(c-d\sqrt{2})}{\beta(c-d\sqrt{2})}.$$
Notice that $|\beta(c-d\sqrt{2})|=\phi(\beta)$ so $\beta(c-d\sqrt{2})\in\mathbb{Z}.$ Also, $(c-d\sqrt{2})\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$, so $\alpha(c-d\sqrt{2})\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$, so
$$\frac{\alpha}{\beta}=\frac{\alpha(c-d\sqrt{2})}{\beta(c-d\sqrt{2})}=t+u\sqrt{2}$$
for some $t, u\in\mathbb{Q}$. We choose $m$ and $n$ as the closest integers to $t$ and $u$, i.e. so that $|m-t|\le1/2$ and $|n-u|\le1/2.$ We write $q=m+n\sqrt{2}$. We have that
$$\phi(\alpha/\beta-q)=|(t-m)^{2}-2(u-n)^{2}|\le|(t-m)^{2}|+|2(u-n)^{2}|\le\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{2}<1.$$
We write $\alpha=q\beta+r$, so $r=\alpha-q\beta.$ If $r\ne0$, then $\phi(r)=\phi(\beta)\phi(\alpha/\beta-q)<\phi(\beta)$. We conclude that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.4.6
question: Let $\epsilon=1+\sqrt{2}.$ Write $\epsilon^{n}=u_{n}+v_{n}\sqrt{2}.$ Show that $u_{n}^{2}-2v_{n}^{2}=\pm1$.
solution:
Since $\phi$ is multiplicative and we have $\phi(\epsilon)=|-1|$ then
$$\phi(\epsilon^{n})=|(-1)^{n}|=|u_{n}^{2}-2v_{n}^{2}|=1.$$
This gives infinitely many solutions to $x^{2}-2y^{2}=\pm1$. It is easy to see that all of these solutions are distinct: $\epsilon\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ and $\epsilon>1$ so $\epsilon^{n+1}>\epsilon^{n}$ for all positive $n$.

label: Exercise 2.4.7
question: Show that there is no unit $\eta$ in $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ such that $1<\eta<1+\sqrt{2}$. Deduce that every unit (greater than zero) of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ is a power of $\epsilon=1+\sqrt{2}$.
solution: Since 1 is a unit, for any unit $\xi$, $-\xi$ is also a unit, and negative and positive units are in one-to-one correspondence; we shall only consider the positive units of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$. We write $\eta$ as $a+b\sqrt{2}.$ Since $\eta$ is a unit, $\phi(\eta)=(a+b\sqrt{2})(a-b\sqrt{2})=\pm1$. By assumption $(a+b\sqrt{2})>1$ and $|(a+b\sqrt{2})(a-b\sqrt{2})|=1$, so it follows that $-1<(a-b\sqrt{2})<1$. Also, by assumption, $1<a+b\sqrt{2}<1+\sqrt{2}.$ So, adding these two inequalities gives $0<2a<2+\sqrt{2}.$ Since $a\in\mathbb{Z}$ this implies that $a=1$. Notice now that there is no integer $b$ such that $1<1+b\sqrt{2}<1+\sqrt{2}.$ If any unit, $\psi$, did exist which was not some power of $\epsilon$, then by our Euclidean algorithm we would be able to divide by $(1+\sqrt{2})^{k}$, where $k$ is chosen so that $(1+\sqrt{2})^{k}<\psi<(1+\sqrt{2})^{k+1}$ and this would produce a new unit $\psi^{\prime}$ where $1<\psi^{\prime}<1+\sqrt{2}$. So the only positive units of $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$ are those of the form $(1+\sqrt{2})^{n}$; there are infinitely many.

label: Exercise 2.5.1
question: Show that $R=\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-7})/2]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
Given $\alpha,\beta\in R$, we want to find $\gamma, \delta\in R$ such that $\alpha=\beta\gamma+\delta,$ with $N(\delta)<N(\beta)$. This is equivalent to showing that we can find a $\gamma$ with $N(\alpha/\beta-\gamma)<1$. Now, $\alpha/\beta=x+y\sqrt{-7}$ with $x,y\in\mathbb{Q}$. Let $\gamma=(u+v\sqrt{-7})/2$ with $u,v\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $u\equiv v$ (mod 2). We want
$$N(x+y\sqrt{-7}-(\frac{u+v\sqrt{-7}}{2}))=(x-\frac{u}{2})^{2}+7(y-\frac{v}{2})^{2}<1$$
or, equivalently, $(2x-u)^{2}+7(2y-v)^{2}<4$. First consider $2y$. Choose for $v$ either $[2y]$ or $[2y]+1$, so that $2y-v\le1/2$. Now choose for $u$ either $[2x]$ or $[2x]+1$, whichever has the same parity as $v$. Then $2x-u\le1$. Then
$$(2x-u)^{2}+7(2y-v)^{2}\le1+\frac{7}{4}=\frac{11}{4}<4.$$
We have found a $\gamma$ which works, and proved that $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-7})/2]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.5.2
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-11})/2]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
Proceed as in Exercise 2.5.1. Given $\alpha, \beta$, we wish to find $\gamma$ such that $N(\alpha/\beta-\gamma)<1$. Let $\alpha/\beta=x+y\sqrt{-11},x,y\in\mathbb{Q},$ and $\gamma=(u+v\sqrt{-11})/2$ with $u, v\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $u\equiv v$ (mod 2). We want
$$N(x+y\sqrt{-11}-(\frac{u+v\sqrt{-11}}{2}))<1$$
or $(2x-u)^{2}+11(2y-v)^{2}<4$. As in the previous exercise, choose $v$ first to be the integer which is closest to $2y$, and then choose $u$ to be the integer closest to $2x$ which also has the same parity as $v$. Then $(2x-u)\le1$ and $(2y-v)\le1/2$ so
$$(2x-u)^{2}+11(2y-v)^{2}\le1+\frac{11}{4}=\frac{15}{4}<4.$$
Therefore $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-11})/2]$ is Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.5.3
question: Find all integer solutions to the equation $x^{2}+11=y^{3}$.
solution:
In the ring $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-11})/2].$ we can factor the equation as
$$(x-\sqrt{-11})(x+\sqrt{-11})=y^{3}.$$
Now, suppose that $\delta|(x-\sqrt{-11})$ and $\delta|(x+\sqrt{-11})$ (which implies that $\delta|y)$. Then $\delta|2x$ and $\delta|2\sqrt{-11}$ which means that $\delta|2$ because otherwise, $\delta|\sqrt{-11}$ meaning that $11$ and $11|y$, which we can see is not true by considering congruences mod $11^{2}$. Then $\delta=1$ or 2, since 2 has no factorization in this ring. We will consider these cases separately.
Case 1. $\delta=1$. Then the two factors of $y^{3}$ are coprime and we can write $(x+\sqrt{-11})=\epsilon(\frac{a+b\sqrt{-11}}{2})^{3};$ where $a, b\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $a\equiv b$ (mod 2). Since the units of $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-11})/2]$ are $\pm1$, which are cubes, then we can bring the unit inside the brackets and rewrite the above without $\epsilon$. We have
$$8(x+\sqrt{-11})=(a+b\sqrt{-11})^{3}=a^{3}+3ab^{2}\sqrt{-11}-33ab^{2}-11b^{3}\sqrt{-11}$$
and so, comparing real and imaginary parts, we get
$$8x=a^{3}-33ab^{2}=a(a^{2}-33b^{2}), \quad 8=3a^{2}b-11b^{3}=b(3a^{2}-11b^{2}).$$
This implies that $b|8$ and so we have 8 possibilities: $b=\pm1,\pm2,\pm4,\pm8.$ Substituting these back into the equations to find $a, x$, and $y$, and remembering that $a\equiv b$ (mod 2) and that $a, x, y\in\mathbb{Z}$ will give all solutions to the equation.
Case 2. $\delta=2$. If $\delta=2.$ then $y$ is even and $x$ is odd. We can write $y=2y_{1},$ which gives the equation
$$(\frac{x+\sqrt{-11}}{2})(\frac{x-\sqrt{-11}}{2})=2y_{1}^{3}.$$
Since 2 divides the right-hand side of this equation, it must divide the left-hand side, so $2|(\frac{x+\sqrt{-11}}{2})$ or $2|(\frac{x-\sqrt{-11}}{2})$. However, since $x$ is odd, 2 divides neither of the factors above. We conclude that $\delta\ne2$, and thus we found all the solutions to the equation in our discussion of Case 1.

label: Exercise 2.5.4
question: Prove that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{3}]$ is Euclidean.
solution: Given $\alpha,\beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{3}]$ we want to find $\gamma,\delta\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{3}]$ such that $\alpha=\beta\gamma+\delta$, with $N(\delta)<N(\beta)$. Put another way, we want to show that $N(\alpha/\beta-\gamma)<1$. Let $\alpha/\beta=x+y\sqrt{3},x,y\in\mathbb{Q}$. Let $\gamma=u+v\sqrt{3}$ with $u,v\in\mathbb{Z}.$ Now, $N(\alpha/\beta-\gamma)=|(x-u)^{2}-3(y-v)^{2}|$. This will be maximized when $(x-u)$ is small and $(y-v)$ is large. Choose for $u$ and $v$ the closest integers to $x$ and $y$, respectively. Then the minimum value for $(x-u)$ is 0, while the maximum value for $(y-v)$ is $1/2$. Then $N(\alpha/\beta-\gamma)\le|-3/4|<1$. The conclusion follows.

label: Exercise 2.5.5
question: Prove that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{6}]$ is Euclidean.
solution:
Assume that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{6}]$ is not Euclidean. This means that there is at least one $x+y\sqrt{6}\in\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{6})$ such that there is no $\gamma=u+v\sqrt{6}\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{6}]$ such that $|(x-u)^{2}-6(y-v)^{2}|<1$. Without loss, we can suppose that $0\le x\le1/2$, and $0\le y\le1/2$. We assert that there exist such a pair $(x, y)$ such that $(x-u)^{2}\ge1+6(y-v)^{2}$ or $6(y-v)^{2}\ge1+(x-u)^{2}$ for every $u, v\in\mathbb{Z}.$ In particular, we will use the following inequalities:
(2.1) either (a) $x^{2}\ge1+6y^{2}$ or (b) $6y^{2}\ge1+x^{2}$,
(2.2) either (a) $(1-x)^{2}\ge1+6y^{2}$ or (b) $6y^{2}\ge1+(1-x)^{2}$,
(2.3) either (a) $(1+x)^{2}\ge1+6y^{2}$ or (b) $6y^{2}\ge1+(1+x)^{2}$.
If $x=y=0$, then both first inequalities fail, so we can rule out this case. Next, we look at the first two inequalities on the left. Since $x^{2}$, $(1-x)^{2}\le1$ and $1+6y^{2}\ge1$ and $x, y$ are not both 0, these two inequalities fail so (2.1 (b)) and (2.2 (b)) must be true. Now consider (2.3 (a)). If $(1+x)^{2}\ge1+6y^{2}$ and $6y^{2}\ge1+(1-x)^{2}$ as we just showed, then $(1+x)^{2}\ge1+6y^{2}\ge2+(1-x)^{2}$ which implies that $4x\ge2$ and since $x\le1/2,$ we conclude that $x=1/2.$ Substituting this into the previous inequalities, we get that $\frac{9}{4}\ge1+6y^{2}\ge\frac{9}{4}$ so $6y^{2}=\frac{5}{4}$. Let $y=r/s$ with $gcd(r,s)=1$. We now have that $24r^{2}=5s^{2}$. If $r|s$ then $r^{2}|5$, so $r=1$. But then $24=5s^{2}$ a contradiction. Therefore, (2.3 (b)) is true, which implies that $6y^{2}\ge1+(1+x)^{2}\ge2.$ However, since $y\le1/2$, $6y^{2}\ge2$ implies that $6\ge8$, a contradiction. Then neither (2.3 (a)) nor (2.3 (b)) are true, so $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{6}]$ must be Euclidean.

label: Exercise 2.5.6
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-19})/2]$ is not Euclidean for the norm map.
solution:
If a ring $R$ is Euclidean, then given any $\alpha,\beta\in R$ we can find $\gamma, \delta$ such that $\alpha=\beta\gamma+\delta$ with $\delta=0$ or $N(\delta)<N(\beta)$. Another way of describing this condition is to say that given any $\beta\in R$ we can find a representative for each nonzero residue class of $R/(\beta)$ such that the representative has norm less than the norm of $\beta$. We will try to find an element of $R=\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-19})/2]$ for which this is not true.
Consider $\beta=2$. $N(2)=4$. We want to find all other elements of $R$ with norm strictly less than 4.
$$N(\frac{a+b\sqrt{-19}}{2})=\frac{a^{2}+19b^{2}}{4}<4, \Rightarrow a^{2}+19b^{2}<16.$$
First note that if $b>0,$ there are no solutions to this inequality. For $b=0$, we can have $a=0, \pm2$, since $a\equiv b$ (mod 2). Thus, there are just three elements with norm less than 4. However, there are more than three residue classes of $R/(2)$ (check this!). Therefore, the ring $R=\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-19})/2]$ is non-Euclidean with respect to the norm map.

label: Exercise 2.5.7
question: Prove that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-10}]$ is not a unique factorization domain.
solution:
Consider the elements $2+\sqrt{-10},2-\sqrt{-10},2,7.$ Show that they are all irreducible and are not associates. Then note that
$$(2+\sqrt{-10})(2-\sqrt{-10})=14$$
$$2\cdot7=14$$

label: Exercise 2.5.8
question: Show that there are only finitely many rings $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{d}]$ with $d\equiv2$ or 3 (mod 4) which are norm Euclidean.
solution:
If $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{d}]$ is Euclidean for the norm map, then for any $\delta\in\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$, we can find $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{d}]$ such that $|N(\delta-\alpha)|<1$. Write $\delta=r+s\sqrt{d},$ $\alpha=a+b\sqrt{d},$ $a,b\in\mathbb{Z}$, $r,s\in\mathbb{Q}$. Then $|(r-a)^{2}-d(s-b)^{2}|<1.$ In particular, take $r=0$, $s=t/d$ where $t$ is an integer to be chosen later. Then $|a^{2}-d(b-\frac{t}{d})^{2}|<1$ so that $|(bd-t)^{2}-da^{2}|<d.$ Since $(bd-t)^{2}-da^{2}\equiv t^{2}$ (mod $d$), there are integers $x$ and $z$ such that $z^{2}-dx^{2}\equiv t^{2}$ (mod $d$), with $|z^{2}-dx^{2}|<d.$
In case $d\equiv3$ (mod 4), we choose an odd integer $t$ such that $5d<t^{2}<6d$, which we can do if $d$ is sufficiently large. Then $z^{2}-dx^{2}=t^{2}-5d$ or $t^{2}-6d$. Then one of the equations $z^{2}-t^{2}=d(x^{2}-5)$ or $z^{2}-t^{2}=d(x^{2}-6)$ is true. We consider this modulo 8. Then $t^{2}\equiv1$ (mod 8) since $t$ is odd. Also, $x^{2}, z^{2}\equiv0,1$ or 4 (mod 8) and $d\equiv3$ or 7 (mod 8). We are easily led to $t^{2}-z^{2}\equiv0,1,$ or 5 (mod 8). This means $d(x^{2}-5)\equiv5,4,$ or 1 (mod 8) or $d(x^{2}-6)\equiv6,5,2$, or 1 (mod 8). All of these congruences are impossible.
