In case $d\equiv2$ (mod 4), we choose $t$ odd satisfying $2d<t^{2}<3d$ and proceed as above. (The case $d\equiv1$ (mod 4) is more difficult and has been handled by Heilbronn who was the first to show that there are only finitely many real quadratic fields which are norm-Euclidean.) A more general and analogous result for imaginary quadratic fields will be proved in Exercise 4.5.21 in Chapter 4.

label: Exercise 2.5.9
question: Find all integer solutions of $y^{2}=x^{3}+1$.
solution:
We will determine all integer solutions of $y^{2}-1=x^{3}$. From $(y-1)(y+1)=x^{3}$, we see that if $(y-1,y+1)=1$, then $y-1=u^{3}$, $y+1=v^{3}$ (say). Thus, $2=v^{3}-u^{3}=(v-u)(v^{2}+vu+u^{2})$ from which we deduce that $v-u=\pm1, v^{2}+vu+u^{2}=\pm2$ or $v-u=\pm2, v^{2}+vu+u^{2}=\pm1$. This gives rise to four cases. The only case that leads to a solution is $v-u=2$ and $v^{2}+vu+u^{2}=1.$ This yields the solution $(x,y)=(-1,0)$.
Now suppose $(y-1,y+1)=2.$ This gives rise to two cases $y-1=2u^{3}, y+1=4v^{3}$ and $y-1=4u^{3}, y+1=2v^{3}$. In the first case, we are led to $u^{3}+1=2v^{3}$ and in the second case, we get $2u^{3}+1=v^{3}$. As 1 is a cube, both equations are covered if we can determine all integer solutions of $x^{3}+y^{3}=2z^{3}$. We will use a "descent" argument to determine all coprime solutions. To this end, we consider the ring of Eisenstein integers $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ where $\rho^{2}+\rho+1=0$. It is well-known that this is a Euclidean domain for the norm map given by $N(a+b\rho)=a^{2}+ab+b^{2}$. Its unit group is $\{\pm1,\pm\rho,\pm\rho^{2}\}$. It is also easily checked that 1, $\rho$, $\rho^{2}$ represent all the distinct coprime residue classes modulo $2\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. We see that the cube of every coprime residue class is 1 (modulo 2). If $u$ is a unit $\equiv 1$ (mod 2), then $u=\pm1$. Now we claim that any coprime solution $(x,y,z)$ of $x^{3}+y^{3}=2uz^{3}$ in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ satisfies $N(xyz)=1$. Suppose not. Let $(x, y, z)$ be such that $N(xyz)$ is minimal and $\ge2$. We may let $A=x+y$, $B=\rho x+\rho^{2}y$, $C=\rho^{2}x+\rho y$ so that $ABC=2uz^{3}$, $A+B+C=0$. Let $d=(A,B,C)$ so that the above equation becomes $\frac{A}{d}\frac{B}{d}\frac{C}{d}=2u(\frac{z}{d})^{3}$. Now 2 is an irreducible element in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ and $A/d, B/d, C/d$ are mutually coprime (as their sum is zero) so it can divide only one of them, say $C/d$ without any loss of generality. Thus, we may write $A/d=u_{1}\alpha^{3}$, $B/d=u_{2}\beta^{3}$, $C/d=-2u_{3}\gamma^{3}$, with $u_{1}$, $u_{2}$, $u_{3}$ units. Also, $\alpha\beta\gamma\ne0$ for otherwise, $z=0$ and $x=\pm y$, which are not coprime solutions. Hence, $u_{1}\alpha^{3}+u_{2}\beta^{3}=2u_{3}\gamma^{3}$ and dividing by the unit $u_{1}$ gives the equation $\alpha^{3}+u^{\prime}\beta^{3}=2u_{4}\gamma^{3}$ for some units $u^{\prime}$ and $u_{4}$. Observe that $(\beta,2)=1$ for otherwise, $2|\alpha$ and $2|\gamma$ which implies that $\alpha, \beta, \gamma$ are not coprime, a contradiction. Reducing the above equation mod 2 shows that $u^{\prime}$ is a cube mod 2, and by our remark above $u^{\prime}$ must be $\pm1$. Thus $u^{\prime}$ is a cube and we have $\alpha^{3}+\beta^{3}=2u\gamma^{3}$. Notice that by our choice of $(x,y,z)$, $N(xyz)^{3}\le N(\alpha\beta\gamma)^{3}=N(ABC/d^{3})=N(z)^{3}/N(d)^{3}$ which means that $N(xyd)^{3}\le1$. Thus, $x, y, d$ are units. Hence, $x^{3}=\pm1$ and $y^{3}=\pm1$ and $z$ is also a unit. Thus, $N(xyz)=1$ contrary to our choice. This proves our claim. Therefore, the only solution for $u^{3}+1=2v^{3}$ is $u^{3}=\pm1$. This leads to the solutions $(x,y)=(2,3),(1,0)$ for the equation $y^{2}-1=x^{3}$. In the other case of $2u^{3}+1=v^{3}$, we have $v=\pm1$ which leads to (0,1), (2, -3). We get a final set of five integer solutions for $y^{2}-1=x^{3}$.

label: Exercise 2.5.10
question: Let $x_{1},...,x_{n}$ be indeterminates. Evaluate the determinant of the $n\times n$ matrix whose $(i, j)$-th entry is $x_{i}^{j-1}$. (This is called the Vandermonde determinant.)
solution: Let $V(x_{1},...,x_{n})$ denote the value of the determinant. If we fix $x_{2},...,x_{n}$ we may view the determinant as a polynomial in $x_{1}$ of degree $n-1$. Since the determinant is zero if $x_{1}=x_{i}$ for $i\ge2$, the roots of the polynomial are $x_{2},...,x_{n}$. It is easy to see that the leading coefficient is $(-1)^{n-1}V(x_{2},...,x_{n})$ so that the determinant is $(-1)^{n-1}V(x_{2},...,x_{n})\prod_{j=2}^{n}(x_{1}-x_{j}).$ By induction, we see that $V(x_{1},...,x_{n})=(-1)^{\binom{n}{2}}\prod_{j>i}(x_{i}-x_{j}).$

label: Example 3.1.1
question: Show that $\sqrt{2}/3$ is an algebraic number but not an algebraic integer.
solution:
Consider the polynomial $f(x)=9x^{2}-2$, which is in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$. Since $f(\sqrt{2}/3)=0$, we know that $\sqrt{2}/3$ is an algebraic number.
Assume $\sqrt{2}/3$ is an algebraic integer. Then there exists a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$, say $g(x)=x^{n}+b_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}$ which has $\alpha=\sqrt{2}/3$ as a root. So
$$g(\alpha)=(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3})^{n}+b_{n-1}(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{3})^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}=0,$$
$$\Rightarrow (\sqrt{2})^{n}+b_{n-1}(\sqrt{2})^{n-1}(3)+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}(3)^{n}=0.$$
If $i$ is odd, $(\sqrt{2})^{i}$ is not an integer. So we can separate our equation into two smaller equations:
$$\sum_{i~odd}b_{i}\sqrt{2}^{i}3^{n-i}=0\Rightarrow\sqrt{2}\sum_{i~odd}b_{i}2^{(i-1)/2}3^{n-i}=0$$
and
$$\sum_{i~even}b_{i}\sqrt{2}^{i}3^{n-i}=0$$
for $i=0,...,n.$ Since $3|0$ each sum above must be divisible by 3. In particular, because each summand containing $b_{i},i\ne n$ has a factor of 3, 3 divides the summand containing $b_{n}=1$. This tells us that $3|2^{(n-1)/2}$ if $n$ is odd, and $2^{n/2}$ if $n$ is even. In either case, this is false and hence we can conclude that $\sqrt{2}/3$ is not an algebraic integer.

label: Theorem 3.1.4
question: Let $\alpha$ be an algebraic number. Show that there exists a unique polynomial $p(x)$ in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ which is monic, irreducible and of smallest degree, such that $p(\alpha)=0$. Furthermore, show that if $f(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$ and $f(\alpha)=0$, then $p(x)|f(x)$.
solution:
Consider the set of all polynomials in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ for which $\alpha$ is a root and pick one of smallest degree, say $p(x)$. If $p(x)$ is not irreducible, it can be written as a product of two lower degree polynomials in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$: $p(x)=a(x)b(x)$. However, $p(\alpha)=a(\alpha)b(\alpha)=0$ and since $\mathbb{C}$ is an integral domain, either $a(\alpha)=0$ or $b(\alpha)=0$. But this contradicts the minimality of $p(x)$, so $p(x)$ must be irreducible.
Suppose there were two such polynomials, $p(x)$ and $q(x)$. By the division algorithm,
$$p(x)=a(x)q(x)+r(x),$$
where $a(x)$, $r(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$, and either $deg(r)=0$ or $deg(r)<deg(q)$. But $p(\alpha)=a(\alpha)q(\alpha)+r(\alpha)=0$ and $q(\alpha)=0$ together imply that $r(\alpha)=0$. Because $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ are the smallest degree polynomials with $\alpha$ as a root, $r=0$. So $p(x)=a(x)q(x)$ and $a(x)\in\mathbb{Q}^{*}$ (the set of all nonzero elements of $\mathbb{Q}$), since $deg(p)=deg(q)$. Thus $p(x)$ is unique up to a constant and so we may suppose its leading coefficient is 1.
Now suppose $f(x)$ is a polynomial in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ such that $f(\alpha)=0$. If $p(x)$ does not divide $f(x)$ then, since $p(x)$ is irreducible, $gcd(p(x), f(x)) = 1$. So we can find $a(x), b(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$ such that $a(x)p(x)+b(x)f(x)=1$. However, putting $x=\alpha$ yields a contradiction. Thus, $p(x)|f(x)$.

label: Example 3.1.5
question: Show that the set of algebraic numbers is countable (and hence the set of transcendental numbers is uncountable).
solution: All polynomials in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ have a finite number of roots. The set of rational numbers, $\mathbb{Q}$, is countable and so the set $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ is also countable. The set of algebraic numbers is the set of all roots of a countable number of polynomials, each with a finite number of roots. Hence the set of algebraic numbers is countable. Since algebraic numbers and transcendental numbers partition the set of complex numbers, $\mathbb{C}$, which is uncountable, it follows that the set of transcendental numbers is uncountable.

label: Theorem 3.2.1 (Liouville)
question: Given $\alpha$, a real algebraic number of degree $n\ne1$, show that there is a positive constant $c=c(\alpha)$ such that for all rational numbers $p/q$, $(p,q)=1$ and $q>0$, the inequality $|\alpha-\frac{p}{q}|>\frac{c(\alpha)}{q^{n}}$ holds.
solution:
Let $f(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ whose degree equals that of $\alpha$ and for which $\alpha$ is a root. ($So~deg(f)\ge2$). Notice that
$$|f(\alpha)-f(\frac{p}{q})|=|f(\frac{p}{q})|$$
$$=|a_{n}(\frac{p}{q})^{n}+a_{n-1}(\frac{p}{q})^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}|$$
$$=|\frac{a_{n}p^{n}+a_{n-1}p^{n-1}q+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}q^{n}}{q^{n}}| \ge\frac{1}{q^{n}}.$$
If $\alpha=\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}$ are the roots of $f$, let $M$ be the maximum of the values $|\alpha_{i}|$, $1\le i\le n$. If $|p/q|$ is greater than $2M$, then
$$|\alpha-\frac{p}{q}|\ge M\ge\frac{M}{q^{n}}.$$
If $|p/q|\le M$ then $|\alpha_{i}-\frac{p}{q}|\le3M$ so that
$$|\alpha-\frac{p}{q}|\ge\frac{1}{|a_{n}|q^{n}\prod_{j=2}^{n}|\alpha_{j}-p/q|}\ge\frac{1}{|a_{n}|(3M)^{n-1}q^{n}}.$$
Hence, the theorem holds with $c(\alpha)=min(M,\frac{1}{|a_{n}|(3M)^{n-1}})$.

label: Example 3.2.2
question: Show that $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{10^{n!}}$ is transcendental.
solution:
Suppose not, and call the sum $\alpha$. Look at the partial sum $\sum_{n=0}^{k}\frac{1}{10^{n!}}=\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}},$ with $q_{k}=10^{k!}$. Thus,
$$|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|=|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{10^{n!}}|$$
$$=\frac{1}{10^{(k+1)!}}+(\frac{1}{10^{(k+1)!}})^{k+2}+(\frac{1}{10^{(k+1)!}})^{(k+2)(k+3)}+\cdot\cdot\cdot$$
$$\le\frac{1}{10^{(k+1)!}}[1+\frac{1}{10^{2}}+\frac{1}{10^{3}}+\cdot\cdot\cdot] =(\frac{1}{10^{(k+1)!}})S,$$
where $S=1+1/10^{2}+1/10^{3}+\cdot\cdot\cdot,$ an infinite geometric series which has a finite sum. So
$$|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{10^{n!}}|\le\frac{S}{10^{(k+1)!}}=\frac{S}{q_{k}^{k+1}}.$$
If $\alpha$ were algebraic of degree of $n$ then, by Liouville's theorem, there exists a constant $c(\alpha)$ such that $|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{n}},$ so we have $\frac{S}{q_{k}^{k+1}}\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{n}}.$ However, we can choose $k$ to be as large as we want to obtain a contradiction. So $\alpha$ is transcendental.

label: Example 3.2.3
question: Let $f(x,y)$ be an irreducible polynomial of binary form of degree $n\ge3$. Assuming Thue's theorem, show that $f(x,y)=m$ for any fixed $m\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}$ has only finitely many solutions.
solution:
Suppose $f(x,y)=m$ has infinitely many solutions, and write it in the form
$$f(x,y)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}(x-\alpha_{i}y)=m,$$
where $\alpha_{i}$ is an algebraic number of degree $\ge3$ $\forall i=1,...,n.$ Without loss of generality, we can suppose that for an infinite number of pairs $(x, y)$, we have
$$|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{1}|\le|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{i}| \text{ for } i=2,...,n.$$
Further, by the triangle inequality,
$$|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{i}|\ge\frac{1}{2}(|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{i}|+|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{1}|) \ge\frac{1}{2}|\alpha_{i}-\alpha_{1}| \text{ for } i=2,...,n$$
Hence,
$$|f(x,y)|=|y^{n}||\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{1}|\cdot\cdot\cdot|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{n}|$$
$$|m|\ge k|y|^{n}|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{1}|$$
where $k=\frac{1}{2^{n-1}}\prod_{i=2}^{n}|\alpha_{i}-\alpha_{1}|.$ So $\frac{|m|}{k|y|^{n}}\ge|\frac{x}{y}-\alpha_{1}|$.
However, by Thue's theorem, this implies
$$\frac{c}{y^{n/2+1}}\le\frac{m}{ky^{n}}\Leftrightarrow\frac{1}{y^{n/2+1}}\le\frac{m(ck)^{-1}}{y^{n}}$$
However, for $n\ge3$ this holds for only finitely many $(x, y)$, contradicting our assumption. Thus $f(x,y)$ has only finitely many solutions.

label: Example 3.3.1
question: Let $\alpha$ be an algebraic number and define $\mathbb{Q}[\alpha]=\{f(\alpha):f\in\mathbb{Q}[x]\}$ a subring of $\mathbb{C}$. Show that $\mathbb{Q}[\alpha]$ is a field.
solution:
Let $f$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$, and consider the map $\phi:\mathbb{Q}[x]\rightarrow\mathbb{Q}[\alpha]$ such that $\sum_{i=0}^{n}a_{i}x^{i}\rightarrow\sum_{i=0}^{n}a_{i}\alpha^{i}.$ Notice that
$$\phi(g)+\phi(h)=\sum_{i=0}^{n}a_{i}\alpha^{i}+\sum_{i=0}^{m}b_{i}\alpha^{i}=\phi(g+h)$$
and
$$\phi(g)\phi(h)=(\sum_{i=0}^{n}a_{i}\alpha^{i})(\sum_{j=0}^{m}b_{j}\alpha^{j})=\sum_{0\le i+j\le n+m}a_{i}b_{j}\alpha^{i+j}=\phi(gh).$$
So $\phi$ is a homomorphism. Furthermore, it is clear that ker $\phi=(f)$, the ideal generated by $f$ (see Theorem 3.1.4). Thus, by the ring homomorphism theorems, $\mathbb{Q}[x]/(f)\simeq\mathbb{Q}[\alpha]$.
Let $g$ be a polynomial in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ such that $f$ does not divide $g$. From Chapter 2, we know that $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ is a Euclidean domain and is therefore also a PID. We also learned in Chapter 2 that the ideal generated by any irreducible element in a PID is a maximal ideal. Since $f$ is irreducible, $\mathbb{Q}[x]/(f)$ is a field and so $\mathbb{Q}[\alpha]$ is a field, as desired.

label: Theorem 3.3.2 (Theorem of the Primitive Element)
question: Show that if $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are algebraic numbers, then $\exists\theta$, an algebraic number, such that $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha,\beta)=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$.
solution:
Let $f$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ and let $g$ be the minimal polynomial of $\beta$. We want to show that we can find $\lambda\in\mathbb{Q}$ such that $\theta=\alpha+\lambda\beta$ and $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha,\beta)=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$. We will denote $\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ by $L$. Clearly $L=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)\subseteq\mathbb{Q}(\alpha,\beta)$.
Define $\phi(x)=f(\theta-\lambda x)\in L[x]$. Notice that $\phi(\beta)=f(\theta-\lambda\beta)=f(\alpha)=0$. So $\beta$ is a root of $\phi$. Choose $\lambda\in\mathbb{Q}$ in such a way that $\beta$ is the only common root of $\phi$ and $g$. This can be done since only a finite number of choices of $\lambda$ are thus ruled out. So $gcd(\phi(x),g(x))=c(x-\beta)$, $c\in\mathbb{C}^{*}$. Then $c(x-\beta)\in L[x]$ which implies that $c, c\beta\in L$, and so $\beta\in L$.
Now, $\theta=\alpha+\lambda\beta\in L$ which means that $\alpha\in L$. So $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha,\beta)\subseteq L=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$. Thus, we have the desired equality: $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha,\beta)=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$.

label: Theorem 3.3.9
question:
Prove that the following statements are equivalent:
(a) $\alpha$ is an algebraic integer.
(b) The minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ is monic $\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$.
(c) $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ is a finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-module.
(d) There exists a finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-submodule $M\ne\{0\}$ of $\mathbb{C}$ such that $\alpha M\subseteq M.$
solution:
$(a)\Rightarrow(b)$ Let $f(x)$ be a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ such that $f(\alpha)=0$. Let $\phi(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. Recall the definition of primitive polynomials given in Chapter 2: a polynomial $f(x)=a_{n}x^{n}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is said to be primitive if the gcd of the coefficients of $f$ is 1. In particular, a monic polynomial is primitive. By Theorem 3.1.4, we know $f(x)=\phi(x)\psi(x)$, for some $\psi(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$. By the proof of Theorem 2.1.10, we know we can write $\phi(x)=\frac{a}{b}\phi_{1}(x)$, $\phi_{1}(x)$ primitive, $a, b\in\mathbb{Z}$, and $\psi(x)=\frac{c}{d}\psi_{1}(x)$, $\psi_{1}(x)$ primitive, $c, d\in\mathbb{Z}$. So $bdf(x)=ac\phi_{1}(x)\psi_{1}(x)$. But by Gauss' lemma (see Theorem 2.1.9), $\phi_{1}(x)\psi_{1}(x)$ is primitive, and $f(x)$ is primitive, so $bd=\pm ac$ and $f(x)=\pm\phi_{1}(x)\psi_{1}(x)$. Thus the leading term of both $\phi_{1}(x)$ and $\psi_{1}(x)$ is $\pm1$. Further, $\phi(\alpha)=0\Rightarrow\phi_{1}(\alpha)=0$. So in fact $\phi(x)=\pm\phi_{1}(x)$ which is monic in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$.
$(b)\Rightarrow(c)$ Let $\phi(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. Recall $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]=\{f(\alpha):f(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]\}$. In order to prove (c), it is enough to find a finite basis for $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$. Claim: $\{1,\alpha,...,\alpha^{n-1}\}$ generates $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ (as a $\mathbb{Z}$-module). Proof: It suffices to show that $\alpha^{N}$ for any $N\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}$, is a linear combination of $\{1,\alpha,...,\alpha^{n-1}\}$ with coefficients in $\mathbb{Z}$. We proceed inductively. Clearly this holds for $N\le n-1$. For $N\ge n$, suppose this holds $\forall\alpha^{j}$, $j<N$. $\alpha^{N}=\alpha^{N-n}\alpha^{n}=\alpha^{N-n}[-(a_{0}+a_{1}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1})] =(-\alpha^{N-n}a_{0})1+(-\alpha^{N-n}a_{1})\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+(-\alpha^{N-n}a_{n-1})\alpha^{n-1}$. By our inductive hypothesis, $-\alpha^{N-n}a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]\forall i=0,1,...,n-1.$ Then $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ is a $\mathbb{Z}$-module generated by $\{1,\alpha,...,\alpha^{n-1}\}$.
$(c)\Rightarrow(d)$ Let $M=\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$. Clearly $\alpha\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]\subseteq\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$.
$(d)\Rightarrow(a)$ Let $x_1,...,x_r$ generate $M$ over $\mathbb{Z}$. So $M\subseteq\mathbb{Z}x_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}x_{r}$. By assumption $\alpha x_{i}\in M\forall i=1,...,r.$ It follows that there exists a set of $c_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $\alpha x_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}c_{ij}x_{j}\forall i=1,...,r$. Let $C=(c_{ij})$. Then $(C-\alpha I)(\begin{matrix}x_{1}\\ \vdots\\ x_{r}\end{matrix})=0.$ Since not all of $x_{1},...,x_{r}$ can vanish, $det(C-\alpha I)=0$. In other words,
$$\begin{bmatrix}c_{11}-x&c_{12}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{1n}\\ c_{21}&c_{22}-x&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{2n}\\ \vdots&&&&\vdots\\ c_{n1}&c_{n2}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{nn}-x\end{bmatrix}=0 \text{ when } x=\alpha$$
This is a polynomial equation in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ of degree $n$ whose leading coefficient is $(-1)^{n}$. Take $f(x)=det(C-xI)$ for $n$ even, and $-det(C-xI)$ for $n$ odd. Then $f(x)$ is a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ such that $f(\alpha)=0$. Thus $\alpha$ is an algebraic integer.

label: Example 3.3.10
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field. Let $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be the set of all algebraic integers in $K$. Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is a ring.
solution: From the above theorem, we know that for $\alpha, \beta$, algebraic integers, $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$, $\mathbb{Z}[\beta]$ are finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-modules. Thus $M=\mathbb{Z}[\alpha,\beta]$ is also a finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-module. Moreover, $(\alpha\pm\beta)M\subseteq M$, and $(\alpha\beta)M\subseteq M.$ So $\alpha\pm\beta$ and $\alpha\beta$ are algebraic integers; i.e., $\alpha\pm\beta$ and $\alpha\beta$ are in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. So $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is a ring.

label: Exercise 3.1.2
question: Show that $r\in\mathbb{Q}$ is an algebraic integer, then $r\in\mathbb{Z}$.
solution:
Let $r=c/d$, $(c,d)=1$ be an algebraic integer. Then $r$ is the root of a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$, say $f(x)=x^{n}+b_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}$. So
$$f(r)=(\frac{c}{d})^{n}+b_{n-1}(\frac{c}{d})^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}=0$$
$$c^{n}+b_{n-1}c^{n-1}d+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{0}d^{n}=0$$
This implies that $d|c^n$, which is true only when $d=\pm1$. So $r=\pm c\in\mathbb{Z}$.

label: Exercise 3.1.3
question: Show that if $4|(d+1)$, then $\frac{-1\pm\sqrt{-d}}{2}$ is an algebraic integer.
solution:
Consider the monic polynomial
$$x^{2}+x+\frac{d+1}{4}\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$$
when $4|d+1$. The roots of this polynomial, which by definition are algebraic integers, are
$$x=\frac{-1\pm\sqrt{1-4\frac{d+1}{4}}}{2}=\frac{-1\pm\sqrt{-d}}{2}.$$

label: Exercise 3.1.6
question: Find the minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{n}$ where $n$ is a squarefree integer.
solution: If $n=1$, the minimal polynomial is $x-1$. If $n\ne1$ then $x^{2}-n$ is irreducible and has $\sqrt{n}$ as a root. Thus, the minimal polynomial is either linear or quadratic. If it is linear, we obtain that $\sqrt{n}$ is rational, a contradiction. Thus, $x^{2}-n$ is the minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{n}$ when $n\ne1$.

label: Exercise 3.1.7
question: Find the minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{2}/3$.
solution: It is $x^{2}-2/9$ since $\sqrt{2}/3$ is a root, and $\sqrt{2}/3$ is not rational.

label: Exercise 3.2.4
question: Show that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}2^{-3^{n}}$ is transcendental.
solution:
Suppose that
$$\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2^{3^{n}}}$$
is algebraic. We proceed as in Example 3.2.2 and consider the partial sum:
$$\sum_{n=1}^{k}\frac{1}{2^{3^{n}}}=\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}},$$
with $q_{k}=2^{3^{k}}$. As before,
$$|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|=|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2^{3^{n}}}|\le\frac{S}{2^{3^{k+1}}}.$$
But since $\alpha$ is algebraic, by Roth's theorem we have the inequality
$$\frac{S}{q_{k}^{3}}\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}.$$
But again we can choose $k$ to be as large as we want, and so for $\epsilon$ sufficiently small, this inequality does not hold. Thus, $\alpha$ is transcendental.

label: Exercise 3.2.5
question:
Show that, in fact, $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}2^{-f(n)}$ is transcendental when
$$lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}>2.$$
solution:
Suppose
$$\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{2^{f(n)}}$$
is algebraic. Following the same argument as above, we get the inequalities
$$\frac{S}{q_{k+1}}\ge|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}},$$
where $q_{k}=2^{f(k)}$. Now, for $k$ sufficiently large,
$$\frac{f(k+1)}{f(k)}>2+\delta\Rightarrow f(k+1)>(2+\delta)f(k).$$
So, for large $k$,
$$\frac{q_{k+1}}{q_{k}}=\frac{2^{f(k+1)}}{2^{f(k)}}>2^{(1+\delta)f(k)}=q_{k}^{(1+\delta)}$$
which implies that $q_{k+1}>q_{k}^{2+\delta}$. By Roth's theorem, we can deduce that
$$\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}\le\frac{S}{q_{k+1}} \Rightarrow \frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}\le\frac{S}{q_{k}^{2+\delta}},$$
$$q_{k}^{\delta}\le\frac{S}{c(\alpha)}q_{k}^{\epsilon}$$
As $q_{k}\rightarrow\infty$ this implies $\delta\le\epsilon$, a contradiction for $\epsilon<\delta/2$ (say).

label: Exercise 3.3.3
question: Let $\alpha$ be an algebraic number and let $p(x)$ be its minimal polynomial. Show that $p(x)$ has no repeated roots.
solution:
Suppose $\alpha$ is a repeated root of $p(x)$. Then we can write
$$p(x)=(x-\alpha)^{2}g(x),$$
for some polynomial $g(x)\in\mathbb{C}[x]$, and
$$p^{\prime}(x)=2(x-\alpha)g(x)+(x-\alpha)^{2}g^{\prime}(x).$$
So $p^{\prime}(\alpha)=0$ and from Theorem 3.1.4, $p(x)|p^{\prime}(x)$. But $deg(p^{\prime})<deg(p)$, and we have a contradiction. If $\beta$ is a repeated root of $p(x)$ then by the following exercise, $\beta$ has the same minimal polynomial and repeating the above argument with $\beta$ leads to a contradiction. Thus $p$ has no repeated roots.

label: Exercise 3.3.4
question: Let $\alpha, \beta$ be algebraic numbers such that $\beta$ is conjugate to $\alpha$. Show that $\beta$ and $\alpha$ have the same minimal polynomial.
solution:
Let $p(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$, and let $q(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\beta$. By the definition of conjugate roots, $\beta$ is a common root of $p(x)$ and $q(x)$.
Using the division algorithm, we can write $p(x)=a(x)q(x)+r(x)$ for some $a(x)$, $r(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$ and either $r=0$ or $deg(r)<deg(q)$. But
$$p(\beta)=a(\beta)q(\beta)+r(\beta)=0$$
and $q(\beta)=0$ so $r(\beta)$ must also be 0. Since $q$ is the minimal polynomial for $\beta$, $r=0$. Thus $p(x)=a(x)q(x)$, but, by Theorem 3.1.4, $p$ is irreducible, and both $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ are monic, so $p(x)=q(x)$.

label: Exercise 3.3.6
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ be of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ be a basis of $K$ as a vector space over $\mathbb{Q}$. Show that the matrix $\Omega=(\omega_{i}^{(j)})$ is invertible.
solution:
$$\Omega=(\begin{matrix}\omega_{1}&\omega_{1}^{(2)}&...&\omega_{1}^{(n)}\\ \omega_{2}&\omega_{2}^{(2)}&...&\omega_{2}^{(n)}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ \omega_{n}&\omega_{n}^{(2)}&...&\omega_{n}^{(n)}\end{matrix}).$$
Since $\theta$ is an algebraic number of degree $n$, $\alpha_{1}=1,\alpha_{2}=\theta,...,\alpha_{n}=\theta^{n-1}$ also forms a basis for $K$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $A=(\alpha_{i}^{(j)})$. Then,
$$det~A=|\begin{matrix}1&1&\cdot\cdot\cdot&1\\ \theta&\theta^{(2)}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&\theta^{(n)}\\ \vdots&&&\vdots\\ \theta^{n-1}&\theta^{(2)n-1}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&\theta^{(n)n-1}\end{matrix}|$$
which is the Vandermonde determinant. So $A$ is invertible. Further,
$$\omega_{i}^{(j)}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}(b_{ik}\alpha_{k})^{(j)}=\sum_{k=1}^{n}b_{ik}\alpha_{k}^{(j)},$$
where $1\le i, j\le n$ and $b_{ik}\in\mathbb{Q}$. Since the set $\{\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}\}$, as well as the set $\{\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}\}$, are linearly independent sets, it follows that both the rows and columns of the matrix $B=(b_{ik})$ are linearly independent. Hence $B$ is invertible and $\Omega=BA$ and from elementary linear algebra, det $\Omega=$ det $B$ det $A\ne0$. Thus $\Omega$ is invertible.

label: Exercise 3.3.7
question: Let $\alpha$ be an algebraic number. Show that there exists $m\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $m\alpha$ is an algebraic integer.
solution:
Let $p(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. So,
$$p(\alpha)=\alpha^{n}+a_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}\alpha+a_{0}=0.$$
Choose $m\in\mathbb{Z}$ so that $ma_{0},ma_{1},...,ma_{n-1}$ are all integers. Now,
$$m^{n}\alpha^{n}+m^{n}a_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+m^{n}a_{1}\alpha+m^{n}a_{0}=0,$$
$$\Rightarrow(m\alpha)^{n}+ma_{n-1}(m\alpha)^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+m^{n-1}a_{1}(m\alpha)+m^{n}a_{0}=0.$$
Let $g(x)=x^{n}+ma_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+m^{n-1}a_{1}x+m^{n}a_{0}$, then $g(x)$ is a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ and $g(m\alpha)=0$. Thus $m\alpha$ is an algebraic integer.

label: Exercise 3.3.8
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is not (a) Euclidean or (b) a PID.
solution:
(a) Consider the elements 2, $x\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$. Clearly there is no way to write $x=a(x)2+r(x)$ where both the conditions (i) $a(x),r(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$ and (ii) $deg(r)<deg(2)=0$ or $r=0$ are satisfied.
(b) Again consider the two polynomials 2, $x\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$. Clearly $(x)
ot\subseteq(2)$ and $(2)
ot\subseteq(x)$. Now, if $(x,2)=(\alpha)$ for some $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$, then $\alpha|2$ and $\alpha|x.$ But if $\alpha|2$, then $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}$, so $\alpha=\pm1$ or $\alpha=\pm2$. However, $\pm1
otin(x,2)$ and $\pm2
mid x$. So the ideal generated by $x$ and 2 is not generated by a single element in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$. $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is not a PID.

label: Exercise 3.3.11
question: Let $f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}x+a_{0}$, and assume that for $p$ prime $p|a_{i}$ for $0\le i<k$ and $p^{2}\nmid a_{0}$. Show that $f(x)$ has an irreducible factor of degree at least $k$. (The case $k=n$ is referred to as Eisenstein's criterion for irreducibility.)
solution:
We will prove this by induction on $n$, the degree of $f(x)$. The case when $n=1$ is trivial, so let us assume that the above statement is true for any polynomial of degree less than $n$.
If $f(x)$ is irreducible, there is nothing to prove, so assume that $f(x)$ is not irreducible. Then we can write
$$f(x)=g(x)h(x)=(b_{0}+b_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{r}x^{r})(c_{0}+c_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{t}x^{t}).$$
Since $p|a_{0}$ and $p^{2}\nmid a_{0}$, and $a_{0}=b_{0}c_{0}$, we deduce $p|b_{0}$ or $p|c_{0}$ but not both. Suppose, without loss of generality, that $p|b_{0}$. We next consider $a_{1}=b_{0}c_{1}+b_{1}c_{0}.$ Since $p|a_{1}$ and $p|b_{0}$, but $p\nmid c_{0}$ then $p|b_{1}$. Continuing in this fashion, we get that $p|b_{i}$ for $0\le i<k$. If $r<k,$ then we can factor out a $p$ from each of the coefficients in $g(x)$, but this is absurd since then $p$ would divide every coefficient in $f(x)$, and $f$ is monic. Therefore $k\le r$, $p|b_{i},0\le i<k,p^{2}\nmid b_{0}$. Also $b_{r}c_{t}=1$ implies that $g(x)$ or $-g(x)$ is monic. In any event, we have another polynomial which satisfies the conditions set out above but which has degree less than $n$. Thus, by induction, $g(x)$ has an irreducible factor of degree greater than or equal to $k$, and this factor is also an irreducible factor of $f(x)$.

label: Exercise 3.3.12
question: Show that $f(x)=x^{5}+x^{4}+3x^{3}+9x^{2}+3$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$.
solution: By applying Exercise 3.3.11 to $f(x)$ with $p=3$, we deduce that if $f(x)$ is not irreducible, then we can factor it into the product of a polynomial of degree 4 and a polynomial of degree 1, and so $f(x)$ has a rational root. However, we showed in Exercise 3.1.2 that if $r\in\mathbb{Q}$ is an algebraic integer, then $r\in\mathbb{Z}$. Thus, $f(x)$ must have an integral root, and this root must divide the constant term which is 3. The only choices are then $\pm1$, $\pm3$, and it is easy to check that these are not roots of the polynomial in question. We conclude that $f(x)$ is irreducible since it has no rational root.

label: Exercise 3.4.1
question: Show that $\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{n!}}$ is transcendental for $a\in\mathbb{Z}$, $a\ge2.$
solution:
Suppose it is algebraic, and call the sum $\alpha$. Look at the partial sum
$$\alpha_{k}=\sum_{n=0}^{k}\frac{1}{a^{n!}}=\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}},$$
with $q_{k}=a^{k!}$. Then
$$|\alpha-\alpha_{k}|=|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{n!}}|\le\frac{1}{a^{(k+1)!}}M;$$
where $M=1+\frac{1}{a^{k+2}}+(\frac{1}{a^{k+2}})^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot,$ an infinite geometric series with a finite sum. Thus,
$$|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{n!}}|\le\frac{M}{q_{k}^{k+1}}.$$
If $\alpha$ is algebraic of degree $n$, then Liouville's theorem tells us that we can find a constant $c(\alpha)$ such that
$$\frac{M}{q_{k}^{k+1}}\ge|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{n}}.$$
However, we can choose $k$ as large as we wish to obtain a contradiction.

label: Exercise 3.4.2
question: Show that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{3^{n}}}$ is transcendental for $a\in\mathbb{Z}$, $a\ge2$.
solution:
Suppose that
$$\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{3^{n}}}$$
is algebraic. Consider the partial sum
$$\alpha_{k}=\sum_{n=1}^{k}\frac{1}{a^{3^{n}}}=\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}},$$
with $q_{k}=a^{3^{k}}$. We have
$$|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|=|\sum_{n=k+1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{3^{n}}}|\le\frac{S}{a^{3^{k+1}}},$$
where $S=1+1/a+1/a^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot.$ Then by Roth's theorem,
$$\frac{S}{q_{k}^{3}}\ge\frac{c(\alpha,\epsilon)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}$$
But, we can choose $k$ to be as large as we want to produce a contradiction.

label: Exercise 3.4.3
question: Show that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{f(n)}}$ is transcendental when $lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{f(n+1)}{f(n)}>2.$
solution:
Suppose that
$$\alpha=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{a^{f(n)}}$$
is algebraic. Following the same argument as in the previous exercise, we get
$$\frac{S}{q_{k+1}}\ge|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|\ge\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}},$$
where $q_{k}=a^{f(k)}$. For $k$ sufficiently large,
$$\frac{f(k+1)}{f(k)}>2+\delta,$$
and so
$$\frac{q_{k+1}}{q_{k}}=\frac{a^{f(k+1)}}{a^{f(k)}}>a^{(1+\delta)f(k)}=q_{k}^{(1+\delta)}.$$
This implies that $q_{k+1}>q_{k}^{2+\delta}$. By Roth's theorem, we can deduce that
$$\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}\le\frac{S}{q_{k+1}}\Rightarrow\frac{c(\alpha)}{q_{k}^{2+\epsilon}}\le\frac{S}{q_{k}^{2+\delta}} \Rightarrow q_{k}^{\delta}\le\frac{S}{c(\alpha)}q_{k}^{\epsilon}.$$
As $q_{k}\rightarrow\infty$ we find $\delta\le\epsilon$, a contradiction for sufficiently small $\epsilon$.

label: Exercise 3.4.4
question: Prove that $f(x)=x^{6}+7x^{5}-12x^{3}+6x+2$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$.
solution: By Exercise 3.3.11, since $2|a_{i}$ for $0\le i<5$ then $f(x)$ has a factor of degree at least 5. This means that the polynomial is either irreducible or it has a rational root. We showed earlier that if a polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ has a rational root, then the root is actually an integer. We also know that any roots of a polynomial will divide its constant term, which in this case is 2. It suffices to check that $\pm1$, $\pm2,$ are not roots to deduce that $f(x)$ is irreducible.

label: Exercise 3.4.5
question: Using Thue's theorem, show that $f(x,y)=x^{6}+7x^{5}y-12x^{3}y^{3}+6xy^{5}+8y^{6}=m$ has only a finite number of solutions for $m\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}$.
solution: Use the previous exercise to prove that the polynomial is irreducible. The result follows from Thue's theorem and Example 3.2.3.

label: Exercise 3.4.6
question: Let $\zeta_{m}$ be a primitive mth root of unity. Show that $\prod_{0\le i,j\le m-1}(\zeta_{m}^{i}-\zeta_{m}^{j})=(-1)^{m-1}m^{m}.$
solution:
Since
$$x^{m}-1=\prod_{i=0}^{m-1}(x-\zeta_{m}^{i}),$$
we see that the constant term is
$$(-1)^{m}\prod_{i=0}^{m-1}\zeta_{m}^{i}=-1.$$
Differentiating $x^{m}-1$ above via the product rule, and setting $x=\zeta_{m}^{j}$ we see that
$$m\zeta_{m}^{j(m-1)}=\prod_{i\ne j}^{m-1}(\zeta_{m}^{j}-\zeta_{m}^{i}).$$
Taking the product over $j$ gives the result.

label: Exercise 3.4.7
question: Let $\phi_{m}(x)=\prod_{\substack{1\le i\le m\\ (i,m)=1}}(x-\zeta_{m}^{i})$ denote the mth cyclotomic polynomial. Prove that $x^{m}-1=\prod_{d|m}\phi_{d}(x).$
solution: Every mth root of unity is a primitive dth root of unity for some $d|m$. Conversely, every dth root of unity is also an mth root of unity for $d|m$. The result is now immediate.

label: Exercise 3.4.8
question: Show that $\phi_{m}(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$.
solution:
We induct on $m$. Form $m=1$, this is clear. Suppose we have proved it true for $\phi_{r}(x)$ with $r<m$. Then setting
$$v(x)=\prod_{d|m}\phi_{d}(x),$$
we have by induction $v(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$. Since $v(x)$ is monic, and $v(x)|(x^{m}-1),$ we find by long division that $(x^{m}-1)/v(x)=\phi_{m}(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$.

label: Exercise 3.4.9
question: Show that $\phi_{m}(x)$ is irreducible in $\mathbb{Q}[x]$ for every $m\ge1$.
solution:
Let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\zeta_{m}$ and suppose $\phi_{m}(x)=f(x)g(x)$ with $f(x),g(x)\in\mathbb{Q}[x]$. By Gauss' lemma (see Theorem 2.1.9) we may suppose that $f(x),g(x)\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$. Let $p$ be coprime to $m$. Then $\zeta_{m}^{p}$ is again a primitive mth root of unity. Thus
$$f(\zeta_{m}^{p})g(\zeta_{m}^{p})=0$$
Suppose $f(\zeta_{m}^{p})\ne0$. Then $g(\zeta_{m}^{p})=0$. Since $g(x^{p})\equiv g(x)^{p}$ (mod $p$) we deduce that $g(x)$ and $f(x)$ have a common root in $\mathbb{F}_{p}$, a contradiction since $x^{m}-1$ has no multiple roots in $\overline{\mathbb{F}_{p}}$. Thus, $f(\zeta_{m}^{p})=0$ for any $(p,m)=1$. It follows that $f(\zeta_{m}^{i})=0$ for any $(i,m)=1$. Therefore $deg(f)=\varphi(m)=deg(\phi_{m})$.

label: Exercise 3.4.10
question: Let $I$ be a subset of the positive integers $\le m$ which are coprime to $m$. Set $f(x)=\prod_{i\in I}(x-\zeta_{m}^{i})$. Suppose that $f(\zeta_{m})=0$ and $f(\zeta_{m}^{p})\ne0$ for some prime $p$. Show that $p|m$. (This observation gives an alternative proof for the irreducibility of $\phi_{m}(x).$)
solution:
Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$. Then $f(\zeta_{m}^{p})$ divides
$$\prod_{0\le i\le m-1}(\zeta_{m}^{p}-\zeta_{m}^{i})$$
in the ring $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$. Hence $N_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(f(\zeta_{m}^{p}))$ divides $m$ by Exercise 3.4.6 above. Since
$$f(x)^{p}-f(x^{p})\in p\mathbb{Z}[x],$$
we see upon setting $x=\zeta_{m}$ that $p|f(\zeta_{m}^{p})$ and hence $p|m$ as desired.

label: Exercise 3.4.11
question: Consider the equation $x^{3}+3x^{2}y+xy^{2}+y^{3}=m.$ Using Thue's theorem, deduce that there are only finitely many integral solutions to this equation.
solution: To use Thue's theorem, we must show that $f(x,y)=x^{3}+3x^{2}+xy^{2}+y^{3}$ is irreducible. If this polynomial is reducible, then so is the polynomial $f(x,1)=x^{3}+3x^{2}+x+1.$ However, since $f(x,1)$ has degree 3, then if it reduces it will have a factor of degree 1, a rational root. We have already shown that all rational roots of a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ are actually integers, and all roots must divide the constant term of a polynomial. The only possibilities for such a root are $x=\pm1$. A quick calculation shows that neither of these two are in fact a root of $f(x,1)$ and so $f(x,1)$ is irreducible, implying that $f(x,y)$ is irreducible. We can now apply the results of Example 3.2.3.

label: Exercise 3.4.12
question: Assume that $n$ is an odd integer, $n\ge3$. Show that $x^{n}+y^{n}=m$ has only finitely many integral solutions.
solution: If $(x_{0},y_{0})$ is a solution to $x^{n}+y^{n}=m$ then $(x_{0}+y_{0})|m$ since $x^{n}+y^{n}=(x+y)(x^{n-1}-x^{n-2}y+\cdot\cdot\cdot+y^{n-1})$. Suppose $|x|\ge m$. Then the distance between $x^{n}$ and the nearest nth power will be greater than $m$, and $x$ cannot satisfy the above equation. We then have a bound on the size of $x$ along with the constraint that $x+y|m$. There can only be a finite number of pairs which satisfy these two constraints.

label: Exercise 3.4.13
question: Let $\zeta_{m}$ denote a primitive mth root of unity. Show that $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$ is normal over $\mathbb{Q}$.
solution: $\zeta_{m}$ is a root of the mth cyclotomic polynomial, which we have shown to be irreducible. Thus, the conjugate fields are $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m}^{j})$ where $(j,m)=1$ and these are identical with $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$.

label: Exercise 3.4.14
question: Let $a$ be squarefree and greater than 1, and let $p$ be prime. Show that the normal closure of $\mathbb{Q}(a^{1/p})$ is $\mathbb{Q}(a^{1/p},\zeta_{p})$.
solution: The polynomial $x^{p}-a$ is irreducible (by Eisenstein's criterion). The conjugates of $a^{1/p}$ are $\zeta_{p}^{j}a^{1/p}$. If $K$ is the normal closure of $\mathbb{Q}(a^{1/p})$, it must contain all the pth roots of unity. The result is now immediate.

label: Lemma 4.1.1
question: If $K$ is an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$, and $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ its ring of integers, then $Tr_{K}(\alpha)$ and $N_{K}(\alpha)$ are in $\mathbb{Z}$.
solution:
We begin by writing $\alpha\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}\omega_{j}\forall i$. Then we have
$$\alpha^{(k)}\omega_{i}^{(k)}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}\omega_{j}^{(k)}\forall i,k,$$
where $\alpha^{(k)}$ is the kth conjugate of $\alpha$. We rewrite the above by introducing the Kronecker delta function to get
$$\sum_{j=1}^{n}\delta_{jk}\alpha^{(j)}\omega_{i}^{(j)}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}\omega_{j}^{(k)},$$
where
$$\delta_{ij}=\begin{cases}0&if~i\ne j,\\ 1&if~i=j.\end{cases}$$
Now, if we define the matrices
$$A_{0}=(\alpha^{(i)}\delta_{ij}), \quad \Omega=(\omega_{i}^{(j)}), \quad A=(a_{ij}),$$
the preceding statement tells us that $\Omega A_{0}=A\Omega$ or $A_{0}=\Omega^{-1}A\Omega,$ so we conclude that $TrA=TrA_{0}$ and $det A=det~A_{0}$. But $TrA_{0}$ is just the sum of the conjugates of $\alpha$ and is thus (up to sign) the coefficient of the $x^{n-1}$ term in the minimal polynomial for $\alpha$; similarly, $det A_{0}$ is just the product of the conjugates of $\alpha$ and is thus equal (up to sign) to the constant term in the minimal polynomial for $\alpha$. Thus $Tr_{K}(\alpha)$ and $N_{K}(\alpha)$ are in $\mathbb{Z}$.

label: Lemma 4.1.4
question: The bilinear pairing given by $B(x,y):K\times K\rightarrow\mathbb{Q}$ such that $(x,y)\rightarrow Tr_{K}(xy)$ is nondegenerate.
solution:
We recall that if $V$ is a finite-dimensional vector space over a field $F$ with basis $e_{1},e_{2},...,e_{n}$ and $B:V\times V\rightarrow F$ is a bilinear map, we can associate a matrix to $B$ as follows. Write
$$v=\sum a_{i}e_{i} \text{ with } a_{i}\in F, \quad u=\sum b_{i}e_{i} \text{ with } b_{i}\in F.$$
Then
$$B(v,u)=\sum_{i}B(a_{i}e_{i},u)=\sum_{i}a_{i}B(e_{i},u)=\sum_{i,j}a_{i}b_{j}B(e_{i},e_{j})$$
and we associate to $B$ the matrix $(B(e_{i},e_{j}))$. $B$ is said to be nondegenerate if the matrix associated to it is nonsingular. This definition is independent of the choice of basis.
Now, if $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ is a $\mathbb{Q}$-basis for $K$, then the matrix associated to $B(x,y)$ with respect to this basis is just
$$(B(\omega_{i},\omega_{j}))=(Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j})),$$
but $Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j})=\sum\omega_{i}^{(k)}\omega_{j}^{(k)}$ and thus we see that
$$(B(\omega_{i},\omega_{j}))=\Omega\Omega^{T},$$
where $\Omega=(\omega_{i}^{(j)})$, is nonsingular because $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ form a basis for $K$. Thus $B(x,y)$ is indeed nondegenerate.

label: Theorem 4.2.2
question:
Let $\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},...,\alpha_{n}$ be a set of generators for a finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-module $M$, and let $N$ be a submodule.
(a) $\exists\beta_{1},\beta_{2},...,\beta_{m}$ in $N$ with $m\le n$ such that
$$N=\mathbb{Z}\beta_{1}+\mathbb{Z}\beta_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\beta_{m}$$
and $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j\ge i}p_{ij}\alpha_{j}$ with $1\le i\le m$ and $p_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$.
(b) If $m=n$, then $[M:N]=p_{11}p_{22}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{nn}$.
solution:
(a) We will proceed by induction on the number of generators of a $\mathbb{Z}$-module. This is trivial when $n=0$. We can assume that we have proved the above statement to be true for all $\mathbb{Z}$-modules with $n-1$ or fewer generators, and proceed to prove it for $n$. We define $M^{\prime}$ to be the submodule generated by $\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3},...,\alpha_{n}$ over $\mathbb{Z}$, and define $N^{\prime}$ to be $N\cap M^{\prime}.$ Now, if $n=1$, then $M^{\prime}=0$ and there is nothing to prove. If $N=N^{\prime}$, then the statement is true by our induction hypothesis. So we assume that $N\ne N^{\prime}$ and consider $A$, the set of all integers $k$ such that $\exists k_{2},k_{3},...,k_{n}$ with $k\alpha_{1}+k_{2}\alpha_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+k_{n}\alpha_{n}\in N$. Since $N$ is a submodule, we deduce that $A$ is a subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}$. All additive subgroups of $\mathbb{Z}$ are of the form $m\mathbb{Z}$ for some integer $m$, and so $A=k_{11}\mathbb{Z}$ for some $k_{11}$. Then let $\beta_{1}=k_{11}\alpha_{1}+k_{12}\alpha_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+k_{1n}\alpha_{n}\in N.$ If we have some $\alpha\in N$ then
$$\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{n}h_{i}\alpha_{i},$$
with $h_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $h_{1}\in A$ so $h_{1}=ak_{11}$. Therefore, $\alpha-a\beta_{1}\in N^{\prime}$. By the induction hypothesis, there exist $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j\ge i}k_{ij}\alpha_{j};$ $i=2,3...,m$, which generate $N^{\prime}$ over $\mathbb{Z}$ and which satisfy all the conditions above. It is clear that adding $\beta_{1}$ to this list gives us a set of generators of $N$.
(b) Consider $\alpha$, an arbitrary element of $M$. Then $\alpha=\sum c_{i}\alpha_{i}$. Recalling that $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j\ge i}p_{ij}\alpha_{j}$ we write $c_{1}=p_{11}q_{1}+r_{1}$, with $0\le r_{1}<p_{11}$. Then $\alpha-q_{1}\beta_{1}=\sum c_{i}^{\prime}\alpha_{i}$ where $0\le c_{1}^{\prime}<p_{11}$. Note that $\alpha\equiv\alpha-q_{1}\beta_{1} \pmod N$. Next we write $c_{2}^{\prime}=p_{22}q_{2}+r_{2}$, where $0\le r_{2}<p_{22}$, and note that $\alpha\equiv\alpha-q_{1}\beta_{1}-q_{2}\beta_{2}\pmod N.$ It is clear by induction that we can continue this process to arrive at an expression $\alpha^{\prime}=\sum k_{i}\alpha_{i}$ with $0\le k_{i}<p_{ii}$ and $\alpha\equiv\alpha^{\prime} \pmod N$. It remains only to show that if we have $\alpha=\sum c_{i}\alpha_{i}$ and $\beta=\sum d_{i}\alpha_{i}$ where $c_{i}\ne d_{i}$ for at least one $i$ and $0\le c_{i}, d_{i}<p_{ii}$, then $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are distinct mod $N$. Suppose that this is not true, and that $\sum c_{i}\alpha_{i}\equiv\sum d_{i}\alpha_{i}\pmod N$ where $c_{i}\ne d_{i}$ for at least one $i$. Suppose $c_{i}=d_{i}$ for $i<r$ and $c_{r}\ne d_{r}$. Then $\sum(c_{i}-d_{i})\alpha_{i}\in N$ so
$$\sum_{i\ge r}(c_{i}-d_{i})\alpha_{i}=\sum_{i\ge r}k_{i}\beta_{i}=\sum_{i\ge r}k_{i}(\sum_{j\ge i}p_{ij}\alpha_{j})$$
Since $c_{r}$, $d_{r}$ are both less than $p_{rr}$ we have $c_{r}=d_{r}$ a contradiction. Thus, each coset in $M/N$ has a unique representative $\alpha=\sum c_{i}\alpha_{i}$ with $0\le c_{i}<p_{ii}$, and there are $p_{11}p_{22}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{nn}$ of them. So $[M:N]=p_{11}p_{22}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{nn}$.

label: Example 4.3.1
question: Suppose that the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ is Eisensteinian with respect to a prime $p$, i.e., $\alpha$ is a root of the polynomial $x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}x+a_{0}$, where $p|a_{i}$, $0\le i\le n-1$ and $p^{2}\nmid a_{0}$. Show that the index of $\alpha$ is not divisible by $p$.
solution:
Let $M=\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{n-1}$. First observe that since $\alpha^{n}+a_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}\alpha+a_{0}=0$ then $\alpha^{n}/p\in M\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Also, $|N_{K}(\alpha)|=a_{0}\not\equiv0\pmod{p^{2}}.$ We will proceed by contradiction. Suppose $p|[\mathcal{O}_{K}:M]$. Then there is an element of order $p$ in the group $\mathcal{O}_{K}/M$ meaning $\exists\xi\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $\xi\notin M$ but $p\xi\in M$. Then
$$p\xi=b_{0}+b_{1}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1};$$
where not all the $b_{i}$ are divisible by $p$, for otherwise $\xi\in M$. Let $j$ be the least index such that $p\nmid b_{j}$. Then
$$\eta=\xi-(\frac{b_{0}}{p}+\frac{b_{1}}{p}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\frac{b_{j-1}}{p}\alpha^{j-1}) =\frac{b_{j}}{p}\alpha^{j}+\frac{b_{j+1}}{p}\alpha^{j+1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\frac{b_{n}}{p}\alpha^{n}$$
is in $\mathcal{O}_{K},$ since both $\xi$ and $\frac{b_{0}}{p}+\frac{b_{1}}{p}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\frac{b_{n}}{p}\alpha^{j-1}$ are in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. If $\eta\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ then of course $\eta\alpha^{n-j-1}$ is also in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, and
$$\eta\alpha^{n-j-1}=\frac{b_{j}}{p}\alpha^{n-1}+\frac{\alpha^{n}}{p}(b_{j+1}+b_{j+2}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n}\alpha^{n-j-2}).$$
Since both $\alpha^{n}/p$ and $(b_{j+1}+b_{j+2}\alpha+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n}\alpha^{n-j-2})$ are in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, we conclude that $(b_{j}\alpha^{n-1})/p\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$. We know from Lemma 4.1.1 that the norm of an algebraic integer is always a rational integer, so
$$N_{K}(\frac{b_{j}}{p}\alpha^{n-1})=\frac{b_{j}^{n}N_{K}(\alpha)^{n-1}}{p^{n}}=\frac{b_{j}^{n}a_{0}^{n-1}}{p^{n}}$$
must be an integer. But $p$ does not divide $b_{j}$, and $p^{2}$ does not divide $a_{0}$, so this is impossible. This proves that we do not have an element of order $p,$ and thus $p\nmid[\mathcal{O}_{K}:M]$.

label: Example 4.3.4
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$ with $D$ a squarefree integer. Find an integral basis for $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution:
An arbitrary element $\alpha$ of $K$ is of the form $\alpha=r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{D}$ with $r_{1},r_{2}\in\mathbb{Q}$. Since $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=2$, $\alpha$ has only one conjugate: $r_{1}-r_{2}\sqrt{D}$. From Lemma 4.1.1 we know that if $\alpha$ is an algebraic integer, then $Tr_{K}(\alpha)=2r_{1}$ and $N_{K}(\alpha)=(r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{D})(r_{1}-r_{2}\sqrt{D}) =r_{1}^{2}-Dr_{2}^{2}$ are both integers. We note also that since $\alpha$ satisfies the monic polynomial $x^{2}-2r_{1}x+r_{1}^{2}-Dr_{2}^{2}$ if $Tr_{K}(\alpha)$ and $N_{K}(\alpha)$ are integers, then $\alpha$ is an algebraic integer.
If $2r_{1}\in\mathbb{Z}$ where $r_{1}\in\mathbb{Q}$, then the denominator of $r_{1}$ can be at most 2. We also need $r_{1}^{2}-Dr_{2}^{2}$ to be an integer, so the denominator of $r_{2}$ can be no more than 2. Then let $r_{1}=g_{1}/2$, $r_{2}=g_{2}/2$ where $g_{1}, g_{2}\in\mathbb{Z}$. The second condition amounts to $\frac{g_{1}^{2}-Dg_{2}^{2}}{4}\in\mathbb{Z},$ which means that $g_{1}^{2}-Dg_{2}^{2}\equiv0 \pmod 4$, or $g_{1}^{2}\equiv Dg_{2}^{2} \pmod 4$. We will discuss two cases:
Case 1. $D\equiv1 \pmod 4$. If $D\equiv1 \pmod 4$, and $g_{1}^{2}\equiv Dg_{2}^{2} \pmod 4$, then $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ are either both even or both odd. So if $\alpha=r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{D}$ is an algebraic integer of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$, then either $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ are both integers, or they are both fractions with denominator 2. We recall from Chapter 3 that if $4|(-D+1)$, then $(1+\sqrt{D})/2$ is an algebraic integer. This suggests that we use $1, (1+\sqrt{D})/2$ as a basis; it is clear from the discussion above that this is in fact an integral basis.
Case 2. $D\equiv2,3 \pmod 4$. If $g_{1}^{2}\equiv Dg_{2}^{2} \pmod 4$, then both $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ must be even. Then a basis for $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is $1, \sqrt{D}$; again it is clear that this is an integral basis.

label: Example 4.3.6
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ where $\alpha=r^{1/3}$, $r=ab^{2}\in\mathbb{Z}$ where $ab$ is squarefree. If $3|r$ assume that $3\nmid a, 3\nmid b$. Find an integral basis for $K$.
solution:
The minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ is $f(x)=x^{3}-r$ and $\alpha$'s conjugates are $\alpha$, $\omega\alpha$, and $\omega^{2}\alpha$ where $\omega$ is a primitive cube root of unity. By Exercise 4.3.3, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=-\prod_{i=1}^{3}f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})=-3^{3}r^{2}.$ So $-3^{3}r^{2}=m^{2}d_{K}$ where $m=[\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}]$. We note that $f(x)$ is Eisensteinian for every prime divisor of $a$ so by Example 4.3.1 if $p|a,$ $p
mid m$. Thus if $3|a,27a^{2}|d_{K}$, and if $3
mid a$, then $3a^{2}|d_{K}$. We now consider $ eta=\alpha^{2}/b$, which is a root of the polynomial $x^{3}-a^{2}b.$ This polynomial is Eisensteinian for any prime which divides $b$. Therefore $b^{2}|d_{K}$. We conclude that $d_{K}=-3^{n}(ab)^{2}$ where $n=3$ if $3|r$ and $n=1$ or 3 otherwise. We will consider three cases: $r
ot\equiv1,8 \pmod 9$, $r\equiv1 \pmod 9$ and $r\equiv8 \pmod 9$.
Case 1. If $r
ot\equiv1,8 \pmod 9$, then $r^{3}
ot\equiv r \pmod 9$. Then the polynomial $(x+r)^{3}-r$ is Eisensteinian with respect to the prime 3. A root of this polynomial is $\alpha-r$ and $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha-r)=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=-27r^{2}$. This implies that $3
mid m$ and so $m=b$. We can choose as our integral basis $1, \alpha, \alpha^2/b$, all of which are algebraic integers. We verify that this is an integral basis by checking the index of $\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}$ in $\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}/b$, which is clearly $b$. Thus $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z} rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}$.
Case 2. If $r\equiv1 \pmod 9$, then $c=(1+\alpha+\alpha^{2})/3$ is an algebraic integer. In fact, since $Tr_{K}(\alpha)=Tr_{K}(\alpha^{2})=0$ then $Tr_{K}(c)=1\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $N_{K}(c)= rac{N_{K}(1+\alpha+\alpha^{2})}{27}= rac{N_{K}(\alpha^{3}-1)}{27N_{K}(\alpha-1)}= rac{(r-1)^{2}}{27}$ because the minimal polynomial for $1-\alpha$ is $x^{3}+3x^{2}+3x+1-r$. The other coefficient for the minimal polynomial of $c$ is $(1-r)/3$ which is an integer. If $c$ is in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\mathcal{O}_{K}/(\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2})$ has an element of order 3, and so $3|m$. Then $d_{K}=-3(ab)^{2}$, so $m=3b$. We will choose as our integral basis $\alpha, \alpha^{2}/b, c$, noting that since $1=3c-\alpha-b rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}$, $\alpha=0+\alpha+0$, $\alpha^{2}=0+0+b rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}$ then Theorem 4.2.2 tells us that the index of $\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}$ in $\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}/b+\mathbb{Z}c$ is $3b$. Therefore $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z} rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}+\mathbb{Z} rac{1+\alpha+\alpha^{2}}{3}$.
Case 3. If $r\equiv8 \pmod 9$, consider $d=(1-\alpha+\alpha^{2})/3$. This is an algebraic integer. $Tr_{K}(d)=1,N_{K}(d)=(1+r)^{2}/27\in\mathbb{Z}$, and the remaining coefficient for the minimal polynomial of $d$ is $(1+r)/3\in\mathbb{Z}.$ By the same reasoning as above, we conclude that $3|m$ and so $m=3b.$ We choose $\alpha, \alpha^{2}/b, d$ as an integral basis, noting that $1=3d+\alpha-b rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}$, $\alpha=0+\alpha+0$, $\alpha^{2}=0+0+b rac{\alpha^{2}}{b};$ so that the index of $\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}$ in $\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z}\alpha^{2}/b+\mathbb{Z}d$ is $3b$. We conclude that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\alpha+\mathbb{Z} rac{\alpha^{2}}{b}+\mathbb{Z} rac{1-\alpha+\alpha^{2}}{b}$.

label: Exercise 4.1.2
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(i)$. Show that $i\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and verify that $Tr_{K}(i)$ and $N_{K}(i)$ are integers.
solution: We know that $i$ is a root of the irreducible polynomial $x^{2}+1$, and so its conjugates are $i,-i.$ Thus, $Tr_{K}(i)=i-i=0\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $N_{K}(i)=i(-i)=1\in\mathbb{Z}.$

label: Exercise 4.1.3
question: Determine the algebraic integers of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$.
solution: We first note that $1,\sqrt{-5}$ form a $\mathbb{Q}$-basis for $K$. Thus any $\alpha\in K$ looks like $\alpha=r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{-5}$ with $r_{1},r_{2}\in\mathbb{Q}$. Since $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=2$, we can deduce that the conjugates of $\alpha$ are $r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{-5}$ and $r_{1}-r_{2}\sqrt{-5}$. Then $Tr_{K}(\alpha)=2r_{1}$ and $N_{K}(\alpha)=(r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{-5})(r_{1}-r_{2}\sqrt{-5}) =r_{1}^{2}+5r_{2}^{2}$. By Lemma 4.1.1, if $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then the trace and norm are integers. Also, $\alpha$ is a root of the monic polynomial $x^{2}-2r_{1}x+r_{1}^{2}+5r_{2}^{2}$ which is in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ when the trace and norm are integers. We conclude that for $\alpha=r_{1}+r_{2}\sqrt{-5}$ to be in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, it is necessary and sufficient that $2r_{1}$ and $r_{1}^{2}+5r_{2}^{2}$ be integers. This implies that $r_{1}$ has a denominator at most 2, which forces the same for $r_{2}$. Then by setting $r_{1}=g_{1}/2$ and $r_{2}=g_{2}/2$ we must have $(g_{1}^{2}+5g_{2}^{2})/4\in\mathbb{Z}$ or, equivalently, $g_{1}^{2}+5g_{2}^{2}\equiv0 \pmod 4$. Thus, as all squares are congruent to 0 or 1 (mod 4), we conclude that $g_{1}$ and $g_{2}$ are themselves even, and thus $r_{1}, r_{2}\in\mathbb{Z}$. We conclude then that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}+\mathbb{Z}\sqrt{-5}$.

label: Exercise 4.1.5
question: Show that the definition of nondegeneracy above is independent of the choice of basis.
solution: If $f_{1},...,f_{n}$ is another basis and $A=(B(f_{i},f_{j}))$, then $A=P^{T}BP$ where $P$ is the change of basis matrix from $e_{1},...,e_{n}$ to $f_{1},...,f_{n}$. Since $P$ is nonsingular, $det A\ne0$ if and only if $det B\ne0$.

label: Exercise 4.2.1
question: Show that $\exists\omega_{1}^{*},\omega_{2}^{*},...,\omega_{n}^{*}\in K$ such that $\mathcal{O}_{K}\subseteq\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}.$
solution: Let $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ be a $\mathbb{Q}$-basis for $K$, and recall from Exercise 3.3.7 that for any $\alpha\in K$ there is a nonzero integer $m$ such that $m\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus we can assume that $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ are in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Now, as the bilinear pairing $B(x,y)$ defined previously was nondegenerate, we can find a dual basis $\omega_{1}^{*},\omega_{2}^{*},...,\omega_{n}^{*}$ satisfying $B(\omega_{i},\omega_{j}^{*})=\delta_{ij}$. If we write $\omega_{j}^{*}=\sum c_{kj}\omega_{k}$ we have $\delta_{ij}=Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}{\omega_{j}}^{*}) =Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}\sum c_{kj}\omega_{k}) =\sum c_{kj}Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}\omega_{k})$. If we introduce now the matrices, $C=(c_{ij}), \Omega=(\omega_i^{(j)})$, then the above becomes $I_{n}=\Omega\Omega^{T}C\Rightarrow C^{-1}=\Omega\Omega^{T}$. We conclude that $C$ is nonsingular and that ${\omega_{1}}^{*},{\omega_{2}}^{*},...,{\omega_{n}}^{*}$ forms a basis for $K$. Let $\alpha$ be an arbitrary element of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. We write $\alpha=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{j}\omega_{j}^{*}$ with $a_{j}\in\mathbb{Q}$. So $\alpha\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{j}\omega_{i}\omega_{j}^{*}$ and $Tr_{K}(\alpha\omega_{i})=\sum a_{j}Tr_{K}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j}^{*})=a_{i} \forall i.$ But $\alpha\omega_{i}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ implies the left-hand side above is in $\mathbb{Z}$, and thus $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ for all $i$. It follows then that $\mathcal{O}_{K}\subseteq\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}$.

label: Exercise 4.2.3
question: Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ has an integral basis.
solution: We apply the results of Theorem 4.2.2 with $M=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}^{*}+ ...+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}$ and $N=\mathcal{O}_{K}$. It follows directly from the theorem that there exist $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}$.

label: Exercise 4.2.4
question: Show that $det(Tr(\omega_{i}\omega_{j}))$ is independent of the choice of integral basis.
solution:
Let $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ and $\theta_{1},\theta_{2},...,\theta_{n}$ be two distinct integral bases for an algebraic number field $K$. We can write $\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}c_{ij}\theta_{j}, \quad \theta_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}d_{ij}\omega_{j}$ for all $i$, where $c_{ij}$ and $d_{ij}$ are all integers. Then $(c_{ij})$ and $(c_{ij})^{-1}$ both have entries in $\mathbb{Z}$. So $det(c_{ij})$, $det(c_{ij})^{-1}\in\mathbb{Z}$, meaning that $det(c_{ij})=\pm1$. Then
$$Tr(\omega_{i}\omega_{j})=Tr((\sum_{l}c_{il}\theta_{l})(\sum_{m}c_{jm}\theta_{m}))=\sum_{l,m}c_{il}c_{jm}Tr(\theta_{l}\theta_{m}).$$
Now if we define $\Omega=(\omega_{i}^{(j)})$, $C=(c_{ij}),\Theta=(\theta_{i}^{(j)})$, then we can write the above as the matrix equation $\Omega^{T}\Omega=C(\Theta^{T}\Theta)C^{T}$ from which it follows that the determinants of $\Omega^{T}\Omega$ and $\Theta^{T}\Theta$ are equal, up to sign. Hence, $det(\Theta^{T}\Theta)=det(\Omega^{T}\Omega)$.

label: Exercise 4.2.5
question: Show that the discriminant is well-defined. In other words, show that given $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ and $\theta_{1},\theta_{2},...,\theta_{n}$ two integral bases for $K$, we get the same discriminant for $K$.
solution: Just as above, we have $\Omega^{T}\Omega=C(\Theta^{T}\Theta)C^{T}$ for some matrix $C$ with determinant $\pm1$. Then $d_{K}=(det~\Omega)^{2}=(det~\Theta)^{2}(det~C)^{2}=(det~\Theta)^{2}$. This proves that the discriminant does not depend upon the choice of integral basis.

label: Exercise 4.2.6
question: Show that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(1,a,...,a^{n-1})=\prod_{i>j}(\sigma_{i}(a)-\sigma_{j}(a))^{2}.$ We denote $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(1,a,...,a^{n-1})$ by $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a)$.
solution:
First we note that $\sigma_{i}(a)$ takes $a$ to its $i$th conjugate, $a^{(i)}$. Define the matrix $\Omega=(\sigma_{i}(a^{j}))$. Then it is easy to see that
$$\Omega=(\begin{matrix}1&a&\cdot\cdot\cdot&a^{n-1}\\ \vdots&\vdots&&\\ 1&a^{(n)}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&a^{(n)n-1}\end{matrix}),$$
which is a Vandermonde matrix, and so $det~\Omega=\prod_{i>j}(a^{(i)}-a^{(j)})=\prod_{i>j}(\sigma_{i}(a)-\sigma_{j}(a))$. It follows that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a)=[det(\sigma_{i}(a^{j}))]^{2} =\prod_{i<j}(\sigma_{i}(a)-\sigma_{j}(a))^{2}$.

label: Exercise 4.2.7
question: Suppose that $u_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}v_{j}$ with $a_{ij}\in\mathbb{Q}$, $v_{j}\in K$. Show that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n})=(det(a_{ij}))^{2}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(v_{1},v_{2},...,v_{n})$.
solution: By definition, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n})=[det(\sigma_{i}(u_{j}))]^{2}.$ Since $\sigma_{i}(u_{j})=\sigma_{i}(\sum_{k=1}^{n}a_{jk}v_{k})=\sum_{k=1}^{n}a_{jk}\sigma_{i}(v_{k}).$ If we define the matrices $U=(\sigma_{i}(u_{j})), A=(a_{ij}), V=(\sigma_{i}(v_{j}))$, then it is clear that $U=VA^{T}$ and so $(det~U)^{2}=(det~VA^{T})^{2},$ and we get the desired result: $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n})=(det(a_{ij}))^{2}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(v_{1},v_{2},...,v_{n})$.

label: Exercise 4.2.8
question: Let $a_{1},a_{2},...,a_{n}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $N=\mathbb{Z}a_{1}+\mathbb{Z}a_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}a_{n}$ and $m=[\mathcal{O}_{K}:N]$. Prove that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a_{1},a_{2},...,a_{n})=m^{2}d_{K}$.
solution:
Let $\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},...,\alpha_{n}$ be an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Theorem 4.2.2 says that $N$ has a basis $\beta_{1},\beta_{2},...,\beta_{n}$ such that $\beta_{i}=\sum_{j\ge i}p_{ij}\alpha_{j}$. Then from Exercise 4.2.7,
$$d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\beta_{1},...,\beta_{n})=(det(p_{ij}))^{2}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}) =m^{2}d_{K}.$$
Reasoning as in Exercise 4.2.5, we deduce $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\beta_{1},...,\beta_{n})=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a_{1},...,a_{n})$ which proves the result.

label: Exercise 4.3.2
question: Let $m\in\mathbb{Z}$, $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Prove that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha+m)=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)$.
solution:
By definition, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=\prod_{i<j}(\alpha^{(i)}-\alpha^{(j)})^{2}.$ We note that the $i$th conjugate of $\alpha+m$ is simply $\alpha^{(i)}+m$, and so
$$d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha+m)=\prod_{i<j}(\alpha^{(i)}+m-(\alpha^{(j)}+m))^{2} =\prod_{i<j}(\alpha^{(i)}-\alpha^{(j)})^{2} =d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha),$$
as desired.

label: Exercise 4.3.3
question: Let $\alpha$ be an algebraic integer, and let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. If $f$ has degree $n$, show that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=(-1)^{\binom{n}{2}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})$.
solution:
Let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. Then if $\alpha^{(1)},...,\alpha^{(n)}$ are the conjugates of $\alpha$, $f(x)=\prod_{k=1}^{n}(x-\alpha^{(k)})$. Then
$$f^{\prime}(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\frac{f(x)}{(x-\alpha^{(k)})}$$
and $f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})=\prod_{k\ne i}(\alpha^{(i)}-\alpha^{(k)}).$ Therefore
$$\prod_{i=1}^{n}f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\prod_{k\ne i}(\alpha^{(i)}-\alpha^{(k)}) =\prod_{i<k}[-(\alpha^{(i)}-\alpha^{(k)})^{2}] =(-1)^{\binom{n}{2}}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha).$$

label: Exercise 4.3.5
question: If $D\equiv1 \pmod 4$, show that every integer of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$ can be written as $(a+b\sqrt{D})/2$ where $a\equiv b \pmod 2$.
solution:
By Example 4.3.4, an integral basis is given by $1, (1+\sqrt{D})/2.$ Thus every integer is of the form
$$c+d(\frac{1+\sqrt{D}}{2})=\frac{(2c+d)+d\sqrt{D}}{2}=\frac{a+b\sqrt{D}}{2}.$$
Then we see that $a=2c+d, b=d$ satisfies $a\equiv b \pmod 2$. Conversely, if $a\equiv b \pmod 2$, writing $d=b$ and $a=2c+d$ for some $c$, we find $\frac{a+b\sqrt{D}}{2}=c+d(\frac{1+\sqrt{D}}{2})$ is an integer of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{D})$.

label: Exercise 4.3.7
question: Let $\zeta$ be any primitive $p$th root of unity, and $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta)$. Show that $1,\zeta,...,\zeta^{p-2}$ form an integral basis of $K$.
solution:
The minimal polynomial of $\zeta$ is the $p$th cyclotomic polynomial, $\Phi(x)=\frac{x^{p}-1}{x-1}=1+x+x^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x^{p-1}.$ We want to show that this is irreducible. Consider instead the polynomial $F(x)=\Phi(x+1)$. Clearly $F$ will be irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$ if and only if $\Phi$ is.
$$F(x)=\frac{(x+1)^{p}-1}{x}=x^{p-1}+px^{p-2}+\binom{p}{2}x^{p-3}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\binom{p}{p-2}x+p.$$
This is Eisensteinian with respect to $p$ and so $F(x)$ (and thus $\Phi(x))$ is irreducible. The conjugates of $\zeta$ are $\zeta,\zeta^{2},...,\zeta^{p-1}$. We can deduce that $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=p-1$. Now, $\Phi^{\prime}(x)=\frac{px^{p-1}(x-1)-(x^{p}-1)}{(x-1)^{2}}=\frac{px^{p-1}-(1+x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x^{p-1})}{x-1}$ and so $\Phi^{\prime}(\zeta^{k})=\frac{p\zeta^{-k}}{\zeta^{k}-1}.$ Using Exercise 4.3.3, we can compute
$$d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta)=\pm\prod_{k=1}^{p-1}\frac{p\zeta^{-k}}{\zeta^{k}-1} =\pm p^{p-1}\frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{p-1}(\zeta^{k}-1)} =\pm p^{p-1}\frac{1}{\prod_{k=1}^{p-1}(1-\zeta^{k})} =\pm p^{p-2},$$
since $\prod_{k=1}^{p-1}(1-\zeta^{k})=\Phi(1)=p$. We know that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta)=p^{p-2}=m^{2}d_{K}$ and also that $p\nmid m$ because $F$, the minimal polynomial for $\zeta-1$ is $p$-Eisensteinian, and $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta-1)=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta)$. Then $m$ must be 1, meaning that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[1,\zeta,...,\zeta^{p-2}]$.

label: Exercise 4.4.1
question: Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be a nonzero ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Show that $\mathfrak{a}\cap\mathbb{Z}\ne\{0\}$.
solution: Let $\alpha$ be a nonzero algebraic integer in $\mathfrak{a}$ satisfying the minimal polynomial $x^{r}+a_{r-1}x^{r-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}=0$ with $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z} \forall i$ and $a_{0}$ not zero. Then $a_{0}=-(\alpha^{r}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}\alpha)$. The left-hand side of this equation is in $\mathbb{Z}$, while the right-hand side is in $\mathfrak{a}$.

label: Exercise 4.4.2
question: Show that $\mathfrak{a}$ has an integral basis.
solution: Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, and let $\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}$ be an integral basis for $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Note that for any $\omega_{i}$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, $a_{0}\omega_{i}=-(\alpha^{r}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}\alpha)\omega_{i}\in\mathfrak{a}.$ Therefore $\mathfrak{a}$ has finite index in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $\mathfrak{a}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}$ has maximal rank. Then since $\mathfrak{a}$ is a submodule of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, by Theorem 4.2.2 there exists an integral basis for $\mathfrak{a}$.

label: Exercise 4.4.3
question: Show that if $\mathfrak{a}$ is a nonzero ideal in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\mathfrak{a}$ has finite index in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution:
Surely, if $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}$ then by the preceding two exercises we can pick a rational integer $a$ such that
$$a\mathcal{O}_{K}=a\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}+a\mathbb{Z}\omega_{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}\subset\mathfrak{a}\subset\mathcal{O}_{K}.$$
But $a\mathcal{O}_{K}$ obviously has index $a^{n}$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, the index of $\mathfrak{a}$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ must be finite.

label: Exercise 4.4.4
question: Show that every nonzero prime ideal in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ contains exactly one integer prime.
solution: If $\wp$ is a prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then certainly it contains an integer, from Exercise 4.4.1. By the definition of a prime ideal, if $ab\in\wp,$ either $a\in\wp$ or $b\in\wp$. So $\wp$ must contain some rational prime. Now, if $\wp$ contained two distinct rational primes $p, q$, say, then it would necessarily contain their greatest common denominator which is 1. But this contradicts the assumption of nontriviality. So every prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ contains exactly one integer prime.

label: Exercise 4.4.5
question: Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an integral ideal with basis $\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}$. Show that $[det(\alpha_{i}^{(j)})]^{2}=(N\mathfrak{a})^{2}d_{K}$.
solution: Since $\mathfrak{a}$ is a submodule of index $N\mathfrak{a}$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, this is immediate from Exercise 4.2.8.

label: Exercise 4.5.1
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field. Show that $d_{K}\in\mathbb{Z}.$
solution: By definition $d_{K}=det(\omega_{i}^{(j)})^{2}=det(Tr(\omega_{i}\omega_{j}))$, where $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Since $Tr(\omega_{i}\omega_{j})\in\mathbb{Z}$ the determinant is an integer.

label: Exercise 4.5.2
question: Let $K/\mathbb{Q}$ be an algebraic number field of degree $n$. Show that $d_{K}\equiv0$ or 1 (mod 4). This is known as Stickelberger's criterion.
solution: Let $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ be an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. By definition, $d_{K}=det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))^{2}$, where $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{n}$ are the distinct embeddings of $K$ into $\overline{\mathbb{Q}}$. Now write $det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))=P-N$ where $P$ is the contribution arising from the even permutations and $N$ the odd permutations in the definition of the determinant. Then $d_{K}=(P-N)^{2}=(P+N)^{2}-4PN.$ Since $\sigma_{i}(P+N)=P+N$ and $\sigma_{i}(PN)=PN$ we see that $P+N$ and $PN$ are integers. Reducing mod 4 gives the result.

label: Exercise 4.5.3
question: Let $f(x)=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{1}x+a_{0}$ with $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ be the minimal polynomial of $\theta$. Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$. If for each prime $p$ such that $p^{2}|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ we have $f(x)$ Eisensteinian with respect to $p$, show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$.
solution: By Example 4.3.1, the index of $\theta$ is not divisible by $p$ for any prime $p$ satisfying $p^{2}|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$. By Exercise 4.2.8, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)=m^{2}d_{K}$ where $m=[\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}[\theta]]$. Hence $m=1$.

label: Exercise 4.5.4
question: If the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ is $f(x)=x^{n}+ax+b$ show that for $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=(-1)^{\binom{n}{2}}(n^{n}b^{n-1}+a^{n}(1-n)^{n-1})$.
solution:
By Exercise 4.3.3, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=(-1)^{\binom{n}{2}}\prod_{i=1}^{n}f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)}).$, where $\alpha^{(1)},...,\alpha^{(n)}$ are the conjugates of $\alpha$. Now $f^{\prime}(x)=nx^{n-1}+a=\frac{1}{x}(nx^{n}+ax)$ so that $f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})=\frac{(-n(a\alpha^{(i)}+b)+a\alpha^{(i)})}{\alpha^{(i)}}$. Hence
$$\prod_{i=1}^{n}f^{\prime}(\alpha^{(i)})=(-1)^{n}b^{-1}\prod_{i=1}^{n}(a(1-n)\alpha^{(i)}-nb) =b^{-1}a^{n}(1-n)^{n}f(\frac{nb}{a(1-n)})$$

label: Exercise 4.5.5
question: Determine an integral basis for $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}+2\theta+1=0.$
solution: By applying the previous exercise, the discriminant of $\theta$ is -59, which is squarefree. Therefore $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$.

label: Exercise 4.5.6 (a)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}-\theta^{2}-2\theta-8=0$. Show that $f(x)=x^{3}-x^{2}-2x-8$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q}$.
solution: Note that if (a) is not true, then $f$ has a linear factor and by the rational root theorem, this factor must be of the form $x-a$ where $a|8$. A systematic check rules out this possibility.

label: Exercise 4.5.6 (b)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}-\theta^{2}-2\theta-8=0$. Consider $\beta=(\theta^{2}+\theta)/2$. Show that $\beta^{3}-3\beta^{2}-10\beta-8=0$. Hence $\beta$ is integral.
solution: (b) can be checked directly.

label: Exercise 4.5.6 (c)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}-\theta^{2}-2\theta-8=0$. Show that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)=-4(503)$, and $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(1,\theta,\beta)=-503$. Deduce that $1, \theta, \beta$ is a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: This is easy to deduce from the formula $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(1,\theta,\beta)=\frac{1}{4}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ as a simple computation shows.

label: Exercise 4.5.6 (d)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}-\theta^{2}-2\theta-8=0$. Show that every integer $\alpha$ of $K$ has an even discriminant.
solution: Write $x=A+B\theta+C\beta, A,B,C\in\mathbb{Z}$. Since $\beta^{2}=6+2\theta+3\beta, \theta^{2}=2\beta-\theta, \theta\beta=2\beta+4,$ we find $x^{2}=(a^{2}+6C^{2}+8BC)+\theta(2C^{2}-B^{2}+2AB)+\beta(2B^{2}+3C^{2}+2AC+4BC)$ so that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(1,x,x^{2})\equiv-503(BC)^{2}(3C+B)^{2} \pmod 2,$ which is an even number in all cases.

label: Exercise 4.5.6 (e)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}-\theta^{2}-2\theta-8=0$. Deduce that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ has no integral basis of the form $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$.
solution: By (d), $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)$ is even and hence is not equal to -503, which proves that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ has no integral basis of the form $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$.

label: Exercise 4.5.7
question: Let $m=p^{a}$ with $p$ prime and $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m}).$ Show that $(1-\zeta_{m})^{\varphi(m)}=p\mathcal{O}_{K}$
solution:
First note that $\frac{x^{m}-1}{x^{m/p}-1}=\prod_{1\le b<m, (b,m)=1}(x-\zeta_{m}^{b})$ so that taking the limit as $x$ goes to 1 of both sides gives
$$p=\prod_{1\le b<m, (b,m)=1}(1-\zeta_{m}^{b}) =(1-\zeta_{m})^{\varphi(m)}\prod_{(b,m)=1, b\ne 1}\frac{1-\zeta_{m}^{b}}{1-\zeta_{m}}.$$
This latter quantity is a unit since $\frac{1-\zeta_{m}}{1-\zeta_{m}^{b}}=\frac{1-\zeta_{m}^{ab}}{1-\zeta_{m}^{b}}=1+\zeta_{m}^{b}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\zeta_{m}^{b(a-1)}$ for any $a$ satisfying $ab\equiv1 \pmod m$.

label: Exercise 4.5.8
question: Let $m=p^{a}$ with $p$ prime, and $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$. Show that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta_{m})=\frac{(-1)^{\varphi(m)/2}m^{\varphi(m)}}{p^{m/p}}$
solution: We need to compute the Vandermonde determinant given by $(-1)^{\varphi(m)/2} \prod_{1\le a,b<m, (a,m)=1, (b,m)=1, a\ne b}(\zeta_{m}^{a}-\zeta_{m}^{b}).$ Let $\theta=\prod_{1\le b<m, (b,m)=1, b\ne 1}(\zeta_{m}-\zeta_{m}^{b}).$ Clearly $\theta=\phi_{m}^{\prime}(\zeta_{m})$ and $N_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ is the discriminant we seek. Since $\phi_{m}(x)=\frac{x^{m}-1}{x^{m/p}-1},$ we find $\phi_{m}^{\prime}(\zeta_{m})=\frac{m\zeta_{m}^{m-1}}{\zeta_{m}^{m/p}-1}$ and the norm of this element is $\frac{m^{m}}{N_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta_{m}^{m/p}-1)}.$ Because $\eta=\zeta_{m}^{m/p}$ is a primitive $p$th root of unity, $N_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\zeta_{m}^{m/p}-1)=N_{\mathbb{Q}(\eta)/\mathbb{Q}}(\eta-1)^{m/p}$. In Exercise 4.3.7, we saw that $N_{\mathbb{Q}(\eta)/\mathbb{Q}}(\eta-1)=p$.

label: Exercise 4.5.9
question: Let $m=p^{a}$, with $p$ prime. Show that $\{1,\zeta_{m},...,\zeta_{m}^{\varphi(m)-1}\}$ is an integral basis for the ring of integers of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$.
solution: Clearly $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$. We want to prove the reverse inclusion. Let $\lambda=1-\zeta_{m}$. Since $\lambda^{j}=(1-\zeta_{m})^{j}\in\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ and $\zeta_{m}^{j}=(1-\lambda)^{j}\in\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$, we see that $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]=\mathbb{Z}[\lambda]$. Thus, it suffices to show $\mathbb{Z}[\lambda]\supseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Let $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and write $\alpha=\sum_{j=0}^{\varphi(m)-1}a_{j}\lambda^{j}=\sum_{j=0}^{\varphi(m)-1}b_{j}\zeta_{m}^{j},$ $a_{j},b_{j}\in\mathbb{Q}$. It suffices to show $a_{j}\in\mathbb{Z}$ for $j=0,1,...,\varphi(m)-1$. Let $\sigma_{c}(\zeta_{m})=\zeta_{m}^{c}.$ Then $\sigma_{c}(\alpha)=\sum_{j=0}^{\varphi(m)-1}b_{j}\sigma_{c}(\zeta_{m})^{j}=\sum_{j=0}^{\varphi(m)-1}b_{j}\zeta_{m}^{cj}$ for each $(c,m)=1$. We solve for $b_{j}$ using Cramer's rule. Moreover, by the previous question, we see that $b_{j}=\frac{c_{j}}{p^{d_{j}}}$ where $c_{j}\in\mathbb{Z}.$ Thus, $a_{j}$ has at most a power of $p$ in its denominator. Let $n$ be the least nonnegative integer such that $p^{n}a_{j}\in\mathbb{Z}$ for $j=0,1,...,\varphi(m)-1$. Suppose $n>0$. Let $k$ be the smallest nonnegative integer such that $p$ does not divide $p^{n}a_{k}$. Then $a_{r}\lambda^{r}\in p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\lambda^{\varphi(m)}\mathcal{O}_{K}$ (by the penultimate question) for $r=0,1,...,k-1$. Since $\alpha$ is an integer, $p^{n}\alpha\in p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\lambda^{\varphi(m)}\mathcal{O}_{K}$ so that $\sum_{j=k}^{\varphi(m)-1}p^{n}a_{j}\lambda^{j-k}\in\lambda\mathcal{O}_{K}$ so that $p^{n}a_{k}\in\lambda\mathcal{O}_{K}\cap\mathbb{Z}=p\mathbb{Z}$ a contradiction.

label: Exercise 4.5.10
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$ where $m=p^{a}.$ Show that $d_{K}=\frac{(-1)^{\varphi(m)/2}m^{\varphi(m)}}{p^{m/p}}.$
solution: This is immediate from the previous two questions.

label: Exercise 4.5.11
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{n}+\zeta_{n}^{-1}]$ is the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{n}+\zeta_{n}^{-1})$, where $\zeta_{n}$ denotes a primitive $n$th root of unity, and $n=p^{\alpha}$.
solution: Suppose $\alpha=a_{0}+a_{1}(\zeta_{n}+\zeta_{n}^{-1})+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{N}(\zeta_{n}+\zeta_{n}^{-1})^{N}$ is an algebraic integer with $N\le\frac{1}{2}\phi(n)-1$ and the $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Q}$. By subtracting those terms with $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$, we may suppose $a_{N}\notin\mathbb{Z}.$ Multiplying by $\zeta_{n}^{N}$ and expanding the result as a polynomial in $\zeta_{n}$ we find that $\zeta_{n}^{N}\alpha=a_{N}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{N}\zeta_{n}^{2N}$ is an algebraic integer in $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{n})$. Therefore, it lies in $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{n}]$. Since $2N\le\phi(n)-2\le\phi(n)-1,$ we conclude $a_{N}\in\mathbb{Z}$ contrary to our assumption above. (This is also true for arbitrary $n$ by applying Exercise 4.5.25.)

label: Exercise 4.5.12
question: Let $K$ and $L$ be algebraic number fields of degree $m$ and $n$, respectively, over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $d=gcd(d_{K},d_{L})$. Show that if $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=mn$, then $\mathcal{O}_{KL}\subseteq 1/d \mathcal{O}_{K}\mathcal{O}_{L}$.
solution: Let $\{\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{m}\}$ be a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis for $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and let $\{\beta_{1},...,\beta_{n}\}$ be a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis for $\mathcal{O}_{L}$. Then $\alpha_{i}\beta_{j}$, $1\le i\le m,$ $1\le j\le n$, is a $\mathbb{Q}$-basis for $KL$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ since $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=mn$. Any $\omega\in\mathcal{O}_{KL}$ can therefore be written as $\omega=\sum_{i,j}\frac{m_{ij}}{r}\alpha_{i}\beta_{j},$ where $r, m_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $gcd(r,gcd(m_{ij}))=1$. It suffices to show that $r|d_{K}$ and by symmetry $r|d_{L}$ so that $r|d.$ Since $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=mn$, every embedding $\sigma$ of $K$ into $\mathbb{C}$ can be extended to $KL$ acting trivially on $L$. Hence $\sigma(\omega)=\sum_{i,j}\frac{m_{ij}}{r}\sigma(\alpha_{i})\beta_{j}.$ Set $x_{i}=\sum_{j}m_{ij}\beta_{j}/r$. We then obtain $m$ equations $\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sigma(\alpha_{i})x_{i}=\sigma(\omega),$ one for each $\sigma:K\hookrightarrow\mathbb{C}$. We solve for $x_{i}$ by Cramer's rule: $x_{i}=\gamma_{i}/\delta$ where $\delta=det(\sigma(\alpha_{i}))$. Since $\delta^{2}=d_{K}$ we find $\delta\gamma_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\frac{\delta^{2}m_{ij}}{r}\beta_{j}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ since $\delta$ and each of $\gamma_{i}$ are algebraic integers. Hence $d_{K}m_{ij}/r$ are all integers. It follows that $r$ divides all $d_{K}m_{ij}$. Since $gcd(r,gcd(m_{ij}))=1$, we deduce $r|d_{K}$.

label: Exercise 4.5.13
question: Let $K$ and $L$ be algebraic number fields of degree $m$ and $n$, respectively, with $gcd(d_{K},d_{L})=1$. If $\{\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{m}\}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $\{\beta_{1},...,\beta_{n}\}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$, show that $\mathcal{O}_{KL}$ has an integral basis $\{\alpha_{i}\beta_{j}\}$ given that $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=mn.$
solution: This is immediate from the previous question.

label: Exercise 4.5.14
question: Find an integral basis for $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2},\sqrt{-3})$.
solution: If $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$, $L=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$ then $d_{K}=8$, $d_{L}=-3$ which are coprime. By the previous question, a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis for the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2},\sqrt{-3})$ is given by $\{1,\sqrt{2},\frac{1+\sqrt{-3}}{2},\sqrt{2}(\frac{1+\sqrt{-3}}{2})\}$.

label: Exercise 4.5.15
question: Let $p$ and $q$ be distinct primes $\equiv1 \pmod 4$. Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p}), L=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{q})$. Find a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis for $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p},\sqrt{q})$.
solution: We have $d_{K}=p,$ $d_{L}=q$ which are coprime. Now invoke the penultimate question to deduce that $\{1,\frac{1+\sqrt{p}}{2},\frac{1+\sqrt{q}}{2},(\frac{1+\sqrt{p}}{2})(\frac{1+\sqrt{q}}{2})\}$ is a $\mathbb{Z}$-basis for the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p},\sqrt{q})$.

label: Exercise 4.5.16
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $a_{1},...,a_{n}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$. Set $\Delta=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a_{1},...,a_{n})$. Show that if $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\Delta\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[a_{1},...,a_{n}]$.
solution: Write $\alpha=c_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{n}a_{n}$ for some rational numbers $c_{i}.$ By taking conjugates, we get a system of $n$ equations and we can solve for $c_{i}$ using Cramer's rule. Thus $c_{j}=A_{j}D/\Delta$ where $D^{2}=\Delta$ and it is easy to see that $A_{j}D$ is an algebraic integer. Therefore $\Delta c_{j}$ is an algebraic integer lying in $\mathbb{Q}$ so $\Delta c_{j}\in\mathbb{Z}$ as required.

label: Exercise 4.5.17
question: Suppose $K$ is an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Let $a_{1},...,a_{n}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$ and set $\Delta=d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a_{1},...,a_{n})$. For each $i$, choose the least natural number $d_{ii}$ so that for some $d_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$, the number $w_{i}=\Delta^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{i}d_{ij}a_{j}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}.$ Show that $w_{1},...,w_{n}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: First observe that there are integers $c_{ij}$ so that $\Delta^{-1}\sum_{j=1}^{i}c_{ij}a_{j}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ (e.g., $c_{ij}=\Delta)$. Clearly $w_{1},...,w_{n}$ are linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$ because $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(w_{1},...,w_{n})=\Delta^{-n}(d_{11}\cdot\cdot\cdot d_{nn})^{2}d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(a_{1},...,a_{n})$ by Exercise 4.2.7, and the right-hand side is nonzero.
