Observe now that if $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ can be written as $\alpha=\Delta^{-1}(c_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{j}a_{j})$ for some $j$, then $d_{jj}|c_{j}$. Indeed, write $c_{j}=sd_{jj}+r,0\le r<d_{jj}$, so that $\alpha-sw_{j}=\Delta^{-1}((c_{1}-d_{j1})a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+ra_{j})\in\mathcal{O}_{K},$ contrary to our choice of $w_{j}$ if $r\ne0$. We now show by induction on $j$ that every number of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ of the form $\Delta^{-1}(x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{j}a_{j})$ with $x_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ lies in $\mathbb{Z}[w_{1},...,w_{n}]$. For $j=1$, there is nothing to prove because then $d_{11}|x_{1}$ and we are done. Assume that we have proved it for $j<k$. Then suppose $y=\Delta^{-1}(x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{k}a_{k})\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ with $x_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}.$ Then $d_{kk}|x_{k}$ so that for some integer $t$, $y-tw_{k}=\Delta^{-1}(x_{1}^{\prime}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{k-1}^{\prime}a_{k-1})\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$. By induction, the right-hand side lies in $\mathbb{Z}[w_{1},...,w_{n}]$ and so does $y$. For $j=n$ this means that every number of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ of the form $\Delta^{-1}(x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}a_{n})$ with $x_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ lies in $\mathbb{Z}[w_{1},...,w_{n}]$. But by the previous exercise, every $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ can be so expressed.

label: Exercise 4.5.18
question: If $K$ is an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$ and $a_{1},...,a_{n}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ are linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$, then there is an integral basis $w_{1},...,w_{n}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $a_{j}=c_{j1}w_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{jj}w_{j}, c_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}, j=1,...,n.$
solution: We take $w_{1},...,w_{n}$ as constructed in the previous exercise. This is an integral basis. Solving for $a_{j}$ and noting that the matrix $(d_{ij})$ is lower triangular, we see that each $a_{j}$ can be written as above. Moreover, the $c_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$ since $w_{1},...,w_{n}$ is an integral basis by construction.

label: Exercise 4.5.19
question: $\mathbb{Q}\subseteq K\subseteq L$ and $K, L$ are algebraic number fields, show that $d_{K}|d_{L}.$
solution: Let $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=m$, $[L:K]=n$. Let $a_{1},...,a_{m}$ be an integral basis of $K$. Extend this to a basis of $L$ (viewed as a vector space over $\mathbb{Q}$) so that $a_{1},...,a_{mn}$ is linearly independent over $\mathbb{Q}$. By Exercise 3.3.7, we may suppose each $a_{i}$ is an algebraic integer. By the previous exercise, there is an integral basis $w_{1},...,w_{mn}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$ such that $a_{j}=c_{j1}w_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{jj}w_{j}, c_{ij}\in\mathbb{Z}$. Since the matrix $(c_{ij})$ is triangular, it is easy to see that $w_{1},...,w_{m}$ lie in $K$. Because the $w_{i}$ are algebraic integers, and $a_{1},...,a_{m}$ is an integral basis of $K$, it follows that $w_{1},...,w_{m}$ is an integral basis of $K$. Now write down the definition of the discriminant of $L$. Let $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{mn}$ be the embeddings of $L$ into $\mathbb{C}$ such that $\sigma_{i}(w_{j})=w_{j}^{(i)}$ for $1\le j\le m$. We order the $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{mn}$ so that $\sigma_{i}(x)=\sigma_{i^{\prime}}(x)$ for $i\equiv i^{\prime} \pmod m$ and $x\in K$. Then $d_{L}=det(\sigma_{i}(w_{j}))^{2} = d_{K}\cdot a,$ where $a$ is an algebraic integer. Since $d_{L}/d_{K}$ is a rational number, we deduce that $a$ is a rational integer.

label: Exercise 4.5.20
question: Suppose $K$ is a number field with $r_{1}$ real embeddings and $2r_{2}$ complex embeddings so that $r_{1}+2r_{2}=[K:\mathbb{Q}]=n$ (say). Show that $d_{K}$ has sign $(-1)^{r_{2}}$.
solution: Let $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ be an integral basis of $K$. Then $d_{K}=det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))^{2}$ where $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{n}$ are the embeddings of $K$. Clearly $\overline{det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))}=(-1)^{r_{2}}det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))$ since complex conjugation interchanges $r_{2}$ rows. If $r_{2}$ is even, then $det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))$ is real so that $d_{K}>0$. If $r_{2}$ is odd, $det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))$ is purely imaginary so that $d_{K}<0$.

label: Exercise 4.5.21
question: Show that only finitely many imaginary quadratic fields $K$ are Euclidean.

label: Exercise 4.5.22
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-19})/2]$ is not Euclidean. (Recall that in Exercise 2.5.6 we showed this ring is not Euclidean for the norm map.)
solution: The argument of the previous exercise shows that not all residue classes mod 2 and mod 3 are represented by elements of smaller $\psi$-value.

label: Exercise 4.5.23 (a)
question:
Let $A=(a_{ij})$ be an $m\times m$ matrix, $B=(b_{ij})$ an $n\times n$ matrix. We define the (Kronecker) tensor product $A\otimes B$ to be the $mn\times mn$ matrix obtained as
$$(\begin{matrix}Ab_{11}&Ab_{12}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ab_{1n}\\ Ab_{21}&Ab_{22}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ab_{2n}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ Ab_{n1}&Ab_{n2}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ab_{nn}\end{matrix}).$$
where each block $Ab_{ij}$ has the form $(\begin{matrix}a_{11}b_{ij}&a_{12}b_{ij}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&a_{1m}b_{ij}\\ a_{21}b_{ij}&a_{22}b_{ij}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&a_{2m}b_{ij}\\ \vdots&&\vdots\\ a_{m1}b_{ij}&a_{m2}b_{ij}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&a_{mm}b_{ij}\end{matrix}).$
If $C$ and $D$ are $m\times m$ and $n\times n$ matrices, respectively, show that $(A\otimes B)(C\otimes D)=(AC)\otimes(BD).$
solution: Part (a) is a straightforward matrix multiplication computation.

label: Exercise 4.5.23 (b)
question: Prove that $det(A\otimes B)=(det~A)^{n}(det~B)^{m}.$
solution: For part (b), we use linear algebra to find a matrix $U$ such that $U^{-1}BU$ is upper triangular: $U^{-1}BU=(\begin{matrix}c_{11}&c_{12}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{1n}\\ 0&c_{22}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{2n}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ 0&0&\cdot\cdot\cdot&c_{m}\end{matrix}).$ Then $det~B=c_{11}c_{22}\cdot\cdot\cdot c_{nn}$. Also, by (a), $(I\otimes U)^{-1}(A\otimes B)(I\otimes U)=A\otimes(U^{-1}BU)$ which is $(\begin{matrix}Ae_{11}&Ae_{12}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ae_{1n}\\ 0&Ae_{22}&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ae_{2n}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\vdots\\ 0&0&\cdot\cdot\cdot&Ae_{m}\end{matrix}).$ Again, by linear algebra, we see that $det(A\otimes B)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}det(Ac_{ii}) =\prod_{i=1}^{n}(c_{ii}^{m}det~A) =(det~B)^{m}(det~A)^{n},$ as desired.

label: Exercise 4.5.24
question: Let $K$ and $L$ be algebraic number fields of degree $m$ and $n$, respectively, with $gcd(d_{K},d_{L})=1.$ Show that $d_{KL}=d_{K}^{n}\cdot d_{L}^{m}.$ If we set $\delta(M)=\frac{log|d_{M}|}{[M:\mathbb{Q}]}$, deduce that $\delta(KL)=\delta(K)+\delta(L)$ whenever $gcd(d_{K},d_{L})=1.$
solution: By a previous exercise, $\mathcal{O}_{KL}$ has integral basis $\{\alpha_{i}\beta_{j}\}$ where $\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{m}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $\beta_{1},...,\beta_{n}$ is an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$. Let $A=(Tr_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha_{i}\alpha_{j}))$, $B=(Tr_{L/\mathbb{Q}}(\beta_{i}\beta_{j}))$. Then it is easily verified that the discriminant of $KL/\mathbb{Q}$ is $det(A\otimes B)$. By the previous exercise, this is $d_{K}^{n}d_{L}^{m}$. The second part of the question is immediate upon taking logarithms.

label: Exercise 4.5.25
question: Let $\zeta_{m}$ denote a primitive $m$th root of unity and let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$. Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ and $d_{K}=\frac{(-1)^{\phi(m)/2}m^{\varphi(m)}}{\prod_{p|m}p^{\phi(m)/(p-1)}}.$
solution: Factor $m=\prod_{p^{\alpha}||m}p^{\alpha}.$ Since the discriminants of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p^{\alpha}})$ for $p^{\alpha}||m$ are coprime, we have by the previous exercise (and Supplementary Exercise 4.5.8) $\frac{log|d_{K}|}{\phi(m)}=\sum_{p^{\alpha}||m}(\alpha-\frac{1}{p-1})log~p.$ The sign of the determinant is $(-1)^{r_{2}}=(-1)^{\varphi(m)/2}$. The fact that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ follows by an induction argument and Exercise 4.5.13.

label: Exercise 4.5.26
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field. Suppose that $\theta\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is such that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ is squarefree. Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$.
solution: Let $m=[\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}[\theta]]$. Then, by Exercise 4.2.8, $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)=m^{2}d_{K}$. If $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ is squarefree, $m=1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.1.1}
question: Show that a nonzero commutative ring $R$ with identity is a field if and only if it has no nontrivial ideals.
solution:
If $x \in R$, $x 
eq 0$, is a nonunit, then $1 
otin (x)$, so $(x)$ is a nontrivial ideal. Suppose that $R$ has a nontrivial ideal $\mathfrak{a}$. Let $x \in \mathfrak{a}$, $x 
eq 0$. Then $(x) \subseteq \mathfrak{a}$. If $x$ is a unit, then $1 \in (x) \subseteq \mathfrak{a}$, so $\mathfrak{a} = R$, a contradiction. Thus, $x$ is not a unit, so $R$ is not a field.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.2 (a)}
question: Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. Show that $\mathfrak{m}$ is a maximal ideal if and only if $R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a field.
solution: By the correspondence between ideals of $R$ containing $\mathfrak{m}$ and ideals of $R/\mathfrak{m}$, $R/\mathfrak{m}$ has a nontrivial ideal if and only if there is an ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ of $R$ strictly between $\mathfrak{m}$ and $R$. Thus, $\mathfrak{m}$ is maximal $\iff$ $R/\mathfrak{m}$ has no nontrivial ideals $\iff$ $R/\mathfrak{m}$ is a field.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.2 (b)}
question: Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. Show that $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal if and only if $R/\mathfrak{p}$ is an integral domain.
solution: $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal $\iff$ $ab \in \mathfrak{p} \Rightarrow a \in \mathfrak{p}$ or $b \in \mathfrak{p}$ $\iff$ $ab + \mathfrak{p} = 0 + \mathfrak{p}$ in $R/\mathfrak{p} \Rightarrow a + \mathfrak{p} = 0 + \mathfrak{p}$ or $b + \mathfrak{p} = 0 + \mathfrak{p}$ in $R/\mathfrak{p}$ $\iff$ $R/\mathfrak{p}$ has no zero-divisors $\iff$ $R/\mathfrak{p}$ is an integral domain.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.2 (c)}
question: Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. Let $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ be ideals of $R$. Show that if $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal containing $\mathfrak{ab}$, then $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$ or $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{b}$.
solution:
Suppose that $\mathfrak{p} 
supseteq \mathfrak{a}$. Let $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, $a 
otin \mathfrak{p}$. We know that $ab \in \mathfrak{p}$ for all $b \in \mathfrak{b}$ since $\mathfrak{ab} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}$. But, $a 
otin \mathfrak{p}$. Thus, $b \in \mathfrak{p}$ for all $b \in \mathfrak{b}$, since $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime. Thus, $\mathfrak{b} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.2 (d)}
question: Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity. If $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal containing the product $\mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{a}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{r}$ of $r$ ideals of $R$, show that $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{i}$ for some $i$.
solution: (By induction on $r$). The base case $r=1$ is trivial. Suppose $r>1$ and $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{a}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{r}$. Then from part (c), $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{a}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{r-1}$ or $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{r}$. If $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{a}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{r-1}$, then the induction hypothesis implies that $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{i}$ for some $i \in \{1,...,r-1\}$. In either case, $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{i}$ for some $i \in \{1,...,r\}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.1.3}
question: Show that a finite integral domain is a field.
solution: Let $R$ be a finite integral domain. Let $x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n}$ be the elements of $R$. Suppose that $x_{i}x_{j}=x_{i}x_{k}$, for some $x_{i} \ne 0$. Then $x_{i}(x_{j}-x_{k})=0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain, $x_{j}=x_{k}$, so $j=k$. Thus, for any $x_{i} \ne 0$, $\{x_{i}x_{1},x_{i}x_{2},...,x_{i}x_{n}\}=\{x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n}\}$. Since $1 \in R$, there exists $x_{j}$ such that $x_{i}x_{j}=1$. Therefore, $x_{i}$ is invertible. Thus all nonzero elements are invertible, so $R$ is a field.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.1.4}
question: Show that every nonzero prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is maximal.
solution: $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}$ is finite from Exercise 4.4.3 and it is an integral domain from Theorem 5.1.2 (b). Thus, Exercise 5.1.3 shows that $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}$ is a field, which in turn implies that $\mathfrak{p}$ is a maximal ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.1.5}
question: Show that every unique factorization domain is integrally closed.
solution: Let $R$ be a unique factorization domain, $\alpha \in Q(R)$. Then $\alpha=a/b$, for some $a, b \in R$ with $(a,b)=1$. If $\alpha$ is integral over $R$, then we have a polynomial equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{n-1}\alpha^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{0}=0$, $c_{i} \in R$. Thus, multiplying through by $b^{n}$ and isolating $a^{n}$, we have $a^{n}=-b(c_{n-1}a^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{1}ab^{n-2}+c_{0}b^{n-1})$. Thus, $b|a^{n}$. But, $(a,b)=1$. By unique factorization, $(a^{n},b)=1$. Therefore, $b$ is a unit in $R$, so $a/b \in R$. Thus, $R$ is integrally closed.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.6 (1) implies (2)}
question: For $\alpha \in \mathbb{C}$, show that if $\alpha$ is integral over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$ is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module.
solution: Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{C}$ be integral over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Say $\alpha$ satisfies a monic polynomial of degree $n$ over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Then $\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]=\mathcal{O}_{K}+\mathcal{O}_{K}\alpha+\mathcal{O}_{K}\alpha^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathcal{O}_{K}\alpha^{n-1}$ and so is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.6 (2) implies (3)}
question: For $\alpha \in \mathbb{C}$, show that if $\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$ is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module, then there is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module $M \subseteq \mathbb{C}$ such that $\alpha M \subseteq M$.
solution: Certainly, $\alpha \mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha] \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$, so if $\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$ is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module, then the condition is satisfied with $M=\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.6 (3) implies (1)}
question: For $\alpha \in \mathbb{C}$, show that if there is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module $M \subseteq \mathbb{C}$ such that $\alpha M \subseteq M$, then $\alpha$ is integral over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: Let $u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n}$ generate $M$ as an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module. Then $\alpha u_{i} \in M$ for all $i=1,2,...,n$ since $\alpha M \subseteq M$. Let $\alpha u_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}u_{j}$ for $i \in \{1,2,...,n\}$, $a_{ij} \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Let $A=(a_{ij})$, $B=\alpha I_{n}-A=(b_{ij})$. Then $\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{ij}u_{j}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}(\alpha\delta_{ij}-a_{ij})u_{j} = \alpha u_{i}-\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}u_{j} = 0$ for all $i$. Thus, $B(u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n})^{T}=(0,0,...,0)^{T}$. But $(0,0,...,0)^{T} \ne (u_{1},u_{2},...,u_{n})^{T} \in \mathbb{C}^{n}$. Thus, $\det(B)=0$. But, the determinant of $B$ is a monic polynomial in $\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$, so $\alpha$ is integral over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.1.7}
question: Prove that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is integrally closed.
solution: If $\alpha \in K$ is integral over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then let $M=\mathcal{O}_{K}u_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathcal{O}_{K}u_{n}$ with $\alpha M \subseteq M$. Let $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}v_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}v_{m}$ where $\{v_{1},...,v_{m}\}$ is a basis for $K$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Then $M=\sum_{i=1}^{m}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\mathbb{Z}v_{i}u_{j}$ is a finitely generated $\mathbb{Z}$-module with $\alpha M \subseteq M$ so $\alpha$ is integral over $\mathbb{Z}$. By definition, $\alpha \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.2.1}
question: If $\mathfrak{a} \subsetneq \mathfrak{b}$ are ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, show that $N(\mathfrak{a}) > N(\mathfrak{b})$.
solution: Define a map $f:\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{a} \longrightarrow \mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{b}$ by $f(x+\mathfrak{a})=x+\mathfrak{b}$. If $x+\mathfrak{a}=y+\mathfrak{a}$, then $x-y \in \mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathfrak{b}$, so $x+\mathfrak{b}=y+\mathfrak{b}$. Thus, $f$ is well-defined. The function $f$ is not one-to-one since for any $y \in \mathfrak{b}\backslash\mathfrak{a}$, $f(y+\mathfrak{a})=0$ but $y+\mathfrak{a} \ne 0$. It is onto since $x+\mathfrak{b}=f(x+\mathfrak{a})$. So we have a map from the finite set $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{a}$ to the finite set $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{b}$ which is onto but not one-to-one. Thus $|\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{a}| > |\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{b}|$ i.e., $N(\mathfrak{a}) > N(\mathfrak{b})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.2.2}
question: Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is Noetherian.
solution: Suppose that $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subsetneq \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subsetneq \mathfrak{a}_{3} \subsetneq \cdot\cdot\cdot$ is an ascending chain of ideals which does not terminate. Then $N(\mathfrak{a}_{1}) > N(\mathfrak{a}_{2}) > N(\mathfrak{a}_{3}) > \cdot\cdot\cdot$ but $N(\mathfrak{a}_{i})$ is finite and positive for all $i$, so such a strictly decreasing sequence of positive integers must stop. Thus, the ascending chain of ideals must terminate.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.2.3 (1) implies (2)}
question: For any commutative ring $R$ with identity, show that if $R$ is Noetherian, then every nonempty set of ideals contains a maximal element.
solution: Suppose that $S$ is a nonempty set of ideals of $R$ that does not contain a maximal element. Let $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \in S$. $\mathfrak{a}_{1}$ is not maximal in $S$, so there is an $\mathfrak{a}_{2} \in S$ with $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subsetneq \mathfrak{a}_{2}$. $\mathfrak{a}_{2}$ is not a maximal element of $S$, so there exists an $\mathfrak{a}_{3} \in S$ with $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subsetneq \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subsetneq \mathfrak{a}_{3}$. Continuing in this way, we find an infinite ascending chain of ideals of $R$. This contradicts $R$ being Noetherian, so every nonempty set of ideals contains a maximal element.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.2.3 (2) implies (3)}
question: For any commutative ring $R$ with identity, show that if every nonempty set of ideals contains a maximal element, then every ideal of $R$ is finitely generated.
solution: Let $\mathfrak{b}$ be an ideal of $R$. Let $A$ be the set of ideals contained in $\mathfrak{b}$ which are finitely generated. $A$ is nonempty, since $(0) \in A$. Thus, $A$ has a maximal element, say $\mathfrak{a}=(x_{1},...,x_{n})$. If $\mathfrak{a} \ne \mathfrak{b}$, then $\exists x \in \mathfrak{b}\backslash\mathfrak{a}$. But then $\mathfrak{a}+(x)=(x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n},x)$ is a larger finitely generated ideal contained in $\mathfrak{b}$, contradicting the maximality of $\mathfrak{a}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{a}$, so $\mathfrak{b}$ is finitely generated.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.2.3 (3) implies (1)}
question: For any commutative ring $R$ with identity, show that if every ideal of $R$ is finitely generated, then $R$ is Noetherian.
solution: Let $\mathfrak{a}_{1} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}_{2} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}_{3} \subseteq \cdot\cdot\cdot$ be an ascending chain of ideals of $R$. Then $\mathfrak{a}=\bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty}\mathfrak{a}_{i}$ is also an ideal of $R$, and so is finitely generated, say $\mathfrak{a}=(x_{1},...,x_{n})$. Then $x_{1} \in \mathfrak{a}_{i_{1}},...,x_{n} \in \mathfrak{a}_{i_{n}}$. Let $m=\max(i_{1},...,i_{n})$. Then $\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}_{m}$, so $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{a}_{m}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{a}_{m}=\mathfrak{a}_{m+1}=\cdot\cdot\cdot$, and the chain does terminate. Thus, $R$ is Noetherian.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.2.4}
question: Show that any principal ideal domain is a Dedekind domain.
solution: Let $R$ be a principal ideal domain. $R$ is Noetherian since every ideal is finitely generated. $R$ is integrally closed since any principal ideal domain is a unique factorization domain, and so is integrally closed by Exercise 5.1.5. Let $(p) \ne 0$ be a prime ideal and $(x) \supseteq (p)$. Then, $p \in (x)$, so $p=xy$, for some $y \in R$. Thus, $xy \in (p)$, so $x \in (p)$ or $y \in (p)$. If $x \in (p)$, then $(x)=(p)$, and if $y \in (p)$, then $y=pq$ for some $q \in R$. This would imply that $p=xy=xqp$ and so $xq=1$ since $R$ is an integral domain. Thus, $(x)=R$. Therefore, $(p)$ is maximal. Thus, $R$ is a Dedekind domain.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.2.5}
question: Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ is a Dedekind domain, but not a principal ideal domain.
solution: $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ is not a unique factorization domain as was seen in Chapter 2 by taking $6=2\times3=(1+\sqrt{-5})(1-\sqrt{-5})$, and so cannot be a principal ideal domain. To see that it is a Dedekind domain, it is enough to show that it is the set of algebraic integers of the algebraic number field $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$. However, we have already proved this, in Exercise 4.1.3. So $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ is a Dedekind domain.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.1}
question: Show that any fractional ideal is finitely generated as an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module.
solution: Let $\mathcal{A}$ be a fractional ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Choose $m \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $m\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Since $\mathcal{A}$ is an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module, $m\mathcal{A}$ is an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module contained in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and so is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Since $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is Noetherian, $m\mathcal{A}$ is finitely generated as an ideal. If $m\mathcal{A}$ is generated as an ideal by $\{a_{1},...,a_{n}\}$, then $\mathcal{A}$ is generated by $\{m^{-1}a_{1},...,m^{-1}a_{n}\}$ as an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module. Thus, $\mathcal{A}$ is finitely generated as an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.2}
question: Show that the sum and product of two fractional ideals are again fractional ideals.
solution: Let $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ be fractional ideals. Since $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ are both $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-modules, so are their sum and product. Let $m\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$, $n\mathcal{B} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$ with $m, n \in \mathbb{Z}$. Then $mn(\mathcal{AB})=(m\mathcal{A})(n\mathcal{B}) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$, so $\mathcal{AB}$ is a fractional ideal. Also, $mn(\mathcal{A}+\mathcal{B})=n(m\mathcal{A})+m(n\mathcal{B}) \subseteq n\mathcal{O}_{K}+m\mathcal{O}_{K} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$, so $\mathcal{A}+\mathcal{B}$ is a fractional ideal.

label: \label{ques: Lemma 5.3.3}
question: Show that any proper ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ contains a product of nonzero prime ideals.
solution:
Let $S$ be the set of all proper ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ that do not contain a product of prime ideals. We need to show that $S$ is empty. If not, then since $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is Noetherian, $S$ has a maximal element, say $\mathfrak{a}$. Then, $\mathfrak{a}$ is not prime since $\mathfrak{a} \in S$ so there exist $a,b \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, with $ab \in \mathfrak{a}$, $a 
otin \mathfrak{a}$, $b 
otin \mathfrak{a}$. Then, $(\mathfrak{a},a) \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$ and $(\mathfrak{a},b) \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$. Thus, $(\mathfrak{a},a) 
otin S$, $(\mathfrak{a},b) 
otin S$, by the maximality of $\mathfrak{a}$. Thus, $(\mathfrak{a},a) \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}$ and $(\mathfrak{a},b) \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{s}^{\prime}$, with the $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$ and $\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{\prime}$ nonzero prime ideals. But $ab \in \mathfrak{a}$, so $(\mathfrak{a},ab)=\mathfrak{a}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{a}=(\mathfrak{a},ab) \supseteq (\mathfrak{a},a)(\mathfrak{a},b) \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{s}^{\prime}$. Therefore $\mathfrak{a}$ contains a product of prime ideals. This contradicts $\mathfrak{a}$ being in $S$, so $S$ must actually be empty.

label: \label{ques: Lemma 5.3.4}
question: Let $\mathfrak{p}$ be a prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Show that there exists $z \in K$, $z \notin \mathcal{O}_{K}$, such that $z\mathfrak{p} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution:
Take $x \in \mathfrak{p}$. From Lemma 5.3.3, $(x)=x\mathcal{O}_{K}$ contains a product of prime ideals. Let $r$ be the least integer such that $(x)$ contains a product of $r$ prime ideals, and say $(x) \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}$ with the $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$ nonzero prime ideals. Since $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}$, $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{i}$, for some $i$, from Theorem 5.1.2 (d). Without loss of generality, we can assume that $i=1$, so $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}$. But $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ is a nonzero prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, and so is maximal. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}$. Now, $\mathfrak{p}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r} 
otin (x)$, since $r$ was chosen to be minimal. Choose an element $b \in \mathfrak{p}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}$, $b

Then $bx^{-1}\mathfrak{p}=bx^{-1}\mathfrak{p}_{1} \subseteq (\mathfrak{p}_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r})(x^{-1}\mathfrak{p}_{1}) = x^{-1}(\mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}) \subseteq x^{-1}x\mathcal{O}_{K} = \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Let $z=bx^{-1}$. Then $z\mathfrak{p} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Now, if $z$ were in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, we would have $bx^{-1} \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, and so $b \in x\mathcal{O}_{K}$. But this is not the case, so $z

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.5}
question: Let $\mathfrak{p}$ be a prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Show that $\mathfrak{p}^{-1}$ is a fractional ideal and $\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{p}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.6}
question: Show that any ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ can be written as a product of prime ideals uniquely.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.7}
question: Show that any fractional ideal $\mathcal{A}$ can be written uniquely in the form $\frac{\mathfrak{p}_{1}...\mathfrak{p}_{r}}{\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}...\mathfrak{p}_{s}^{\prime}}$ where the $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$ and $\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{\prime}$ may be repeated, but no $\mathfrak{p}_{i}=\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{\prime}$.
solution: Choose a nonzero element $c \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $\mathfrak{b}:=c\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Let $(c)=\mathfrak{m}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{m}_{s}$, $\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{n}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{n}_{t}$, the $\mathfrak{m}_{i}$, $\mathfrak{n}_{j}$ prime. Then $(c)\mathcal{A}=\mathfrak{b}$, so $\mathcal{A}=\frac{\mathfrak{n}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{n}_{t}}{\mathfrak{m}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{m}_{s}}$ and cancelling the primes on the numerator that equal some prime on the denominator, we have that $\mathfrak{m}_{i} \ne \mathfrak{n}_{j} \forall i,j$. Also, if $\mathcal{A}=\frac{\mathfrak{a}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{v}}{\mathfrak{b}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{b}_{w}}$ with no $\mathfrak{a}_{i}=\mathfrak{b}_{j}$, then $\mathfrak{a}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{a}_{v}\mathfrak{m}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{m}_{s}=\mathfrak{b}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{b}_{w}\mathfrak{n}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{n}_{t}$. By unique factorization and the fact that no $\mathfrak{b}_{i}$ is an $\mathfrak{a}_{j}$ and no $\mathfrak{m}_{i}$ is an $\mathfrak{n}_{j}$, the $\mathfrak{b}_{i}$ must coincide up to reordering with the $\mathfrak{m}_{j}$'s and the $\mathfrak{a}_{i}$ with the $\mathfrak{n}_{j}$'s, and so the factorization is unique.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.8}
question: Show that, given any fractional ideal $\mathcal{A} \ne 0$ in $K$, there exists a fractional ideal $\mathcal{A}^{-1}$ such that $\mathcal{AA}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: Let $\mathcal{A}=\frac{\mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}}{\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{s}^{\prime}}.$ Then $\mathcal{A}^{-1}=\frac{\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{s}^{\prime}}{\mathfrak{p}_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}}$ is a fractional ideal with $\mathcal{AA}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.9}
question: Show that if $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\mathfrak{b} | \mathfrak{a}$ (where divisibility denotes $\mathfrak{b} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$) if and only if there is an ideal $\mathfrak{c}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ with $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{bc}$.
solution: If $\mathfrak{b} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$, then $\mathfrak{c}:=\mathfrak{ab}^{-1} \subseteq \mathfrak{bb}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{bc},$ with $\mathfrak{c}$ an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. If $\mathfrak{a} = \mathfrak{bc}$ with $\mathfrak{c} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$, then $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{bc} \subseteq \mathfrak{b}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.10}
question: Let $\mathfrak{a}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{f_{i}}$ with $e_i, f_i \in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}$. Show that $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})=\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}$.
solution: $\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$, $\mathfrak{b} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$, so $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{b}$. If $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{b}$ then $\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathfrak{e}$, $\mathfrak{b} \subseteq \mathfrak{e}$, so that $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b} \subseteq \mathfrak{e}$ i.e., $\mathfrak{e} | \mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$. Therefore, $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}=\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})$. Let $\mathfrak{d}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{\min(e_{i},f_{i})}$, and let $\min(e_{i},f_{i})=a_{i}$. $\mathfrak{a}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}} = \prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}-a_{i}}\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{a_{i}} = \prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}-a_{i}}\mathfrak{d},$ $e_{i}-a_{i} \ge 0$ $\forall i$. Thus, $\mathfrak{d} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}$ which implies that $\mathfrak{d}|\mathfrak{a}$. Similarly, $\mathfrak{d} | \mathfrak{b}$. Suppose that $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{b}$. Let $\mathfrak{c}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{k_{i}}$ ($k_{i} \ge 0$) be the unique factorization of $\mathfrak{e}$ as a product of prime ideals. Suppose $k_{i} > e_{i}$ for some $i \in \{1,...,r\}$. We know that $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{a}$ and so $\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathfrak{e}$, i.e., $\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{k_{i}} \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}_{i} \supseteq \mathfrak{p}_{j}$ for some $j \ne i$ or $k_i \le e_i$. Since $\mathfrak{p}_i$ are distinct, we must have $k_{i} \le e_{i}$ for all $i$. Similarly for $\mathfrak{b}$, so $k_{i} \le \min(e_{i},f_{i})$. Thus, $\mathfrak{e}|\mathfrak{d}$ so $\mathfrak{d}=\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.11}
question: Let $\mathfrak{a}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{f_{i}}$ with $e_i, f_i \in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}$. Show that $\text{lcm}(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})=\mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}$.
solution: $\mathfrak{a} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}$, $\mathfrak{b} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}$ so $\mathfrak{a}|\mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}, \mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}$. Suppose that $\mathfrak{a}|\mathfrak{e}$ and $\mathfrak{b}|\mathfrak{e}$. Then $\mathfrak{e} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{e} \subseteq \mathfrak{b}$, so $\mathfrak{e} \subseteq \mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{a}\cap\mathfrak{b}=\text{lcm}(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})$. Let $\mathfrak{m}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{\max(e_{i},f_{i})}$ and let $\mathfrak{c}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{k_{i}}\prod_{j=1}^{s}(\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{\prime})^{t_{j}}$. Suppose $k_{i} < e_{i}$ for some $i$. $\mathfrak{e} \subseteq \mathfrak{a} \implies \prod \mathfrak{p}^{k} \prod (\mathfrak{p}')^t \subseteq \prod \mathfrak{p}^e \subseteq \mathfrak{p}_i^{e_i} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}_i$. Thus $\mathfrak{p}_i$ must contain some factor on the left. Since primes are distinct, this implies $k_i \ge e_i$. Similarly $k_i \ge f_i$. Thus $k_i \ge \max(e_i, f_i)$, so $\mathfrak{m} | \mathfrak{e}$. Thus $\mathfrak{m}=\text{lcm}(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.12}
question: Suppose $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}, \mathfrak{c}$ are ideals of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Show that if $\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{c}^{g}$ and $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})=1$ then $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{d}^{g}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{e}^{g}$ for some ideals $\mathfrak{d}$ and $\mathfrak{e}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: We factor uniquely into prime ideals: $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=(\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime})^{f_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(\mathfrak{p}_{t}^{\prime})^{f_{t}}$ where $\mathfrak{p}_{1},...,\mathfrak{p}_{r},\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime},...,\mathfrak{p}_{t}^{\prime}$ are distinct prime ideals since $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})=1.$ Now let $\mathfrak{c}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{a_{r}}(\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime})^{b_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(\mathfrak{p}_{t}^{\prime})^{b_{t}}$. Since $\mathfrak{ab} = \mathfrak{c}^{g}$ we must have $e_{i}=a_{i}g$ ($1\le i\le r$) and $f_{i}=b_{i}g$ ($1\le i\le t$) by unique factorization. Thus $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{d}^{g}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{e}^{g}$ with $\mathfrak{d}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{a_{r}}$ and $\mathfrak{e}=(\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime})^{b_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(\mathfrak{p}_{t}^{\prime})^{b_{t}}$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.13 (a)}
question: Let $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ be ideals so that $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{b})=1$, i.e., $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Given $a, b \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, show that we can solve $x \equiv a \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$, $x \equiv b \pmod{\mathfrak{b}}$.
solution: Since $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$, $\exists x_{1} \in \mathfrak{a},$ $x_{2} \in \mathfrak{b}$ with $x_{1}+x_{2}=1$. Let $x=bx_{1}+ax_{2} \equiv ax_{2} \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$. But, $x_{2}=1-x_{1} \equiv 1 \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$. Thus, we have found an $x$ such that $x \equiv a \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$. Similarly, $x \equiv b \pmod{\mathfrak{b}}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.13 (b)}
question: Let $\mathfrak{p}_{1},...,\mathfrak{p}_{r}$ be distinct prime ideals in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Given $a_{i} \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, $e_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}_{>0}$, show that there exists $x$ such that $x \equiv a_{i} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}}$ for all $i \in \{1,...,r\}$.
solution: We proceed by induction on $r$. If $r=1$, there is nothing to show. Suppose $r>1$, and that we can solve $x \equiv a_{i} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}}$ for $i=1,...,r-1$, say $a \equiv a_{i} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}}$ for $i=1,...,r-1$. From part (a), we can solve $x \equiv a \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r-1}^{e_{r-1}}}$ and $x \equiv a_{r} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}}$. Then $x-a_{i} \in \mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{r-1}^{e_{r-1}}$ and $x \equiv a_{r} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}}$. Thus, $x-a_{i} \in \mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}} \forall i$, i.e., $x \equiv a_{i} \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}} \forall i$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.14}
question: Show that $\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{ab})=\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{a})+\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{b})$ where $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal.
solution: From a previous exercise, $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{p}^{t}\mathfrak{a}_{1}$ and $\mathfrak{b}=\mathfrak{p}^{s}\mathfrak{b}_{1}$, where $\mathfrak{p} \nmid \mathfrak{a}_{1}$, and $\mathfrak{p} \nmid \mathfrak{b}_{1}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{ab}=\mathfrak{p}^{t+s}\mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{b}_{1}$, so $\mathfrak{p}^{s+t} | \mathfrak{ab}$. If $\mathfrak{p}^{s+t+1} | \mathfrak{ab}$, then $\mathfrak{ab}=\mathfrak{p}^{s+t+1}\mathfrak{c}$, so $\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{c}=\mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{b}_{1}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{1}\mathfrak{b}_{1}$, so $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{a}_{1}$ or $\mathfrak{p} \supseteq \mathfrak{b}_{1}$, since $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime. This is a contradiction, so $\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{ab})=t+s=\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{a})+\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\mathfrak{b})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.15}
question: Show that, for $\alpha \ne 0$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, $N((\alpha))=|N_{K}(\alpha)|$.
solution: Let $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}$. There exist $\alpha_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}p_{ij}\omega_{j}$, with $p_{ii}>0$, $p_{ij} \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $(\alpha)=\mathbb{Z}\alpha_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\alpha_{n}$ and $N((\alpha))=p_{11}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{nn},$ from Theorem 4.2.2. We also know that $(\alpha)=\mathbb{Z}\alpha\omega_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\alpha\omega_{n}$. Now, $N_{K}(\alpha)=\det(c_{ij})$ where $\alpha\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}c_{ij}\omega_{j}$. And, if $C=(c_{ij})$, $R=(r_{ij})$, $P=(p_{ij})$, then $(\alpha\omega_{1},...,\alpha\omega_{n})^{T}=C(\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n})^{T} = R(\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n})^{T} = RP(\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n})^{T}$ where $\alpha\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=i}^{n}r_{ji}\alpha_{j}$, $r_{ji} \in \mathbb{Z}$. Therefore, by definition, $N_{K}(\alpha)=\det(RP)=\det(R)\det(P)$. $R$ and $R^{-1}$ have integer entries, since $\{\alpha\omega_{i}\}$ and $\{\alpha_{i}\}$ are both $\mathbb{Z}$-bases for $(\alpha)$. Thus, $\det(R)=\pm 1$. So, $\det(C)=\pm \det(P)$, $\det(P) \ge 0$. Thus, $|\det(C)|=\det(P)$. Thus, $|N_{K}(\alpha)|=|\det(C)|=\det(P)=N((\alpha))$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.16 (a)}
question: If $\mathfrak{a}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}$ show that $N(\mathfrak{a})=\prod_{i=1}^{r}N(\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}).$
solution: Consider the map $\phi:\mathcal{O}_{K}\longrightarrow\bigoplus_{i=1}^{r}(\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}})$ defined by $x \longrightarrow (x_{1},...,x_{r})$ where $x_{i} \equiv x \pmod{\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}}$. The function is surjective by the Chinese Remainder Theorem, and is a homomorphism since each of the $r$ components is a homomorphism. Next, we show by induction that $\bigcap_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}$. The base case $r=1$ is trivial. Suppose $r>1$, and that the result is true for numbers smaller than $r$. $\bigcap_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}} = \text{lcm}(\bigcap_{i=1}^{r-1}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}},\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}) = \text{lcm}(\prod_{i=1}^{r-1}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}},\mathfrak{p}_{r}^{e_{r}}) = \prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}.$ Thus, $\ker(\phi)=\bigcap_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}=\prod_{i=1}^{r}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}$, which implies that $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{a} \simeq \oplus(\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}).$ Hence, $N(\mathfrak{a})=\prod_{i=1}^{r}N(\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}})$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.3.16 (b)}
question: Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p} \simeq \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}$ and $N(\mathfrak{p}^{e})=(N(\mathfrak{p}))^{e}$ for any integer $e \ge 0$.
solution: Since $\mathfrak{p}^{e} \subsetneq \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}$, we can find an element $\alpha \in \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e},$ so that $\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\alpha)=e-1$. Then $\mathfrak{p}^{e} \subseteq (\alpha)+\mathfrak{p}^{e} \subseteq \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}$. So $\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}|(\alpha)+\mathfrak{p}^{e}$. But $(\alpha)+\mathfrak{p}^{e} \ne \mathfrak{p}^{e}$ so $\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}=(\alpha)+\mathfrak{p}^{e},$ by unique factorization. Define the map $\phi:\mathcal{O}_{K}\longrightarrow\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}$ by $\phi(\gamma)=\gamma\alpha+\mathfrak{p}^{e}$. This is clearly a homomorphism and is surjective since $\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}=(\alpha)+\mathfrak{p}^{e}$. Now, $\gamma \in \ker(\phi) \iff \gamma\alpha \in \mathfrak{p}^{e} \iff \text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\gamma\alpha) \ge e \iff \text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\gamma)+\text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\alpha) \ge e \iff \text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\gamma)+e-1 \ge e \iff \text{ord}_{\mathfrak{p}}(\gamma) \ge 1 \iff \gamma \in \mathfrak{p}$. Thus, $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p} \simeq \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}$. Also, $(\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e})/(\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}) \simeq \mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}$ since the map from $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}$ to $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}$ taking $x+\mathfrak{p}^{e}$ to $x+\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}$ is a surjective homomorphism with kernel $\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}$. Thus, $N(\mathfrak{p}^{e})=|\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}|=|\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}| |\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}/\mathfrak{p}^{e}| = N(\mathfrak{p}^{e-1})N(\mathfrak{p}) = N(\mathfrak{p})^{e-1}N(\mathfrak{p}) = N(\mathfrak{p})^{e}$ by the induction hypothesis.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.3.17}
question: If we write $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ as its prime factorization, $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}$, show that $N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})$ is a power of $p$ and that if $N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})=p^{f_{i}}$ then $\sum_{i=1}^{g}e_{i}f_{i}=n$.
solution: Since $\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}}+\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{e_{j}}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$ for $i \ne j$, $\mathcal{O}_{K}/p\mathcal{O}_{K} \simeq \mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}} \oplus \cdot\cdot\cdot \oplus \mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}$, by the Chinese Remainder Theorem. Therefore $p^{n}=N(\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}})\cdot\cdot\cdot N(\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}) = N(\mathfrak{p}_{1})^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot N(\mathfrak{p}_{g})^{e_{g}}$. Thus, $N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})=p^{f_{i}}$ for some positive integer $f_{i},$ and $n=e_{1}f_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+e_{g}f_{g}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.4.1}
question: Let $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\{x \in K : \text{Tr}(x\mathcal{O}_{K}) \subseteq \mathbb{Z}\}$. Show that $\mathcal{D}^{-1}$ is a fractional ideal of $K$ and find an integral basis.
solution: $\mathcal{D}^{-1}$ is an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module since if $x \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $y \in \mathcal{D}^{-1}$, then $xy \in \mathcal{D}^{-1}$ because $\text{Tr}(xy\mathcal{O}_{K}) \subseteq \text{Tr}(y\mathcal{O}_{K}) \subseteq \mathbb{Z}$. Thus, $\mathcal{O}_{K}\mathcal{D}^{-1} \subseteq \mathcal{D}^{-1}$. Now, let $\{\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}\}$ be an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. There is a dual basis $\{\omega_{1}^{*},...,\omega_{n}^{*}\}$ such that $\text{Tr}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j}^{*})=\delta_{ij}$, $1 \le i, j \le n$. Now $\text{Tr}(\omega_{i}^{*}\omega_{j}) \in \mathbb{Z}$ for all $\omega_{j}$, $\omega_{i}^{*}$, so $\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*} \subseteq \mathcal{D}^{-1}$. We claim that $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}$. Let $x \in \mathcal{D}^{-1}$. Then $x=\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\omega_{i}^{*},$ $a_{i} \in \mathbb{Q}$, $\text{Tr}(x\omega_{j})=\text{Tr}(\sum_{i=1}^{r}a_{i}\omega_{i}^{*}\omega_{j})=a_{j} \in \mathbb{Z}$ since $\{\omega_{1}^{*},...,\omega_{n}^{*}\}$ is a $\mathbb{Q}$-basis for $K$. Therefore $x \in \mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}$. Therefore $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathbb{Z}\omega_{1}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}\omega_{n}^{*}$. Since for each $\omega_{i}^{*}$ there is an $a_{i} \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $a_{i}\omega_{i}^{*} \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, if we let $m=\prod_{i=1}^{n}a_{i},$ then $m\mathcal{D}^{-1} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, $\mathcal{D}^{-1}$ is a fractional ideal.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.4.2}
question: Let $\mathcal{D}$ be the fractional ideal inverse of $\mathcal{D}^{-1}$. We call $\mathcal{D}$ the different of $K$. Show that $\mathcal{D}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: $\mathcal{D}$ is certainly a fractional ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $\mathcal{D}\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$. But, from Lemma 4.1.1, $1 \in \mathcal{D}^{-1}$. Thus, $\mathcal{D} \subseteq \mathcal{D}\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, $\mathcal{D}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.4.3}
question: Let $\mathcal{D}$ be the different of an algebraic number field $K$. Show that $N(\mathcal{D})=|d_{K}|$.
solution: For some $m>0$, $m\mathcal{D}^{-1}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Now, $m\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathbb{Z}m\omega_{1}^{*}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}m\omega_{n}^{*}$. Let $m\omega_{i}^{*}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}\omega_{j},$ so $\omega_{i}^{*}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\frac{a_{ij}}{m}\omega_{j}$ and $\omega_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}b_{ij}\omega_{j}^{*}$. Thus, $(b_{ij})$ is the matrix inverse of $(a_{ij}/m)$. But $\text{Tr}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j})=\text{Tr}(\sum_{k=1}^{n}b_{ik}\omega_{k}^{*}\omega_{j}) = \sum_{k=1}^{n}b_{ik}\text{Tr}(\omega_{k}^{*}\omega_{j}) = b_{ij}$. Thus, $\det(b_{ij})=d_{K}$. However, by Exercise 4.2.8, since $m\mathcal{D}^{-1}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ with integral basis $m\omega_{1}^{*},...,m\omega_{n}^{*}$ we know that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(m\omega_{1}^{*},...,m\omega_{n}^{*})=N(m\mathcal{D}^{-1})^{2}d_{K}$ and from Exercise 4.2.7 we have $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(m\omega_{1}^{*},...,m\omega_{n}^{*})=(\det(a_{ij}))^{2}d_{K}$ which shows that $|\det(a_{ij})|=N(m\mathcal{D}^{-1})=m^{n}N(\mathcal{D}^{-1})$, and thus $|\det(\frac{a_{ij}}{m})|=N(\mathcal{D}^{-1})=N(\mathcal{D})^{-1}$. Hence, $|d_{K}|=|\det(b_{ij})|=|\det(a_{ij}/m)|^{-1}=N(\mathcal{D})$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.4.4}
question: Let $p \in \mathbb{Z}$ be prime, $\mathfrak{p} \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$ a prime ideal and $\mathcal{D}$ the different of $K$. Show that if $\mathfrak{p}^{e}|(p)$, then $\mathfrak{p}^{e-1}|\mathcal{D}$.
solution: We may assume that $e$ is the highest power of $\mathfrak{p}$ dividing $(p)$. So let $(p)=\mathfrak{p}^{e}\mathfrak{a}$, $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{p})=1$. Let $x \in \mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{a}$. Then $x=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}a_{i}$ $p_{i} \in \mathfrak{p},$ $a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}.$ Hence, $x^{p} \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{p}a_{i}^{p} \pmod p,$ and $x^{p^{m}} \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}^{p^{m}}a_{i}^{p^{m}} \pmod p.$ For sufficiently large $m$, $p_{i}^{p^{m}} \in \mathfrak{p}^{e}$, so $x^{p^{m}} \in \mathfrak{p}^{e}$ and thus, $x^{p^{m}} \in \mathfrak{p}^{e}\mathfrak{a}=(p)$. Therefore, $\text{Tr}(x^{p^{m}}) \in p\mathbb{Z},$ which implies that $(\text{Tr}(x))^{p^{m}} \in p\mathbb{Z} \Rightarrow \text{Tr}(x) \in p\mathbb{Z} \Rightarrow \text{Tr}(p^{-1}\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{a}) \subseteq \mathbb{Z} \Rightarrow p^{-1}\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathcal{D}^{-1} \Rightarrow \mathcal{D}p^{-1}\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{a} \subseteq \mathcal{D}\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\mathcal{O}_{K} \Rightarrow \mathcal{D} \subseteq p\mathfrak{p}^{-1}\mathfrak{a}^{-1}=\mathfrak{p}^{e}\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{p}^{-1}\mathfrak{a}^{-1}=\mathfrak{p}^{e-1} \Rightarrow \mathfrak{p}^{e-1}|\mathcal{D}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.4.5}
question: Show that if $p$ is ramified, $p|d_{K}$.
solution: Since $p$ is ramified, $e_{\mathfrak{p}}>1$ for some prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ containing $p$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}|\mathcal{D}$ from the previous theorem, say $\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{a}=\mathcal{D}.$ From the multiplicativity of the norm function, we have $N(\mathfrak{p})N(\mathfrak{a})=N(\mathcal{D})$, so $N(\mathfrak{p})|N(\mathcal{D}).$ Thus, $p^{f_{\mathfrak{p}}}|d_{K}$, and so $p|d_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 5.5.1}
question: Suppose that there is a $\theta \in K$ such that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. Let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\theta$ over $\mathbb{Z}[x]$. Let $p$ be a rational prime, and suppose $f(x) \equiv f_{1}(x)^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot f_{g}(x)^{e_{g}} \pmod p$, where each $f_{i}(x)$ is irreducible in $\mathbb{F}_{p}[x]$. Show that $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}$ where $\mathfrak{p}_{i}=(p,f_{i}(\theta))$ are prime ideals, with $N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})=p^{\deg f_{i}}$.
solution: We first note that $(p,f_{1}(\theta))^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(p,f_{g}(\theta))^{e_{g}} \subseteq p\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus it suffices to show that $(p,f_{i}(\theta))$ is a prime ideal of norm $p^{d_{i}}$ where $d_{i}$ is the degree of $f_{i}$. Now, since $f_{i}(x)$ is irreducible over $\mathbb{F}_{p}$, then $\mathbb{F}_{p}[x]/(f_{i}(x))$ is a field. Also, $\mathbb{Z}[x]/(p) \simeq \mathbb{F}_{p}[x] \Rightarrow \mathbb{Z}[x]/(p, f_{i}(x)) \simeq \mathbb{F}_{p}[x]/(f_{i}(x)),$ and so $\mathbb{Z}[x]/(p,f_{i}(x))$ is a field. Consider the map $\varphi:\mathbb{Z}[x]\rightarrow\mathbb{Z}[\theta]/(p,f_{i}(\theta))$. Clearly $(p,f_{i}(x)) \subseteq \ker(\varphi)=\{n(x):n(\theta) \in (p,f_{i}(\theta))\}$. If $n(x) \in \ker(\varphi)$, we can divide by $f_{i}(x)$ to get $n(x)=q(x)f_{i}(x)+r_{i}(x)$, $\deg(r_{i})<\deg(f_{i})$. We assume that $r_{i}$ is nonzero, for otherwise the result is trivial. Since $n(\theta) \in (p,f_{i}(\theta))$, then $r_{i}(\theta) \in (p,f_{i}(\theta))$ so $r_{i}(\theta)=pa(\theta)+f_{i}(\theta)b(\theta)$. Here we have used the fact that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. Now define the polynomial $h(x)=r_{i}(x)-pa(x)-f_{i}(x)b(x)$. Since $h(\theta)=0$ and $f$ is the minimal polynomial of $\theta$, then $h(x)=g(x)f(x)$ for some polynomial $g(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$. We conclude that $r_{i}(x)=p\tilde{a}(x)+f_{i}(x)\tilde{b}(x)$ for some $\tilde{a}(x),\tilde{b}(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$. Therefore $r_{i}(x) \in (p,f_{i}(x))$. Thus, $\mathbb{Z}[\theta]/(p,f_{i}(\theta)) \simeq \mathbb{Z}[x]/(p,f_{i}(x)) \simeq \mathbb{F}_{p}[x]/(f_{i}(x))$ and is therefore a field. Hence, $(p,f_{i}(\theta))$ is a maximal ideal and is therefore prime. Now, let $e_{i}^{\prime}$ be the ramification index of $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$, so that $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}^{\prime}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}^{\prime}}$ and let $d_{i}=[\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}_{i}:\mathbb{Z}/p].$ Clearly $d_{i}$ is the degree of the polynomial $f_{i}(x).$ Since $f(\theta)=0$ and since $f(x)-f_{1}(x)^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot f_{g}(x)^{e_{g}} \in p\mathbb{Z}[x]$, it follows that $f_{1}(\theta)^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot f_{g}(\theta)^{e_{g}} \in p\mathcal{O}_{K}=p\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. Also, $\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{e_{i}} \subset p\mathcal{O}_{K}+(f_{i}(\theta)^{e_{i}})$ and so $\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}} \subseteq p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}^{\prime}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}^{\prime}}$. Therefore, $e_{i} \ge e_{i}^{\prime}$ for all $i$. But $\sum e_{i}d_{i}=\deg f=[K:\mathbb{Q}]=\sum e_{i}^{\prime}d_{i}$. Thus, $e_{i}=e_{i}^{\prime}$ for all $i$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.5.2}
question: If in the previous theorem (Theorem 5.5.1) we do not assume that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$ but instead that $p \nmid [\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}[\theta]]$, show that the same result holds.
solution: Let $m$ be the index of $\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$ in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Then for $\alpha \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$, $m\alpha \in \mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. In other words, given any $\alpha$, we may write $m\alpha=b_{0}+b_{1}\theta+b_{2}\theta^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n-1}\theta^{n-1}$. Consider this expression mod $p$. Since $m$ is coprime to $p$ there is an $m^{\prime}$ such that $m^{\prime}m \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Then $\alpha \equiv b_{0}m^{\prime}+b_{1}m^{\prime}\theta+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n-1}m^{\prime}\theta^{n-1} \pmod p.$ Thus, $\mathcal{O}_{K} \equiv \mathbb{Z}[\theta] \pmod p$. In the proof of the previous exercise, we only used the fact that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$ at one point. This was when we wrote that $r_{i}(\theta)=pa(\theta)+f_{i}(\theta)b(\theta)$. We now note that we simply need that $r_{i}(\theta) \equiv pa(\theta)+f_{i}(\theta)b(\theta) \pmod p$. The proof will follow through in the same way, and we deduce that $(p,f_{i}(\theta))$ is a prime ideal of $\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. However, since $\mathcal{O}_{K}/(p) \simeq \mathbb{Z}[\theta]/(p)$, then $\mathcal{O}_{K}/(p,f_{i}(\theta)) \simeq \mathbb{Z}[\theta]/(p,f_{i}(\theta)).$ The rest of the proof will be identical to what was written above.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.5.3}
question: Suppose that $f(x)$ in the previous exercise (Theorem 5.5.1/Exercise 5.5.2) is Eisensteinian with respect to the prime $p$. Show that $p$ ramifies totally in $K$. That is, $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=(\mathfrak{p})^{n}$ where $n=[K:\mathbb{Q}]$.
solution: By Example 4.3.1, we know that $p \nmid [\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}[\theta]]$. Moreover, $f(x) \equiv x^{n} \pmod p$. The result is now immediate from Exercise 5.5.2.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.5.4}
question: Show that $(p)=(1-\zeta_{p})^{p-1}$ when $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$.
solution: The minimal polynomial of $\zeta_{p}$ is $\Phi_{p}(x)$, the $p$th cyclotomic polynomial. Recall that $f(x)=\Phi_{p}(x+1)$ is $p$-Eisensteinian, and that $\zeta_{p}-1$ is a root. Since $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})=\mathbb{Q}(1-\zeta_{p}),$ and $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{p}]=\mathbb{Z}[1-\zeta_{p}]$, the previous exercise tells us that $(p)=(1-\zeta_{p})^{p-1}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.1}
question: Show that if a ring $R$ is a Dedekind domain and a unique factorization domain, then it is a principal ideal domain.
solution: Consider an arbitrary prime ideal $I$ of $R$. Since $R$ is a Dedekind domain, $I$ is finitely generated and we can write $I=(a_{1},...,a_{n})$ for some set of generators $a_{1},...,a_{n}$. In a unique factorization domain, every pair of elements has a gcd, and so $d=\gcd(a_{1},...,a_{n})$ exists. Then $(d)=(a_{1},...,a_{n})=I$, thus proving that $R$ is a principal ideal domain.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.2}
question: Using Theorem 5.5.1, find a prime ideal factorization of $5\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $7\mathcal{O}_{K}$ in $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-3})/2]$.
solution: We now consider $f(x)$ (mod 7). We have $x^{2}-x+1 \equiv x^{2}+6x+1 \equiv (x+2)(x+4) \pmod 7$ so 7 splits and its factorization is $(7)=(7,\frac{5+\sqrt{-3}}{2})(7,\frac{9+\sqrt{-3}}{2})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.3}
question: Find a prime ideal factorization of (2), (5), (11) in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$.
solution: The minimal polynomial of $i$ is $x^{2}+1$. We consider it first mod 2. $x^{2}+1 \equiv (x+1)^{2} \pmod 2$, so $(2)=(2,i+1)^{2}=(i+1)^{2}$ since $2i=(i+1)^{2}$. $x^{2}+1 \equiv x^{2}-4 \equiv (x+2)(x-2) \pmod 5$, so $(5)=(5,i+2)(5,i-2)=(i+2)(i-2)$ since $(2+i)(2-i)=5$. Finally, we consider $f(x) \pmod{11}$. Since if the polynomial reduces it must have an integral root, we check all the possibilities mod 11 and deduce that it is in fact irreducible. Thus, 11 stays prime in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.4}
question: Compute the different $\mathcal{D}$ of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-2})$.
solution: By Theorem 5.4.3, we know that $N(\mathcal{D})=|d_{K}|=8$. Also, we showed in Chapter 2 that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-2}]$ is Euclidean and thus a principal ideal domain. Then $\mathcal{D}=(a+b\sqrt{-2})$ for some $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$ and $N(\mathcal{D})=a^{2}+2b^{2}=8$. The only solution in integers is $a=0$, $b=\pm 2,$ so $\mathcal{D}=(2\sqrt{-2})=(-2\sqrt{-2})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.5}
question: Compute the different $\mathcal{D}$ of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$.
solution: As in the previous exercise, we first observe that $N(\mathcal{D})=|d_{K}|=3$ and since the integers of this ring are the Eisenstein integers, which form a Euclidean ring, $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is a principal ideal domain and $\mathcal{D}=(a+b\rho)$ for some $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}.$ We must find all solutions to the equation $N(\mathcal{D})=3=a^{2}-ab+b^{2}.$ Since this is equivalent to $(2a-b)^{2}+3b^{2}=12$, we note that $|b|$ cannot be greater than 2. Checking all possibilities, we find all the elements of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ of norm 3: $2+\rho$, $-1+\rho$, $-2-\rho,$ $1-\rho$, $1+2\rho$ and $-1-2\rho$. Some further checking reveals that these six elements are all associates, and so they each generate the same principal ideal. Thus, $\mathcal{D}=(2+\rho)$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.6}
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ be an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Suppose $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ and that $f(x)$ is the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$. Write $f(x)=(x-\alpha)(b_{0}+b_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n-1}x^{n-1})$, $b_{i} \in \mathcal{O}_{K}$. Prove that the dual basis to $1,\alpha,...,\alpha^{n-1}$ is $\frac{b_{0}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)},...,\frac{b_{n-1}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}$ and deduce that $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}(\mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}).$
solution: Let $\alpha_{1}=\alpha,\alpha_{2},...,\alpha_{n}$ be the $n$ distinct roots of $f(x)$. We would like to show that $\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{f(x)}{x-\alpha_{i}}\cdot\frac{\alpha_{i}^{r}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha_{i})}=x^{r}$ for $0 \le r \le n-1$. Define the polynomial $g_{r}(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{f(x)}{x-\alpha_{i}}\cdot\frac{\alpha_{i}^{r}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha_{i})}-x^{r}.$ Consider $g_{r}(\alpha_{1})$. Note that $f(\alpha_{1})/(\alpha_{1}-\alpha_{i})=0$ for all $i$ except $i=1.$ Also, $(\frac{f(x)}{x-\alpha_{1}})_{x=\alpha_{1}}=f^{\prime}(\alpha_{1}).$ Thus, $g_{r}(\alpha_{1})=0$, and similarly, $g_{r}(\alpha_{i})=0$ for $1 \le i \le n$. Since $\deg(g_{r}(x)) \le n-1$, it can have at most $n-1$ roots. As we found $n$ distinct roots, $g_{r}(x)$ must be identically zero. For a polynomial $h(x)=c_{0}+c_{1}x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{m}x^{m} \in K[x]$ we define the trace of $h(x)$ to be $\text{Tr}(h(x))=\sum_{i=0}^{m}\text{Tr}(c_{i})x^{i} \in \mathbb{Q}[x].$ Since $\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}$ are all the conjugates of $\alpha$, it is clear that $\text{Tr}(\frac{f(x)\alpha^{r}}{(x-\alpha)f^{\prime}(\alpha)})=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\frac{f(x)\alpha_{i}^{r}}{(x-\alpha_{i})f^{\prime}(\alpha_{i})}=x^{r}.$ But, $\text{Tr}(\frac{f(x)\alpha^{r}}{(x-\alpha)f^{\prime}(\alpha)})=\sum_{i=0}^{n-1}\text{Tr}(\frac{b_{i}\alpha^{r}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)})x^{i}=x^{r}.$ Thus, $\text{Tr}(\frac{b_{i}\alpha^{r}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)})=0$ unless $i=r$ in which case the trace is 1. Recall that if $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ is a basis, its dual basis $\omega_{1}^{*},...,\omega_{n}^{*}$ is characterized by $\text{Tr}(\omega_{i}\omega_{j}^{*})=\delta_{ij},$ the Kronecker delta function. Thus, we have found a dual basis to $1,\alpha,...,\alpha^{n-1}$ and it is $\frac{b_{0}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)},...,\frac{b_{n-1}}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}.$ By Exercise 5.4.1, $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}(\mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}).$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.7}
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ be of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Suppose that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\alpha].$ Prove that $\mathcal{D}=(f^{\prime}(\alpha))$.
solution: Let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$, and let $f(x)=(x-\alpha)(b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+b_{n-1}x^{n-1})$. Since $f(x)$ is monic, $b_{n-1}=1.$ Also, $a_{n-1}=b_{n-2}-\alpha b_{n-1}$ which means that $b_{n-2}=a_{n-1}+\alpha$, where $a_{n-1}$ is an integer. We know from the previous exercise that $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}(\mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}).$ Since $b_{n-1}=1,\mathbb{Z} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}$. Since $b_{n-2}=a_{n-1}+\alpha,$ we can deduce that $\alpha \in \mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}$ and by considering the expressions for $a_{i}$, $0 \le i \le n$, we see that in fact $\alpha^{i} \in \mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1}$ for $1 \le i \le n-1.$ Thus, $\mathbb{Z}[\alpha] \subseteq \mathbb{Z}b_{0}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}b_{n-1} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ and so we have equality. Thus, $\mathcal{D}^{-1}=\frac{1}{f^{\prime}(\alpha)}\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and so $\mathcal{D}=(f^{\prime}(\alpha))$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.8}
question: Compute the different $\mathcal{D}$ of $\mathbb{Q}[\zeta_{p}]$ where $\zeta_{p}$ is a primitive $p$th root of unity.
solution: We can apply the results of the previous exercise to get $\mathcal{D}=(f^{\prime}(\zeta_{p}))$. $f(x)=\frac{x^{p}-1}{x-1}=x^{p-1}+x^{p-2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x+1,$ $f^{\prime}(x)=\frac{px^{p-1}(x-1)-(x^{p}-1)}{(x-1)^{2}},$ $f^{\prime}(\zeta_{p})=\frac{p\zeta_{p}^{-1}}{\zeta_{p}-1}$. Since $\zeta_{p}^{-1}$ is a unit, we find $\mathcal{D}=(\frac{p}{\zeta_{p}-1})$. From Exercise 5.5.4 we know that $(p)=(1-\zeta_{p})^{p-1}$, and so $\mathcal{D}=(1-\zeta_{p})^{p-2}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.9}
question: Let $p$ be a prime, $p \nmid m$, and $a \in \mathbb{Z}$. Show that $p|\phi_{m}(a)$ if and only if the order of $a \pmod p$ is $m$. (Here $\phi_{m}(x)$ is the $m$th cyclotomic polynomial.)
solution: Since $x^{m}-1=\prod_{d|m}\phi_{d}(x)$, we have $a^{m} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Let $k$ be the order of $a \pmod p$. Then $k|m$. If $k<m$, then $a^{k}-1=\prod_{d|k}\phi_{d}(a) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ so that $\phi_{d}(a) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ for some $d|k$. Then $a^{m}-1=\phi_{m}(a)\phi_{d}(a)(\text{other factors}) \equiv 0 \pmod{p^{2}}$. Since $\phi_{m}(a+p) \equiv \phi_{m}(a) \pmod p$ and similarly for $\phi_{d}(a)$, we also have $(a+p)^{m} \equiv 1 \pmod{p^{2}}$. But then $(a+p)^{m}=a^{m}+ma^{m-1}p \pmod{p^{2}}$ so that $ma^{m-1} \equiv 0 \pmod p$, a contradiction. Conversely, suppose that $a$ has order $m$ so that $a^{m} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Then $\phi_{d}(a) \equiv 0 \pmod p$ for some $d|m$. If $d<m,$ then the order of $a \pmod p$ would be less than $m$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.10}
question: Suppose $p \nmid m$ is prime. Show that $p|\phi_{m}(a)$ for some $a \in \mathbb{Z}$ if and only if $p \equiv 1 \pmod m$. Deduce from Exercise 1.2.5 that there are infinitely many primes congruent to 1 (mod m).
solution: If $p|\phi_{m}(a)$, by the previous exercise the order of $a \pmod p$ is $m$ so that $m|p-1$. Conversely, if $p \equiv 1 \pmod m$, there is an element $a$ of order $m \pmod p$ because $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{*}$ is cyclic. Again by the previous exercise $p|\phi_{m}(a)$. If there are only finitely many primes $p_{1},...,p_{r}$ (say) that are congruent to 1 (mod m), then setting $a=(p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{r})m$ we examine the prime divisors of $\phi_{m}(a)$. Observe that the identity $x^{m}-1=\prod_{d|m}\phi_{d}(x)$ implies that $\phi_{m}(0)=\pm 1$. Thus, the constant term of $\phi_{m}(x)$ is $\pm 1$ so that $\phi_{m}(a)$ is coprime to $a$ and hence coprime to $m$. (If $\phi_{m}(a)=\pm 1$ one can replace $a$ by any suitable power of $a$, so that $|\phi_{m}(a)|>1.$) By what we have proved, any prime divisor $p$ of $\phi_{m}(a)$ coprime to $m$ must be congruent to 1 (mod m). The prime $p$ is distinct from $p_{1},...,p_{r}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.11}
question: Show that $p \nmid m$ splits completely in $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$ if and only if $p \equiv 1 \pmod m$.
solution: Observe that $\phi_{m}(x)$ has a root mod $p$ if and only if $p \equiv 1 \pmod m$ by the previous exercise. But then if it has one root $a$ it has $\varphi(m)$ roots because $m|(p-1)$ and so $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{*}$ has a cyclic subgroup of order $m$. Thus, $\phi_{m}(x)$ splits completely if and only if $p \equiv 1 \pmod m$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.12}
question: Let $p$ be prime and let $a$ be squarefree and coprime to $p$. Set $\theta=a^{1/p}$ and consider $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$. Show that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$ if and only if $a^{p-1} \not\equiv 1 \pmod{p^{2}}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.13}
question: Suppose that $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ and $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. Show that if $p|d_{K}$, $p$ ramifies.
solution: We will use the result of Theorem 5.5.1. Let $f(x)$ be the minimal polynomial of $\mathbb{Z}[\theta]$. Suppose that $p|d_{K}$ and $f(x) \equiv f_{1}(x)^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot f_{g}(x)^{e_{g}} \pmod p$. Since $p|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)=\prod(\theta_{i}-\theta_{j})^{2}$, then $\theta_{i} \equiv \theta_{j}$ in $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$ for some $i \ne j$. Thus, $f$ has multiple roots in $\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{p}$. Hence, one of the $e_{i}$ is greater than 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.14}
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ and suppose that $p|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$, $p^{2} \nmid d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta).$ Show that $p|d_{K}$ and $p$ ramifies in $K$.
solution: Recall that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)=m^{2}d_{K}$ where $m=[\mathcal{O}_{K}:\mathbb{Z}[\theta]]$. Clearly, since $p|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta)$ but $p^{2} \nmid d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\theta), p|d_{K}$, and $p \nmid m$. We can now apply the result of Exercise 5.5.2. Using the same argument as in 5.6.13, we deduce that $f(x)$ has a multiple root mod $p$ and so $p$ ramifies in $K$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.15}
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field of discriminant $d_{K}.$ Show that the normal closure of $K$ contains a quadratic field of the form $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d_{K}})$.
solution: Let $\tilde{K}$ be the normal closure of $K$, $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ an integral basis of $K, \sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{n}$ the distinct embeddings of $K$ into $\mathbb{C}$. Then $d_{K}=\det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j}))^{2} \in \mathbb{Z}.$ Thus $\sqrt{d_{K}}=\det(\sigma_{i}(\omega_{j})) \in \tilde{K}.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.16}
question: Show that if $p$ ramifies in $K$, then it ramifies in each of the conjugate fields of $K$. Deduce that if $p$ ramifies in the normal closure of $K$, then it ramifies in $K$.
solution: Since each embedding $\sigma_{i}:K\rightarrow K^{(i)}$ is an isomorphism of fields, any factorization of $(p)=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}$ takes each prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}_{j}$ into a conjugate prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}_{j}^{(i)}.$ If some $e_{j}>1$ then in each conjugate field, $p$ ramifies. The second part is straightforward upon intersecting with $K$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.17}
question: Deduce the following special case of Dedekind's theorem: if $p^{2m+1}||d_{K}$ show that $p$ ramifies in $K$.
solution: By the penultimate exercise, $p$ ramifies in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d_{K}})$ and hence in the normal closure. By the previous exercise, $p$ ramifies in $K$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.18}
question: Determine the prime ideal factorization of (7), (29), and (31) in $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{2})$.
solution: By Example 4.3.6, $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[2^{1/3}]$. We may apply Theorem 5.5.1. Since $x^{3}-2$ is irreducible mod 7, $7\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is prime in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Since $x^{3}-2 \equiv (x+3)(x^{2}-3x+9) \pmod{29}$ and the quadratic factor is irreducible, we get $29\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ where $\deg \mathfrak{p}_{1}=1$, $\deg \mathfrak{p}_{2}=2$ and $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$, $\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ are prime ideals. Finally, $x^{3}-2 \equiv (x-4)(x-7)(x+11) \pmod{31}$ so that $31\mathcal{O}_{K}$ splits completely in $K$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.19}
question: If $L/K$ is a finite extension of algebraic number field, we can view $L$ as a finite dimensional vector space over $K$. If $\alpha \in L$, the map $v \mapsto \alpha v$ is a linear mapping and one can define, as before, the relative norm $N_{L/K}(\alpha)$ and relative trace $\text{Tr}_{L/K}(\alpha)$ as the determinant and trace, respectively, of this linear map. If $\alpha \in \mathcal{O}_{L}$ show that $\text{Tr}_{L/K}(\alpha)$ and $N_{L/K}(\alpha)$ lie in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.
solution: By taking a basis $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ of $L$ over $K$ and repeating the argument of Lemma 4.1.1, the result follows immediately.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.20}
question: If $K \subseteq L \subseteq M$ are finite extensions of algebraic number fields, show that $N_{M/K}(\alpha)=N_{L/K}(N_{M/L}(\alpha))$ and $\text{Tr}_{M/K}(\alpha)=\text{Tr}_{L/K}(\text{Tr}_{M/L}(\alpha))$ for any $\alpha \in M.$
solution: Fix an algebraic closure $\overline{M}$ of $M$. Let $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{m}$ be the distinct embeddings of $L$ into $\overline{M}$ which are equal to the identity on $K$. By field theory, we can extend these to embeddings of $M$ into $\overline{M}.$ Of these, let $\eta_{1},...,\eta_{n}$ be the ones trivial on $L$. If $\sigma$ is an arbitrary embedding of $M$ into $\overline{M}$ which is trivial on $K$, then as $\sigma$ is also an embedding of $L$ into $\overline{M},$ it must be $\sigma_{j}$ for some $j$. Thus, $\sigma_{j}^{-1}\sigma$ fixes $L$ and so must be an $\eta_{i}$ for some $i$. Thus, every embedding of $M$ is of the form $\sigma_{j}\circ\eta_{i}$ so that $N_{M/K}(\alpha)=\prod_{i,j}\sigma_{j}(\eta_{i}(\alpha))=\prod_{j}\sigma_{j}(N_{M/L}(\alpha))=N_{L/K}(N_{M/L}(\alpha))$, as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.21}
question: Let $L/K$ be a finite extension of algebraic number fields. Show that the map $\text{Tr}_{L/K}:L\times L\rightarrow K$ is non-degenerate.
solution: This follows from an argument analogous to the proof of Lemma 4.1.4.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.22}
question: Let $L/K$ be a finite extension of algebraic number fields. Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module contained in $L$. The set $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})=\{x \in L:\text{Tr}_{L/K}(x\mathfrak{a}) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}\}$ is called codifferent of $\mathfrak{a}$ over $K$. If $\mathfrak{a} \ne 0$ show that $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})$ is a finitely generated $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module. Thus, it is a fractional ideal of $L$.
solution: The fact that $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})$ is an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-module is clear. To see that it is finitely generated, we take an $\mathcal{O}_{K}$-basis of $\mathfrak{a}$ and repeat the argument in Exercise 5.4.1 to deduce the result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.23}
question: If in the previous exercise $\mathfrak{a}$ is an ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$, show that the fractional ideal inverse, denoted $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a})$ of $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})$ is an integral ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$. (We call $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a})$ the different of $\mathfrak{a}$ over $K$. In the case $\mathfrak{a}$ is $\mathcal{O}_{L}$, we call it the relative different of $L/K$ and denote it by $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}$.)
solution: We have $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a})\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})=\mathcal{O}_{L}$ and $1 \in \mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a})$ so that $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a}) \subseteq \mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a})\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}(\mathfrak{a}) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{L}$ so that $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}(\mathfrak{a})$ is an integral ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.24}
question: Let $K \subseteq L \subseteq M$ be algebraic number fields of finite degree over the rationals. Show that $\mathcal{D}_{M/K}=\mathcal{D}_{M/L}(\mathcal{D}_{L/K}\mathcal{O}_{M}).$
solution: We have $x \in \mathcal{D}_{M/L}^{-1}$ if and only if $\text{Tr}_{M/L}(x\mathcal{O}_{M}) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{L}$ which is equivalent to $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}\text{Tr}_{M/L}(x\mathcal{O}_{M}) \subseteq \mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}\mathcal{O}_{L}$ iff $\text{Tr}_{L/K}(\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}\text{Tr}_{M/L}(x\mathcal{O}_{M})) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$ which by transitivity of the trace is equivalent to $\text{Tr}_{M/K}(x\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1}) \subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. That is, we must have $x\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{-1} \subseteq \mathcal{D}_{M/K}^{-1}$ which is true if and only if $x \in \mathcal{D}_{L/K}\mathcal{D}_{M/K}^{-1}$ which means $\mathcal{D}_{M/L}^{-1}=\mathcal{D}_{L/K}\mathcal{D}_{M/K}^{-1}$ which gives the required result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.25}
question: Let $L/K$ be a finite extension of algebraic number fields. We define the relative discriminant of $L/K$, denoted $d_{L/K}$, as $N_{L/K}(\mathcal{D}_{L/K})$. This is an integral ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. If $K \subseteq L \subseteq M$ are as in Exercise 5.6.24, show that $d_{M/K}=d_{L/K}^{[M:L]}N_{L/K}(d_{M/L})$.
solution: By the transitivity of the norm map and by Exercise 5.6.24, we have $N_{M/K}(\mathcal{D}_{M/K})=N_{M/K}(\mathcal{D}_{M/L}\mathcal{D}_{L/K})=N_{L/K}(N_{M/L}(\mathcal{D}_{L/K}\mathcal{D}_{M/L}))=N_{L/K}(\mathcal{D}_{L/K}^{[M:L]}N_{M/L}(\mathcal{D}_{M/L}))$ which gives the result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.26}
question: Let $L/K$ be a finite extension of algebraic number fields. Suppose that $\mathcal{O}_{L}=\mathcal{O}_{K}[\alpha]$ for some $\alpha \in L.$ If $f(x)$ is the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ over $\mathcal{O}_{K}$, show that $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}=(f^{\prime}(\alpha)).$
solution: This result is identical to Exercises 5.6.6 and 5.6.7.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.27}
question: Let $K_{1}$, $K_{2}$ be algebraic number fields of finite degree over $K$. If $L/K$ is the compositum of $K_{1}/K$ and $K_{2}/K,$ show that the set of prime ideals dividing $d_{L/K}$ and $d_{K_{1}/K}d_{K_{2}/K}$ are the same.
solution: By Exercise 5.6.25, we see that every prime ideal dividing $d_{K_{1}/K}d_{K_{2}/K}$ also divides $d_{L/K}$. Suppose now that $\mathfrak{p}$ is a prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ which divides $d_{L/K}$ but not $d_{K_{1}/K}$. We have to show that $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $d_{K_{2}/K}$. By the definition of the relative discriminant, there is a prime ideal of $\mathcal{O}_{L}$ lying above $\mathfrak{p}$ which divides the different $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}$. This ideal cannot divide $\mathcal{D}_{K_{1}/K}\mathcal{O}_{L}$ for this would imply that $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $d_{K_{1}/K}$, contrary to assumption. Since $\mathcal{D}_{L/K}=\mathcal{D}_{L/K_{1}}\mathcal{D}_{K_{1}/K}$ we deduce that divides $\mathcal{D}_{L/K_{1}}$. Now let $\alpha \in \mathcal{O}_{K_{2}}$ so that $\alpha$ generates $K_{2}$ over $K$. Let $f(x)$ be its minimal polynomial over $K_{1}$ and $g(x)$ its minimal polynomial over $K$. (We have assumed that we have fixed a common algebraic closure which contains $K_{1}$ and $K_{2}$) Then $L=K_{1}(\alpha)$ and $g(x)=f(x)h(x)$ for some polynomial $h$ over $K_{1}$. Hence, $g^{\prime}(x)=f^{\prime}(x)h(x)+f(x)h^{\prime}(x)$ which implies $g^{\prime}(\alpha)=f^{\prime}(\alpha)h(\alpha)$. Thus, $g^{\prime}(\alpha)$ is in the ideal generated by $f^{\prime}(\alpha)$. By the remark in the solution of Exercise 5.6.26, we deduce that $f^{\prime}(\alpha) \in \mathcal{D}_{L/K} \subseteq \mathcal{P}$. Therefore, $g^{\prime}(\alpha) \in \mathcal{P}$. The same remark enables us to deduce that $g^{\prime}(\alpha) \in \mathcal{D}_{K_{2}/K}$ implying that $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $d_{K_{2}/K}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 5.6.28}
question: Let $L/K$ be a finite extension of algebraic number fields. If $\tilde{L}$ denotes the normal closure, show that a prime $\mathfrak{p}$ of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is unramified in $L$ if and only if it is unramified in $\tilde{L}$.
solution: If we apply the preceding exercise to the compositum of the conjugate fields of $L$, the result is immediate.

label: \label{ques: Lemma 6.1.1}
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field. Show that there is a constant $H_{K}$ such that given $\alpha\in K$, there exists $\beta\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$, and a non-zero integer $t$, with $|t|\le H_{K}$, such that $|N(t\alpha-\beta)|<1$.
solution: Let $\{\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}\}$ be an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Given any $\alpha\in K$, there exists $m\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $m\alpha\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$, so $\alpha$ can be written as $\alpha=\sum_{i=1}^{n}c_{i}\omega_{i},$ with $c_{i}\in\mathbb{Q}$ for all $i=1,2,...,n.$ Let $L$ be a natural number. Partition the interval $[0, 1]$ into $L$ parts, each of length $1/L$. This induces a subdivision of $[0, 1]^n$ into $L^{n}$ subcubes. Consider the map $\varphi:\alpha\mathbb{Z}\longrightarrow[0,1]^{n}$ defined by $t\alpha \mapsto (\{tc_{1}\},\{tc_{2}\},...,\{tc_{n}\})$ where $t\in\mathbb{Z}$, and $\{a\}$ denotes the fractional part of $a\in\mathbb{R}$. Let $t$ run from $0$ to $L^{n}$ (the number of subcubes in $[0,1]^n$). The number of choices for $t$ is then $L^{n}+1$ which is one more than the number of subcubes. There must be two distinct values of $t$, say $t_{1}$ and $t_{2}$, so that $t_{1}\alpha$ and $t_{2}\alpha$ get mapped to the same subcube of $[0, 1]^n$. Let $\beta=\sum_{i=1}^{n}([t_{1}c_{i}]-[t_{2}c_{i}])\omega_{i},$ where $[a]$ denotes the integer part of $a\in\mathbb{R}$. Then, $(t_{1}-t_{2})\alpha-\beta=\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\{t_{1}c_{i}\}-\{t_{2}c_{i}\})\omega_{i}.$ Let $t=t_{1}-t_{2}$, then $|N(t\alpha-\beta)|=|N(\sum_{i=1}^{n}(\{t_{1}c_{i}\}-\{t_{2}c_{i}\})\omega_{i})|$. Since $|(\{t_{1}c_{i}\}-\{t_{2}c_{i}\})|\le1/L$ we then have $|N(t\alpha-\beta)|\le\frac{1}{L^{n}}\prod_{j=1}^{n}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}|\omega_{i}^{(j)}|)$ where $\omega_{i}^{(j)}$ is the $i$th conjugate of $\omega_{i}$. If we take $L^{n}>\prod_{j=1}^{n}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}|\omega_{i}^{(j)}|)=H_{K}$ (say), then $|N(t\alpha-\beta)|<1$. Furthermore, since $0\le t_{1}, t_{2}\le L^{n}$, we have $|t|\le L^{n}$. Thus, if we choose $L=H_{K}^{1/n}$ we are done.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.1.2}
question: Show that given $\alpha,\beta\in\mathcal{O}_{K},$ there exist $t\in\mathbb{Z},|t|\le H_{K}$ and $w\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ so that $|N(\alpha t-\beta w)|<|N(\beta)|$.
solution: If we apply Lemma 6.1.1 with $\alpha$ replaced by $\alpha/\beta$, we conclude that there exist $t\in\mathbb{Z}$, $|t|\le H_{K}$, and $w\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $|N(t\alpha/\beta-w)|<1$. This implies $|N(t\alpha-w\beta)|<|N(\beta)|$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.2.1}
question: Two fractional ideals $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ in $K$ are said to be equivalent if there exist $\alpha,\beta\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ such that $(\alpha)\mathcal{A}=(\beta)\mathcal{B}$. In this case, we write $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{B}$. Show that the relation $\sim$ defined above is an equivalence relation.
solution: It is trivial that $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{A}$ and if $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{B}$ then $\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{A}$ for any ideals $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$. Suppose now that $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{B}$, and $\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{C}$. That is, there exist $\alpha,\beta,\gamma,\theta\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $(\alpha)\mathcal{A}=(\beta)\mathcal{B}$ and $(\gamma)\mathcal{B}=(\theta)\mathcal{C}$. It is now easily seen that $(\alpha\gamma)\mathcal{A}=(\beta\theta)\mathcal{C}$. Thus, $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{B}$ and $\mathcal{B}\sim\mathcal{C}$ imply $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathcal{C}$. Hence, $\sim$ is an equivalence relation.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 6.2.2}
question: Show that there exists a constant $C_{K}$ such that every ideal $\mathfrak{a}\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ is equivalent to an ideal $\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ with $N(\mathfrak{b})\le C_{K}$.
solution: Suppose $\mathfrak{a}$ is an ideal of $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$. Let $\beta\in\mathfrak{a}$ be a non-zero element such that $|N(\beta)|$ is minimal. For each $\alpha\in\mathfrak{a}$, by Exercise 6.1.2, we can find $t\in\mathbb{Z},$ $|t|\le H_{K}$ and $w\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $|N(t\alpha-w\beta)|<|N(\beta)|$. Moreover, since $\alpha, \beta\in\mathfrak{a}$, so $\alpha-w\beta\in\mathfrak{a};$ and therefore, by the minimality of $|N(\beta)|$, we must have $t\alpha=w\beta$. Thus, we have shown that for any $\alpha\in\mathfrak{a}$ there exist $t\in\mathbb{Z}$, $|t|\le H_{K}$, and $w\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ such that $t\alpha=w\beta$. Let $M=\prod_{|t|\le H_{K}}t;$ and we have $M\mathfrak{a}\subseteq(\beta)$. This means that $(\beta)$ divides $(M)\mathfrak{a}$, and so $(M)\mathfrak{a}=(\beta)\mathfrak{b}$, for some ideal $\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$. Observe that $\beta\in\mathfrak{a}$, so $M\beta\in(\beta)\mathfrak{b}$, and hence $(M)\subseteq\mathfrak{b}$. This implies that $|N(\mathfrak{b})|\le N((M))=C_{K}$. Hence, $\mathfrak{a}\sim\mathfrak{b}$, and $C_{K}=N((M))$ satisfies the requirements.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.2.3}
question: Show that each equivalence class of ideals has an integral ideal representative.
