solution: Suppose $\mathcal{A}$ is a fractional ideal in $K$. Let $\mathcal{A}=\mathfrak{b}/\mathfrak{c}$ with $\mathfrak{b}, \mathfrak{c}\subseteq \mathcal{O}_{K}$. We know from Exercise 4.4.1 that $\mathfrak{c}\cap\mathbb{Z}\ne\{0\}$, so there exists $0\ne t\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $t\in\mathfrak{c}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{c}\supseteq(t)=t\mathcal{O}_{K}$, and so $\mathfrak{c}$ divides $(t)$. This implies that there exists an integral ideal $\mathfrak{e}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $\mathfrak{ce}=(t)$. We now have $(t)\mathcal{A}=(t)\frac{\mathfrak{b}}{\mathfrak{c}}=\frac{\mathfrak{ce}\mathfrak{b}}{\mathfrak{c}}=\mathfrak{e}\mathfrak{b}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}.$ Thus, $\mathcal{A}\sim\mathfrak{be}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and the result is proved.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.2.4}
question: Prove that for any integer $x>0$, the number of integral ideals $\mathfrak{a}\subseteq\mathbb{O}_{K}$ for which $N(\mathfrak{a})\le x$ is finite.
solution: Since the norm is multiplicative and takes values $> 1$ on prime ideals, and since integral ideals have unique factorization, it is sufficient to prove that there are only a finite number of prime ideals with $N(\mathfrak{p})\le x.$ Now, any prime contains exactly one prime $p\in\mathbb{Z}$, as shown in Exercise 4.4.4. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}$ occurs in the factorization of $(p)\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ into prime ideals. Since $N(\mathfrak{p})\ge2$, we have $N(\mathfrak{p})=p^{t}$ for some $t\ge1$. This implies there are at most $n$ possibilities for such $\mathfrak{p}$, since the factorization $(p)=\prod_{i=1}^{s}\mathfrak{p}_{i}^{a_{i}}$ implies that $p^{n}=N((p))=\prod_{i=1}^{s}N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})^{a_{i}}$ leading to $s\le n$. Moreover, $p\le N(\mathfrak{p})\le x$. This proves the exercise.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 6.2.5}
question: Show that the number of equivalence classes of ideals is finite.
solution: By Exercise 6.2.3, each equivalence class of ideals can be represented by an integral ideal. This integral ideal, by Theorem 6.2.2, is equivalent to another integral ideal with norm less than or equal to a given constant $C_{K}$. Apply Exercise 6.2.4, and we are done.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.2.6}
question: Let $\mathcal{H}$ be the set of all the equivalence classes of ideals of $K$. Given $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}$ in $\mathcal{H}$, we define the product of $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}$ to be the equivalence class of $\mathcal{AB}$, where $\mathcal{A}$ and $\mathcal{B}$ are two representatives of $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}$, respectively. Show that the product defined above is well defined, and that $\mathcal{H}$ together with this product form a group, of which the equivalence class containing the principal ideals is the identity element.
solution: To show that the product defined above is well-defined we only need to show that if $\mathcal{A}_{1}\sim\mathcal{B}_{1}$ and $\mathcal{A}_{2}\sim\mathcal{B}_{2}$, then $\mathcal{A}_{1}\mathcal{A}_{2}\sim\mathcal{B}_{1}\mathcal{B}_{2}$. Indeed, by definition, there exist $\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\beta_{1},\beta_{2}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $(\alpha_{1})\mathcal{A}_{1}=(\beta_{1})\mathcal{B}_{1}$ and $(\alpha_{2})\mathcal{A}_{2}=(\beta_{2})\mathcal{B}_{2}$. Therefore $(\alpha_{1}\alpha_{2})\mathcal{A}_{1}\mathcal{A}_{2}=(\beta_{1}\beta_{2})\mathcal{B}_{1}\mathcal{B}_{2}$. Thus, $\mathcal{A}_{1}\mathcal{A}_{2}\sim\mathcal{B}_{1}\mathcal{B}_{2}$. Now, it is easy to check that $\mathcal{H}$ with the product defined above is closed, associative, commutative, and has the class of principal ideals as the identity element. Thus, to finish the exercise, we need to show that each element of $\mathcal{H}$ does have an inverse. Suppose $\mathcal{C}$ is an arbitrary element of $\mathcal{H}$. Let $\mathfrak{a}\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ be a representative of $\mathcal{C}$ (we showed in Exercise 6.2.3 that every equivalence class of ideals contains an integral representative). If we proceed as we did when deriving equation (6.1) [in Exercise 6.2.3], we conclude that there exists an integral ideal $\mathfrak{b}$ such that $\mathfrak{ab}$ is principal. It then follows immediately that the class containing $\mathfrak{b}$ is the inverse of $\mathcal{C}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.2.7}
question: Show that the constant $C_{K}$ in Theorem 6.2.2 could be taken to be the greatest integer less than or equal to $H_{K}$, the Hurwitz constant.
solution: As in Lemma 6.1.1, let $\{\omega_{1},\omega_{2},...,\omega_{n}\}$ be an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a given class of ideals. We denote by $\mathcal{C}^{-1}$ the inverse class of $\mathcal{C}$ in $\mathcal{H}$. Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an integral representative of $\mathcal{C}^{-1}$. Consider the following set $S=\{s\in\mathbb{O}_{K}|s=\sum_{i=1}^{n}m_{i}\omega_{i},m_{i}\in\mathbb{Z},0\le m_{i}<(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{1/n}+1\}.$ Then $|S|\ge N(\mathfrak{a})+1$. Since $N(\mathfrak{a})=[\mathfrak{O}_{K}:\mathfrak{a}],$ we can find distinct $a, b\in S$ such that $a\equiv b$ (mod $\mathfrak{a}$). Thus, $(a-b)\subseteq\mathfrak{a}$. This implies that there exists an integral ideal $\mathfrak{b}$ such that $(a-b)=\mathfrak{ab}$. It is easy to observe that $\mathfrak{b}\in\mathcal{C}$. We may write $a-b=\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\omega_{i}$. Since $a, b\in S,$ $|p_{i}|\le(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{1/n}+1,$ and so we have $|N(a-b)|=|\prod_{j=1}^{n}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}p_{i}\omega_{i}^{(j)})| \le\prod_{j=1}^{n}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}|p_{i}||\omega_{i}^{(j)}|) \le[(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{1/n}+1]^{n}\prod_{j=1}^{n}(\sum_{i=1}^{n}|\omega_{i}^{(j)}|) \le[(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{1/n}+1]^{n}H_{K}$. We also know that since $(a-b)=\mathfrak{ab}, |N(a-b)|=N(\mathfrak{a})N(\mathfrak{b})$. Thus, $N(\mathfrak{b})\le[1+(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{-1/n}]^{n}H_{K}$. However, observe that we can always replace $\mathfrak{a}$ by the ideal $c\mathfrak{a}$, in the same equivalence class, for any $c\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}\backslash\{0\},$ and with $|N(c)|$ arbitrarily large; we can therefore make $[1+(N(\mathfrak{a}))^{-1/n}]^n$ arbitrarily close to 1. Thus, every equivalence class $\mathcal{C}$ has an integral representative $\mathfrak{b}$ with $N(\mathfrak{b})\le H_{K}$. This implies that every ideal is equivalent to another integral ideal with norm less than or equal to $H_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Example 6.2.8}
question: Show that the class number of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ is 2.
solution: We proved in Exercise 4.1.3 that the integers in $K$ are $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ so that $\omega_{1}^{(1)}=1$, $\omega_{2}^{(1)}=\sqrt{-5}$, $\omega_{1}^{(2)}=1$, $\omega_{2}^{(2)}=-\sqrt{-5}$, and the Hurwitz constant is $(1+\sqrt{5})^{2}=10.45...$. Thus, $C_{K}=10.$ This implies that every equivalence class of ideals $\mathcal{C}\in\mathcal{H}$ has an integral representative $\mathfrak{a}$ such that $N(\mathfrak{a})\le10$. $\mathfrak{a}$ has a factorization into a product of primes, say, $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{p}_{1}\mathfrak{p}_{2}...\mathfrak{p}_{m}$. Consider $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$. There exists, by Exercise 4.4.4, a unique prime number $p\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $p\in\mathfrak{p}_{1}$. This implies that $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ is in the factorization of $(p)$ into product of primes in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, $N(\mathfrak{p}_{1})$ is a power of $p$. Since $N(\mathfrak{a})=\prod_{i=1}^{m}N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})$, and $N(\mathfrak{a})\le10$, we deduce that $N(\mathfrak{p}_{i})\le10$ for all $i$. And so, in particular, $N(\mathfrak{p}_{1})\le10$. Therefore, $p\le10$. Thus, $p$ could be 2, 3, 5, or 7. For $p=2,3,5$, and 7, $(p)$ factors in $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ as follows: $(2)=(2,1+\sqrt{-5})(2,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(3)=(3,1+\sqrt{-5})(3,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(7)=(7,3+\sqrt{-5})(7,3-\sqrt{-5})$, $(5)=(\sqrt{-5})^{2}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ can only be $(2,1+\sqrt{-5})$, $(2,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(3,1+\sqrt{-5})$, $(3, 1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(7,3+\sqrt{-5})$, $(7,3-\sqrt{-5})$, or $(\sqrt{-5})$. The same conclusion holds for any $\mathfrak{p}_{i}$ for $i=2,...,m$. Moreover, it can be seen that $(\sqrt{-5})$ is principal, and all the others are not principal (by taking the norms), but are pairwise equivalent by the following relations: $(2,1+\sqrt{-5})=(2,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(3,1+\sqrt{-5})(1-\sqrt{-5})=(3)(2,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(3,1-\sqrt{-5})(1+\sqrt{-5})=(3)(2,1+\sqrt{-5})$, $(7,3+\sqrt{-5})(3-\sqrt{-5})=(7)(2,1-\sqrt{-5})$, $(7,3-\sqrt{-5})(3+\sqrt{-5})=(7)(2,1+\sqrt{-5})$. Therefore, $\mathfrak{a}$ is equivalent to either the class of principal ideals or the class of those primes listed above. Hence, the class number of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ is 2.

label: \label{ques: Example 6.3.1}
question: Show that the equation $x^{2}+5=y^{3}$ has no integral solution.
solution: Observe that if $y$ is even, then $x$ is odd, and $x^{2}+5\equiv0$ (mod 4), and hence $x^{2}\equiv3$ (mod 4), which is a contradiction. Therefore, $y$ is odd. Also, if a prime $p|(x,y)$, then $p|5$, so $p=5;$ and hence, by dividing both sides of the equation by 5, we end up with $1\equiv0$ (mod 5), which is absurd. Thus, $x$ and $y$ are coprime. Suppose now that $(x, y)$ is an integral solution to the given equation. We consider the factorization $(x+\sqrt{-5})(x-\sqrt{-5})=y^{3}$ in the ring of integers $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$. Suppose a prime $\mathfrak{p}$ divides the gcd of $(x+\sqrt{-5})$ and $(x-\sqrt{-5})$ (which implies $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(y)$). Then $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(2x)$. Also, since $y$ is odd, $\mathfrak{p}$ does not divide $(2)$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(x)$. This is a contradiction to the fact that $x$ and $y$ are coprime. Hence, $(x+\sqrt{-5})$ and $(x-\sqrt{-5})$ are coprime ideals. This and the equation ensure (by Exercise 5.3.12) that $(x+\sqrt{-5})=\mathfrak{a}^{3}$ and $(x-\sqrt{-5})=\mathfrak{b}^{3}$, for some ideals $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$. Since the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ was found in Example 6.2.8 to be 2, $\mathfrak{c}^{2}$ is principal for any ideal $\mathfrak{c}$. Thus, since $\mathfrak{a}^{3}$ and $\mathfrak{b}^{3}$ are principal, we deduce that $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are also principal. Moreover, since the units of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ are 1 and -1, which are both cubes, we conclude that $x+\sqrt{-5}=(a+b\sqrt{-5})^{3}$ for some integers $a$ and $b$. This implies that $1=b(3a^{2}-5b^{2})$. It is easy to see that $b|1$ so $b=\pm1$. Therefore, $3a^{2}-5=\pm1$. Both cases lead to contradiction with the fact that $a\in\mathbb{Z}$. Hence, the given equation does not have an integral solution.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.3.2}
question: Let $k>0$ be a squarefree positive integer. Suppose that $k\equiv1,2$ (mod 4), and $k$ does not have the form $k=3a^{2}\pm1$ for an integer $a$. Consider the equation $x^{2}+k=y^{3}$. Show that if 3 does not divide the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-k})$ then this equation has no integral solution.
solution: Similar to what was done in Example 6.3.1, $y$ must be odd (consider congruences modulo 4). Also, if a prime $p|(x,y)$, then $p|k$; and hence, since $k$ is squarefree (so, in particular, $k$ is not divisible by $p^{2}$), by dividing both sides of the equation by $p$, we end up having a contradiction modulo $p$. Thus, $x$ and $y$ are coprime. Suppose now that $(x,y)$ is an integral solution. As given, $k\equiv1,2$ (mod 4), so $-k\equiv3,2$ (mod 4). Thus, the integers in $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-k})$ are $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-k}]$. We consider the factorization $(x+\sqrt{-k})(x-\sqrt{-k})=y^{3}$ in the ring of integers $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-k}]$. As in Example 6.3.1, suppose a prime $\mathfrak{p}$ divides the gcd of the ideals $(x+\sqrt{-k})$ and $(x-\sqrt{-k})$ (which implies $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(y)$). Then $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(2x)$. Since $y$ is odd, $\mathfrak{p}$ does not divide $(2)$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}$ divides $(x)$. This contradicts the fact that $x$ and $y$ are coprime. Hence, $(x+\sqrt{-k})$ and $(x-\sqrt{-k})$ are coprime. The equation now implies that $(x+\sqrt{-k})=\mathfrak{a}^{3}$ and $(x-\sqrt{-k})=\mathfrak{b}^{3}$ for some ideals $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$. Let $h(K)$ be the class number of the field $K$, then $\mathfrak{c}^{h(K)}$ is principal for any ideal $\mathfrak{c}$. As given, $3 \nmid h(K)$, so $(3,h(K))=1$. Thus, since $\mathfrak{a}^{3}$ and $\mathfrak{b}^{3}$ are principal, $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are also principal. We must have $(x+\sqrt{-k})=\epsilon(a+b\sqrt{-k})^{3}$ for some integers $a, b$, and a unit $\epsilon\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-k}]$. Let $\epsilon=x_{1}+x_{2}\sqrt{-k}$. Then, since $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-k}]$ is a unit if and only if $N(\alpha)=\pm1$, we have $x_{1}^{2}+kx_{2}^{2}=\pm1$. As given $k>0$ and $k$ is square-free, so $k>1$. Thus, $x_{2}=0$ and $x_{1}=\pm1$. Hence, $\epsilon=\pm1$, and in the equation it could be absorbed into the cube. We have $(x+\sqrt{-k})=(a+b\sqrt{-k})^{3}$. This implies $1=b(3a^{2}-kb^{2})$. It is clear that $b|1$, so $b=\pm1$. Both cases lead to either $k=3a^{2}+1$ or $k=3a^{2}-1$, which violates the hypothesis. Hence, we conclude that equation does not have an integral solution.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.4.1}
question: Fix a positive integer $g>1$. Suppose that $n$ is odd, greater than 1, and $n^{g}-1=d$ is squarefree. Show that the ideal class group of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ has an element of order $g$.
solution: Since $d$ is even and squarefree, $d\equiv2$ (mod 4). The ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ is $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-d}].$ We have the ideal factorization: $(n)^{g}=(n^{g})=(1+d)=(1+\sqrt{-d})(1-\sqrt{-d})$. The ideals $(1+\sqrt{-d})$ and $(1-\sqrt{-d})$ are coprime since $n$ is odd. Thus by Theorem 5.3.13, each of the ideals $(1+\sqrt{-d})$, $(1-\sqrt{-d})$ must be $g$th powers. Thus $\mathfrak{a}^{g}=(1+\sqrt{-d})$, $(\mathfrak{a}^{\prime})^{g}=(1-\sqrt{-d})$, with $\mathfrak{a}\mathfrak{a}^{\prime}=(n)$. Hence $\mathfrak{a}$ has order dividing $g$ in the class group. Suppose $\mathfrak{a}^{m}=(u+v\sqrt{-d})$ for some $u, v\in\mathbb{Z}.$ Note that $v$ cannot be zero for otherwise $\mathfrak{a}^{m}=(u)$ implies that $(\mathfrak{a}^{\prime})^{m}=(u)$ so that $(u)=\gcd(\mathfrak{a}^{m},(\mathfrak{a}^{\prime})^{m})$, contrary to $\gcd(\mathfrak{a},\mathfrak{a}^{\prime})=1$. Therefore $v\ne0$. Now take norms of the equation $\mathfrak{a}^{m}=(u+v\sqrt{-d})$ to obtain $n^{m}=u^{2}+v^{2}d\ge d=n^{g}-1$. If $m\le g-1$, we get $n^{g-1}\ge n^{g}-1$ which implies that $1\ge n^{g-1}(n-1)\ge2,$ a contradiction. Therefore $\mathfrak{a}^{g}=(1+\sqrt{-d})$ and $\mathfrak{a}^{m}$ is not principal for any $m<g$. Thus there is an element of order $g$ in the ideal class group of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.4.2}
question: Let $g$ be odd and greater than 1. If $d=3^{g}-x^{2}$ is squarefree with $x$ odd and satisfying $x^{2}<3^{g}/2$, show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ has an element of order $g$ in the class group.
solution: Observe that $d\equiv2$ (mod 4) so the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ is $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-d}]$. The factorization $3^{g}=(x+\sqrt{-d})(x-\sqrt{-d})$ shows that 3 splits in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$, as the ideals $(x+\sqrt{-d})$ and $(x-\sqrt{-d})$ are coprime. Thus $(3)=\mathfrak{p}_{1}\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}$. We must have $(x+\sqrt{-d})=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{g}$. Therefore, the order of $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ in the ideal class group is a divisor of $g$. If $\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{m}=(u+v\sqrt{-d})$ then $3^{m}=u^{2}+v^{2}d$. If $v\ne0$, we deduce $3^{m}\ge d>3^{g}/2$ which is a contradiction if $m\le g-1$. Either $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ has order $g$ or $v=0.$ In the latter case, we get $u^{2}=3^{m}$, a contradiction since $m$ is odd.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.4.3}
question: Let $g$ be odd. Let $N$ be the number of squarefree integers of the form $3^{g}-x^{2}$, $x$ odd, $0<x^{2}<3^{g}/2$. For $g$ sufficiently large, show that $N\gg3^{g/2}$. Deduce that there are infinitely many imaginary quadratic fields whose class number is divisible by $g$.
solution: The number of integers under consideration is $\frac{1}{2\sqrt{2}}3^{g/2}+O(1).$ From these, we will remove any number divisible by the square of a prime. Since $g$ is odd, $x^{2}\equiv3^{g}$ (mod 4) implies that $x^{2}\equiv-1$ (mod 4) has a solution. This is a contradiction. Therefore $4 \nmid 3^{g}-x^{2}$. If $3|x$, then $3|3^{g}-x^{2}$ so we remove such numbers. Their count is $\frac{1}{6\sqrt{2}}3^{g/2}+O(1).$ If $p$ is odd and greater than 3, the number of $3^{g}-x^{2}$ divisible by $p^{2}$ is at most $\frac{3^{g/2}}{p^{2}\sqrt{2}}+O(1).$ Thus, $N\ge\frac{3^{g/2}}{\sqrt{2}}\{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{6}-\sum_{5\le p\le 3^{g/2}}\frac{1}{p^{2}}+O(\frac{3^{g/2}}{g})\}$ by using Exercise 1.1.26. Now $\sum_{p\ge5}\frac{1}{p^{2}}\le\sum_{n=5}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n(n-1)}=(\frac{1}{4}-\frac{1}{5})+(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{6})+\cdot\cdot\cdot =\frac{1}{4}$. Since $\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{4}- rac{1}{6}=\frac{1}{12}$ we see $N\gg3^{g/2}$. By the previous exercise, each of these values gives rise to a distinct quadratic field whose class group has exponent divisible by $g$. By applying this result for powers of $g$ we deduce that there are infinitely many imaginary quadratic fields of class number divisible by $g$. (This argument is due to Ankeny and Chowla.)

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.1}
question: Show that the class number of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-19})$ is 1.
solution: We know that $1, (1+\sqrt{-19})/2$ forms an integral basis. We then write $\omega_{1}^{(1)}=1, \omega_{2}^{(1)}=\frac{1+\sqrt{-19}}{2}, \omega_{1}^{(2)}=1, \omega_{2}^{(2)}=\frac{1-\sqrt{-19}}{2},$ and use this to find the Hurwitz constant $H_{K}=\prod_{j=1}^{2}(\sum_{i=1}^{2}|\omega_{i}^{(j)}|) = (1+|\frac{1+\sqrt{-19}}{2}|)(1+|\frac{1-\sqrt{-19}}{2}|) = 13.53...$. Just as in Example 6.2.8, we examine all the primes $p\le13$ to determine the prime ideals with $N(\mathfrak{p})\le13$. The primes in question are 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, and 13. They factor in $\mathbb{Z}[(1+\sqrt{-19})/2]$ as follows: 2, 3, and 13 stay prime, and $5=(\frac{1+\sqrt{-19}}{2})(\frac{1-\sqrt{-19}}{2})$, $7=(\frac{3+\sqrt{-19}}{2})(\frac{3-\sqrt{-19}}{2})$, $11=(\frac{5+\sqrt{-19}}{2})(\frac{5-\sqrt{-19}}{2})$. These are all principal ideals and thus are all equivalent. This shows that the class number of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-19})$ is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.2}
question: (Siegel) Let $C$ be a symmetric, bounded domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. (That is, $C$ is bounded and if $x\in C$ so is $-x$.) If $\text{vol}(C)>1$, then there are two distinct points $P,Q\in C$ such that $P-Q$ is a lattice point.
solution: Let $\varphi(x)=1$ or 0 according as $x\in C$ or not. Then set $\psi(x)=\sum_{\gamma\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\varphi(x+\gamma).$ Clearly, $\psi(x)$ is bounded and integrable. Thus $\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}/\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\psi(x)dx=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}/\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\sum_{\gamma\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\varphi(x+\gamma)dx =\sum_{\gamma\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}/\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\varphi(x+\gamma)dx =\sum_{\gamma\in\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\int_{\gamma+\mathbb{R}^{n}/\mathbb{Z}^{n}}\varphi(x)dx =\int_{\mathbb{R}^{n}}\varphi(x)dx =\text{vol}(C)>1$. Since $\psi(x)$ takes only integer values, we must have $\psi(x)\ge2$ for some $x$. Therefore, there are two distinct points $P+\gamma,$ $P+\gamma^{\prime}$ in $C$ so their difference is a lattice point.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.3}
question: If $C$ is any convex, bounded, symmetric domain of volume $>2^{n}$, show that $C$ contains a non-zero lattice point. ($C$ is said to be convex if $x, y\in C$ implies $\lambda x+(1-\lambda)y\in C$ for $0\le\lambda\le1.$)
solution: By the previous question, the bounded symmetric domain $\frac{1}{2}C$ contains two distinct points $\frac{1}{2}P$ and $\frac{1}{2}Q$ such that $\frac{1}{2}P-\frac{1}{2}Q$ is a lattice point, because $\text{vol}(\frac{1}{2}C)=\frac{\text{vol}(C)}{2^{n}}>1.$ Since $C$ is convex, $0\ne\gamma=\frac{1}{2}P-\frac{1}{2}Q\in C$ as $P,Q\in C.$ This is a nonzero lattice point in $C$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.4}
question: Show in the previous question if the volume $\ge2^{n}$, the result is still valid, if $C$ is closed.
solution: We can enlarge our domain by $\epsilon$ to create $C_{\epsilon}$ of volume $>2^{n}.$ For each $\epsilon$, $C_{\epsilon}$ contains a lattice point. Since $\lim_{\epsilon\rightarrow0}C_{\epsilon}=C,$ $C$ also contains a lattice point (perhaps on the boundary).

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.5}
question: Show that there exist bounded, symmetric convex domains with volume $<2^{n}$ that do not contain a lattice point.
solution: Consider $-1<x_{i}<1$, $1\le i\le n$. This hypercube has volume $2^{n}$ and the only lattice point it contains is 0.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.6}
question: (Minkowski) For $x=(x_{1},...,x_{n})$, let $L_{i}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}x_{j}, 1\le i\le n$ be $n$ linear forms with real coefficients. Let $C$ be the domain defined by $|L_{i}(x)|\le\lambda_{i}, 1\le i\le n$. Show that if $\lambda_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\lambda_{n}\ge|\det A|$ where $A=(a_{ij})$, then $C$ contains a nonzero lattice point.
solution: Clearly $C$ is convex, bounded, and symmetric. We want to compute the volume of $C/2$. We make a linear change of variables: $y=Ax$. Then $dy_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot dy_{n}=(\det A)dx_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot dx_{n}$, so we get $\text{vol}(C/2)=\frac{\lambda_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\lambda_{n}}{|\det A|}\ge1$ from which the result follows because $C$ is closed.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.7}
question: Suppose that among the $n$ linear forms $L_{i}(x)$ defined in Exercise 6.5.6, $1\le i\le r_{1}$ are real (i.e., $a_{ij}\in\mathbb{R})$, and $2r_{2}$ are not real (i.e., some $a_{ij}$ may be nonreal). Further assume that $L_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}=\overline{L_{r_{1}+j}}$ for $1\le j\le r_{2}$. That is, $L_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}(x)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\overline{a}_{r_{1}+j,k}x_{k}$ for $1\le j\le r_{2}$. Now let $C$ be the convex, bounded symmetric domain defined by $|L_{i}(x)|\le\lambda_{i}$ ($1\le i\le n$), with $\lambda_{r_{1}+j}=\lambda_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}$ ($1\le j\le r_{2}$). Show that if $\lambda_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\lambda_{n}\ge|\det A|,$ then $C$ contains a nonzero lattice point.
solution: We replace the nonreal linear forms by real ones and apply the previous result. Set $L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime}=\frac{L_{r_{1}+j}+L_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}}{2}$ and $L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime\prime}=\frac{L_{r_{1}+j}-L_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}}{2}.$ Then $L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime},L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime\prime}$ are linear forms. Clearly, if $|L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime}|\le\frac{\lambda_{r_{1}+j}}{\sqrt{2}}$ and $|L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime\prime}|\le\frac{\lambda_{r_{1}+j}}{\sqrt{2}}$ then $|L_{r_{1}+j}|\le\lambda_{r_{1}+j}$, so we replace $|L_{r_{1}+j}|\le\lambda_{r_{1}+j}$, $|L_{r_{1}+r_{2}+j}|\le\lambda_{r_{1}+j}$ with $L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime}$ and $L_{r_{1}+j}^{\prime\prime}$ satisfying the inequalities above. We deduce by the results established in the previous questions, that this domain contains a nonzero lattice point provided $\frac{\lambda_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\lambda_{n}2^{-r_{2}}}{|\det A^{\prime}|}>1,$ where $A^{\prime}$ is the appropriately modified matrix. A simple linear algebra computation shows $\det A^{\prime}=2^{-r_{2}}\det A$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.8}
question: Using the previous result, deduce that if $K$ is an algebraic number field with discriminant $d_{K}$, then every ideal class contains an ideal $\mathfrak{b}$ satisfying $N\mathfrak{b}\le\sqrt{|d_{K}|}$.
solution: Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be any integral ideal and $\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{n}$ an integral basis of $\mathfrak{a}$. Consider the linear forms $L_{i}(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\alpha_{j}^{(i)}x_{j}$ and the bounded symmetric convex domain defined by $|L_{i}(x)|\le|\Delta|^{1/n}$, where $|\Delta|=|\det(\alpha_{j}^{(i)})|$. By the previous question, the system has a non-trivial integral solution, $(x_{1},...,x_{n})$. Let $\omega=x_{1}\alpha_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}\alpha_{n}\in\mathfrak{a}$. Then $(\omega)\subseteq\mathfrak{a}$ so that for some ideal $\mathfrak{b}$, $\mathfrak{ab}=(\omega)$. But $|N(\omega)|=|N\mathfrak{a}||N\mathfrak{b}|\le|\Delta|$ by construction. Also, $|\Delta|^{2}=(N\mathfrak{a})^{2}|d_{K}|$ by Exercise 4.4.5. Hence, $|N\mathfrak{b}|\le\sqrt{|d_{K}|}$. Given any ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ we have found an ideal $\mathfrak{b}$ in the inverse class whose norm is less than or equal to $\sqrt{|d_{K}|}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.9}
question: Let $X_{t}$ consist of points $(x_{1},...,x_{r},y_{1},z_{1},...,y_{s},z_{s})$ in $\mathbb{R}^{r+2s}$ where the coordinates satisfy $|x_{1}|+\cdot\cdot\cdot+|x_{r}|+2\sqrt{y_{1}^{2}+z_{1}^{2}}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+2\sqrt{y_{s}^{2}+z_{s}^{2}}<t.$ Show that $X_{t}$ is a bounded, convex, symmetric domain.
solution: The fact that $X_{t}$ is bounded and symmetric is clear. To see convexity, let $P=(a_{1},...,a_{r},b_{1},c_{1},...,b_{s},c_{s})$ and $Q=(d_{1},...,d_{r},e_{1},f_{1},...,e_{s},f_{s})$ be points of $X_{t}$. We must show that $\lambda P+\mu Q\in X_{t}$ whenever $\lambda, \mu\ge0$ and $\lambda+\mu=1$. Clearly $|\lambda a_{i}+\mu d_{i}|\le\lambda|a_{i}|+\mu|d_{i}|$. Also $\sqrt{(\lambda b_{i}+\mu e_{i})^{2}+(\lambda c_{i}+\mu f_{i})^{2}}\le\lambda\sqrt{b_{i}^{2}+c_{i}^{2}}+\mu\sqrt{e_{i}^{2}+f_{i}^{2}},$ as is easily verified. From these inequalities, it follows that $\lambda P+\mu Q\in X_{t}$ so that $X_{t}$ is convex.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.10}
question: In the previous question, show that the volume of $X_{t}$ is $\frac{2^{r-s}\pi^{s}t^{n}}{n!}$ where $n=r+2s$.
solution: We begin by making a change of variables to polar coordinates: $2y_{j}=\rho_{j}\cos\theta_{j}$, $2z_{j}=\rho_{j}\sin\theta_{j}$, $4 dy_j dz_j = \rho_j d\rho_j d\theta_j$ so that integrating over $x_{i}\ge0$ for $1\le i\le r$ gives $\text{vol}(X_{t})=2^{r}\cdot2^{-2s}\int\rho_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{s}dx_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot dx_{r}d\rho_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot d\rho_{s}d\theta_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot d\theta_{s} =2^{r}2^{-2s}(2\pi)^{s}\int_{Y_{t}}\rho_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{s}dx_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot dx_{r}d\rho_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot d\rho_{s}$ where $Y_{t}=\{(x_{1},...,x_{r},\rho_{1},...,\rho_{s}):x_{i},\rho_{j}\ge0,x_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{r}+\rho_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\rho_{s}\le t\}.$ Let $f_{r,s}(t)$ denote the value of the above integral. By changing variables, it is clear that $f_{r,s}(1)=\int_{0}^{1}f_{r-1,s}(1-x_{1})dx_{1} =f_{r-1,s}(1)\int_{0}^{1}x_{1}^{r-1+2s}dx_{1} =\frac{1}{r+2s}f_{r-1,s}(1)$. Proceeding inductively, we get $f_{r,s}(1)=\frac{(2s)!}{(r+2s)!}f_{0,s}(1).$ Now we evaluate $f_{0,s}(1)$ by integrating with respect to $\rho_{s}$ first: $f_{0,s}(1)=\int_{0}^{1}\rho_{s}f_{0,s-1}(1-\rho_{s})d\rho_{s} =f_{0,s-1}(1)\int_{0}^{1}\rho_{s}(1-\rho_{s})^{2s-2}d\rho_{s} =\frac{f_{0,s-1}(1)}{2s(2s-1)}.$ Again, proceeding inductively, we find $f_{0,s}(1)=1/(2s)!$ so that $f_{r,s}(1)=\frac{1}{(r+2s)!}=\frac{1}{n!}.$ This completes the proof.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.11}
question: Let $C$ be a bounded, symmetric, convex domain in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Let $a_{1},...,a_{n}$ be linearly independent vectors in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Let $A$ be the $n\times n$ matrix whose rows are the $a_{i}$. If $\text{vol}(C)>2^{n}|\det A|$ show that there exist rational integers $x_{1},...,x_{n}$ (not all zero) such that $x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}a_{n}\in C$.
solution: Consider the set $D$ of all $(x_{1},...,x_{n})\in\mathbb{R}^{n}$ such that $x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}a_{n}\in C$. It is easily seen that $D$ is bounded, symmetric, and convex because $C$ is. Moreover, $D=A^{-1}C$ so that by linear algebra, $\text{vol}(D)=\text{vol}(C)(|\det A|)^{-1}$. Thus, if $\text{vol}(D)>2^{n}$, then $D$ contains a lattice point $(x_{1},...,x_{n})\ne0$ such that $x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}a_{n}\in C$. But $\text{vol}(D)>2^{n}$ is equivalent to $\text{vol}(C)>2^{n}|\det A|$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.12}
question: (Minkowski's Bound) Let $K$ be an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Show that each ideal class contains an ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ satisfying $N\mathfrak{a}\le\frac{n!}{n^{n}}(\frac{4}{\pi})^{r_{2}}|d_{K}|^{1/2},$ where $r_{2}$ is the number of pairs of complex embeddings of $K$, and $d_{K}$ is the discriminant.
solution: Given any ideal $\mathfrak{b}$, let $\omega_{1},...,\omega_{n}$ be a basis of $\mathfrak{b}$. Let $a_{i}=(\sigma_{1}(\omega_{i}),...,\sigma_{r_{1}}(\omega_{i}),\text{Re}(\sigma_{r_{1}+1}(\omega_{i})), \text{Im}(\sigma_{r_{1}+1}(\omega_{i})),...,\text{Re}(\sigma_{r_{1}+r_{2}}(\omega_{i})),\text{Im}(\sigma_{r_{1}+r_{2}}(\omega_{i})))\in\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Then the $a_{i}$ are linearly independent vectors in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. Consider the bounded symmetric convex domain $X_{t}$ defined in Exercise 6.5.9 above (with $r=r_{1}, s=r_{2}$). By Exercise 6.5.10 above, the volume of $X_{t}$ is $\frac{2^{r_{1}-r_{2}}\pi^{r_{2}}t^{n}}{n!}$. If $t$ is chosen so that this volume is greater than $2^{n}|\det A|$, then $X_{t}$ contains a lattice point $(x_{1},...,x_{n})$ so that $0\ne x_{1}a_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}a_{n}\in X_{t}.$ Let us set $\alpha=x_{1}\omega_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}\omega_{n}\in\mathfrak{b}.$ By the arithmetic mean geometric mean inequality, we find $|N(\alpha)|^{1/n}<\frac{t}{n}$ so that $|N(\alpha)|<(\frac{t}{n})^{n}$. Moreover, $\det A=2^{-r_{2}}|N(\mathfrak{b})||d_{K}|^{1/2}$ and $\frac{t^{n}}{n!}=\frac{2^{n}|\det A|}{2^{r_{1}-r_{2}}\pi^{r_{2}}}=(\frac{4}{\pi})^{r_{2}}|N\mathfrak{b}||d_{K}|^{1/2}.$ Thus, there is an $\alpha\in\mathfrak{b}$, $\alpha\ne0$ such that $|N(\alpha)|\le\frac{n!}{n^{n}}(\frac{4}{\pi})^{r_{2}}|N\mathfrak{b}||d_{K}|^{1/2}.$ Write $(\alpha)=\mathfrak{ab}$ for some ideal $\mathfrak{a}$. Then $N\mathfrak{a}\le\frac{n!}{n^{n}}(\frac{4}{\pi})^{r_{2}}|d_{K}|^{1/2},$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.13}
question: Show that if $K\ne\mathbb{Q}$, then $|d_{K}|>1$. Thus, by Dedekind's theorem, in any nontrivial extension of $K$, some prime ramifies.
solution: Since $N\mathfrak{a}\ge1$, we have by the Minkowski bound, $1\le\frac{n!}{n^{n}}(\frac{4}{\pi})^{r_{2}}|d_{K}|^{1/2}$ so that $|d_{K}|^{1/2}\ge\frac{n^{n}}{n!}(\frac{\pi}{4})^{r_{2}}\ge\frac{n^{n}}{n!}(\frac{\pi}{4})^{n/2}=c_{n},$ say. Then $\frac{c_{n+1}}{c_{n}}=(\frac{\pi}{4})^{1/2}(1+\frac{1}{n})^{n}$ which is greater than 1 for every positive $n$. Hence $c_{n+1}>c_{n}$. We have $c_{2}>1$ so that $|d_{K}|>1$, if $n\ge2$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.14}
question: If $K$ and $L$ are algebraic number fields such that $d_{K}$ and $d_{L}$ are coprime, show that $K\cap L=\mathbb{Q}$. Deduce that $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=[K:\mathbb{Q}][L:\mathbb{Q}]$.
solution: If $M=K\cap L$ then by a result of Chapter 4, $d_{M}|d_{K}$ and $d_{M}|d_{L}$. Since $d_{K}$ and $d_{L}$ are coprime, $d_{M}=1$. But then, by the previous exercise, $M=\mathbb{Q}$. We have $[KL:\mathbb{Q}]=[KL:K][K:\mathbb{Q}]$. Let $L=\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ and $g$ its minimal polynomial over $\mathbb{Q}$. If $[KL:K]<[L:\mathbb{Q}]$, then the minimal polynomial $h$ of $\theta$ over $K$ divides $g$ and has degree smaller than that of $g$. Thus the coefficients of $h$ generate a proper extension $T$ (say) of $\mathbb{Q}$ which is necessarily contained in $K$. Hence, $d_{T}|d_{K}$. If we let $\tilde{L}$ be the normal closure of $L$ over $\mathbb{Q}$, then $h\in\tilde{L}[x]$. We now need to use the fact that primes which ramify in $L$ are the same as the ones that ramify in $\tilde{L}$ (see Exercise 5.6.28). Since $T$ is contained in $\tilde{L}$, we see that $d_{T}|d_{\tilde{L}}$ and by the quoted fact, we deduce that $d_{L}$ and $d_{K}$ have a common prime factor if $d_{T}>1$, which is contrary to hypothesis. Thus, $d_{T}=1$ and by Exercise 6.5.13 we deduce $T=\mathbb{Q}$, a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.15}
question: Use Minkowski's bound to show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$ has class number 1.
solution: The discriminant of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$ is 5 and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{2!}{2^{2}}\sqrt{5}=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{2}=1.11....$ The only ideal of norm less than $\sqrt{5}/2$ is the trivial ideal which is principal.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.16}
question: Using Minkowski's bound, show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ has class number 2.
solution: The discriminant of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-5})$ is 20 and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{20}=\frac{4}{\pi}(2.236...)=2.84...$ We need to look at ideals of norm 2. There is only one ideal of norm 2 and by Exercise 5.2.5 we know that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-5}]$ is not a principal ideal domain. Hence the class number must be 2.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.17}
question: Compute the class numbers of the fields $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})$, and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{13})$.
solution: The discriminants of these fields are 8, 12, and 13 respectively. The Minkowski bound is $\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{|d_{K}|}<\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{13}=1.802....$ The only ideal of norm less than 1.8 is the trivial ideal, which is principal, so the class number is 1. (Recall that in Exercises 2.4.5 and 2.5.4 we showed that the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$ and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})$ are Euclidean and hence PIDs. So that the class number is 1 for each of these was already known to us from Chapter 2.)

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.18}
question: Compute the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{17}).$
solution: The discriminant of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{17})$ is 17 and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{17}=2.06...$ We need to consider ideals of norm 2. Since $-2=\frac{9-17}{4}=\frac{3-\sqrt{17}}{2}\cdot\frac{3+\sqrt{17}}{2},$ 2 splits and the principal ideals $((3+\sqrt{17})/2)$ and $((3-\sqrt{17})/2)$ are the only ones of norm 2. Therefore, the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.19}
question: Compute the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{6})$.
solution: The discriminant is 24 and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{24}=\sqrt{6}=2.44...,$ 2 ramifies in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{6})$. Moreover, $-2=(2-\sqrt{6})(2+\sqrt{6})$ so that the ideal $(2-\sqrt{6})$ is the only one of norm 2 since $(2+\sqrt{6})/(2-\sqrt{6})$ is a unit. Thus, the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.20}
question: Show that the fields $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-1})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-2})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$, and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-7})$ each have class number 1.
solution: The Minkowski bound for an imaginary quadratic field $K$ is $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{|d_{K}|}$. The given fields have discriminants equal to -4, -8, -3, -7, respectively. Since $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{8}=\frac{4\sqrt{2}}{\pi}=1.80...$ we deduce that every ideal is principal.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.21}
question: Let $K$ be an algebraic number field of degree $n$ over $\mathbb{Q}$. Prove that $|d_{K}|\ge(\frac{\pi}{4})^{n}(\frac{n^{n}}{n!})^{2}$.
solution: This follows directly from Minkowski's bound.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.22}
question: Show that $|d_{K}|\rightarrow\infty$ as $n\rightarrow\infty$ in the preceding question.
solution: From integral calculus, $\log n!=n\log n-n+O(\log n)$, so that $\log|d_{K}|\ge(2+\log\frac{\pi}{4})n+O(\log n).$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.23}
question: (Hermite) Show that there are only finitely many algebraic number fields with a given discriminant.
solution: We give a brief hint of the proof. From the preceding question, the degree $n$ of $K$ is bounded. By Minkowski's theorem, we can find an element $\alpha\ne0$ in $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ so that $|\alpha^{(1)}|\le\sqrt{|d_{K}|},$ $|\alpha^{(i)}|<1$, $i=2,...,r.$ We must show $\alpha$ generates $K$, but this is not difficult. With these inequalities, the coefficients of the minimal polynomial of $\alpha$ are bounded. Since the coefficients are integers, there are only finitely many such polynomials.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.24}
question: Let $p$ be a prime $\equiv11$ (mod 12). If $p>3^{n}$, show that the ideal class group of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-p})$ has an element of order greater than $n$.
solution: Since $-p\equiv1$ (mod 3), $x^{2}\equiv-p$ (mod 3) has a solution and so 3 splits in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$. [Note: The context implies $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-p})$.] Write $(3)=\mathfrak{p}_{1}\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime}$. We claim the order of $\mathfrak{p}_{1}$ in the ideal class group is at least $n$. If not, $\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{m}$ is principal and equals $(u+v\sqrt{-p})$ (say) for some $m<n$. Taking norms, we see $3^{m}=u^{2}+pv^{2}$ has a solution. If $v\ne0$, this is a contradiction since $p>3^{n}$. If $v=0$, we get $m$ is even, so that $\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{m}=(u)=(3^{m/2})=\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{m/2}(\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{\prime})^{m/2}$, contradicting unique factorization.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.25}
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ where $\alpha$ is a root of the polynomial $f(x)=x^{5}-x+1$. Prove that $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$ has class number 1.
solution: Since $f(x)$ is a polynomial of the type described in Exercise 4.5.4, we deduce immediately that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)=5^{5}-4^{4}=2869=19\cdot151$. Since $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(\alpha)$ is squarefree, Exercise 4.5.26 tells us that $\mathfrak{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\alpha]$ and $d_{K}=2869$. A quick look at the graph of $f(x)=x^{5}-x+1$ shows that $r_{1}=1$ and $r_{2}=2$. Using Minkowski's bound, we find that every ideal class must contain an ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ of norm strictly less than 4. Therefore we must look at the numbers 2 and 3 to see how they factor in this ring. Let $\mathfrak{p}$ be an ideal such that $N\mathfrak{p}=2$ or 3. Then $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime, because $\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathfrak{p}$ is a field. Recall that to find $\mathfrak{p}$ we consider $f(x)$ mod $p$. If $f(x)\equiv f_{1}^{e_{1}}(x)\cdot\cdot\cdot f_{g}^{e_{g}}(x) \pmod p$, then $p\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ factors as $\mathfrak{p}_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{g}^{e_{g}}$ with $N\mathfrak{p}_{i}=p^{f_{i}}$ where $f_{i}$ is the degree of $f_{i}(x)$. First, suppose we have an ideal with $N\mathfrak{p}=2$. Then $\mathfrak{p}$ must appear in the prime factorization of $2\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and so in the factorization of $f(x)$ (mod 2), there is a linear factor. However, it is easy to see that $x^{5}-x+1$ has no linear factor mod 2, and so there are no ideals of norm 2. By a similar argument, we see that $x^{5}-x+1$ must have a linear factor mod 3, if there exists an ideal with norm 3. Again, it is clear that $x^{5}-x+1$ can have no linear factor, and we conclude that there are no ideals of norm 3 in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, the only ideal of norm less than 4 is the trivial ideal, and we conclude that $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ has class number 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.26}
question: Determine the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{14})$.
solution: The Minkowski bound in this case is $\frac{2!}{2^{2}}\sqrt{14\cdot4}=\sqrt{14}=3.74...$ Then we must check ideals of norm less than or equal to 3. Therefore we must look at $2\mathcal{O}_{K}$ and $3\mathcal{O}_{K}$ to see how they factor in this ring. Since 3 is inert, there are no ideals of norm 3. However, 2 ramifies as $(2)=(4+\sqrt{14})(4-\sqrt{14})=\mathfrak{p}^{2}$, where $\mathfrak{p}=(4+\sqrt{14})$. This is a principal ideal, and we conclude that all ideals of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{14})$ are principal and so the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 6.5.27}
question: If $K$ is an algebraic number field of finite degree over $\mathbb{Q}$ with $d_{K}$ squarefree, show that $K$ has no non-trivial subfields.
solution: By Exercise 6.5.13 and 5.6.25, any proper subfield would introduce a power into the discriminant of $K$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.1}
question: Let $p$ be a prime and $a \ne 0$. Show that $x^{2} \equiv a \pmod p$ has a solution if and only if $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$.
solution:
Suppose that $x^{2} \equiv a \pmod p$ has a solution. Let $x_{0}$ be this solution, i.e., $x_{0}^{2} \equiv a \pmod p$. But then, $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (x_{0}^{2})^{(p-1)/2} \equiv x_{0}^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. The last congruence follows from Fermat's Little Theorem.

We begin by noting that $a \not\equiv 0 \pmod p$. So $a \pmod p$ can be viewed as an element of $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{\times}$, the units of $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})$. Since $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{\times}$ is a cyclic group, there exists some generator $g$ such that $\langle g\rangle=(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{\times}$. So, $a=g^{k}$, where $1 \le k \le p-1$. From our hypothesis, $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv g^{k(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Because the order of $g$ is $p-1$, $p-1|k(p-1)/2.$ But this implies that $2|k$. So $k=2k^{\prime}$. So, we can write $a \pmod p$ as $a \equiv g^{k} \equiv g^{2k^{\prime}} \equiv (g^{k^{\prime}})^{2} \pmod p$. Hence $a$ is a square mod $p$, completing the proof.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.2}
question: Using Wilson's theorem and the congruence $k(p-k) \equiv -k^{2} \pmod p$, compute $(-1/p)$ for all primes $p$.
solution:
The case when $p=2$ is trivial since every odd number is congruent to 1 (mod 2). Then we will assume that $p$ is an odd prime. To begin, we recall Wilson's theorem (proved in Exercise 1.4.10) which states that for any prime $p$, we have $(p-1)! \equiv -1 \pmod p$. We note that $(p-1)!$ can be expressed as $(p-1)! = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot\cdot\cdot \frac{p-1}{2} \cdot (p-\frac{p-1}{2}) \cdot (p-(\frac{p-1}{2}-1)) \cdot\cdot\cdot (p-1).$ Thus, when we mod out by $p$ on both sides, we get $-1 \equiv 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot\cdot\cdot \frac{p-1}{2} \cdot (-\frac{p-1}{2}) \cdot (-(\frac{p-1}{2}-1)) \cdot\cdot\cdot (-1) \equiv (-1)^{(p-1)/2} [(\frac{p-1}{2})!]^{2} \pmod p$.

If $p \equiv 1 \pmod 4$, then it follows that $(p-1)/2=2a$ for some integer $a$. Hence, from the above identity, $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}[(\frac{p-1}{2})!]^{2} \equiv [(\frac{p-1}{2})!]^{2} \equiv -1 \pmod p$. So, $-1$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if $p \equiv 1 \pmod 4$.

If $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$, we find that $(p-1)/2$ is odd. If $x^{2} \equiv -1 \pmod p$, then by Exercise 7.1.1, $(-1)^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. But since $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$, we know that $(-1)^{(p-1)/2} \equiv -1 \pmod p$. So, there can be no solutions to $x^{2} \equiv -1 \pmod p$ if $p \equiv 3 \pmod 4$.

Thus $(\frac{-1}{p}) = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } p \equiv 1 \pmod 4, \\ -1 & \text{if } p \equiv 3 \pmod 4. \end{cases}$ Finally, we observe that we can encode this information more compactly as $(\frac{-1}{p}) = (-1)^{(p-1)/2}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.3}
question: Show that $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (\frac{a}{p}) \pmod p$.
solution:
If $p|a$, then the conclusion is trivial. So, suppose $p$ does not divide $a$. By Fermat's Little Theorem, $a^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. We can factor this statement as $a^{p-1}-1 \equiv (a^{(p-1)/2}-1)(a^{(p-1)/2}+1) \equiv 0 \pmod p$. Thus, $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv \pm 1 \pmod p$. We will consider each case separately.

If $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$, then by Exercise 7.1.1, there exists a solution to the equation $x^{2} \equiv a \pmod p$. But this implies $(a/p)=1$.

If $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv -1 \pmod p$, then Exercise 7.1.1 tells us there is no solution to the equation $x^{2} \equiv a \pmod p$. So, $(a/p)=-1$. We conclude that $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (\frac{a}{p}) \pmod p$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.4}
question: Show that $(\frac{ab}{p}) = (\frac{a}{p})(\frac{b}{p})$.
solution: We will use Exercise 7.1.3 to prove this result. Thus, $(\frac{ab}{p}) \equiv (ab)^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$. Similarly, $(\frac{a}{p}) \equiv a^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$ and $(\frac{b}{p}) \equiv b^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$. But then $(\frac{ab}{p}) \equiv (ab)^{(p-1)/2} = a^{(p-1)/2}b^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (\frac{a}{p})(\frac{b}{p}) \pmod p$. Thus $(\frac{ab}{p}) \equiv (\frac{a}{p})(\frac{b}{p}) \pmod p$. But because the Legendre symbol only takes on the values $\pm 1$, we can rewrite this statement as $(\frac{ab}{p}) = (\frac{a}{p})(\frac{b}{p})$ which is what we wished to show.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.5}
question: If $a \equiv b \pmod p$, show that $(\frac{a}{p}) = (\frac{b}{p})$.
solution: This is clear from the definition of the Legendre symbol. If $a$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ then so is $b$. The same is true if $a$ is a quadratic nonresidue.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.1.6}
question: For all odd primes $p$, show that $(\frac{2}{p}) = \begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } p \equiv \pm 1 \pmod 8, \\ -1 & \text{if } p \equiv 3, 5 \pmod 8. \end{cases}$
solution:
To exhibit this result, we will work in the field $\mathbb{Q}(i)$, where $i=\sqrt{-1}.$ Notice that the ring of integers of this field is $\mathbb{Z}[i]$. We wish to find when there exist solutions to $x^{2} \equiv 2 \pmod p$. We will make use of Exercise 7.1.1 which tells us there exists a solution if and only if $2^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$.

Working in $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, we observe that $(1+i)^{2} = 1+2i+i^{2} = 2i$. Also, for $p$ prime, $(1+i)^{p} = 1+\binom{p}{1}i+\binom{p}{2}i^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+i^{p}.$ Considering the above equation mod $p\mathbb{Z}[i]$ we get $(1+i)^{p} \equiv 1+i^{p} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. But we also observe that $(1+i)^{p} = (1+i)(1+i)^{p-1} = (1+i)((1+i)^{2})^{(p-1)/2} = (1+i)(2i)^{(p-1)/2} = i^{(p-1)/2}(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2}.$ So, $i^{(p-1)/2}(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1+i^{p} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$.

We now consider the various possibilities for $p \pmod 8$.

If $p \equiv 1 \pmod 8$, then $i^{p}=i.$ As well, $i^{(p-1)/2}=1$. So, the equation becomes $(1+i) \equiv (1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$, which implies $1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. So, $1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$, and thus $(2/p)=1$ by Exercise 7.1.1.

If $p \equiv -1 \pmod 8$, then $i^{p}=-i$. As well, $i^{(p-1)/2}=-i$. So, the equation becomes $(1-i) \equiv -i(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$, which implies $1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. Again, we have $1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$, and thus $(2/p)=1$.

If $p \equiv 3 \pmod 8$, then $i^{p}=-i$. Also, $i^{(p-1)/2}=i$. So, the equation becomes $(1-i) \equiv i(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. So $-i(1+i) \equiv i(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$, which simplifies to $-1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. Since $1 \not\equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod p$, $(2/p)=-1$.

Finally, if $p \equiv 5 \pmod 8$, then $i^{p}=i$. As well, $i^{(p-1)/2}=-1$. From this, it follows that $(1+i) \equiv -1(1+i)2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$, so $-1 \equiv 2^{(p-1)/2} \pmod{p\mathbb{Z}[i]}$. Hence, $(2/p)=-1$ thus completing the proof.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.7}
question: Show that the number of quadratic residues mod $p$ is equal to the number of quadratic nonresidues mod $p$.
solution: The equation $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$ will have $(p-1)/2$ solutions. This can be deduced from the fact that $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{\times}$ is a cyclic group with some generator $g$, where $g$ is a $(p-1)$-st root of unity. So, for any even power of $g$, i.e., $g^{2k}$, we will have $(g^{2k})^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (g^{p-1})^{k} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. For any odd power, $(g^{2k+1})^{(p-1)/2} \equiv (g^{(p-1)/2}) \not\equiv 1 \pmod p$. The last congruence holds since $g$ is a $(p-1)$-st root of unity. Thus, half of the elements of $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^{\times}$ will correspond to some even power of $g$, and hence, $a^{(p-1)/2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. But this in turn implies that there are $(p-1)/2$ elements such that $(a/p)=1$. Since there are $(p-1)$ residues mod $p$, there are $(p-1)-(p-1)/2=(p-1)/2$ residues that are not squares. But now we have that the number of quadratic residues mod $p$ and the number of quadratic nonresidues mod $p$ are equal.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.1.8}
question: Show that $\sum_{a=1}^{p-1}(\frac{a}{p})=0$ for any fixed prime $p$.
solution: From Exercise 7.1.7, the number of residues equals the number of nonresidues. So, there are $(p-1)/2$ residues, and $(p-1)/2$ nonresidues. Thus $\sum_{a=1}^{p-1}(\frac{a}{p})=\frac{p-1}{2}(1)+\frac{p-1}{2}(-1)=0.$

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.2.1}
question: For $S=\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{a}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a}$, show that $S^{2}=(\frac{-1}{p})p.$
solution:
From the definition of a Gauss sum, we have $S^{2}=(\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{a}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a})(\sum_{b \pmod p}(\frac{b}{p})\zeta_{p}^{b})$. By applying Exercise 7.1.4, we can simplify the above to get $S^{2}=\sum_{a,b}(\frac{ab}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a+b}.$ We now make a substitution by letting $b=ca$, where $(c,p)=1$. Thus, $S^{2}=\sum_{(a,p)=1}\sum_{(c,p)=1}(\frac{a^{2}c}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)}.$ Again, using Exercise 7.1.4, we get $S^{2}=\sum_{(a,p)=1}\sum_{(c,p)=1}(\frac{c}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)} =\sum_{(c,p)=1}(\frac{c}{p})(\sum_{(a,p)=1}\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)})$.

Observe that $(1+c,p)=1$ or $(1+c,p)=p.$ Since $(c,p)=1$, the second case will only happen if $c=p-1$. But then, if $(1+c,p)=1$, we will have $\sum_{(a,p)=1}\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)}=\zeta_{p}^{(1+c)}+\zeta_{p}^{2(1+c)}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\zeta_{p}^{(p-1)(1+c)}=-1.$ But $(1+c,p)=p$ implies that $\sum_{(a,p)=1}\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)}=1+1^{2}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+1^{p-1}=p-1$.

Thus $S^{2}=\sum_{(c,p)=1}(\frac{c}{p})(\sum_{(a,p)=1}\zeta_{p}^{a(1+c)}) =\sum_{1\le c\le p-2}(\frac{c}{p})(-1)+(\frac{p-1}{p})(p-1) =(-1)\sum_{1\le c\le p-2}(\frac{c}{p})+(\frac{-1}{p})(p-1).$ But $\sum_{1\le c\le p-2}(\frac{c}{p})=\sum_{1\le c\le p-1}(\frac{c}{p})-(\frac{-1}{p})$. From Exercise 7.1.8, we know that the first term on the right-hand side must be equal to 0. So, $S^{2}=(-1)[-(\frac{-1}{p})]+(\frac{-1}{p})(p-1) =(\frac{-1}{p})+(\frac{-1}{p})(p-1) =(\frac{-1}{p})p.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.2.2}
question: Show that $S^q \equiv (\frac{q}{p})S \pmod q$, where $q$ and $p$ are odd primes.
solution: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{q})$, where $\zeta_{q}$ is a primitive $q$th root of unity. Let $R=\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be its ring of integers. So $S^{q}=[\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{a}{p})\zeta_{p}^{a}]^{q} \equiv\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{a}{p})^{q}\zeta_{p}^{aq} \pmod{qR}.$ This follows from the fact that $(x_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n})^{q}\equiv x_{1}^{q}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x_{n}^{q} \pmod q$. Also, because $q$ is an odd prime, and because $(a/p)$ only takes on the values $\pm1$, we have $(a/p)^{q}=(a/p)$. Hence $S^{q}\equiv\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{a}{p})\zeta_{p}^{aq} \pmod{qR}.$ However, $(\frac{a}{p})=(\frac{a}{p})(\frac{q^{2}}{p})=(\frac{aq^{2}}{p})$. So, it follows that $S^{q}\equiv\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{aq^{2}}{p})\zeta_{p}^{aq} \pmod{qR} \equiv(\frac{q}{p})\sum_{a \pmod p}(\frac{aq}{p})\zeta_{p}^{aq} \pmod{qR}.$ But as $a$ runs through all the residue classes mod $p$, so will $aq$. Thus, $S^{q}\equiv(\frac{q}{p})S \pmod{qR}.$ From this, it follows that $S^q \equiv (\frac{q}{p})S \pmod q$, completing the proof.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.3.1}
question: (Law of Quadratic Reciprocity) Let $p$ and $q$ be odd primes. Show that $(\frac{p}{q})=(\frac{q}{p})(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q-1}{2}}.$
solution: From Exercise 7.2.2, we have $S^q \equiv (\frac{q}{p})S \pmod q$. Thus, cancelling out an $S$ from both sides will give us $S^{q-1}\equiv(\frac{q}{p}) \pmod q$. Since $q$ is odd, $q-1$ must be divisible by 2. So $S^{q-1}=(S^{2})^{(q-1)/2}=[p(\frac{-1}{p})]^{(q-1)/2}$. The last equality follows from Theorem 7.2.1. Thus, $(\frac{q}{p})\equiv[p(\frac{-1}{p})]^{(q-1)/2} \pmod q.$ From Exercise 7.1.2, $(-1/p)=(-1)^{(p-1)/2}$. We substitute this into the above equation to get $(\frac{q}{p})\equiv p^{\frac{q-1}{2}}(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q-1}{2}} \pmod q.$ Exercise 7.1.3 tells us that $p^{(q-1)/2}\equiv(p/q) \pmod q$. So, $(\frac{q}{p})\equiv(\frac{p}{q})(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q-1}{2}} \pmod q$. But both sides only take on the value $\pm1$, and since $q\ge3$ the congruence can be replaced by an equals sign. This gives us $(\frac{p}{q})=(\frac{q}{p})(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q-1}{2}}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.3.2 (a)}
question: Let $q$ be an odd prime. Prove that if $q\equiv1 \pmod 4$, then $q$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if and only if $p\equiv r \pmod q$, where $r$ is a quadratic residue mod $q$.
solution: We begin by rewriting the result of Theorem 7.3.1 in the following equivalent form: $(\frac{p}{q})(\frac{q}{p})=(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q-1}{2}}.$ Since $q\equiv1 \pmod 4$, $(q-1)/2$ is even, so we will have $(\frac{p}{q})(\frac{q}{p})=1.$ From this it follows that either $(p/q)=1=(q/p)$ or $(p/q)=-1=(q/p)$. We can now prove the statement. If $(q/p)=1$, then $(p/q)=1.$ So, by Exercise 7.1.5, $p\equiv r \pmod q$, where $r$ is a quadratic residue mod $q$. Suppose $p\equiv r \pmod q$, and $(r/q)=1$. But then $(p/q)=(r/q)$, and thus, $(p/q)=1$. Since $(q/p)=(p/q)$ by quadratic reciprocity, we must also have that $(q/p)=1$, which implies that $q$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$. This completes the proof of (a).

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.3.2 (b)}
question: Let $q$ be an odd prime. Prove that if $q\equiv3 \pmod 4$, then $q$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if and only if $p\equiv\pm b^{2} \pmod{4q}$, where $b$ is an odd integer prime to $q$.
solution:
Suppose $q\equiv3 \pmod 4$. Then, quadratic reciprocity gives us $(\frac{q}{p})=(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}}(\frac{p}{q})$. Suppose $(q/p)=1$. Then, we have two cases:
Case 1. $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=-1$ and $(p/q)=-1$.
Case 2. $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=1$ and $(p/q)=1$.

Case 1. First we note that $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=-1$ implies that $p\equiv3 \pmod 4$. Because $q\equiv3 \pmod 4$, we have from an earlier exercise that $(\frac{-1}{q})=-1$. But then, we find that $(p/q)=(\frac{-1}{q})(\frac{b^{2}}{q})=(\frac{-b^{2}}{q})$. Hence $(p/q)=(-b^{2}/q)$, and $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod q$. We can suppose that $b$ is odd. If not, we can replace it with $b^{\prime}=b+q,$ which is odd. Since $b$ is odd, $b=2n+1$. Thus $b^{2}=4n^{2}+4n+1$, and so $-b^{2}\equiv3 \pmod 4$. Since we already deduced that $p\equiv3 \pmod 4$, we have $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod 4$. Because $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod q$, we conclude that $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod{4q}$.

Case 2. $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=1$ implies that $p\equiv1 \pmod 4$. Also, $(p/q)=(b^{2}/q)$. Assume $b$ is odd for the same reason given above. So $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod q$. Because $b$ is odd, we have $b=2n+1$, which means that $b^{2}\equiv1 \pmod 4$. But $p\equiv1 \pmod 4$, so clearly $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod 4$. Since we also know that $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod q$, we conclude that $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod{4q}$.

Suppose we have $p\equiv\pm b^{2} \pmod{4q}$, where $b$ is coprime to $q$. We will examine each case, $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod{4q}$ and $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod{4q}$ separately.

If $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod{4q}$, we have $p\equiv b^{2}\equiv1 \pmod 4$, and $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod q$. But $p\equiv1 \pmod 4$ implies that $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=1$. Since $p\equiv b^{2} \pmod q$ it follows that $(\frac{p}{q})=1=(\frac{b^{2}}{q})$. Hence $(\frac{q}{p})=(-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2}}(\frac{p}{q})=1\cdot1=1,$ so $q$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$.

If $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod{4q}$, we have both that $p\equiv-b^{2}\equiv3 \pmod 4$, and $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod q$. So, $(-1)^{(p-1)/2}=-1$ from the fact that $p\equiv3 \pmod 4$. From $p\equiv-b^{2} \pmod q$, we deduce that $(\frac{p}{q})=(\frac{-b^{2}}{q})=(\frac{-1}{q})(\frac{b^{2}}{q})=(\frac{-1}{q})$. Since $q\equiv3 \pmod 4$, we know that $(-1/q)=-1.$ So, $(p/q)=-1.$ Thus, $(\frac{q}{p})=(-1)^{(p-1)/2}(\frac{p}{q})=(-1)(-1)=1.$ It now follows that $q$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.3.3}
question: Compute $(\frac{5}{p})$ and $(\frac{7}{p})$.
solution:
We will first compute $(5/p)$. Since $5\equiv1 \pmod 4$, we can use part (a) of Exercise 7.3.2. So $(5/p)=1$ if and only if $p\equiv r \pmod 5$, where $r$ is a quadratic residue mod 5. It is easy to determine which $r$ are quadratic residues mod 5; $1^{2}\equiv1$, $2^{2}\equiv4$, $3^{2}\equiv4$, $4^{2}\equiv1$. So, 1 and 4 are quadratic residues mod 5, while 2 and 3 are not. Thus $(\frac{5}{p})=\begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } p\equiv 1,4 \pmod 5, \\ -1 & \text{if } p\equiv 2,3 \pmod 5, \\ 0 & \text{if } p=5. \end{cases}$

Now, we will find $(7/p)$. Since $7\equiv3 \pmod 4$, we must use part (b) of Exercise 7.3.2. So, we have to compute all the residues mod 28 of all the squares of odd integers prime to 7. Some calculation reveals that $1^{2}, 13^{2}, 15^{2}, 27^{2}\equiv1 \pmod{28}$, $3^{2}, 11^{2}, 17^{2}, 25^{2}\equiv9 \pmod{28}$, and $5^{2}, 9^{2}, 17^{2}?, 23^{2}\equiv25 \pmod{28}$. [Note: 19^2 = 361 = 12*28 + 25. 9^2=81=2*28+25. 23^2=529=18*28+25]. Thus $(\frac{7}{p})=\begin{cases} 1 & \text{if } p\equiv\pm1,\pm9,\pm25 \pmod{28}, \\ -1 & \text{if } p\equiv\pm5,\pm11,\pm13 \pmod{28}, \\ 0 & \text{if } p=7. \end{cases}$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.4.1 (a)}
question: Find the discriminant of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$ when $d\equiv2,3 \pmod 4$.
solution: If $d\equiv2,3 \pmod 4$, then $\omega_{1}=1$, $\omega_{2}=\sqrt{d}$ forms an integral basis for $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Then an easy calculation shows that $d_{K}=4d.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.4.1 (b)}
question: Find the discriminant of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$ when $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$.
solution: For $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$, then $\omega_{1}=1$, $\omega_{2}=(1+\sqrt{d})/2$ forms an integral basis. Then $d_{K}=d$.

In the comments after Exercise 7.4.1 we noted that $\{1,(m+\sqrt{m})/2\}$ always forms an integral basis of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ where $m=d$ if $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$ and $m=4d$ if $d\equiv2,3 \pmod 4$. Since $\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{p}^{\prime}=p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ there must exist $a\in\mathfrak{p}$, but $a

We can write $a\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{q}, \mathfrak{q}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Now, taking the norms of both sides, we discover that $N(\mathfrak{p})=p$ must divide $N(a\mathcal{O}_{K})=|(x+ rac{ym}{2})^{2}- rac{y^{2}m}{4}|.$ So, $(2x+ym)^{2}\equiv y^{2}m \pmod p$. If $p|y$ then $p|(2x+ym)^{2}$. But then $p|2x$, and since $p$ is odd, $p|x$. This contradicts the fact that $p$ did not divide both $x$ and $y$. So $p$ does not divide $y$, and since $\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ is a field, $ rac{(2x+ym)^{2}}{y^{2}}\equiv m \pmod p$. But then we have found some $z$ such that $z^{2}\equiv m \pmod p$. Since $m=d$ or $m=4d,$ then $(d/p)=1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.4.3}
question: Assume that $p$ is an odd prime. Show that $(d/p)=0$ if and only if $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}^{2}$, where $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime.
solution:
We claim that $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=(p,\sqrt{d})^{2}$. Notice that $(p,\sqrt{d})^{2}=(p^{2},p\sqrt{d},d)=(p)(p,\sqrt{d},d/p).$ Because $d$ is squarefree, $d/p$ and $p$ are relatively prime. So, $(p,\sqrt{d},d/p)=1.$ Since $(p,\sqrt{d})$ is a prime ideal (for the same reason given above), we have shown that $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ ramifies.

Once again, let $m$ be the discriminant of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$. Since $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ ramifies we can find some $a\in\mathfrak{p}$, but $a\notin p\mathcal{O}_{K}$. So, $a=x+y(m+\sqrt{m})/2$. Since $a^{2}\in p\mathcal{O}_{K}$, we get $\frac{(2x+ym)^{2}+my^{2}}{4}+2y\frac{(2x+ym)}{4}\sqrt{m}\in p\mathcal{O}_{K}$. Thus, $p|(2x+ym)^{2}+my^{2}$ and $p|y(2x+ym)$. If $p|y$, then $p|2x$. Since $p$ is odd, $p|x$. But then $a\in p\mathcal{O}_{K}$. This is a contradiction. So, $p|(2x+ym)$ and $p|my^{2}$. Thus, $p|m$. But this means that $(d/p)=0$, since $p$ is an odd prime.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.4.4}
question: Assume $p$ is an odd prime. Then $(d/p)=-1$ if and only if $p\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}$, where $\mathfrak{p}$ is prime.
solution: This follows immediately from Theorem 7.4.3 [Note: Reference should be 7.4.2] and Exercise 7.4.3. If $(d/p)=-1$ then we know that $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ does not split, nor does it ramify. So $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ must stay inert. Conversely, if $p\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is inert, the only possible value for $(d/p)$ is -1.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.4.5 (a)}
question: Suppose $p=2$. Show that $2\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}^{2}$, $\mathfrak{p}$ prime if and only if $2|d_{K}$.
solution:
If $2|d_{K}$, then $d\equiv2,3 \pmod 4$. If $d\equiv2 \pmod 4$, then we claim that $(2)=(2,\sqrt{d})^{2}.$ Note that $(2,\sqrt{d})^{2}=(4,2\sqrt{d},d)=(2)(2,\sqrt{d},d/2)$. Since $d$ is squarefree, then 2 and $d/2$ are relatively prime and thus the second ideal above is actually $\mathcal{O}_{K}.$ So $(2)=(2,\sqrt{d})^{2}$.

If $d\equiv3 \pmod 4$ we claim that $(2)=(2,1+\sqrt{d})^{2}$, since $(2,1+\sqrt{d})^{2}=(4,2+2\sqrt{d},1+d+2\sqrt{d})=(2)(2,1+\sqrt{d},\frac{1+d}{2}+\sqrt{d})$. Now we note that $1+\sqrt{d}$ and $(1+d)/2+\sqrt{d}$ are relatively prime, and so the second ideal is $\mathcal{O}_{K}$.

We consider $d_{K}$, which we know is congruent to either 0 or 1 mod 4. Suppose that $d_{K}\equiv1 \pmod 4$. Then $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ is generated as a Z-module by $1, (1+\sqrt{d})/2$. There must exist some element $a$ in $\mathfrak{p}$ which is not in $\mathfrak{p}^{2}.$ So $a=m+n(1+\sqrt{d})/2$ where we can assume that $m$ and $n$ are either 0 or 1, since for any $\alpha\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$, $a+2\alpha$ is in $\mathfrak{p}$ but not in $\mathfrak{p}^{2}$. Now, if $n=0$, then $m\ne0$ because otherwise $a=0$ and is obviously in (2). But if $m=1$, then $a=1$ and $a\notin\mathfrak{p}$. So, $n=1$ and $m=0$ or 1. We know that $a^{2}\in(2)$, and $a^{2}=(m+\frac{1+\sqrt{d}}{2})^{2} =m^{2}+\frac{d-1}{4}+(2m+1)\frac{1+\sqrt{d}}{2}\in(2).$ But $2m+1$ is odd and so $a^{2}\notin(2)$ and we have arrived at a contradiction. We conclude that $d_{K}\equiv0 \pmod 4$, and so clearly $2|d_{K}$.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.4.5 (b)}
question: Suppose $p=2$. Show that $2\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{p}^{\prime}$, $\mathfrak{p}$ prime if and only if $d\equiv1 \pmod 8$ and $2 \nmid d_{K}$.
solution:
Suppose that $d\equiv1 \pmod 8$. Then clearly from the previous problem $2 
mid d_{K}$. We claim that $(2)=(2,(1+\sqrt{d})/2)(2,(1-\sqrt{d})/2)$. Note that $(2, rac{1+\sqrt{d}}{2})(2, rac{1-\sqrt{d}}{2})=(2)(2, rac{1+\sqrt{d}}{2}, rac{1-\sqrt{d}}{2}, rac{1-d}{8})$. But the second ideal is just $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ since it contains $1=(1+\sqrt{d})/2+(1-\sqrt{d})/2$.

Now suppose that (2) splits in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$. We know from part (a) that $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$. If $(2)=\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{p}^{\prime}$, then $N(\mathfrak{p})=2$. There exists an element $a$ which is in $\mathfrak{p}$ but not in $\mathfrak{p}\mathfrak{p}^{\prime}=(2)$. Then $a=m+n(1+\sqrt{d})/2$ where not both $m, n$ are even. Therefore 2 divides the norm of the ideal generated by $a$, and $N((a))=|N(a)|=| rac{(2m+n)^{2}}{4}- rac{n^{2}d}{4}|$. So $(2m+n)^{2}\equiv n^{2}d \pmod 8$. We know that $2 
mid d$. So suppose that $n$ is even, and further suppose that $n=2n_{1}$ where $n_{1}$ is odd. Then $2 | (m+n_{1})^{2}+n_{1}^{2}d,$ and since $2|n_{1}^{2}d$ then $2 
mid (m+n_{1})^{2}$, which implies that $m$ is even. But we assumed that not both $m$ and $n$ were even. Now suppose that $4|n$. Then $4|(2m+n)$ and so $m$ is even, a contradiction. Then $n$ must be odd, and we can find an integer $n_{2}$ such that $nn_{2}\equiv1 \pmod 8$. Then $d\equiv n_{2}^{2}(2m+n)^{2} \pmod 8$, and since $2 
mid d$, we conclude $n_{2}(2m+n)$ is odd, and $d\equiv1 \pmod 8$, as desired.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 7.4.5 (c)}
question: Suppose $p=2$. Show that $2\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathfrak{p}$, $\mathfrak{p}$ prime if and only if $d\equiv5 \pmod 8$ and $2 \nmid d_{K}$.
solution: Just as in Exercise 7.4.4, this follows directly from parts (a) and (b), since if $2 \nmid d_{K}$ and $d\not\equiv1 \pmod 8$, then $d\equiv5 \pmod 8$. We know that (2) cannot split or ramify in this case, so it must remain inert.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.5.1}
question: Show that there are infinitely many primes of the form $4k+1$.
solution: Suppose there are only a finite number of primes of this form. Let $p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}$ be these primes. Let $d=(2p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}+1$. Let $p$ be a prime that divides this number. So $d\equiv0 \pmod p$, which implies that $(-1/p)=1$. From Exercise 7.1.2, we know that this only occurs if $p\equiv1 \pmod 4$. So, $p\in\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$. But for any $p_{i}\in\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$, $p_{i}$ does not divide $d$ by construction. So $p\notin\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$. Thus, our assumption is incorrect, and so, there must exist an infinite number of primes of the form $4k+1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.5.2}
question: Show that there are infinitely many primes of the form $8k+7$.
solution: Suppose the statement is false, that is, there exist only a finite number of primes of the form $8k+7$. Let $p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}$ be these primes. Construct the following integer, $d=(4p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-2$. Let $p$ be any prime that divides this number. But then $(4p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}\equiv2 \pmod p$, so $(2/p)=1$. From Theorem 7.1.6, we can deduce that $p\equiv\pm1 \pmod 8$. We claim that all the odd primes that divide $d$ cannot have the form $8k+1$. We observe that $d = (4p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-2$. So, any odd prime that divides $d$ must divide $8(p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-1$. If all primes were of the form $8k+1$, we would have $8(p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-1=(8k_{1}+1)^{e_{1}}\cdot(8k_{2}+1)^{e_{2}}\cdot\cdot\cdot(8k_{m}+1)^{e_{m}}$. But now consider this equation mod 8. We find that $-1\equiv1 \pmod 8$, which is clearly false. So, there must be at least one odd prime $p$ of the form $8k+7$ that divides $d$. So, $p\in\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$. But $p$ cannot be in $\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$ since every $p_{i}$ leaves a remainder of -2 when dividing $d$. So, $\{p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}\}$ does not contain all the primes of the form $8k+7$. But we assumed that it did. We have arrived at a contradiction. Therefore, there must be an infinite number of primes of the form $8k+7$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.5.3}
question: Show that $p\equiv4 \pmod 5$ for infinitely many primes $p$.
solution: From the preceding comments, we know that we can use a Euclid-type proof to prove this assertion since $4^{2}\equiv1 \pmod 5$. So, suppose there exists only a finite number of such primes, say $p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}$. Consider the integer $25(p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-5$. Then for any prime divisor not equal to 5, we will have $(5/p)=1$. From Exercise 7.3.3, we know that this will only occur if $p\equiv1,4 \pmod 5$. Since $p\ne5$, then $p|5(p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-1$. So, all the prime divisors cannot be congruent to 1 (mod 5), because if this was true, $-1\equiv1 \pmod 5$ which is clearly false. So, there is some $p\equiv4 \pmod 5$ that divides $5(p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-1$. But $p$ is not any of the $p_{1},...,p_{n}$ since none of these numbers divide $5(p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})^{2}-1$. This gives us a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Example 7.5.4}
question: Show there are an infinite number of primes in the arithmetic progession $15k+4$.
solution:
Since $4^{2}\equiv1 \pmod{15}$, we can use a Euclid-type proof. We will start with a couple of observations about the polynomial $f(x)=x^{4}-x^{3}+2x^{2}+x+1$. First, we note that it can be factored in the following three ways:
(7.2) $f(x)=(x^{2}-\frac{x}{2}-1)^{2}+\frac{15}{4}x^{2},$
(7.3) $f(x)=(-x^{2}+\frac{x}{2}-\frac{1}{2})^2 - \frac{3}{4}(x+1)^2$
(7.4) $f(x)=(-x^{2}+\frac{x}{2}-\frac{3}{2})^2 - \frac{5}{4}(x-1)^{2}$

We note by (7.2) that if $p$ divides $f(x)$, then 15 is a quadratic residue mod $p$. By quadratic reciprocity, $(\frac{p}{3})(\frac{p}{5})=1.$ So, there will be a solution only if $(p/3)=1$ and $(p/5)=1$ or if they both equal -1. The first case will happen if $p\equiv1 \pmod 3$ and $p\equiv1,4 \pmod 5$. The second happens if $p\equiv2 \pmod 3$ and $p\equiv2,3 \pmod 5$. So, $(\frac{p}{15})=1$ if $p\equiv1,2,4,8 \pmod{15}$, and $-1$ if $p\equiv7,11,13 \pmod{15}$.

From equation (7.3), we see that $(-3/p)=1$. Using Exercise 7.3.2, $(\frac{3}{p})=1$ if $p\equiv1,11 \pmod{12}$, and $-1$ if $p\equiv5,7 \pmod{12}$. So, since we already know what $(-1/p)$ is, we find that $(\frac{-3}{p})=1$ if $p\equiv1,7 \pmod{12}$, and $-1$ if $p\equiv5,11 \pmod{12}$.

Finally, equation (7.4) tells us that $(5/p)=1$. But we know this only happens when $p\equiv1,4 \pmod 5$. When we combine all these results, we find that any prime divisor of $f(x)$ must be congruent to either 1 (mod 15) or 4 (mod 15). We can now begin the Euclid-type proof. Suppose that there were only a finite number of primes such that $p\equiv4 \pmod{15}$. Let $p_{1},...,p_{n}$ be these primes. We now consider the integer $d=f(15p_{1}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n}+1).$ From what we have just said, $d$ is divisible by some prime $p$ such that $p\equiv1,4 \pmod 5$. Not all the prime divisors have the form $p\equiv1 \pmod 5$. This follows from the fact that $d=f(15p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n}+1)=15p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n}g(p_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{n})+4$ where $g(x)$ is some polynomial. So, there is a divisor $p$ such that $p\equiv4 \pmod{15}$. But $p$ cannot be in $p_{1},p_{2},...,p_{n}$ because when they divide $d$, they leave a remainder of 4. This gives us the needed contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.1}
question: Compute $(11/p)$.
solution: Since $11\equiv3 \pmod 4$, we use Exercise 7.3.2 (b) which says that 11 is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if and only if $p\equiv\pm b^{2} \pmod{44}$ where $b$ is an odd integer prime to $p$. If we compute $b^{2} \pmod{44}$ for all possible $b$, we get $1^{2}, 21^{2}, 23^{2}, 43^{2} \equiv 1 \pmod{44}$, $3^{2}, 19^{2}, 25^{2}, 41^{2} \equiv 9 \pmod{44}$, $5^{2}, 17^{2}, 27^{2}, 39^{2} \equiv 25 \pmod{44}$, $7^{2}, 15^{2}, 29^{2}, 37^{2} \equiv 5 \pmod{44}$, $9^{2}, 13^{2}, 31^{2}, 35^{2} \equiv 37 \pmod{44}$. It is now easy to determine the primes for which 11 is a quadratic residue by applying Exercise 7.3.2.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.3}
question: If $p\equiv1 \pmod 3$, prove that there are integers $a, b$ such that $p=a^{2}-ab+b^{2}$.
solution: Let $\rho=(1+\sqrt{-3})/2$ and consider $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$. The ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$ is $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Since $p\equiv1 \pmod 3$, $x^{2}+3\equiv0 \pmod p$ has a solution. Hence $p$ splits in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Now use the fact that $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is Euclidean.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.4}
question: If $p\equiv\pm1 \pmod 8$, show that there are integers $a, b$ such that $a^{2}-2b^{2}=\pm p$.
solution: Consider the Euclidean ring $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{2}]$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.5}
question: If $p\equiv\pm1 \pmod 5$, show that there are integers $a, b$ such that $a^{2}+ab-b^{2}=\pm p.$
solution: Let $\omega=(1+\sqrt{5})/2$ and consider $\mathbb{Z}[\omega]$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.10}
question: Show that the number of solutions of the congruence $x^{2}+y^{2}\equiv1 \pmod p$, $0<x<p$, $0<y<p$ ($p$ an odd prime), is even if and only if $p\equiv\pm3 \pmod 8$.
solution: Pair up the solutions, $(x, y)$ with $(y, x)$. The number of solutions is even unless $(x, x)$ is a solution which means that 2 is a square mod $p$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.11}
question: If $p$ is a prime such that $p-1=4q$ with $q$ prime, show that 2 is a primitive root mod $p$.
solution: The only possible orders of 2 (mod $p$) are 1, 2, 4, $q$, $2q$, or $4q$. Since $p>q$ the orders 1, 2, 4 are impossible. If the order is $q$ or $2q$, then 2 is a quadratic residue mod $p$. However, $p\equiv5 \pmod 8$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.12}
question:
(The Jacobi Symbol) Let $Q$ be a positive odd number. We can write $Q=q_{1}q_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot q_{s}$ where the $q_{i}$ are odd primes, not necessarily distinct. Define the Jacobi symbol $(\frac{a}{Q})=\prod_{j=1}^{s}(\frac{a}{q_{i}})$. If $Q$ and $Q^{\prime}$ are odd and positive, show that:
(a) $(a/Q)(a/Q^{\prime})=(a/QQ^{\prime})$
(b) $(a/Q)(a^{\prime}/Q)=(aa^{\prime}/Q)$.
(c) $(a/Q)=(a^{\prime}/Q)$ if $a\equiv a^{\prime} \pmod Q$.
solution: All of these are evident from the properties of the Legendre symbol. For (c), note that $a\equiv a^{\prime} \pmod Q$ implies $a\equiv a^{\prime} \pmod{q_i}$ for $i=1,2,...,s.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.13}
question: If $Q$ is odd and positive, show that $(\frac{-1}{Q})=(-1)^{(Q-1)/2}.$
solution: $(\frac{-1}{Q})=\prod_{j=1}^{s}(\frac{-1}{q_{j}})=\prod_{j=1}^{s}(-1)^{(q_{j}-1)/2}=(-1)^{\sum_{j=1}^{s}(q_{j}-1)/2}.$ Now, if $a$ and $b$ are odd, observe that $\frac{ab-1}{2}-(\frac{a-1}{2}+\frac{b-1}{2})=\frac{(a-1)(b-1)}{2}\equiv0 \pmod 2$. Hence $\frac{a-1}{2}+\frac{b-1}{2} \equiv \frac{ab-1}{2} \pmod 2$. Applying this observation repeatedly in our context gives $(\frac{-1}{Q})=(-1)^{(Q-1)/2}.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.14}
question: If $Q$ is odd and positive, show that $(2/Q)=(-1)^{(Q^{2}-1)/8}$.
solution: If $a$ and $b$ are odd, then $\frac{a^{2}b^{2}-1}{8}-(\frac{a^{2}-1}{8}+\frac{b^{2}-1}{8})=\frac{(a^{2}-1)(b^{2}-1)}{8}\equiv0 \pmod 8$. so we have $\frac{a^{2}-1}{8}+\frac{b^{2}-1}{8} \equiv \frac{a^{2}b^{2}-1}{8} \pmod 8$. Again applying this repeatedly in our context gives the result.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.15}
question: (Reciprocity Law for the Jacobi Symbol) If $P$ and $Q$ are odd, positive, and coprime, show that $(\frac{P}{Q})(\frac{Q}{P})=(-1)^{\frac{P-1}{2}\cdot\frac{Q-1}{2}}$
solution: Write $P=\prod_{i=1}^{r}p_{i}$ and $Q=\prod_{j=1}^{s}q_{j}$. Then $(\frac{P}{Q})=\prod_{j=1}^{s}(\frac{P}{q_{j}})=\prod_{j=1}^{s}\prod_{i=1}^{r}(\frac{p_{i}}{q_{j}}) =\prod_{j=1}^{s}\prod_{i=1}^{r}(\frac{q_{j}}{p_{i}})(-1)^{\frac{p_{i}-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q_{j}-1}{2}} =(\frac{Q}{P})(-1)^{\sum_{i,j}\frac{p_{i}-1}{2}\cdot\frac{q_{j}-1}{2}}$ by the reciprocity law for the Legendre symbol. But, as noted in the previous exercises, $\sum_{i=1}^{r}\frac{p_{i}-1}{2} \equiv \frac{P-1}{2} \pmod 2$ and $\sum_{j=1}^{s}\frac{q_{j}-1}{2}\equiv\frac{Q-1}{2} \pmod 2,$ which completes the proof.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.16}
question: (The Kronecker Symbol) We can define $(a/n)$ for any integer $a\equiv0$ or 1 (mod 4), as follows. Define $(\frac{a}{2})=(\frac{a}{-2})=\begin{cases}0&if~a\equiv0~(mod~4),\\ 1~if~a\equiv1~(mod~8),\\ -1~if~a\equiv5~(mod~8).\end{cases}$ For general $n$, write $n=2^{c}n_{1}$, with $n_{1}$ odd, and define $(\frac{a}{n})=(\frac{a}{2})^{c}(\frac{a}{n_{1}})$ where $(a/2)$ is defined as above and $(a/n_{1})$ is the Jacobi symbol. Show that if $d$ is the discriminant of a quadratic field, and $n, m$ are positive integers, then $(\frac{d}{n})=(\frac{d}{m})$ for $n\equiv m \pmod d$ and $(\frac{d}{n})=(\frac{d}{m})sgn~d$ for $n\equiv-m \pmod d$.
solution: Let $d=2^{a}d^{\prime}$, $n=2^{b}n^{\prime}$, $m=2^{c}m^{\prime}$ with $d^{\prime}$, $n^{\prime}.$ $m^{\prime}$ odd. If $a>0$, the case $b>0$ is trivial since then $c>0$ and both the symbols are zero. So suppose $b=c=0$. Then $(\frac{d}{n})=(\frac{2^{a}d^{\prime}}{n})=(\frac{2}{n})^{a}(\frac{d^{\prime}}{n})=(-1)^{a(n^{2}-1)/8}(\frac{n}{d^{\prime}})(-1)^{(n-1)(d^{\prime}-1)/4}$ and similarly $(\frac{d}{m})=(\frac{2^{a}d^{\prime}}{m})=(-1)^{a(m^{2}-1)/8}(\frac{m}{d^{\prime}})(-1)^{(m-1)(d^{\prime}-1)/2}.$ Since $4|d$, the first factors coincide for $m$ and $n$. The same is true for the other factors in the case $n\equiv m \pmod d$. But if $n\equiv-m \pmod d$, they differ by sgn $d'$ which is sgn $d$. In the case $a=0$, we note $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$. Then $(\frac{d}{n})=(\frac{d}{2^{b}n^{\prime}})=(\frac{d}{2})^{b}(\frac{d}{n^{\prime}})=(\frac{2}{d})^{b}(\frac{d}{n^{\prime}})$ since $(d/2)=(2/d)$ for $d\equiv1 \pmod 4$. Thus $(d/n)=(n/d)$ and $(-1/d)=$ sgn $d$. Therefore $(\frac{d}{m})=(\frac{d}{n})$ for $m, n>0$, $m\equiv n \pmod d$ and $(\frac{d}{n})=(\frac{n}{d})=(\frac{-m}{d})=sgn~d(\frac{m}{d})=(\frac{d}{m})sgn~d$ for $n\equiv-m \pmod d$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.17}
question: If $p$ is an odd prime show that the least positive quadratic nonresidue is less than $\sqrt{p}+1$.
solution: Let $n$ be the least positive quadratic nonresidue and $m$ the least such that $mn>p$ so that $n(m-1)\le p$. Since $p$ is prime, $n(m-1)<p<mn$. Now $mn-p<n$ so that $1=(\frac{mn-p}{p})=(\frac{mn}{p})=-(\frac{m}{p})$. Therefore $m\ge n$, so that $(n-1)^{2}<n(n-1)<p.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.18}
question: Show that $x^{4}\equiv25 \pmod{1013}$ has no solution.
solution: First observe that 1013 is prime. If $x^{4}\equiv25 \pmod{1013}$ had a solution $x_{0}$, then $x_{0}^{2}\equiv\pm5 \pmod{1013}$. However, $(\frac{\pm5}{1013})=(\frac{5}{1013})=(\frac{1013}{5})=(\frac{3}{5})=-1$ so the congruence has no solutions.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.19}
question: Show that $x^{4}\equiv25 \pmod p$ has no solution if $p$ is a prime congruent to 13 or 17 (mod 20).
solution: If the congruence has a solution, then $1=(\frac{\pm5}{p})=(\frac{5}{p})=(\frac{p}{5})=(\frac{\pm3}{5})=-1,$ a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.20}
question: If $p$ is a prime congruent to 13 or 17 (mod 20), show that $x^{4}+py^{4}=25z^{4}$ has no solutions in integers.
solution: We may suppose that $gcd(x,y,z)=1$ because otherwise we can cancel the common factor. Also $gcd(p,z)=1$ for otherwise $p|x$ and $p|y$. Now reduce the equation mod $p$. We have a solution to $x^{4}\equiv25z^{4} \pmod p$ so that by the previous question, $1=(\frac{\pm5z^{2}}{p})=(\frac{\pm5}{p})=-1,$ a contradiction.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.21}
question: Compute the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{33})$.
solution: The discriminant is 33 and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{33}=2.87...$ Since $33\equiv1 \pmod 8$, 2 splits as a product of two ideals each of norm 2. Moreover, $2=\frac{\sqrt{33}-5}{2}\cdot\frac{\sqrt{33}+5}{2}$ and so the principal ideals $(\frac{\sqrt{33}-5}{2})$ and $(\frac{\sqrt{33}+5}{2})$ are the only ones of norm 2. Hence the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.22}
question: Compute the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{21})$.
solution: The discriminant is 21 and the Minkowski bound is 2.29.... However, $21\equiv5 \pmod 8$ so that 2 is inert in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{21})$. Therefore, there are no ideals of norm 2 and the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.23}
question: Show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-11})$ has class number 1.
solution: The field has discriminant -11 and Minkowski's bound is $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{11}=2.11.....$ We must examine ideals of norm 2. Since $-11\equiv5 \pmod 8$, by Theorem 7.4.5, 2 is inert in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-11})$ so that there are no ideals of norm 2. Hence the class number is 1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.24}
question: Show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-15})$ has class number 2.
solution: The field has discriminant -15 and Minkowski's bound is $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{15}=2.26.....$ $-15\equiv1 \pmod 8$, by Theorem 7.4.5, 2 splits as a product of two ideals, $\mathfrak{p}$ and $\mathfrak{p}'$, each of norm 2. If $\mathfrak{p}$ were principal, then $\mathfrak{p}=(\frac{u+v\sqrt{-15}}{2})$ for integers $u, v$. However, $8=u^{2}+15v^{2}$ has no solution. Thus $\mathfrak{p}$ is not principal and the class number is 2.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 7.6.25}
question: Show that $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-31})$ has class number 3.
solution: The discriminant is -31 [Text says 31, but context of imaginary field implies -31] and the Minkowski bound is $\frac{2}{\pi}\sqrt{31}=3.26....$ So we must consider ideals of norm less than or equal to 3. Since $-31\equiv1 \pmod 8$, 2 splits as $\mathfrak{p}_{2}\cdot\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime}$ (say). Since $(\frac{-31}{3})=-1,$ 3 is inert so there are no ideals of norm 3. Moreover, neither $\mathfrak{p}_2$ or $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime}$ are principal since we cannot solve $8=u^{2}+31v^{2}$. Since $8=\frac{1^{2}+(31)\cdot1^{2}}{4}=(\frac{1-\sqrt{-31}}{2})(\frac{1+\sqrt{-31}}{2})$ and $((1-\sqrt{-31})/2)$ $((1+\sqrt{-31})/2)$ are coprime, $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{3}$ and $(\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime})^{3}$ are principal. $\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ cannot be principal since $16=u^{2}+31v^{2}$ has no solution except $(u,v)=(\pm4,0)$ in which case $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{2}=(4)=(2)^{2}=\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{2}(\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime})^{2}$ which implies $(\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime})^{2}=1$ a contradiction. Thus, as each ideal class contains either (1), $\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ or $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime}$ and because $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{2}$ is inequivalent to (1) or $\mathfrak{p}_{2}$ we must have $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{2}\sim\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{\prime}$. Thus, $\mathfrak{p}_{2}^{3}\sim(1)$. Thus, the class number is 3.

label: Theorem 8.1.3
question: Show that any discrete subgroup of $\mathbb{R}^{m}$ is a lattice.
