solution:
Proof. We prove this by induction on m:
In the trivial case, where $\Gamma=(0)$, $\Gamma$ is a lattice of dimension 0. We will thus, heretofore, assume that $\Gamma\ne(0)$.
Suppose first that $m=1$, so that $\Gamma\subseteq\mathbb{R}$
Let $\alpha$ be a nonzero element of $\Gamma$ and let $A=\{\lambda\in\mathbb{R}:\lambda\alpha\in\Gamma\}$. By hypothesis, the set $\{\gamma\in\Gamma:|\gamma|\le|\alpha|\}$ is finite.
Then $A\cap[-1,1]$ is finite and contains a least positive element $0<\mu\le1$.
Let $\beta=\mu\alpha$ and suppose that $\lambda\beta\in\Gamma$ with $\lambda\in\mathbb{R}$. Then
$\lambda\beta-[\lambda]\beta=(\lambda-[\lambda])\beta=(\lambda-[\lambda])\mu\alpha\in\Gamma$
which, by the minimality of $\mu$, implies that $\lambda=[\lambda]$, i.e., $\lambda\in\mathbb{Z}$ which implies that $\Gamma=\mathbb{Z}\beta$ is a lattice of dimension 1.
Now, suppose that $m>1$.
Let $\{v_{1},...,v_{k}\}$ be a maximal linearly independent subset of $\Gamma$ (so that $\Gamma\subseteq\mathbb{R}v_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{R}v_{k})$, let V be the subspace of $\mathbb{R}^{m}$ spanned by $\{v_{1},...,v_{k-1}\}$ and let $\Gamma_{0}=\Gamma\cap V.$ Then $\Gamma_{0}$ is a discrete subgroup of $V\simeq\mathbb{R}^{k-1}$ (as vector spaces) so, by the induction hypothesis, is a lattice.
That is, there are linearly independent vectors $w_{1},...,w_{l}\in V$ such that $\Gamma_{0}=\mathbb{Z}w_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}w_{l}$ and, since $v_{1},...,v_{k-1}\in\Gamma_{0}$ we must have $l=k-1$
Evidently, $\{w_{1},...,w_{k-1},w_{k}:=v_{k}\}$ is also a maximal linearly independent subset of $\Gamma$ (since span $\{v_{1},...,v_{k-1}\}=span\{w_{1},...,w_{k-1}\}=V)$. Let
$T=\{\sum_{i=1}^{k}a_{i}w_{i}\in\Gamma:0\le a_{i}<1~for~1\le i\le k-1~and~0\le a_{k}\le1\}$
T is bounded, hence finite, by hypothesis. We may therefore choose an element $x\in T$ with smallest nonzero coefficient $a_{k}$ of $w_{k}$, say $x=\sum_{i=1}^{k}b_{i}w_{i}$ .
Since $b_{k}\ne0$, the set $\{w_{1},...,w_{k-1},x\}$ is linearly independent.
Moreover, for any $\gamma\in\Gamma$, writing $\gamma=c_{1}w_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{k-1}w_{k-1}+c_{k}x.$ we see that there are integers $d_{1},...,d_{k-1}$ so that
$\gamma^{\prime}=\gamma-[c_{k}]x-\sum_{i=1}^{k-1}d_{i}w_{i}\in T.$
Since the coefficient of $w_{k}$ in $\gamma^{\prime}$ is $(c_{k}-[c_{k}])b_{k}<b_{k}$, by the minimality of $b_{k}$, we must have that $c_{k}-[c_{k}]=0$ so that $c_{k}\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $\gamma^{\prime}\in\Gamma_{0}\Rightarrow\gamma\in \Gamma_{0}+\mathbb{Z}x\Rightarrow\Gamma=\Gamma_{0}+\mathbb{Z}x=\mathbb{Z}w_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+\mathbb{Z}w_{k-1}+\mathbb{Z}x$ is a lattice of dimension k.

label: Lemma 8.1.4 (a)
question: Let $m,n\in\mathbb{Z}$ with $0<m\le n$ and let $\Delta=(d_{ij})\in M_{n\times m}(\mathbb{R})$. For any integer $t>1$, show that there is a nonzero $x=(x_{1},...,x_{n})\in \mathbb{Z}^{n}$ with each $|x_{i}|\le t$ such that, if $y=x\Delta=(y_{1},...,y_{m})\in\mathbb{R}^{m}$, then each $|y_{i}|\le ct^{1-n/m}$, where c is a constant depending only on the matrix $\Delta$.
solution:
Proof. (a) Let $\delta=max_{1\le j\le m}\sum_{i=1}^{n}|d_{ij}|$. Then, for $0\ne x=(x_{1},...,x_{n})\in\mathbb{Z}_{\ge0}^{n}$ with each $|x_{i}|\le t$
$|y_{j}|=|\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i}d_{ij}|\le\delta t.$
Consider the cube $[-\delta t,\delta t]^{m}\in\mathbb{R}^{m}$. Let h be an integer $\ge 1$ and divide the given cube into $h^{m}$ equal subcubes so that each will have side length $2\delta t/h.$ Now, for each $x=(x_{1},...,x_{n})\in[0,t]^{n}\cap\mathbb{Z}^{n},y=(y_{1},...,y_{m})\in [-\delta t,\delta t]^{m}$ which means that there are $(t+1)^{n}$ such points $y\in[-\delta t,\delta t]^{m}$.
Thus, if $h^{m}<(t+1)^{n}$, then two of the points must lie in the same subcube.
That is, for some $x^{\prime}\ne x^{\prime\prime}$, we have that, if $y=(x^{\prime}-x^{\prime\prime})\Delta=(y_{1},...,y_{m})$, then each $|y_{i}|\le2\delta t/h$
Since $t>1$ and $n/m\ge1$, $(t+1)^{n/m}>t^{n/m}+1$ so there exists an integer h with $t^{n/m}<h<(t+1)^{n/m}$ (in particular, $h^{m}<(t+1)^{n})$.
Then $|y_{i}|\le2\delta t/h<2\delta t^{1-n/m}$ for each i.

label: Lemma 8.1.5 (a)
question:
Let $E=A\cup B$ be a proper partition of E. Show that there exists a sequence of nonzero integers $\{\alpha_{v}\}\subseteq\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ such that
$|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|>|\alpha_{v+1}^{(k)}|$ for $k\in A$, $|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|<|\alpha_{v+1}^{(k)}|$ for $k\in B$,
and $|N_{K}(\alpha_{v})|\le c^{m}$, where c is a positive constant depending only on K and $m=|A\cup\overline{A}|$.
solution:
Proof. (a) Let $t_{1}$ be an integer greater than 1 and let $\{t_{v}\}$ be the sequence defined recursively by the relation $t_{v+1}=Mt_{v}$ for all $v\ge1$, where M is a positive constant that will be suitably chosen.
By Lemma 8.1.4, for each $v,\exists\alpha_{v}\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that
$c^{1-m}t_{v}^{1-n/m}\le|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|\le ct_{v}^{1-n/m}$ for $k\in A.$
$c^{-m}t_{v}\le|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|\le t_{v}$ for $k\in B$
Now, let $\kappa=min\{1,n/m-1\}$ and choose M such that $M^{\kappa}>c^{m}$ so that both $M>c^{m}$ and $M^{n/m-1}>c^{m}$. Then, if $k\in A$,
$|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|\ge c^{-m+1}t_{v}^{1-n/m}=c^{-m+1}(\frac{t_{v+1}}{M})^{1-n/m}>ct_{v+1}^{1-n/m}\ge|\alpha_{v+1}^{(k)}|$
and if $k\in B$, then
$|\alpha_{v}^{(k)}|\le t_{v}=\frac{t_{v+1}}{M}<c^{-m}t_{v+1}\le|\alpha_{v+1}^{(k)}|.$
Also,
$|N_{K}(\alpha_{v})|=\prod_{i\in A\cup\overline{A}}|\alpha_{v}^{(i)}|\prod_{j\in B\cup\overline{B}}|\alpha_{v}^{(j)}|\le(ct_{v}^{1-n/m})^{m}t_{v}^{n-m}=c^{m}.$

label: Lemma 8.1.5 (b)
question: Let $E=A\cup B$ be a proper partition of E. Show that there exists a unit $\epsilon$ with $|\epsilon^{(k)}|<1$, for $k\in A$ and $|\epsilon^{(k)}|>1$ for $k\in B$
solution:
Proof. (b) Let $\{\alpha_{v}\}\subseteq\mathcal{O}_{K}$ be the sequence of algebraic integers in (a).
Define the sequence of principal ideals $\mathcal{A}_{v}=(\alpha_{v}).$ Then $N(\mathcal{A}_{v})=N_{K}(\alpha_{v})\le c^{m}$ (where $N(\mathcal{A}_{v}):=\#\mathcal{O}_{K}/\mathcal{A}_{v})$.
Since there are only finitely many integral ideals $\mathcal{A}_{v}$ of bounded norm, $\exists\mu\in\mathbb{N}$ such that, for some $v>\mu$.
$\mathcal{A}_{v}=\mathcal{A}_{\mu}$ which means that $\alpha_{\mu}=\epsilon\alpha_{v}$ for some unit $\epsilon$. We conclude that
$|\epsilon^{(k)}|=|\frac{\alpha_{\mu}^{(k)}}{\alpha_{v}^{(k)}}|\begin{cases}<1&for~k\in A,\\ >1&for~k\in B.\end{cases}$

label: Theorem 8.1.6 (Dirichlet's Unit Theorem)
question:
Let $U_{K}$ be the unit group of K. Let $n=[K:\mathbb{Q}]$ and write $n=r_{1}+2r_{2}$, where, as usual, $r_{1}$ and $2r_{2}$ are, respectively, the number of real and nonreal embeddings of K in C. Show that there exist fundamental units $\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{r},$ where $r=r_{1}+r_{2}-1$, such that every unit $\epsilon\in U_{K}$ can be written uniquely in the form
$\epsilon=\zeta\epsilon_{1}^{n_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\epsilon_{r}^{n_{r}}$,
where $n_{1},...,n_{r}\in\mathbb{Z}$ and $\zeta$ is a root of unity in $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$.
More precisely, if $W_{K}$ is the subgroup of $U_{K}$ consisting of roots of unity, show that $W_{K}$ is finite and cyclic and $U_{K}\simeq W_{K}\times\mathbb{Z}^{r}$.
solution:
Proof. Let $U_{K}$ be the unit group of K and consider the homomorphism
$f:U_{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{r}$
$\epsilon\mapsto(log|\epsilon^{(1)}|,...,log|\epsilon^{(r)}|)$.
We will show that:
(a) ker $f=W_{K}$ and
(b) Im $f=\Gamma$ is a lattice of dim r in $\mathbb{R}^{r}$.
a) Suppose that $\epsilon\in ker~f,$ i.e.,
$|\epsilon^{(1)}|=\cdot\cdot\cdot=|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2}-1)}|=1$ , $\Rightarrow|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2}+1)}|=\cdot\cdot\cdot=|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+2r_{2}-1)}|=1.$
But, since $\epsilon\in U_{K}$,
$1=|N_{K}(\epsilon)|=\prod_{i=1}^{n}|\epsilon^{(i)}|=|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2})}|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+2r_{2})}|=|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2})}|^{2},$
$\Rightarrow|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2})}|=|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+2r_{2})}|=1$
By Exercise 8.1.1, the number of $\epsilon\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ such that $|\epsilon^{(i)}|\le1$ for all i is finite.
$\epsilon$ must, therefore, have finite order in $U_{K}$, i.e, $\epsilon^{k}=1$, for some positive integer k and so $\epsilon\in W_{K}$.
(b) If $-M<log|\epsilon^{(i)}|<M$ for $i=1,...,r$ then $e^{-M}<|\epsilon^{(i)}|<e^{M}$ for all $i\notin S=\{r_{1}+r_{2},r_{1}+2r_{2}\}$. But
$|\epsilon^{(r_{1}+r_{2})}|^{2}=\frac{|N_{K}(\epsilon)|}{\prod_{i\notin S}|\epsilon^{i}|}<e^{M^{r_{1}+2(r_{2}-1)}<e^{Mn}.}$
Thus, we have that each $|\epsilon^{(i)}|<e^{Mn/2}$. By Exercise 8.1.1, there are only finitely many $\epsilon$ for which this inequality holds.
Therefore, any bounded region in $\mathbb{R}^{m}$ contains only finitely many points of $\Gamma$ so, by Theorem 8.1.3, $\Gamma$ is a lattice of dimension $t\le r$.
By Lemma 8.1.5 (b), we can find for each $1\le i\le r,$ a unit $\epsilon_{i}$ such that $|\epsilon_{i}^{(i)}|>1$ and $|\epsilon_{i}^{(j)}|<1$ for $j\ne i$ and $1\le j\le r.$ Let $x_{i}$ be the image of $\epsilon_{i}$ under the map f.
We claim that $x_{1},...,x_{r}$ are linearly independent. For suppose that
$c_{1}x_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+c_{r}x_{r}=0$,
with the $c_{i}$ not all zero. We may suppose without loss of generality that $c_{1}>0$ and $c_{1}\ge c_{j}$ for $1\le j\le r.$ Then,
$0=\sum_{i=1}^{r}c_{i}log|\epsilon_{1}^{(i)}|\ge c_{1}\sum_{i=1}^{r}log|\epsilon_{1}^{(i)}|,$
so that $\sum_{i=1}^{r}log|\epsilon_{1}^{(i)}|\le0.$
Now the product of the conjugates of $\epsilon_{1}$ has absolute value 1. By our choice of $\epsilon_{1}$, we see that $|\epsilon_{1}^{(i)}|<1$
and we deduce that
$\sum_{i=1}^{r}log|\epsilon_{1}^{(i)}|>0,$
which is a contradiction. Thus, $U_{K}\simeq W_{K}\times\Gamma$ and as shown above, $\Gamma\simeq\mathbb{Z}^{r}$

label: Theorem 8.1.10 (a)
question: Let $\zeta_{m}=e^{2\pi i/m}$, $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$. Show that if m is even, the only roots of unity in K are the mth roots of unity, so that $W_{K}\simeq\mathbb{Z}/m\mathbb{Z}$. If m is odd, show that the only ones are the 2mth roots of unity, so that $W_{K}\simeq \mathbb{Z}/2m\mathbb{Z}$.
solution:
Proof. (a) If m is odd, then $\zeta_{2m}=-\zeta_{2m}^{m+1}=-\zeta_{m}^{(m+1)/2}$ which implies that $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{2m})$.
It will, therefore, suffice to establish the statement for m even.
Suppose that $\theta\in\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$ is a primitive kth root of unity, $k \nmid m$. Then $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$ contains a primitive rth root of unity, where $r=lcm(k,m)>m.$ Then $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{r})\subseteq\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$
$\Rightarrow \varphi(r)=[\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{r}):\mathbb{Q}]\le[\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m}):\mathbb{Q}]=\varphi(m)$
(where $\varphi$ denotes the Euler phi-function). But m is even and m properly divides r implies that $\varphi(m)$ properly divides $\varphi(r)$, so that, in particular, $\varphi(m)<\varphi(r)$, a contradiction.
Thus, the mth roots of unity are the only roots of unity in $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$.

label: Theorem 8.1.10 (b)
question: Let $\zeta_{m}=e^{2\pi i/m}$, $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{m})$. Suppose that $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=4$. Show that $W_{K}$ is one of the six groups Z/2lZ, $1\le l\le6$. If, furthermore, K has no real embedding, show that $U_{K}\simeq W_{K}\times\mathbb{Z}.$
solution:
Proof. (b) $W_{K}$ is cyclic, generated by an rth root of unity, for some even $r\ge2$. $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{r})\subseteq K$ means that $4=[K:\mathbb{Q}]\ge\varphi(r)$.
A straightforward computation shows that $\varphi(r) \le 4$
$\Rightarrow r\in\{2,4,6,8,10,12\}$.
If K has no real embedding, then $r_{1}=0,$ $r_{2}=2\Rightarrow r=r_{1}+r_{2}-1=1$. By Dirichlet's theorem, $U_{K}\simeq W_{K}\times\mathbb{Z}.$

label: Theorem 8.1.10 (c)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$, p an odd prime. Show that for any unit $\epsilon\in U_{K}$, $\epsilon=\zeta_{p}^{k}u$, for some real unit $u\in U_{K}\cap\mathbb{R}$, $k\in\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$.
solution:
Proof. (c) Let $\epsilon\in U_{K}$. Then $1=|(\epsilon/\overline{\epsilon})^{(i)}|=|\epsilon^{(i)}/\overline{\epsilon^{(i)}}|$, for $i=1,...,n=[K:\mathbb{Q}]$. By the remark in the solution to Exercise 8.1.1, $\epsilon/\overline{\epsilon}$ is a root of unity in K and so $\epsilon/\overline{\epsilon}=\pm\zeta_{p}^{k}$, for some k.
Since $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{p}]$ we may write $\epsilon=\sum_{i=0}^{p-2}a_{i}\zeta_{p}^{i}$ each $a_{i}\in\mathbb{Z}$ Then
$z^{p}=(\sum_{i=0}^{p-2}a_{i}\zeta_{p}^{i})^{p}\equiv\sum_{i=0}^{p-2}a_{i}(mod~p).$
Since $\overline{\epsilon}=\sum_{i=0}^{p-2}a_{i}\zeta^{-i}$
$\overline{\epsilon}^{p}\equiv\sum_{i=0}^{p-2}a_{i}\equiv\epsilon^{p}$ (mod p).
If $\epsilon=-\zeta_{p}^{k}\overline{\epsilon}$ then $\epsilon^{p}\equiv-\overline{\epsilon}^{p}(mod~p)$ This implies that $2\epsilon^{p}\equiv0$ (mod p) and so $\epsilon^{p}\equiv0$ (mod p).
In other words, $\epsilon^{p}\in(p)$, a contradiction, since $\epsilon$ is a unit.
Thus $\epsilon/\overline{\epsilon}=\zeta_{p}^{k}$ for some k. $r\in\mathbb{Z}$ such that $2r\equiv k(mod~p)$ and let $\epsilon_{1}=\zeta_{p}^{-r}\epsilon$. Then $\overline{\epsilon_{1}}=\zeta_{p}^{r}\overline{\epsilon}=\zeta_{p}^{r-k}\epsilon=\zeta_{p}^{-r}\epsilon=\epsilon_{1}\Rightarrow\epsilon_{1}\in\mathbb{R}$ and $\epsilon=\zeta_{p}^{r}\epsilon_{1}$.

label: Theorem 8.1.10 (d)
question: Let $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$, p an odd prime, and let $L=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p}+\zeta_{p}^{-1})$. Show that $L=K\cap\mathbb{R}$ and conclude that $U_{K}=\langle\zeta_{p}\rangle\times U_{L}$.
solution:
Proof. (d) Let $\alpha=\zeta_{p}+\zeta_{p}^{-1}$ Then $\alpha=2~cos(2\pi/p)\in\mathbb{R}$ so $L=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)\subseteq K\cap\mathbb{R}$.
But since $[K:K\cap\mathbb{R}]=2$ and $\zeta_{p}^{2}-\alpha\zeta_{p}+1=0$ so that $[K:\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)]\le2$, we have that $L=K\cap\mathbb{R}$.
Thus, $\epsilon\in U_{K}$, meaning $\epsilon=\pm\zeta_{p}^{k}\epsilon_{1}$, for some $\epsilon_{1}\in L$, so that $U_{K}=\langle\zeta_{p}\rangle\times U_{L}$.

label: Theorem 8.1.10 (e)
question: For $K=\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{5})$, show that $U_{K}=\{\pm\zeta_{5}^{k}\epsilon^{l}:k\in\mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z},l\in\mathbb{Z}\}$ where $\epsilon=(1+\sqrt{5})/2$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$.
solution:
Proof. (e) It remains only to show that $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{5}+\zeta_{5}^{-1})=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5}).$ Let $\alpha=\zeta_{5}+\zeta_{5}^{-1}$.
$\zeta_{5}^{4}+\zeta_{5}^{3}+\zeta_{5}^{2}+\zeta_{5}+1=0$
$\zeta_{5}^{2}+\zeta_{5}+1+\zeta_{5}^{-1}+\zeta_{5}^{-2}=0$
or $\alpha^{2}+\alpha-1=0$ Since $\alpha=2~cos(2\pi/5)>0$ this implies that $\alpha= (-1+\sqrt{5})/2$ and we conclude that $\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5}).$

label: Theorem 8.2.4 (a)
question: Let $\alpha$ be an irrational number and let $C_{j}=p_{j}/q_{j}$, for $j\in\mathbb{N}$, be the convergents of the simple continued fraction of $\alpha$. If $r, s\in\mathbb{Z}$ with $s>0$ and k is a positive integer such that $|s\alpha-r|<|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|,$ then show that $s\ge q_{k+1}$.
solution:
Proof. (a) Suppose, on the contrary, that $1\le s<q_{k+1}$. For each $k\ge0$ consider the system of linear equations
$p_{k}x+p_{k+1}y=r$ ,
$q_{k}x+q_{k+1}y=s.$
Using Gaussian elimination, we easily find that
$(p_{k+1}q_{k}-p_{k}q_{k+1})y=rq_{k}-sp_{k}$ ,
$(p_{k}q_{k+1}-p_{k+1}q_{k})x=rq_{k+1}-sp_{k+1}$
By Exercise 8.2.1 (b), $p_{k+1}q_{k}-p_{k}q_{k+1}=(-1)^{k}$ so $p_{k}q_{k+1}-p_{k+1}q_{k}=(-1)^{k+1}$. Thus, the unique solution to this system is given by
$\begin{matrix}x&=&(-1)^{k}(sp_{k+1}-rq_{k+1}\end{matrix})$ ,
$\begin{matrix}y&=&(-1)^{k}(rq_{k}-sp_{k}\end{matrix})$ .
We will show that x and y are nonzero and have opposite signs.
If $x=0$, then
$\frac{r}{s}=\frac{p_{k+1}}{q_{k+1}}$
and since $(p_{k+1},q_{k+1})=1.$ this implies that $q_{k+1}|s$ and so $q_{k+1}\le s,$ contradicting our hypothesis.
If $y=0$, then $r=p_{k}x,$ $s=q_{k}x$, so that
$|s\alpha-r|=|x|\cdot|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|\ge|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|$,
again contradicting our hypothesis.
Suppose now that $y<0$ Then since $q_{k}x=s-q_{k+1}y$ and each $q_{j}\ge 0,x>0$ On the other hand, if $y>0$ then $q_{k+1}y\ge q_{k+1}>s$ SO $q_{k}x= s-q_{k+1}y<0$ and $x<0$.
By Exercise 8.2.1 (d), if k is even,
$\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}<\alpha<\frac{p_{k+1}}{q_{k+1}}$
while, if k is odd,
$\frac{p_{k+1}}{q_{k+1}}<\alpha<\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}$ .
Thus, in either case, $q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}$ and $q_{k+1}\alpha-p_{k+1}$ have opposite signs so that $x(q_{k}\alpha-p_{k})$ and $y(q_{k+1}\alpha-p_{k+1})$ have the same sign.
$\Rightarrow|s\alpha-r|=|(q_{k}x+q_{k+1}y)\alpha-(p_{k}x+p_{k+1}y)|$
$=|x(q_{k}\alpha-p_{k})+y(q_{k+1}\alpha-p_{k+1})|$
$\ge|x|\cdot|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|+|y|\cdot|q_{k+1}\alpha-p_{k+1}|$
$\ge|x|\cdot|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|\ge|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|$,
a contradiction, thus establishing our assertion.

label: Theorem 8.2.4 (b)
question: If $\alpha$ is an irrational number and $r/s$ is a rational number in lowest terms, $s>0$, such that $|\alpha-r/s|<\frac{1}{2s^{2}}$ then show that $r/s$ is a convergent of the continued fraction of $\alpha$.
solution:
Proof. (b) Suppose that $r/s$ is not a convergent of the continued fraction of $\alpha$, i.e., $r/s\ne p_{n}/q_{n}$ for all n. Let k be the largest nonnegative integer such that $s\ge q_{k}$. (Since $s\ge q_{0}=1$ and $q_{k}\rightarrow\infty$ as $k\rightarrow\infty$, we know that such a k exists.) Then $q_{k}\le s\le q_{k+1}$ and by (a),
$|q_{k}\alpha-p_{k}|\le|s\alpha-r|=s|\alpha-r/s|<\frac{1}{2s}$
$\Rightarrow|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|<\frac{1}{2sq_{k}}.$
Since $r/s \ne p_k/q_k$, $|sp_{k}-rq_{k}|\ge1$,
$\frac{1}{sq_{k}}\le\frac{|sp_{k}-rq_{k}|}{sq_{k}}=|\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}-\frac{r}{s}|$
$=|\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}-\frac{r}{s}+\alpha-\alpha|$
$\le|\alpha-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|+|\alpha-\frac{r}{s}|$
$<\frac{1}{2sq_{k}}+\frac{1}{2s^{2}}$
This would imply that $\frac{1}{2sq_{k}}<\frac{1}{2s^{2}}$ so $q_{k}>s$, a contradiction.

label: Theorem 8.2.9 (a)
question: Let n be the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$. Show that all integer solutions to the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=\pm1$ are given by $x+y\sqrt{d}=\pm(p_{n-1}+q_{n-1}\sqrt{d})^{l}:l\in\mathbb{Z}$ where $p_{n-1}/q_{n-1}$ is the $(n-1)th$ convergent of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$.
solution:
Proof. (a) For any solution (x, y) to the given equation,
$(x+\sqrt{d}y)^{-1}=\pm(x-\sqrt{d}y)$.
Therefore, one of $\pm(a,\pm b)$ is a solution to $x^{2}-dy^{2}=\pm1$ if and only if each of the four pairs is a solution. It will, thus, suffice to show that all positive solutions are given by
$x+y\sqrt{d}=(p_{n-1}+q_{n-1}\sqrt{d})^{m}:m>0$
By Exercise 8.2.5, if $x^{2}-dy^{2}=\pm1$, then $x=p_{k-1}$, $Y = q_{k-1}$, for some k.
By Exercise 8.2.8, $p_{k-1}^{2}-dq_{k-1}^{2}=(-1)^{k}Q_{k}=\pm1\Rightarrow Q_{k}=\pm1$ and, by our Remark, this implies that $n|k$. Since
$p_{n-1}<p_{2n-1}<\cdot\cdot\cdot$ and $q_{n-1}<q_{2n-1}<\cdot\cdot\cdot$,
we have that, in particular, the least positive solution to the given equation is $x_{1}=p_{n-1},y_1=q_{n-1}$ We will now show that all positive solutions $(x_{m},y_{m})$ are given by $x_{m}+y_{m}\sqrt{d}=(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{m}$, m > 0.
Taking Q-conjugates, $x_{m}-y_{m}\sqrt{d}=(x_{1}-y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{m}$
$(x_{m}+y_{m}\sqrt{d})(x_{m}-y_{m}\sqrt{d})=(x_{1}^{2}-dy_{1}^{2})^{m}=(\pm1)^{m}=\pm1$,
so that $(x_{m},y_{m})$ is indeed a solution. Evidently, $x_{1}<x_{m}$, $y_{1}<y_{m}$, so that $(x_{m},y_{m})$ is a positive solution.
Now, suppose that (X, Y) is a positive solution that is not one of the $(x_{m},y_{m})$.
Then an integer $\kappa\ge0$ such that
$(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{\kappa}<X+Y\sqrt{d}<(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{\kappa+1}$,
оr
$1<(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{-\kappa}(X+Y\sqrt{d})<x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d}.$
But $x_{1}^{2}-dy_{1}^{2}=\pm1$ which implies that $(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{-\kappa}=[\pm(x_{1}-y_{1}\sqrt{d})]^{\kappa}.$ Define the integers s, t such that
$s+t\sqrt{d}=(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{-\kappa}(X+Y\sqrt{d})=\pm(x_{1}-y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{\kappa}(X+Y\sqrt{d}).$
Then
$s^{2}-dt^{2}=[\pm(x_{1}-y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{\kappa}(X+Y\sqrt{d})][\pm(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{\kappa}(X-Y\sqrt{d})]$
$=X^{2}-dY^{2}=\pm1.$
Thus, (s, t) is a solution to the given equation with
$1<s+t\sqrt{d}<x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d}.$
Also,
$0<(x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d})^{-1}<(s+t\sqrt{d})^{-1}<1<s+t\sqrt{d}.$
But this implies that
$\begin{matrix}s&=&s+t\sqrt{d}\pm[\pm(s-t\sqrt{d})\end{matrix}]=s+t\sqrt{d}\pm(s+t\sqrt{d})^{-1}>0\end{matrix}$ ,
$\begin{matrix}2t\sqrt{d}&=&s+t\sqrt{d}\mp[\pm(s-t\sqrt{d})\end{matrix}]>0$ ,
and so (s, t) is a positive solution. By hypothesis, then, $s\ge x_{1}$, $t\ge y_{1}$ and, since $s+t\sqrt{d}<x_{1}+y_{1}\sqrt{d}.$ we have a contradiction.

label: Theorem 8.2.9 (b)
question: Let n be the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$. If d is squarefree, $d\equiv2,3(mod~4)$, show that $p_{n-1}+q_{n-1}\sqrt{d}$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$.
solution: Proof. (b) Since $p_{n-1}+q_{n-1}\sqrt{d}>1$ this follows immediately from part (a).

label: Theorem 8.2.9 (c)
question: Let n be the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$. Show that the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=-1$ has an integer solution if and only if n is odd.
solution:
Proof. (c) $x^2-dy^2=-1$ implies $x = p_{k-1}$, $y=q_{k-1}$ for some k, by Exercise 8.2.5.
But $p_{k-1}^{2}-dq_{k-1}^{2}=(-1)^{k}Q_{k}=-1$ if and only if $n|k$ and k is odd. Clearly then, a solution exists if and only if n is odd.

label: Theorem 8.2.9 (d)
question: Let n be the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$. If d has a prime divisor $p\equiv3$ (mod 4), show that the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=-1$ has no integer solution.
solution: Proof. (d) $x^{2}-dy^{2}=-1$ implies that $x^{2}\equiv-1(mod~p)$ for all $p|d$. But, for $p\equiv3$ mod 4, this congruence has no solutions.

label: Exercise 8.1.1 (a)
question: Let K be a number field and $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ its ring of integers. Show that there are only finitely many roots of unity in K.
solution:
Solution. (a) Suppose that $\alpha^{m}=1$ Then $\alpha\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$, $|\alpha|^{m}=1\Rightarrow|\alpha|=1$ and, if $\sigma_{1},...,\sigma_{n}$ are the distinct embeddings of K in C, then, for each $\alpha^{(i)}=\sigma_{i}(\alpha)$, we have that $\sigma_{i}(\alpha)^{m}=\sigma_{i}(\alpha^{m})=1\Rightarrow|\alpha^{(i)}|=1$ for $i=1,...,n.$
The characteristic polynomial of a is
$f_{\alpha}(x)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}(x-\alpha^{(i)})=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}\in\mathbb{Z}[x].$
Now,
$a_{n-j}=(-1)^{j}s_{j}(\alpha^{(1)},...,\alpha^{(n)})$
where $s_{j}(\alpha^{(1)},...,\alpha^{(n)})$ is the jth symmetric function in the $\alpha^{(i)}$ i.e., the sum of all products of the $\alpha^{(i)}$, taken j at a time.
This implies that
$|a_{n-j}|\le\binom{n}{j}\le n!.$
Thus, since the $a_{j}$ are bounded, there are only finitely many choices for the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial of a root of unity $\alpha\in K$ and, hence, only finitely many such roots of unity.

label: Exercise 8.1.1 (b)
question: Let K be a number field and $\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ its ring of integers. Show, similarly, that for any positive constant c, there are only finitely many $\alpha\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ for which $|\alpha^{(i)}|\le c$ for all i.
solution:
Solution. (b) Suppose that $\alpha\in\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ such that $|\alpha^{(i)}|\le c$ for all $i=1,...,n.$ As in (a), let
$f_{\alpha}(x)=\prod_{i=1}^{n}(x-\alpha^{(i)})=x^{n}+a_{n-1}x^{n-1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{0}\in\mathbb{Z}[x]$
be the characteristic polynomial of a. Then
$|a_{n-j}|=|s_{j}(\alpha^{(1)},...,\alpha^{(n)})|\le c^{j}\binom{n}{j}\le c^{n}n!.$
Thus, the coefficients of the characteristic polynomial of such an a in $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ are bounded.
There are, therefore, only finitely many such a.

label: Exercise 8.1.2
question: Show that $W_{K}$, the group of roots of unity in K, is cyclic, of even order.
solution:
Solution. Let $\alpha_{1},...,\alpha_{l}$ be the roots of unity in K. For $j=1,...,l$, $\alpha_{j}^{q_{j}}=1$ for some $q_{j}$ which implies that $\alpha_{j}=e^{2\pi ip_{j}/q_{j}}$, for some $0\le p_{j}\le q_{j}-1.$ Let $q_{0}=\prod_{i=1}^{l}q_{j}$ Then, clearly, each $\alpha_{i}\in\langle e^{2\pi i/q_{0}}\rangle$ so $W_{K}$ is a subgroup of the cyclic group $\langle e^{2\pi i/q_{0}}\rangle$ and is, thus, cyclic.
Moreover, since $\{\pm1\}\subseteq W_{K}$, $W_{K}$ has even order.

label: Exercise 8.1.7 (a)
question:
Let $\Gamma$ be a lattice of dimension n in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$ and suppose that $\{v_{1},...,v_{n}\}$ and $\{w_{1},...,w_{n}\}$ are two bases for $\Gamma$ over Z. Let V and W be the $n\times n$ matrices with rows consisting of the $v_{i}$ and $w_{i}$, respectively.
Show that det $V|=|det~W|$. Thus, we can unambiguously define the volume of the lattice $\Gamma$, $vol(\Gamma)=$ the absolute value of the determinant of the matrix formed by taking, as its rows, any basis for $\Gamma$ over Z.
solution:
Solution. (a) Since $\{w_{1},...,w_{n}\}$ is a Z-basis for $\Gamma$ , we can express each $v_{i}$ as a Z-linear combination of the $w_{j}$, say $v_{i}=\sum_{j=1}^{n}a_{ij}w_{j}$ .
Setting $A=(a_{ij})$, we have that $V=AW$. Since $\{v_{1},...,v_{n}\}$ is also an integral basis for $\Gamma$ , the matrix A is invertible, $A\in GL_{n}(\mathbb{Z})\Rightarrow$ det $A\in\mathbb{Z}^{*}=\{\pm1\}.$
Thus, det $V|=|det~A||det~W|=|det~W|$

label: Exercise 8.1.7 (b)
question: Let $\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{r}$ be a fundamental system of units for a number field K. Show that the regulator of K, $R_{K}=|det(log|\epsilon_{j}^{(i)}|)|$, is independent of the choice of $\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{r}$.
solution:
Solution. (b) As before, define
$f:U_{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{r}$,
$\epsilon\mapsto(log|\epsilon^{(1)}|,...,log|\epsilon^{(r)}|)$.
Im f is a lattice of dimension r in $\mathbb{R}^{r}.$ with Z-basis $\{f(\epsilon_{1}),...,f(\epsilon_{r})\},$ for any system of fundamental units, $\epsilon_{1},...,\epsilon_{r}$.
By definition, $R_{K}$ is the absolute value of the determinant of the matrix formed by taking, as its rows, the $f(\epsilon^{(i)})^{\prime}s$.
By (a) then, $R_{K}$ is independent of the particular system of fundamental units.

label: Exercise 8.1.8 (a)
question: Show that, for any real quadratic field $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$, where d is a positive squarefree integer, $U_{K}\simeq\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\times\mathbb{Z}.$ That is, there is a fundamental unit $\epsilon\in U_{K}$ such that $U_{K}=\{\pm\epsilon^{k}:k\in\mathbb{Z}\}$. Conclude that the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=1$ (erroneously dubbed Pell's equation) has infinitely many integer solutions for $d\equiv2,3$ mod 4 and that the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=4$ has infinitely many integer solutions for $d\equiv1$ mod 4.
solution:
Solution. (a) Since $K\subseteq\mathbb{R}$, the only roots of unity in K are $\{\pm1\}$, so $W_{K}=\{\pm1\}$.
Moreover, since there are $r_{1}=2$ real and $2r_{2}=0$ nonreal embeddings of K in C, by Dirichlet's theorem, we have that $U_{K}\simeq W_{K}\times\mathbb{Z}\simeq \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}\times\mathbb{Z}$
Suppose that $d\equiv2,3$ (mod 4), so that $\mathcal{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{d}]$. If $\epsilon=a+b\sqrt{d}\in U_{K}^{2}$, then $N_{K}(\epsilon)=(a+b\sqrt{d})(a-b\sqrt{d})=a^{2}-db^{2}=1$
i.e., each $\epsilon=a+b\sqrt{d}\in U_{K}^{2}$ yields a solution $(a,b)\in\mathbb{Z}^{2}$ to the equation $x^{2}-dy^{2}=1.$ Since $U_{K}^{2}\simeq\mathbb{Z}$ is infinite, there are infinitely many such solutions.
Suppose, now, that $d\equiv1$ (mod 4), so that
$\mathcal{O}_{K}=\{\frac{a+b\sqrt{d}}{2}:a,b\in\mathbb{Z},a\equiv b(mod~2)\}$
If $\epsilon=(a+b\sqrt{d})/2\in U_{K}^{2}$, then $N_{K}(\epsilon)=(a^{2}-db^{2})/4=1\Rightarrow a^{2}-db^{2}=4.$ Since $U_{K}^{2}$ is infinite and each of its elements yields an integral solution to $x^{2}-dy^{2}=4$, this equation has infinitely many solutions x $,y\in\mathbb{Z}$

label: Exercise 8.1.8 (b)
question: Let $d\equiv2,3$ (mod 4). Let b be the smallest positive integer such that one of $db^{2}\pm1$ is a square, say $a^{2}$, $a>0.$ Then $a+b\sqrt{d}$ is a unit. Show that it is the fundamental unit. Using this algorithm, determine the fundamental units of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$ $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})$
solution:
Solution. (b) We have that $db^{2}\pm1=a^{2}$ so $N_{K}(a+b\sqrt{d})=\pm1$ and $a+b\sqrt{d}\in U_{K}$.
Also, a, $b>0$ means that $a+b\sqrt{d}>1$ so $a+b\sqrt{d}=\epsilon^{k}$, for some $k\ge1$, where $\epsilon$ is the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$.
If $k>1$, then write $\epsilon=\alpha+\beta\sqrt{d},$ $\alpha,\beta>0$ It is easy to see that $a+b\sqrt{d}=(\alpha+\beta\sqrt{d})^{k}$ implies that $\alpha<a$ and $\beta\le b$.
But $d\beta^{2}\pm1=\alpha^{2}$, contradicting the minimality of b. Therefore, $a+b\sqrt{d}$ is, in fact, the fundamental unit.
In $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$, $2(1)^{2}-1=1^{2}\Rightarrow1+\sqrt{2}$ is the fundamental unit. In $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})$, $3(1)^{2}+1=2^{2}\Rightarrow2+\sqrt{3}$ is the fundamental unit.

label: Exercise 8.1.8 (c)
question: Devise a similar algorithm to compute the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$, for $d\equiv1$ (mod 4). Determine the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$.
solution:
Solution. (c) Let $d\equiv1$ (mod 4). The same argument as in (b) shows that, if b is the smallest positive integer such that one of $db^{2}\pm4$ is a square, say $a^{2}$, $a>0$ then $(a+b\sqrt{d})/2$ is the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$.
In $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$,
$5(1)^{2}-4=1^{2}\Rightarrow(1+\sqrt{5})/2$ is the fundamental unit.

label: Exercise 8.1.9 (a)
question:
For an imaginary quadratic field $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ (d a positive, squarefree integer), show that
$U_{K}\simeq\begin{cases}\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}&for~d=1,\\ \mathbb{Z}/6\mathbb{Z}&for~d=3,\\ \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}&otherwise.\end{cases}$
solution:
Solution. (a) Suppose that $-d\equiv2,3$ (mod 4) so that $\mathfrak{O}_{K}=\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{-d}]$. Let $a+b\sqrt{-d}\in U_{K}$.
Then $a^{2}+db^{2}=1$ (since $a^{2}$, $b^{2}$, $d\ge0$, $a^{2}+db^{2}\ne-1)$ If $b=0$, then $a=\pm1$. If $b\ne0$, then $a^{2}+db^{2}\ge d;$ thus,
$d>1\Rightarrow U_{K}=\{\pm1\}\simeq\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}$ .
For d $=1,a^{2}+db^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}=1\Rightarrow(a,b)\in\{(\pm1,0),(0,\pm1)\}$
$U_{K}=\{\pm1,\pm i\}=\langle i\rangle\simeq\mathbb{Z}/4\mathbb{Z}.$
Suppose now that $-d\equiv1$ (mod 4). Then $(a+b\sqrt{-d})/2\in U_{K}\Rightarrow$ $a^{2}+db^{2}=4$ If $d>4$ then the only solutions to this equation are $(a,b)=$ (±2,0)
$\Rightarrow U_{K}\simeq\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}$
If $d=3$, then $a^{2}+db^{2}=a^{2}+3b^{2}=4$ Then $(a,b)\in\{(\pm2,0),(\pm1,\pm1)\}$ so that
$U_{K}=\{\pm\zeta_{3},\pm\zeta_{3}^{2},\pm1\}=\langle-\zeta_{3}\rangle\simeq\mathbb{Z}/6\mathbb{Z}$
(where $\zeta_{3}=(-1+\sqrt{-3})/2)$.

label: Exercise 8.1.9 (b)
question: Show that $U_{K}$ is finite $\Leftrightarrow K=\mathbb{Q}$ or K is an imaginary quadratic field.
solution:
Solution. (b) We have already shown that for K a quadratic imaginary field, $U_{K}$ is finite.
Now, suppose that $U_{K}$ is finite. Then $r_{1}+r_{2}=1$ which implies that either $r_{1}=1$, $r_{2}=0$ so that $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=r_{1}+2r_{2}=1$ and $K=\mathbb{Q}$ or $r_{1}=0$, $r_{2}=1$ and $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=2$ and $K\notin\mathbb{R}$ so that K is quadratic imaginary.

label: Exercise 8.1.9 (c)
question: Show that, if there exists an embedding of K in R, then $W_{K}\simeq\{\pm1\}\simeq\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}.$ Conclude that, in particular, this is the case if $[K:\mathbb{Q}]$ is odd.
solution: Solution. (c) If there exists an embedding $\sigma:K\rightarrow\mathbb{R}$ then $K\simeq\sigma(K)$ and in particular $W_{K}\simeq W_{\sigma(K)}\subseteq\mathbb{R}$ Since the only real roots of unity are $\{\pm1\}$, we must have $W_{K}=\sigma^{-1}(\{\pm1\})=\{\pm1\}$ In particular, if $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=r_{1}+2r_{2}$ is odd, then $r_{1}$ is odd and, therefore, $\ge1$.

label: Exercise 8.1.11 (a)
question:
Let $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=3$ and suppose that K has only one real embedding. Then, by Exercise 8.1.8 (c), $W_{K}=\{\pm1\}$ implies that $U_{K}=\{\pm u^{k}:k\in\mathbb{Z}\}$, where $u>1$ is the fundamental unit in K.
Let $u,\rho e^{i\theta}$, $\rho e^{-i\theta}$ be the Q-conjugates of u. Show that $u=\rho^{-2}$ and that $d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)=-4~sin^{2}\theta(\rho^{3}+\rho^{-3}-2~cos~\theta)^{2}$.
solution:
Solution. (a) $N_{K}(u)=u\rho^{2}=\pm1$ so $u=\pm\rho^{-2}$, but $u>1$ implies that $u=\rho^{-2}$
$d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)=\prod_{1\le r<s\le3}(u^{(r)}-u^{(s)})^{2}$
$=(\rho^{-2}-\rho e^{i\theta})^{2}(\rho^{-2}-\rho e^{-i\theta})^{2}(\rho e^{i\theta}-\rho e^{-i\theta})^{2}$
$=(\rho^{-4}-\rho(e^{i\theta}+e^{-i\theta})+\rho^{2})^{2}(\rho(e^{i\theta}-e^{-i\theta}))^{2}$
$=(\rho^{-4}-\rho(2~cos~\theta)+\rho^{2})^{2}(\rho(2i~sin~\theta))^{2}$
$=-4~sin^{2}\theta(\rho^{3}+\rho^{-3}-2~cos~\theta)^{2}$ .

label: Exercise 8.1.11 (b)
question: Let $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=3$ and suppose that K has only one real embedding. Let u be the fundamental unit in K. Show that $|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)|<4(u^{3}+u^{-3}+6)$.
solution:
Solution. (b)
$|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)|=4~sin^{2}\theta(\rho^{3}+\rho^{-3}-2~cos~\theta)^{2}$.
Now set $x=\rho^{3}+\rho^{-3}$ $c=cos~\theta$ and consider
$f(x)=(1-c^{2})(x-2c)^{2}-x^{2}.$
This function attains a maximum when $x=-2(1-c^{2})/c$ and this maximum is $4(1-c^{2})\le4$ Therefore
$|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)|\le4(\rho^{3}+\rho^{-3})^{2}+16 =4(u^{3}+u^{-3}+6)$ .

label: Exercise 8.1.11 (c)
question: Let $[K:\mathbb{Q}]=3$ and suppose that K has only one real embedding. Let u be the fundamental unit in K. Conclude that $u^{3}>d/4-6-u^{-3}>d/4-7,$ where $d=|d_{K}|.$
solution:
Solution. (c) Since $d=|d_{K}|<|d_{K/\mathbb{Q}}(u)|$, we have
$u^{3}>\frac{d}{4}-6-u^{-3}>\frac{d}{4}-7.$

label: Exercise 8.1.12 (a)
question: Let $\alpha=\sqrt[3]{2}$, $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$. Given that $d_{K}=-108$. Show that, if u is the fundamental unit in K, $u^{3}>20$.

label: Exercise 8.1.12 (b)
question: Let $\alpha=\sqrt[3]{2}$, $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$. Given that $d_{K}=-108$. Show that $\beta=(\alpha-1)^{-1}=\alpha^{2}+\alpha+1$ is a unit, $1<\beta<u^{2}$. Conclude that $\beta=u.$
solution:
Solution. (b) Computation shows that $\frac{1}{7}<\alpha-1<1$ and therefore $1<(\alpha-1)^{-1}<7<u^{2}$.
Since $\beta$ is a power of u, this power must be 1. Therefore $\beta=u$ is the fundamental unit in K.

label: Exercise 8.1.13 (a)
question: Show that, if $\alpha\in K$ is a root of a monic polynomial $f\in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ and $f(r)=\pm1$, for some $r\in\mathbb{Z}.$ then $\alpha-r$ is a unit in K.
solution:
Solution. (a) Let $g(x)=f(x+r)$. Then $g(x)$ is a monic polynomial in $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ with constant term $g(0)=f(r)=\pm1$ Since $g(\alpha-r)=0$ the minimal polynomial of $\alpha-r\in\mathcal{O}_{K}$ divides $g(x)$ and, thus, has constant term $\pm1$.
Therefore $N_{K}(\alpha-r)=\pm1$ so $\alpha-r\in U_{K}$.

label: Exercise 8.1.13 (b)
question: Using the fact that if $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{m})$, then $d_{K}=-27m^{2}$, for any cubefree integer m, determine the fundamental unit in $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{7})$.
solution:
Solution. (b) $d_{K}=-27\cdot7^{2}$ implies that $u^{3}>27\cdot7^{2}/4-7>323$ and so $u^{2}> (323)^{2/3}>47$ by Exercise 8.1.11.
Let $f(x)=x^{3}-7$ and note that $f(2)=1$ Then $\sqrt[3]{7}-2\in U_{K}$. Also, $1/u^{2}<1/47<2-\sqrt[3]{7}<1$ implies that $1<(2-\sqrt[3]{7})^{-1}<u^{2}$.
Therefore, $(2-\sqrt[3]{7})^{-1}$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{7})$.

label: Exercise 8.1.13 (c)
question: Determine the fundamental unit in $K=\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt[3]{3})$.
solution:
Solution. (c) Let $\alpha=\sqrt[3]{3}$, $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$. $d_{K}=-27\cdot3^{2}=-3^{5}$ . We observe that $\alpha^{2}$ is a root of $f(x)=x^{3}-9$ and $f(2)=-1$ so $\alpha^{2}-2\in U_{K}.$ We have $u^{3}>3^{5}/4-7>53$ and thus $u^{2}>14$ Since $\frac{1}{14}<\alpha^{2}-1< 1,1<(\alpha^{2}-2)^{-1}<14<u^{2}$.
Thus, $(\alpha^{2}-2)^{-1}$ is the fundamental unit of $K=\mathbb{Q}(\alpha)$

label: Exercise 8.2.1 (a)
question:
Consider the continued fraction $[a_{0},...,a_{n}]$. Define the sequences $p_{0},...,p_{n}$ and $q_{0},...,q_{n}$ recursively as follows:
$p_{0}=a_{0}$
$p_{1}=a_{0}a_{1}+1$,
$p_{k}=a_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}$
$q_{0}=1$,
$q_{1}=a_{1}$,
$q_{k}=a_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}$,
for $k\ge2$ Show that the kth convergent $C_{k}=p_{k}/q_{k}$.

label: Exercise 8.2.1 (b)
question:
Consider the continued fraction $[a_{0},...,a_{n}]$. Define the sequences $p_{0},...,p_{n}$ and $q_{0},...,q_{n}$ recursively as follows:
$p_{0}=a_{0}, p_{1}=a_{0}a_{1}+1, p_{k}=a_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}$
$q_{0}=1, q_{1}=a_{1}, q_{k}=a_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}$, for $k\ge2$.
Show that $p_{k}q_{k-1}-p_{k-1}q_{k}=(-1)^{k-1},$ for $k\ge1.$
solution:
Solution. (b) Again, we apply induction on k. For $k=1$
$p_{1}q_{0}-p_{0}q_{1}=(a_{0}a_{1}+1)\cdot1-a_{0}a_{1}=1$.
For $k\ge1$,
$p_{k+1}q_{k}-p_{k}q_{k+1}=(a_{k+1}p_{k}+p_{k-1})q_{k}-p_{k}(a_{k+1}q_{k}+q_{k-1})$
$=p_{k-1}q_{k}-p_{k}q_{k-1}=-(-1)^{k-1}=(-1)^{k},$
by our induction hypothesis.

label: Exercise 8.2.1 (c)
question:
Consider the continued fraction $[a_{0},...,a_{n}]$. Define the sequences $p_{0},...,p_{n}$ and $q_{0},...,q_{n}$ recursively as follows:
$p_{0}=a_{0}, p_{1}=a_{0}a_{1}+1, p_{k}=a_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}$
$q_{0}=1, q_{1}=a_{1}, q_{k}=a_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}$, for $k\ge2$.
Derive the identities
$C_{k}-C_{k-1}=\frac{(-1)^{k-1}}{q_{k}q_{k-1}}$ for $1\le k\le n$, and
$C_{k}-C_{k-2}=\frac{a_{k}(-1)^{k}}{q_{k}q_{k-2}}$ for $2\le k\le n$.
solution:
Solution. (c) By (b),
$p_{k}q_{k-1}-q_{k}p_{k-1}=(-1)^{k-1}$ .
Dividing by $q_{k}q_{k-1}$, we obtain the first identity. Now,
$C_{k}-C_{k-2}=\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}-\frac{p_{k-2}}{q_{k-2}}=\frac{p_{k}q_{k-2}-p_{k-2}q_{k}}{q_{k}q_{k-2}}.$
But
$p_{k}q_{k-2}-p_{k-2}q_{k}=(a_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2})q_{k-2}-p_{k-2}(a_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2})$
$=a_{k}(p_{k-1}q_{k-2}-p_{k-2}q_{k-1})=a_{k}(-1)^{k-2}$
establishing the second identity.

label: Exercise 8.2.1 (d)
question:
Show that
$C_{1}>C_{3}>C_{5}>\cdot\cdot\cdot,$
$C_{0}<C_{2}<C_{4}<\cdot\cdot\cdot,$
and that every odd-numbered convergent $C_{2j+1}$ $j\ge0$, is greater than every even-numbered convergent $C_{2k}$, $k\ge0$.
solution:
Solution. (d) By (c),
$C_{k}-C_{k-2}=\frac{a_{k}(-1)^{k}}{q_{k}q_{k-2}}.$
Thus, $C_{k}<C_{k-2}$ for k odd and $C_{k}>C_{k-2}$ for k even. In addition,
$C_{2m}-C_{2m-1}=\frac{(-1)^{2m-1}}{q_{2m}q_{2m-1}}<0\Rightarrow C_{2m-1}>C_{2m},$
$\Rightarrow C_{2k}<C_{2(j+k+1)}<C_{2(j+k)+1}<C_{2j+1}.$

label: Exercise 8.2.2
question: Let $\{a_{i}\}_{i\ge0}$ be an infinite sequence of integers with $a_{i}\ge0$ for $i\ge1$ and let $C_{k}=[a_{0},...,a_{k}]$. Show that the sequence $\{C_{k}\}$ converges.
solution:
Solution. By Exercise 8.2.1 (d), we have
$C_{1}>C_{3}>C_{5}>\cdot\cdot\cdot$
Moreover, each $C_{2j+1}>a_{0}$ so that the sequence $\{C_{2j+1}\}_{j\ge0}$ is decreasing and bounded from below and is, thus, convergent, say $lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}C_{2j+1}=\alpha_{1}$.
Also,
$C_{0}<C_{2}<C_{4}<\cdot\cdot\cdot$
and $C_{2j}<C_{2k+1}$ for all $j,k\ge0$ In particular, each $C_{2j}<C_{1}$. The sequence $\{C_{2j}\}_{j\ge0}$ is increasing and bounded from above and, therefore, also converges, say $lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}C_{2j}=\alpha_{2}$ We will show that $\alpha_{1}=\alpha_{2}$.
Since each $a_{i}\ge1,q_{0},q_{1}\ge1$, we easily see, by induction on k, that $q_{k}=a_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}\ge2k-3.$ By Exercise 8.2.1 (c),
$C_{2j+1}-C_{2j}=\frac{1}{q_{2j+1}q_{2j}}\le\frac{1}{(4j-1)(4j-3)}\rightarrow0,$
as $j\rightarrow\infty$. Thus, both sequences converge to the same limit and $lim_{j\rightarrow\infty}C_{j}=\alpha=\alpha_{1}=\alpha_{2}$.

label: Exercise 8.2.3
question:
Let $\alpha=\alpha_{0}$ be an irrational real number greater than 0. Define the sequence $\{a_{i}\}_{i\ge0}$ recursively as follows:
$a_{k}=[\alpha_{k}]$,
$\alpha_{k+1}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{k}-a_{k}}$
Show that $\alpha=[a_{0},a_{1},...]$ is a representation of a as a simple continued fraction.
solution:
Solution. By induction on k, we easily see that each $\alpha_{k}$ is irrational. Therefore $\alpha_{k+1}>1$ which means that $a_{k+1}\ge1$ so that $[a_{0},a_{1},...]$ is a simple continued fraction. Also,
$\alpha=\alpha_{0}=[\alpha_{0}]+(\alpha_{0}-[\alpha_{0}])=a_{0}+\frac{1}{\alpha_{1}}$
$=[\begin{matrix}a_{0},\alpha_{1}\end{matrix}]=[a_{0},a_{1},\alpha_{2}\end{matrix}]=\cdot\cdot\cdot=[a_{0},a_{1},...,a_{k},\alpha_{k+1}\end{matrix}]$
for all k. By Exercise 8.2.1 (a),
$\alpha=\frac{\alpha_{k+1}p_{k}+p_{k-1}}{\alpha_{k+1}q_{k}+q_{k-1}}$
so that
$|\alpha-C_{k}|=|\frac{\alpha_{k+1}p_{k}+p_{k-1}}{\alpha_{k+1}q_{k}+q_{k-1}}-\frac{p_{k}}{q_{k}}|$
$=|\frac{-(p_{k}q_{k-1}-p_{k-1}q_{k})}{(\alpha_{k+1}q_{k}+q_{k-1})q_{k}}|$
$=|\frac{1}{(\alpha_{k+1}q_{k}+q_{k-1})q_{k}}|$
$<\frac{1}{q_{k}^{2}}\le\frac{1}{(2k-3)^{2}}\rightarrow0$
as $k\rightarrow\infty$ Thus,
$\alpha=lim_{k\rightarrow\infty}C_{k}=[a_{0},a_{1},...].$

label: Exercise 8.2.5
question: Let d be a positive integer, not a perfect square. Show that, if $|x^{2}-dy^{2}|<\sqrt{d}$ for positive integers x, y, then $x/y$ is a convergent of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}.$
solution:
Solution. Suppose first that $0<x^{2}-dy^{2}<\sqrt{d}$ Then
$(x+y\sqrt{d})(x-y\sqrt{d})>0\Rightarrow x>y\sqrt{d};$
$\Rightarrow|\sqrt{d}-\frac{x}{y}|=\frac{x}{y}-\sqrt{d}=\frac{x-y\sqrt{d}}{y}$
$=\frac{x^{2}-dy^{2}}{y(x+y\sqrt{d})}<\frac{x^{2}-dy^{2}}{y(2y\sqrt{d})}<\frac{1}{2y^{2}}$
Thus, by Theorem 8.2.4 (b), $x/y$ is a convergent of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}$.
Similarly, if $-\sqrt{d}<x^{2}-dy^{2}<0$ then
$0<y^{2}-\frac{1}{d}x^{2}<\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}\Rightarrow y>\frac{x}{\sqrt{d}}.$
$\Rightarrow|\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}-\frac{y}{x}|=\frac{y}{x}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}=\frac{y-x/\sqrt{d}}{x}$
$=\frac{y^{2}-x^{2}/d}{x(y+x/\sqrt{d})}<\frac{y^{2}-x^{2}/d}{2x^{2}/\sqrt{d}}<\frac{1}{2x^{2}}.$
Thus $y/x$ is a convergent of the continued fraction of $1/\sqrt{d}$.
Let a be any irrational number. Then $\alpha=[a_{0},a_{1},...]$ implies $1/\alpha=[0,a_{0},a_{1},...]$. We therefore have that the $(k+1)t$ th convergent of the continued fraction of $1/\alpha$ is the reciprocal of the kth convergent of a, for all $k\ge0$.
Using this fact, we find that, as before, $x/y$ is a convergent of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d}.$

label: Exercise 8.2.6
question:
Let a be a quadratic irrational (i.e, the minimal polynomial of the real number a over has degree 2). Show that there are integers $P_{0}$, $Q_{0}$, d such that
$\alpha=\frac{P_{0}+\sqrt{d}}{Q_{0}}$
with $Q_{0}|(d-P_{0}^{2})$. Recursively define
$\alpha_{k}=\frac{P_{k}+\sqrt{d}}{Q_{k}};$ $a_{k}=[\alpha_{k}],$
$P_{k+1}=a_{k}Q_{k}-P_{k},$ $Q_{k+1}=\frac{d-P_{k+1}^{2}}{Q_{k}};$
for $k=0,1,2,...$ Show that $[a_{0},a_{1},a_{2},...]$ is the simple continued fraction of $\alpha$.
solution:
Solution. There exist a, b, e, $f\in\mathbb{Z}$, e, $f>0,$ e not a perfect square, such that
$\alpha=\frac{a+b\sqrt{e}}{f}=\frac{af+\sqrt{eb^{2}f^{2}}}{f^{2}}$
and, evidently, $f^{2}|(a^{2}f^{2}-eb^{2}f^{2})$. Set $P_{0}=af$ $Q_{0}=f^{2}$, $d=eb^{2}f^{2}$ This sequence is well-defined, since d is not a perfect square $\Rightarrow Q_{k}\ne0$ for all k.
By Exercise 8.2.3, it will suffice to show that $\alpha_{k+1}=\frac{1}{\alpha_{k}-a_{k}}$ for all k.
$\begin{matrix}\alpha_{k}-a_{k}&=&\frac{P_{k}+\sqrt{d}}{Q_{k}}-a_{k}\end{matrix}$
$=\frac{\sqrt{d}-(a_{k}Q_{k}-P_{k})}{Q_{k}}$
$=\frac{\sqrt{d}-P_{k+1}}{Q_{k}}$
$=\frac{d-P_{k+1}^{2}}{Q_{k}(\sqrt{d}+P_{k+1})}$
$=\frac{Q_{k}Q_{k+1}}{Q_{k}(\sqrt{d}+P_{k+1})}$
$=\frac{1}{\alpha_{k+1}}.$

label: Exercise 8.2.7
question: Show that the simple continued fraction expansion of a quadratic irrational a is periodic.
solution:
Solution. By Exercise 8.2.6, we may write
$\alpha=\frac{P_{0}+\sqrt{d}}{Q_{0}}$
with $Q_{0}|(P_{0}^{2}-d)$. Setting
$\alpha_{k}=\frac{P_{k}+\sqrt{d}}{Q_{k}},$ $a_{k}=[\alpha_{k}],$ $P_{k+1}=a_{k}Q_{k}-P_{k},$ $Q_{k+1}=\frac{d-P_{k+1}^{2}}{Q_{k}}$
we have
$P_{0}=0, P_{1}=d, Q_{0}=1, Q_{1}=1, \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d^{2}+1}, \alpha_{1}=d+\sqrt{d^{2}+1}, a_{0}=d, a_{1}=2d.$
and $\alpha=[a_{0},a_{1},...]$. Now,
$\alpha=\frac{\alpha_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}}{\alpha_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}}$
and if $\alpha^{\prime}$ denotes the Q-conjugate of a,
$\alpha^{\prime}=\frac{\alpha_{k}^{\prime}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}}{\alpha_{k}^{\prime}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}}\Rightarrow\alpha_{k}^{\prime}=-\frac{q_{k-2}}{q_{k-1}}(\frac{\alpha^{\prime}-C_{k-2}}{\alpha^{\prime}-C_{k-1}})$
Since $C_{k-1},C_{k-2}\rightarrow\alpha~as~k\rightarrow\infty$, $\frac{\alpha^{\prime}-C_{k-2}}{\alpha^{\prime}-C_{k-1}}\rightarrow1.$
Therefore, $\alpha_{k}^{\prime}<0$, and, since $\alpha_{k}>0$ $\alpha_{k}-\alpha_{k}^{\prime}=2\sqrt{d}/Q_{k}>0,$ for all sufficiently large k. We also have $Q_{k}Q_{k+1}=d-P_{k+1}^{2}$ SO $Q_{k}\le Q_{k}Q_{k+1}=d-P_{k+1}^{2}\le d$ and $P_{k+1}^{2}\le d-Q_{k}\le d$ for sufficiently large k. Thus there are only finitely many possible values for $P_{k}$, $Q_{k}$ and we conclude that there exist integers $i<j$ such that $P_{i}=P_{j},Q_{i}=Q_{j}$ Then $a_{i}=a_{j}$ and, since the $a_{i}$ are defined recursively, we have $\alpha=[a_{0},a_{1},...,a_{i-1},\overline{a_{i},...,a_{j-1}}]$.

label: Exercise 8.2.8
question:
Show that, if d is a positive integer but not a perfect square, and $\alpha=\alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d},$ then
$p_{k-1}^{2}-dq_{k-1}^{2}=(-1)^{k}Q_{k},$
for all $k\ge1$, where $p_{k}/q_{k}$ is the kth convergent of the continued fraction of a and $Q_{k}$ is as defined in Exercise 8.2.6.
solution:
Solution. By inspection, $p_{0}^{2}-dq_{0}^{2}=[\sqrt{d}]^{2}-d=-Q_{1}$. Now, suppose that $k\ge2$ Writing
$\sqrt{d}=\alpha_{0}=[a_{0},a_{1},...,a_{k-1},\alpha_{k}]=\frac{\alpha_{k}p_{k-1}+p_{k-2}}{\alpha_{k}q_{k-1}+q_{k-2}}$
and recalling that $\alpha_{k}=(P_{k}+\sqrt{d})/Q_{k}$, we have
$\sqrt{d}=\frac{(P_{k}+\sqrt{d})p_{k-1}+Q_{k}p_{k-2}}{(P_{k}+\sqrt{d})q_{k-1}+Q_{k}q_{k-2}},$
$\Rightarrow dq_{k-1}+(P_{k}q_{k-1}+Q_{k}q_{k-2})\sqrt{d}=P_{k}p_{k-1}+Q_{k}p_{k-2}+p_{k-1}\sqrt{d}.$
Equating coefficients in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$, we have
$dq_{k-1}=P_{k}p_{k-1}+Q_{k}p_{k-2}$ and $p_{k-1}=P_{k}q_{k-1}+Q_{k}q_{k-2}.$
Computation yields
$p_{k-1}^{2}-dq_{k-1}^{2}=(p_{k-1}q_{k-2}-p_{k-2}q_{k-1})Q_{k}=(-1)^{k}Q_{k}$.

label: Exercise 8.2.10 (a)
question: Find the simple continued fractions of $\sqrt{6},\sqrt{23}.$
solution:
Solution. (a) Using notation of previous exercises, setting $\alpha=\alpha_{0}=\sqrt{6},$ we have
$P_{0}=0, P_{1}=2, P_{2}=2, Q_{0}=1, Q_{1}=2, Q_{2}=1, \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{6}, a_{0}=2, \alpha_{1}=\frac{2+\sqrt{6}}{2}, a_{1}=2, \alpha_{2}=2+\sqrt{6}, a_{2}=4.$
Thus, the period of the continued fraction of a is $2\Rightarrow\sqrt{6}=[a_{0},\overline{a_{1},a_{2}}]=[2,2,4]$. Applying the same procedure, we find $\sqrt{23}=[4,\overline{1,3,1,8}]$.

label: Exercise 8.2.10 (b)
question: Using Theorem 8.2.9 (c), compute the fundamental unit in both $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{6})$ and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{23})$.
solution:
Solution. (b) For $\sqrt{6}$ $C_{1}=p_{1}/q_{1}=[a_{0},a_{1}]=a_{0}+1/a_{1}=2+1/2=5/2$ Thus, the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{6})$ is $5+2\sqrt{6}$
For $\sqrt{23}$, $C_{3}=[4,1,3,1]=24/5$. Therefore the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{23})$ is $24+5\sqrt{23}$

label: Exercise 8.2.11 (a)
question: Show that $[d,\overline{2d}]$ is the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d^{2}+1}.$
solution:
Solution. (a) Observing that $d^{2}<d^{2}+1\le(d+1)^{2}$ for all $d>0$, we see that $[\sqrt{d^{2}+1}]=d$ and setting $\alpha=\alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d^{2}+1},$ we have
$P_{0}=0, P_{1}=d, Q_{0}=1, Q_{1}=1, \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d^{2}+1}, \alpha_{1}=d+\sqrt{d^{2}+1}, a_{0}=d, a_{1}=2d.$
This implies that the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d^{2}+1}$ is 1.
Therefore $\sqrt{d^{2}+1}=[a_{0},\overline{a_{1}}]=[d,\overline{2d}]$.

label: Exercise 8.2.11 (b)
question: Conclude that, if $d^{2}+1$ is squarefree, $d\equiv1,3$ (mod 4), then the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d^{2}+1})$ is $d+\sqrt{d^{2}+1}.$ Compute the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{2})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{10})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{26})$.
solution: Solution. (b) $d\equiv1,3$ (mod 4) and thus $d^{2}+1\equiv2$ (mod 4). Thus, if $d^{2}+1$ is squarefree, then the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d^{2}+1})$ is $p_{0}+q_{0}\sqrt{d^{2}}+1=d+\sqrt{d^{2}+1}.$

label: Exercise 8.2.11 (c)
question: Show that the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d^{2}+2}$ is $[d,\overline{d,2d}]$.
solution:
Solution. (c) Observing that $d^{2}<d^{2}+2<(d+1)^{2}$ for all $d\ge1$ we get $[\sqrt{d^{2}+2}]=d$ and setting $\alpha=\alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d^{2}+2}$, we have
$P_{0}=0, Q_{0}=1, a_{0}=d, P_{1}=d, Q_{1}=2, a_{1}=d, \alpha_{0}=\sqrt{d^{2}+2}, \alpha_{1}=\frac{d+\sqrt{d^{2}+2}}{2}, P_{2}=d, Q_{2}=1, \alpha_{2}=d+\sqrt{d^{2}+2}, a_{2}=2d$
Therefore the period of the continued fraction of $\sqrt{d^{2}+2}$ is 2, so
$\sqrt{d^{2}+2}=[a_{0},\overline{a_{1},a_{2}}]=[d,\overline{d,2d}]$

label: Exercise 8.2.11 (d)
question: Conclude that, if $d^{2}+2$ is squarefree, then the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d^{2}+2})$ is $d^{2}+1+d\sqrt{d^{2}+2}$ Compute the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{3})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{11})$, $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{51})$, and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{66})$.
solution: Solution. (d) For all d, $d^{2}+2\equiv2,3$ (mod 4) so, if d is squarefree, the fundamental unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d^{2}+2})$ is $p_{1}+q_{1}\sqrt{d^{2}+2}=d^{2}+1+d\sqrt{d^{2}+2}$.

label: Exercise 8.3.1
question: If $n^{2}-1$ is squarefree, show that $n+\sqrt{n^{2}-1}$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{n^{2}-1})$.
solution: Solution. The continued fraction of $\sqrt{n^{2}-1}$ is $[n-1,1,2(n-1)]$, so that the first two convergents are $(n-1)/1$ and $n/1$. Now apply Theorem 8.2.9.

label: Exercise 8.3.2
question: Determine the units of an imaginary quadratic field from first principles.
solution:
Solution. We have already determined the units of $\mathbb{Q}(i)$ and $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3}).$ They are $\pm1$, $\pm i$ and $\pm1$, $\pm\rho,\pm\rho^{2}$, respectively.
Now we determine the units of an arbitrary field $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-d})$ where $-d\equiv2,3$ (mod 4).
All units are of the form $a+b\sqrt{-d}$ with $a^{2}+db^{2}=1$ It is easy to see that since $d\ge2$, this has no solution except for $a=\pm1,$ $b=0$ If $-d\equiv1$ (mod 4), then units will be of the form $(a+b\sqrt{-d})/2$ where $a\equiv b$ (mod 2) and $a^{2}+db^{2}=4$ Since we already know the units for $d=3$ then $d\ge7$ and once again, the only solution is $a=\pm1$, $b=0$.

label: Exercise 8.3.3
question: Suppose that $2^{2n}+1=dy^{2}$ with d squarefree. Show that $2^{n}+y\sqrt{d}$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$ whenever $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})\ne\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{5})$
solution:
Solution. Suppose not. Let $(a+b\sqrt{d})/2$ be the fundamental unit. Then $2^{n}+y\sqrt{d}=(\frac{a+b\sqrt{d}}{2})^{j}$ for some integer j. If an odd prime p divides j, we can write $2^{n}+y\sqrt{d}=(\frac{u+v\sqrt{d}}{2})^{p}$ where $(u+v\sqrt{d})/2$ is again a unit. Hence
$2^{n+p}=\sum_{k}\binom{p}{2k}v^{2k}d^{k}u^{p-2k}=uA,$
say. Clearly, $(u,A)=1$ so we must have either $u=1$, $A=2^{n+p}$ or $u=2^{n+p}$, $A=1$ The latter case is impossible since $A=pv^{p-1}d^{(p-1)/2}>1.$ Hence $u=1$ But then $dv^{2}=5$ or -3. The former case is ruled out by the hypothesis and the latter is impossible.
Thus, if $2^{n}+y\sqrt{d}$ is not the fundamental unit, it must be the square of a unit. But then, this means that $2^{n+4}+4y\sqrt{d}=(u+v\sqrt{d})^{2}=(u^{2}+dv^{2})+2uv\sqrt{d}$ and this case is also easily ruled out.

label: Exercise 8.3.4 (a)
question: Determine the continued fraction expansion of $\sqrt{51}$ and use it to obtain the fundamental unit $\epsilon$ of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{51})$.
solution: Solution. See Exercise 8.2.11.

label: Exercise 8.3.4 (b)
question: Prove from first principles that all units of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{51})$ are given by $\epsilon^{n}$, $n\in\mathbb{Z.}$
solution: Solution. See Exercise 8.2.11.

label: Exercise 8.3.5
question: Determine a unit $\ne\pm1$ in the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\theta)$ where $\theta^{3}+6\theta+8=0$.
solution: Solution. Consider $\eta=1+\theta.$

label: Exercise 8.3.6
question: Let p be an odd prime $>3$ and suppose that it does not divide the class number of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$ Show that $x^{p}+y^{p}+z^{p}=0$ is impossible for integers x, y, z such that $p\nmid xyz$.
solution:
Solution. We factor $x^{p}+y^{p}=\prod_{i=0}^{p-1}(x+\zeta_{p}^{i}y)=-z^{p}.$ Since $p\nmid xyz$, the terms $(x+\zeta_{p}^{i}y)$ are mutually coprime for $0\le i\le p-1.$ Moreover, viewing the equation as an ideal equation gives $(x+\zeta_{p}^{i}y)=\mathfrak{a}_{i}^{p}$ for some ideal $\mathfrak{a}_{i}$. Since p does not divide the class number, $\mathfrak{a}_{i}$ itself must be principal. Therefore $(x+\zeta_{p}^{i}y)=\epsilon\alpha^{p}$, where $\epsilon$ is a unit in $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$ and a is an integer of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$.
By Exercise 4.3.7, $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{p}]$ is the ring of integers of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$ and $1,\zeta_{p},\zeta_{p}^{2},...,\zeta_{p}^{p-2}$ is an integral basis. Therefore, we can express $\alpha=a_{0}+a_{1}\zeta_{p}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{p-2}\zeta_{p}^{p-2}$, so that $\alpha^{p}\equiv a_{0}^{p}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+a_{p-2}^{p}\equiv a(mod~p);$, where $a=a_{0}+...+a_{p-2}$, by a simple application of Fermat's little Theorem (Exercise 1.1.13).
Also, we may write $\epsilon=\zeta_{p}^{s}\eta$ where $0\le s<p$ and $\eta$ is a real unit, by Theorem 8.1.10. Hence, for $i=1$,
$x+\zeta_{p}y\equiv\zeta_{p}^{s}\beta(mod~p)$
where $\beta$ is a real integer of $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$. Also, by complex conjugation,
$x+\zeta_{p}^{-1}y\equiv\zeta_{p}^{-s}\beta(mod~p)$ .
Then
$\zeta_{p}^{-s}(x+\zeta_{p}y)-\zeta_{p}^{s}(x+\zeta_{p}^{-1}y)\equiv0(mod~p).$
Since $1,\zeta_{p},...,\zeta_{p}^{p-2}$ is an integral basis for $\mathbb{Q}(\zeta_{p})$,
$C_{0} + C_{1}\zeta_p +... + C_{p-2}\zeta_p^{p-2}=0 (mod p)$
holds if and only if $c_{0}\equiv c_{1}\equiv\cdot\cdot\cdot\equiv c_{p-2}\equiv0(mod~p)$.
Write $\zeta_{p}^{p-s}(x+\zeta_{p}y)-(\zeta_{p}^{s}x+\zeta_{p}^{s-1}y)\equiv0(mod~p)$. If $2<s\le p-2$ and $s\ne(p+1)/2$ the powers of $\zeta_{p}$ are all different and less than $p-1$ in the above congruence. Hence $x\equiv y\equiv0$ (mod p), a contradiction.
If $s=(p+1)/2$ then $x+\zeta_{p}y\equiv\zeta_{p}x+y(mod~p)$ so that $x\equiv y(mod~p)$. Similarly, $x\equiv z(mod~p)$ so that $x^{p}+y^{p}+z^{p}\equiv3x^{p}\equiv0(mod~p)$. Since $p>3$, we get $p|x$ a contradiction.
If $s=0$, then $x+\zeta_{p}y-(x+\zeta_{p}^{-1}y)\equiv0(mod~p)$ so that y = 0 (mod p), a contradiction.
If $s=1$, $\zeta_{p}^{-1}x+y\equiv\zeta_{p}x+y$ (mod p) and so $p|x$, a contradiction.
If $s=2$, $x+\zeta_{p}y\equiv\zeta_{p}^{4}x+\zeta_{p}^{3}y$ and so $x\equiv y\equiv0(mod~p).$ again a contradiction.
Finally, if $s=p-1,$ that is, $\zeta_{p}(x+\zeta_{p}y)\equiv\zeta_{p}^{-1}x+\zeta_{p}^{-2}y(mod~p)$, $\zeta_{p}^{3}(x+\zeta_{p}y)\equiv\zeta_{p}x+y(mod~p).$ which gives $p|x$ (since $p\ge5$, again a contradiction.

label: Exercise 8.3.7
question: Let K be a quadratic field of discriminant d. Let $P_{0}$ denote the group of principal fractional ideals $\alpha\mathcal{O}_{K}$ with $\alpha\in K$ satisfying $N_{K}(\alpha)>0$. The quotient group $H_{0}$ of all nonzero fractional ideals modulo $P_{0}$ is called the restricted class group of K. Show that $H_{0}$ is a subgroup of the ideal class group H of K and $[H:H_{0}]\le2$.
solution: Solution. If $d<0$, the norm of any nonzero element is greater than 0 and so the notions of restricted class group and ideal class group coincide. If $d>0$, then $H=H_{0}$ if and only if there exists a unit in K of norm -1. This is because $\sqrt{d}\mathfrak{O}_{K}$ is in the same coset of $\mathcal{U}_{K}$ (mod $P_{0})$ if and only if $\sqrt{d}=\epsilon\alpha$ with $N_{K}(\alpha)>0$, and $\epsilon$ is a unit. Since $N_{K}(\sqrt{d})<0$, this can happen if and only if $\epsilon$ is a unit of norm -1.

label: Exercise 8.3.8
question:
Given an ideal a of a quadratic field K, let $\mathfrak{a^{\prime}}$ denote the conjugate ideal. If K has discriminant d, write $|d|=p_{1}^{\alpha_{1}}p_{2}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{t}$, where $p_{1}=2$, $\alpha_{1}=0,2,$ or 3 and $p_{2},...,p_{t}$ are distinct odd primes. If we write $p_{i}\mathcal{O}_{K}=\rho_{i}^{2}$ show that for any ideal a of $\mathcal{O}_{K}$ satisfying $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{a}^{\prime}$ we can write
$\mathfrak{a}=r\rho_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}^{a_{t}}$,
$r>0$ $a_{i}=0,$ 1 uniquely.
solution:
Solution. We first factor a as a product of prime ideals. The fact that $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{a}^{\prime}$ implies that if a prime ideal divides a, so does $8^{\prime}$. If is inert then it is principal and generated by a rational prime. If splits, then (which both occur in a with the same multiplicity) can be paired to give again a principal ideal generated by a rational prime. Only the ramified prime ideals cannot be so paired. Since $\rho_{i}^{2}=p_{i}\mathcal{O}_{K}$, we see immediately that a has a factorization of the form described above.
If we have another factorization $\mathfrak{a}=r_{1}\rho^{b_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho^{b_{t}}$ , $r_{1}>0$ $b_{i}=0,1$, then taking norms we obtain $r^{2}p_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{t}^{a_{t}}=r_{1}^{2}p_{1}^{b_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot p_{t}^{b_{t}}$ so that $a_{i}\equiv b_{i}$ (mod 2). Since $a_{i}=0$ or 1, and $b_{i}=0$ or 1, this means $a_{i}=b_{i}$. Hence $r=r_{1}$

label: Exercise 8.3.9
question:
An ideal class C of $H_{0}$ is said to be ambiguous if $C^{2}=1$ in $H_{0}.$ Show that any ambiguous ideal class is equivalent (in the restricted sense) to one of the at most $2^{t}$ ideal classes
$\rho_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}^{a_{t}}$
$a_{i}=0,1.$
solution:
Solution. Let a be an ideal lying in an ambiguous class. Then $\mathfrak{a}^{2}=(\alpha)$ with $N_{K}(\alpha)>0$ But we have $\mathfrak{aa}^{\prime}=(N_{K}(\mathfrak{a}))$. Therefore
$\mathfrak{aa}^{\prime}=(N_{K}(\mathfrak{a})/\alpha)(\alpha)=(N_{K}(\mathfrak{a})/\alpha)\mathfrak{a}^{2}$
so that $\mathfrak{a}=\mathfrak{a}^{\prime}$ By the previous question, a can be written as
$r\rho_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}^{a_{t}}$.
$r>0$, $a_{i}=0,1$ . In the restricted class group, these form at most $2^{t}$ ideal classes.

label: Exercise 8.3.10
question:
With the notation as in the previous two questions, show that there is exactly one relation of the form
$\rho_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}^{a_{t}}=\rho\mathcal{O}_{K}$ , $N_{K}(\rho)>0$
with $a_{i}=0$ or 1, $\sum_{i=1}^{t}a_{i}>0$
solution:
Solution. We first show there is at least one such relation. If $d<0$, then $\rho_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}=(\sqrt{d})$ If $d>0$ let $\epsilon$ be a generator of all the totally positive units of K (i.e., units $\epsilon>0$ and $\epsilon^{\prime}>0)$. Set $\mu=\sqrt{d}(1-\epsilon)$ . Then $\mu^{\prime}=-\sqrt{d}(1-\epsilon^{\prime})$ so that $\epsilon\mu^{\prime}=-\sqrt{d}(\epsilon-1)=\mu.$ Therefore $(\mu)=(\mu^{\prime})$ and by the penultimate question, we have the result.
To establish uniqueness, consider first the case $d<0.$ If
$\rho_{1}^{a_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\rho_{t}^{a_{t}}=\rho\mathcal{O}_{K}$, $N_{K}(\rho)>0$
then $(\rho)=(\rho^{\prime})$ since $\rho_{i}^{\prime}=\rho_{i}$ . Therefore $\rho=b\sqrt{d}$ for some $b\in\mathbb{Q}$ The other two cases of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-1})$ are $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{-3})$ are similarly dealt with.
If now $d>0$, then $\rho=\eta\rho^{\prime}$ with $\eta$ a totally positive unit. We write $\eta=\epsilon^{m}$ for some m. With $\mu$ defined as above, notice that $\rho/\mu^{m}=\rho^{\prime}/(\mu^{\prime})^{m}$ so that $\rho/\mu^{m}=r\in\mathbb{Q}$. Hence $(\rho)=(\mu)^{m}$. Since ( ) has order 2 in the (restricted) class group we are done.

label: Exercise 8.3.11
question: Let K be a quadratic field of discriminant d. Show that the number of ambiguous ideal classes is $2^{t-1}$ where t is the number of distinct primes dividing d. Deduce that $2^{t-1}$ divides the order of the class group.
solution: Solution. This is now immediate from the previous two exercises. Since the restricted class group has index 1 or 2 in the ideal class group, the divisibility assertion follows.

label: Exercise 8.3.12
question: If K is a quadratic field of discriminant d and class number 1, show that d is prime or $d=4$ or 8.
solution: Solution. If d has t distinct prime divisors, then $2^{t-1}$ divides the class number. Thus $t\le1$ Since the discriminant is either squarefree or four times a squarefree number, the result is now clear.

label: Exercise 8.3.13
question: If a real quadratic field K has odd class number, show that K has a unit of norm-1.
solution: Solution. Since K has odd class number, $H=H_{0}$ This means there is a unit of norm -1.

label: Exercise 8.3.14
question: Show that $15+4\sqrt{14}$ is the fundamental unit of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{14}).$
solution:
Solution. The continued fraction development of $\sqrt{14}$ is [3, 1, 2, 1,6] and the convergents are easily computed: $\frac{3}{1},\frac{4}{1},\frac{11}{3},\frac{15}{4},....$
By Theorem 8.2.9, we find that $15+4\sqrt{14}$ is the fundamental unit.

label: Exercise 8.3.15
question: In Chapter 6 we showed that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{14}]$ is a PID (principal ideal domain). Assume the following hypothesis: given $\alpha, \beta\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{14}]$, such that $gcd(\alpha,\beta)=1$ there is a prime $\pi\equiv\alpha$ (mod 3) for which the fundamental unit $\epsilon=15+4\sqrt{14}$ generates the coprime residue classes (mod $\pi$). Show that $\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{14}]$ is Euclidean.
solution: Solution. We define the Euclidean algorithm inductively as follows. For $u\in\mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{14}]$ define $\varphi(u)=1$ If $\pi$ generates the residue classes (mod $\pi$), where $\pi$ is prime, define $\varphi(\pi)=2$ If $\beta$ is a prime for which $\epsilon$ does not generate the residue classes (mod 3), define $\varphi(\beta)=3.$ Now for any $\gamma\in \mathbb{Z}[\sqrt{14}]$ factor $\gamma=\pi_{1}^{e_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\pi_{r}^{e_{r}}\beta_{1}^{f_{1}}\cdot\cdot\cdot\beta_{s}^{f_{s}}$ where $\varphi(\pi_{i})=2$, $\varphi(\beta_{i})=3.$ Define $\varphi(\gamma)=2(e_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+e_{r})+3(f_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+f_{s})$. An easy induction argument using the Chinese Remainder Theorem (Theorem 5.3.13) shows that is a Euclidean algorithm.

label: Exercise 8.3.16
question: Let $d=a^{2}+1$. Show that if $|u^{2}-dv^{2}|\ne0,1$ for integers u, v, then $|u^{2}-dv^{2}|>\sqrt{d}.$
solution: Solution. The continued fraction expansion of $\sqrt{d}$ is $[a,2a,2a,...]$ and the convergents $p_{k}/q_{k}$ always satisfy $p_{k}^{2}-dq_{k}^{2}=\pm1$ If $|u^{2}-dv^{2}|<\sqrt{d},$ then $u/v$ is a convergent of $\sqrt{d},$ by Exercise 8.2.5. Since $|u^{2}-dv^{2}|\ne0,1$, we are done.

label: Exercise 8.3.17
question: Suppose that n is odd, $n\ge5$, and that $n^{2g}+1=d$ is squarefree. Show that the class group of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$ has an element of order 2g.
solution:
Solution. We have $(n)^{2g}=(\sqrt{d}-1)(\sqrt{d}+1)$. Since n is odd, each of the ideals $(-1+\sqrt{d})$ and $(1+\sqrt{d})$ must be coprime. By Exercise 5.3.12, each of them must be a 2gth power. Therefore
$\mathfrak{a}^{2g}=(\sqrt{d}-1)$ and $(\mathfrak{a}^{\prime})^{2g}=(\sqrt{d}+1)$
We claim that a has order greater than or equal to g. Observe that $n^{2g}+1\equiv$ 2 (mod 4) because n is odd. Therefore 1, $\sqrt{d}$ is an integral basis of $\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{d})$. If $\mathfrak{a}^{m}$ were principal, then $\mathfrak{a}^{m}=(u+v\sqrt{d})$ implies that $n^{m}=|u^{2}-dv^{2}|$ which by the previous exercise is either 0,1 or $>\sqrt{d}.$ The former cannot hold since $n\ge5$ Thus,
$n^{m}>\sqrt{d}=\sqrt{n^{2g}+1}>n^{g}.$
Hence, $m>g.$ Since m| 2g, we must have that a has order 2g.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.2}
question: If $\pi\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ is such that $N(\pi)=p$ a rational prime, show that $\pi$ is a prime of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.
solution: If $\pi$ factored in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$, then $\pi=\alpha\beta$ and $p=N(\pi)=N(\alpha)N(\beta)$ which implies that $N(\alpha)=1$ or $N(\beta)=1$ so that $\pi$ cannot be factored nontrivially in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.3a}
question: If $p$ is a rational prime congruent to 2 (mod 3), show that $p$ is prime in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.
solution: Let $p\equiv2$ (mod 3) be a rational prime. If $p=\pi\gamma$, with $N(\gamma) > 1, N(\pi)>1$, then $p^{2}=N(\pi)N(\gamma)$ implies that $N(\pi)=p$ and $N(\gamma)=p.$ Writing $\pi=a+b\rho$, we find $p=N(\pi)=a^{2}-ab+b^{2}$ so that $4p=4a^{2}-4ab+4b^{2}=(2a-b)^{2}+3b^{2}$. Hence $p\equiv(2a-b)^{2}$ (mod 3), a contradiction since 2 is not a square mod 3.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.4}
question: Let $\pi$ be a prime of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Show that $\alpha^{N(\pi)-1}\equiv1 \pmod \pi$ for all $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ which are coprime to $\pi$.
solution: Since $\pi$ is prime, the ideal $(\pi)$ is prime. Hence $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]/(\pi)$ is a field, containing $N(\pi)$ elements. Its multiplicative group, consisting of classes coprime to $\pi$, has $N(\pi)-1$ elements. Thus, by Lagrange's theorem, the result is immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.5a}
question: Let $\pi$ be a prime not associated to $(1-\rho)$. First show that $3|N(\pi)-1$.
solution: By Exercise 9.1.3, we know that $\pi|(\alpha^{N(\pi)-1}-1)$. By Exercise 9.1.4, we know $N(\pi)\equiv1$ (mod 3).

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.5b}
question: Let $\pi$ be a prime not associated to $(1-\rho)$. If $(\alpha,\pi)=1$, show that there is a unique integer $m=0, 1$ or 2 such that $\alpha^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv\rho^{m} \pmod \pi$.
solution: We can write $\beta=\alpha^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}$ and observe that $\beta^{3}-1=(\beta-1)(\beta-\rho)(\beta-\rho^{2})$. Since $\pi$ is prime and divides $\beta^{3}-1,$ it must divide one of the three factors on the right. If $\pi$ divides at least two factors, then $\pi|(1-\rho)$ which means $\pi$ is an associate of $1-\rho$, contrary to assumption. Thus, $\beta\equiv1, \rho, \text{or } \rho^{2} \pmod \pi$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.6a}
question: Show that $(\alpha/\pi)_{3}=1$ if and only if $x^{3}\equiv\alpha \pmod \pi$ is solvable in $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$.
solution: Clearly if $x^{3}\equiv\alpha \pmod \pi$ has a solution, then by Exercise 9.1.4, $\alpha^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv1 \pmod \pi$ so that $(\alpha/\pi)_{3}=1$. For the converse, let $g$ be a primitive root of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]/(\pi)$. Then, writing $\alpha=g^{r}$ we find $g^{(rN(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv1 \pmod \pi$ so that $\frac{r(N(\pi)-1)}{3}\equiv0 \pmod{N(\pi)-1}$. Hence $3 | r$, and $\alpha$ is a cube mod $\pi$. That is, $x^{3}\equiv\alpha \pmod \pi$ has a solution. This proves (a).

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.6b}
question: Show that $(\alpha\beta/\pi)_{3}=(\alpha/\pi)_{3}(\beta/\pi)_{3}$.
solution: $(\frac{\alpha\beta}{\pi})_{3}\equiv(\alpha\beta)^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv\alpha^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\beta^{(N(\pi)-1)/3} \equiv(\frac{\alpha}{\pi})_{3}(\frac{\beta}{\pi})_{3} \pmod \pi.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.6c}
question: Show that if $\alpha\equiv\beta \pmod \pi$, then $(\alpha/\pi)_{3}=(\beta/\pi)_{3}$.
solution: If $\alpha\equiv\beta \pmod \pi$ then $(\frac{\alpha}{\pi})_{3}\equiv\alpha^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv\beta^{(N(\pi)-1)/3}\equiv(\frac{\beta}{\pi})_{3} \pmod \pi.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.7a}
question: Show that $\overline{\chi_{\pi}(\alpha)}=\chi_{\pi}(\alpha)^{2}=\chi_{\pi}(\alpha^{2}).$
solution: $\chi_{\pi}(\alpha)$ is by definition one of $1, \rho, \text{or } \rho^{2}$ so that (a) is immediate.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.9}
question: Let $N(\pi)=p\equiv1$ (mod 3). Among the associates of $\pi$, show there is a unique one which is primary.
solution: Write $\pi=a+b\rho.$ All the associates of $\pi$ can be written down: $a+b\rho,-b+(a-b)\rho,(b-a)-a\rho,-a-b\rho,b+(b-a)\rho,(a-b)+a\rho$. Since $p=a^{2}-ab+b^{2}$, not both $a$ and $b$ are divisible by 3. If $b\equiv0$ (mod 3), then $\pi\equiv1$ (mod 3) implies $a\equiv1$ (mod 3) so that $-a\equiv2$ (mod 3) and hence $-a-b\rho$ is the primary. If $a\equiv0$ (mod 3) then one of $(b-a)-a\rho$ or $(a-b)+a\rho$ is primary. If both $a$ and $b$ are coprime to 3, then we must have $a\equiv b$ (mod 3), for otherwise $3|p,$ contrary to assumption. Thus $a\equiv b\equiv\pm1$ (mod 3), so that one of $b+(b-a)\rho$ or $-b+(a-b)\rho$ is primary, as desired.

label: \label{ques: Theorem 9.1.10}
question: Prove Theorem 9.1.10: If $\chi\ne\chi_{0}$, then $|g(\chi)|=\sqrt{p}$.
solution:
We first observe that $a
e0$ and $\chi
e\chi_{0}$ together imply that $g_{a}(\chi)=\chi(a^{-1})g(\chi)$ because $\chi(a)g_{a}(\chi) = \chi(a)\sum_{t\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\chi(t)\zeta^{at} = \sum_{t\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\chi(at)\zeta^{at} = g(\chi)$. With our conventions that $\chi_{0}(0)=1$ we see for $a
e0$, $g_{a}(\chi_{0})=\sum_{t\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\zeta^{at}=0,$ since this is just the sum of the $p$th roots of unity. Finally, $g_{0}(\chi)=0$ if $\chi
e\chi_{0}$ and $g_{0}(\chi_{0})=p$. Now, by our first observation, $\sum_{a\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}g_{a}(\chi)\overline{g_{a}(\chi)}=|g(\chi)|^{2}(p-1).$ On the other hand, $\sum_{a\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}g_{a}(\chi)\overline{g_{a}(\chi)}=\sum_{s\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\sum_{t\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\chi(s)\overline{\chi(t)}\sum_{a\in\mathbb{F}_{p}}\zeta^{as-at}.$ If $s
e t$, the innermost sum is zero, being the sum of all the $p$th roots of unity. If $s=t$ the sum is $p$. Hence $|g(\chi)|^{2}=p.$

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.11}
question: If $\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r}$ are nontrivial and the product $\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r}$ is also nontrivial prove that $g(\chi_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot g(\chi_{r})=J(\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r})g(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r})$.
solution: Define $\psi:\mathbb{F}_{p}\rightarrow\mathbb{C}$ by $\psi(t)=\zeta^{t}$. Then $\psi(t_{1}+t_{2})=\psi(t_{1})\psi(t_{2})$ and we can write $g(\chi)=\sum_{t}\chi(t)\psi(t).$ This is just for notational convenience. Now $g(\chi_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot g(\chi_{r}) = (\sum_{t_{1}}\chi_{1}(t_{1})\psi(t_{1}))\cdot\cdot\cdot(\sum_{t_{r}}\chi_{r}(t_{r})\psi(t_{r})) = \sum_{s}\psi(s)(\sum_{t_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+t_{r}=s}\chi_{1}(t_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r}(t_{r}))$. If $s\ne0$, writing $t_{i}=su_{i}$, the inner sum becomes $(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r})(s)J(\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r})$. If $s=0$, then the inner sum is $\sum_{t_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+t_{r}=0}\chi_{1}(t_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r}(t_{r})=0$ since $t_{1},...,t_{r-1}$ can be chosen arbitrarily so that $t_{r}=-t_{1}-\cdot\cdot\cdot-t_{r-1}$, and each of the sums corresponding to $t_{1},...,t_{r-1}$ is zero since $\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r}$ are nontrivial. This completes the proof.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.12}
question: If $\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r}$ are nontrivial, and $\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r}$ is trivial, show that $g(\chi_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot g(\chi_{r})=\chi_{r}(-1)pJ(\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r-1}).$
solution: By the previous exercise, $g(\chi_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot g(\chi_{r-1})=J(\chi_{1},...,\chi_{r-1})g(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r-1})$. Multiplying both sides of the equation by $g(\chi_{r})$ leads us to evaluate $g(\chi_{r})g(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r-1})$. However, $(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r-1})\chi_{r}=\chi_{0}$ means that $g(\chi_{1}\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi_{r-1})=g(\overline{\chi_{r}})=\chi_{r}(-1)p$ by the proof of Theorem 9.1.10.

label: \label{ques: Lemma 9.1.13}
question: Prove Lemma 9.1.13: Let $\pi$ be a prime of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ such that $N(\pi)=p\equiv1$ (mod 3). The character $\chi_{\pi}$ introduced above can be viewed as a character of the finite field $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]/(\pi)$ of $p$ elements. Show that $J(\chi_{\pi},\chi_{\pi})=\pi$.
solution: If $\chi$ is any cubic character, Exercise 9.1.12 shows that $g(\chi)^{3}= pJ(\chi,\chi)$ since $\chi(-1)=1$. We can write $J(\chi,\chi)=a+b\rho$ for some $a, b\in\mathbb{Z}$. But $g(\chi)^{3}=(\sum_{t}\chi(t)\zeta^{t})^{3} \equiv\sum_{t}\chi^{3}(t)\zeta^{3t} \pmod{3} \equiv\sum_{t\ne0}\zeta^{3t} \pmod{3} \equiv-1 \pmod{3}$. Therefore, $a+b\rho\equiv-1 \pmod{3}$. In a similar way, $g(\overline{\chi})^{3}\equiv a+b\overline{ho}\equiv-1 \pmod{3}$. Thus, $b\sqrt{-3}\equiv0 \pmod{3}$ which means $-3b^{2}/9$ is an algebraic integer and by Exercise 3.1.2, it is an ordinary integer. Thus, $b\equiv0 \pmod{3}$ and $a\equiv-1 \pmod{3}$. Also, from Exercise 9.1.12 and Theorem 9.1.10, it is clear that $|J(\chi,\chi)|^{2}=p=J(\chi,\chi)\overline{J(\chi,\chi)}$. Therefore, $J(\chi,\chi)$ is a primary prime of norm $p$. Set $J(\chi_{\pi},\chi_{\pi})=\pi^{\prime}$. Since $\pi\overline{\pi}=p=\pi^{\prime}\overline{\pi^{\prime}}$, we have $\pi|\pi^{\prime}$ or $\pi|\overline{\pi^{\prime}}.$ We want to eliminate the latter possibility. By definition, $J(\chi_{\pi},\chi_{\pi})=\sum_{t}\chi_{\pi}(t)\chi_{\pi}(1-t) \equiv\sum_{t}t^{(p-1)/3}(1-t)^{(p-1)/3} \pmod \pi.$ The polynomial $x^{(p-1)/3}(1-x)^{(p-1)/3}$ has degree $\frac{2}{3}(p-1)<p-1.$ Let $g$ be a primitive root (mod $\pi$). Then $\sum_{t}t^{j}=\sum_{a=0}^{p-2}g^{aj}\equiv0 \pmod \pi$ if $g^{j}\not\equiv1 \pmod \pi$ which is the case since $j<p-1$. Thus, $J(\chi_{\pi},\chi_{\pi})\equiv0 \pmod \pi$. Therefore $\pi|\pi^{\prime}$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.14}
question: Show that $g(\chi)^{3}=p\pi.$
solution: By Exercise 9.1.12, $g(\chi)^{3}=pJ(\chi,\chi)$ and by the previous exercise, $J(\chi,\chi)=\pi.$

label: \label{ques: Lemma 9.1.15}
question: Prove Lemma 9.1.15: Let $\pi_{1}=q\equiv2$ (mod 3) and $\pi_{2}=\pi$ be a prime of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$ of norm $p$. Show that $\chi_{\pi}(q)=\chi_{q}(\pi)$.
solution: Let $\chi_{\pi}=\chi,$ and consider the Jacobi sum $J(\chi,...,\chi)$ with $q$ terms. Since $3 \nmid q+1$, we have, by Exercise 9.1.12, $g(\chi)^{q+1}=pJ(\chi,...,\chi)$. By Exercise 9.1.14, $g(\chi)^{3}=p\pi$ so that $g(\chi)^{q+1}=(p\pi)^{(q+1)/3}$. Recall that $J(\chi,...,\chi)=\sum\chi(t_{1})\cdot\cdot\cdot\chi(t_{q})$, where the sum is over all $t_{1},...,t_{q}\in\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z}$ such that $t_{1}+\cdot\cdot\cdot+t_{q}=1$. The term in which $t_{1}=\cdot\cdot\cdot=t_{q}$ satisfies $qt_{1}=1$ and so $\chi(q)\chi(t_{1})=1.$ Raising both sides to the $q$th power and noting that $q\equiv2$ (mod 3) gives $\chi(q)^{2}\chi(t_{1})^{q}=1$ and so $\chi(t_{1})^{q}=\chi(q)$. Therefore, the "diagonal" term which corresponds to $t_{1}=\cdot\cdot\cdot=t_{q}$ has the value $\chi(q)$. If not all the $t_{i}$ are equal, then we get $q$ different $q$-tuples from a cyclic permutation of $(t_{1},...,t_{q}).$ Thus $J(\chi,...,\chi)\equiv\chi(q)$ (mod $q$). Hence $(p\pi)^{(q+1)/3}\equiv p\chi(q) \pmod q$ so that $p^{(q-2)/3}\pi^{(q+1)/3} \equiv \chi(q) \pmod q$. We raise both sides of this congruence to the $(q-1)$ st power (recalling that $q-1\equiv1$ (mod 3)): $p^{(q-2)(q-1)/3}\pi^{(q^{2}-1)/3}\equiv\chi(q)^{q-1}\equiv\chi(q) \pmod q.$ By Fermat's little Theorem, $p^{q-1}\equiv1 \pmod q$. Therefore, $\chi_{\pi}(q)\equiv\pi^{(q^{2}-1)/3}\equiv\chi_{q}(\pi)$ (mod $q$) so that $\chi_{\pi}(q)=\chi_{q}(\pi)$ as desired.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.1.17}
question: Let $\pi$ be a prime of $\mathbb{Z}[\rho]$. Show that $x^{3}\equiv2 \pmod \pi$ has a solution if and only if $\pi\equiv1 \pmod 2$.
solution: We first observe that $x^{3}\equiv2 \pmod \pi$ is solvable if and only if $x^{3}\equiv2 \pmod{\pi^{\prime}}$ is solvable for any associate $\pi^{\prime}$ of $\pi$. Thus we may assume that $\pi$ is primary. If $\pi=q$ is a rational prime, then $\chi_{q}(2)=\chi_{2}(q)=\chi_{2}(1)=1$ so that 2 is a cubic residue for all such primes. If $\pi=a+b\rho$ is primary, by cubic reciprocity, $\chi_{\pi}(2)=\chi_{2}(\pi)$. The norm of (2) is 4 and $\pi=\pi^{(4-1)/3}\equiv\chi_{2}(\pi) \pmod 2$. Thus $\chi_{\pi}(2)=\chi_{2}(\pi)=1$ if and only if $\pi\equiv1 \pmod 2$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.1}
question: Let $\wp$ be a prime ideal of $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ not containing $m$. Let $q$ be its norm. Show that $q\equiv1$ (mod $m$) and that $1,\zeta_{m},\zeta_{m}^{2},...,\zeta_{m}^{m-1}$ are distinct coset representatives mod $\wp$.
solution: Observe that $\frac{x^{m}-1}{x-1}=1+x+\cdot\cdot\cdot+x^{m-1}=\prod_{i=1}^{m-1}(x-\zeta_{m}^{i}).$ Putting $x=1$ in this identity gives $m=\prod_{i=1}^{m-1}(1-\zeta_{m}^{i}).$ If $\zeta_{m}^{i}\equiv\zeta_{m}^{j} \pmod \wp$ (say), then $\zeta_{m}^{j-i}\equiv1 \pmod \wp$ so that $m\equiv0 \pmod \wp$, contrary to $m\notin\wp$. Thus $1,\zeta_{m},...,\zeta_{m}^{m-1}$ are distinct mod $\wp$. Moreover, the cosets they represent form a multiplicative subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]/\wp$ of order $m$. Since $(\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]/\wp)^{*}$ has order $q-1=N(\wp)-1$, we must have $m|q-1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.2}
question: Let $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$, $\alpha\notin\wp$. Show that there is a unique integer $i$ (modulo $m$) such that $\alpha^{(q-1)/m}\equiv\zeta_{m}^{i} \pmod \wp$.
solution: Since $(\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]/\wp)^{*}$ has $q-1$ elements, we have $\alpha^{q-1}\equiv1 \pmod \wp$. Thus $\prod_{i=1}^{m-1}(\alpha^{(q-1)/m}-\zeta_{m}^{i})\equiv0 \pmod \wp$. Since $\wp$ is a prime ideal, there is an integer $i$, $0\le i<m$, such that $\alpha^{(q-1)/m}\equiv\zeta_{m}^{i} \pmod \wp.$ This $i$ is unique by Exercise 9.2.1.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.3a}
question: Show that $(\alpha/\wp)_{m}=1$ if and only if $x^{m}\equiv\alpha \pmod \wp$ is solvable in $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$.
solution: If $x^{m}\equiv\alpha \pmod \wp$ has a solution, then $\alpha^{(N(\wp)-1)/m}\equiv x^{N(\wp)-1}\equiv1 \pmod \wp$ by the analogue of Fermat's little Theorem. Thus, $(\alpha/\wp)_{m}=1$. For the converse, we know that $(\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]/\wp)^{*}$ is cyclic, being the multiplicative group of a finite field. Let $g$ be a generator, and set $\alpha=g^{r}$. If $(\alpha/\wp)=1$, then $\alpha^{(q-1)/m}\equiv1 \pmod \wp$. Hence $g^{r(q-1)/m}\equiv1 \pmod \wp$. Since $g$ has order $q-1$ we must have $r\frac{q-1}{m}\equiv0 \pmod{q-1}.$ Hence, $m|r$, so that $\alpha$ is an $m$th power. This proves (a).

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.3b}
question: Show that for all $\alpha\in\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}],$ $\alpha^{(N(\wp)-1)/m}\equiv(\alpha/\wp)_{m} \pmod \wp$.
solution: We need only note the case $\alpha\equiv0 \pmod \wp$ which is clear.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.3c}
question: Show that $(\alpha\beta/\wp)_{m}=(\alpha/\wp)_{m}(\beta/\wp)_{m}$.
solution: Parts (c) and (d) are proved exactly as in the case of the cubic residue symbol in Exercise 9.1.6.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.3d}
question: Show that if $\alpha\equiv\beta \pmod \wp$, then $(\alpha/\wp)_{m}=(\beta/\wp)_{m}$.
solution: Parts (c) and (d) are proved exactly as in the case of the cubic residue symbol in Exercise 9.1.6.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.4}
question: If $\wp$ is a prime ideal of $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ not containing $m$, show that $(\frac{\zeta_{m}}{\wp})_{m}=\zeta_{m}^{(N(\wp)-1)/m}$.
solution: By definition, $(\frac{\zeta_{m}}{\wp})_{m}\equiv\zeta_{m}^{(N(\wp)-1)/m} \pmod \wp$. Since both $(\zeta_{m}/\wp)_{m}$ and $\zeta_{m}^{(N(\wp)-1)/m}$ are $m$th roots of unity and by Exercise 9.2.1, distinct roots represent distinct classes, we must have $(\frac{\zeta_{m}}{\wp})_{m}=\zeta_{m}^{(N(\wp)-1)/m}$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.5a}
question: Suppose $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are ideals coprime to $(m)$. Show that $(\alpha\beta/\mathfrak{a})_{m}=(\alpha/\mathfrak{a})_{m}(\beta/\mathfrak{a})_{m}$.
solution: Parts (a) and (b) are immediate from Exercise 9.2.3.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.5b}
question: Suppose $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are ideals coprime to $(m)$. Show that $(\alpha/\mathfrak{ab})_{m}=(\alpha/\mathfrak{a})_{m}(\beta/\mathfrak{b})_{m}$.
solution: Parts (a) and (b) are immediate from Exercise 9.2.3.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.5c}
question: Suppose $\mathfrak{a}$ and $\mathfrak{b}$ are ideals coprime to $(m)$. If $\mathfrak{a}$ is prime to $\alpha$ and $x^{m}\equiv\alpha \pmod{\mathfrak{a}}$ is solvable in $\mathbb{Z}[\zeta_{m}]$ then $(\alpha/\mathfrak{a})_{m}=1.$
solution: For (c), we note that $x^{m}\equiv\alpha \pmod \wp$ has a solution for every prime ideal $\wp$ dividing $\mathfrak{a}$. Thus by Exercise 9.2.3 (a), $(\alpha/\wp)_{m}=1$ for every prime ideal dividing $\mathfrak{a}$. thus, $(\alpha/\mathfrak{a})_{m}=1$.

label: \label{ques: Exercise 9.2.6}
question: Show that the converse of (c) in the previous exercise is not necessarily true.
solution: Choose two distinct prime ideals $\wp_{1}$ $\wp_{2}$ coprime to $(m)$.
